upeuuoz1.title: Evaluation of Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3-δ as a potential cathode for an anode-supported proton-conducting solid-oxide fuel cell
upeuuoz1.abstract: The potential application of Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ (BSCF) as a cathode for a proton-conducting solid-oxide fuel cell based on BaCe 0.9 Y 0.1 O 2.95 (BCY) electrolyte was investigated. Cation diffusion from BCY to BSCF with the formation of a perovskite-type Ba 2+ -enriched BSCF and a Ba 2+ -deficient BCY at a firing temperature as low as 900 °C was observed, the higher the firing temperature the larger deviation of the A to B ratio from unit for the perovskites. Symmetric cell tests demonstrated the impurity phases did not induce a significant change of the cathodic polarization resistance, however, the ohmic resistance of the cell increased obviously. Anode-supported cells with the electrolyte thickness of ∼50 μm were successfully fabricated via a dual-dry pressing process for the single-cell test. Under optimized conditions, a maximum peak power density of ∼550 and 100 mW cm −2 was achieved at 700 and 400 °C, respectively, for the cell with the BSCF cathode layer fired from 950 °C. At 500 °C, the ohmic resistance is still the main source of cell resistance. A further reduction in membrane thickness would envisage an increase in power density significantly. Keywords Proton Perovskite Cathode Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ Solid-oxide fuel cells 1 Introduction Solid-oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) are a promising clean power source characterized by high energy conversion efficiency, all solid cell components, high power density, low environmental impact and excellent fuel flexibility. Nowadays, there is increasing interest in SOFCs both for residential and stationary applications. Lowering the operating temperature of SOFCs from ∼1000 to 400–800 °C can significantly improve materials’ compatibility, reduce capital costs both for materials and operation, and prolong the operational lifetime. Typical SOFCs are based on oxygen-ion-conducting electrolyte (SOFC-O 2− ) [1–3] . Recently, the proton-conducting SOFCs have also received considerable attention (SOFC-H + ) for reduced-temperature application [4–23] . Selected protonic conductors show even higher ionic conductivity than stabilized zirconia and doped ceria at <600 °C [20,24] . Furthermore, SOFC-H + have higher theoretical electromotive force (EMF) and electrical efficiency than SOFC-O 2− [25] . Although several oxides with high protonic conductivity at reduced temperature have been developed, the progress of SOFC-H + is much retarded as compared to SOFC-O 2− . Table 1 is a summary of the recent advances in the SOFC performance based on proton-conducting electrolyte in literature. Nowadays, peak power density of >1.0 W cm −2 at intermediate temperatures of 600–800 °C is frequently reported in literature for SOFC-O 2− with thin-film electrolytes [26–30] , while the power density of SOFC-H + seldom exceeds 500 mW cm −2 [4–23] . In order to achieve high power density of SOFC-H + at reduced temperatures, besides the development of new electrolyte material with high protonic conductivity, the reduction of electrolyte thickness, the development of cathode with low over-potential is also of great importance. As compared to the great efforts in searching for new protonic oxides, the research on cathode for SOFC-H + is much less up to now. Uchida et al. have demonstrated that the cathodic overpotential of Pt in SOFC-H + could not be neglected below 800 °C [31] . Several authors have also exploited conducting oxides such as La 1− x Sr x MO 3− δ (M = Co, Fe, Mn) as the cathode materials for SOFC-H + [32] . Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ (BSCF) is a mixed conductor with ultra-high oxygen ionic conductivity, which has demonstrated to be a high-performance cathode for SOFC based on oxygen-ion conducting electrolyte [26,27,33–36] . In this study the application of BSCF as a cathode for proton-conducting BaCe 0.9 Y 0.1 O 2.95 (BCY) electrolyte fuel cell was reported. The fuel cell performance was found to be closely related with the phase reaction between the cathode and the electrolyte layers. By optimizing the firing temperature, the fuel cells demonstrated high power density of >500 mW cm 2 at 700 °C and high OCV of ∼1.06 V at 500 °C. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of oxide power Both BCY and BSCF powders were synthesized by a combined EDTA–citrate complexing sol–gel process [37,38] . The synthesis of BCY, as an example, is described as follows. Required amounts of analytic reagents of Ba(NO 3 ) 2 , Ce(NO 3 ) 3 , and Y(NO 3 ) 2 , according to the cation stoichiometry of the composite oxide BCY, were prepared into a mixed solution under stirring. EDTA and citric acid were added to the solution at the mole ratio of total metal ions:EDTA:citric acid of 1:1:2. NH 4 OH was applied to adjust the pH value of the solution to be around 6 during the water evaporation. Under stirring and heating, a clear viscous gel was obtained, which was solidified by pre-heating at 250 °C for several hours and finally calcined at 900–1100 °C for 5 h to obtain a pure-phase composite oxide with the nominated composition of BCY. 2.2 Cell fabrication Symmetrical cells with the configuration of electrode|BCY|electrode were used for the impedance studies. Dense BCY pellets of 12 mm in diameter and 0.55 mm in thickness were prepared by die pressing and sintered in air at 1400 °C for 5 h. To prepare the electrode, the BSCF oxide powder was first prepared into a colloidal suspension by dispersing it into a mixed solution of glycerol, ethylene glycol and isopropyl alcohol by high-energy ball milling (Fritsch Pulverisettle 6) at the rotation rate of 400 rpm for 0.5 h. It was then spray-deposited symmetrically on both surfaces of the BCY pellets, followed by calcined at 950–1100 °C for 2 h in air. Silver paste was adopted as the current collectors. Anode-supported cells with BCY electrolyte were prepared using a co-pressing technique. Anode powders were prepared by well mixing of NiO and BCY in weight ratio of 60 to 40 by a high-energy ball miller. To fabricate the single cell, the NiO + BCY powder was first pressed as a substrate, onto which the fine BCY powder was added and pressed again to form a bi-layer pellet. The electrolyte thickness was controlled by the amount of BCY applied during the fabrication. A final anode thickness of 0.56 mm was adopted. The green pellets were then sintered in air at 1400 °C for 5 h for the densification of the electrolyte layer, the diameter of the anode-supported cells is 13 mm. BSCF slurry was spray-deposited onto the central surface of the electrolyte and fired at various temperatures between 900 and 1100 °C in air for 2 h; the cathode effect area is ∼0.26 cm −2 and its layer thickness is around 20 μm. 2.3 Electrochemical impedance test The electrode performance was investigated with the symmetrical or complete cell configuration by the ac impedance method using an electrochemical workstation based on a Solartron 1260A frequency response analyzer in combination with a Solartron 1287 potentiostat. The frequency applied was ranged from 0.01 Hz to 1000 kHz with a signal amplitude of 30 mV under open cell voltage (OCV). 2.4 Single-cell test The fuel cell reactor was put into a vertical split tube furnace, a thermocouple was inserted near the cathode surface both for the temperature controlling and monitoring. Three percent H 2 O humidified H 2 at a flow rate of 80 ml min −1 [STP: standard temperature and pressure] was fed into the anode chamber as fuel while ambient air was applied as the cathode atmosphere. I – V polarization curves were collected using a Keithley 2420 source meter based on the four-probe configuration. 2.5 Other characterization The phase structure of the oxides was examined by X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Bruker D8 Advance). The microscopic features of the prepared electrodes or single cell were characterized using an environmental scanning electron microscope (ESEM, QUANTA-2000). The powders were also conducted oxygen temperature-programmed desorption (O 2 -TPD) experiment. About 150 mg of sample was loaded in a quartz tube, which was then placed in a single-zone furnace equipped with a temperature controller. Argon was used as the carrier gas with a flow rate of 20 ml min −1 [STP]. The temperature was increased from 50 to 950 °C at the rate of 10 °C min −1 and the effluent gases were monitored by the mass spectrometer (MS, Hiden, QIC-20). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Phase reaction between BSCF and BCY Interfacial phase reaction between fuel-cell components during the fuel-cell fabrication sometimes may become a practical problem. For example, it was found that the reaction between La 0.8 Sr 0.2 MnO 3− δ (cathode) and yttria-doped zirconia (electrolyte) was happened when the firing temperature for attaching the cathode layer to the electrolyte surface is 1100 °C or higher [39] . It led to the formation of non-conductive phases of La 2 Zr 2 O 7 and SrZrO 3 at the cathode–electrolyte interface, which significantly increased the interfacial polarization resistance of the cell and substantially deteriorated the fuel cell performance. BSCF is an active material, which has turned out to be reactive with samaria-doped ceria electrolyte at high temperatures [40] . To get the information about the possible phase formation at the cathode–electrolyte interface during the high-temperature firing, the solid-state reaction between BSCF and BCY was investigated by mixed powders. These two samples in powder state were mixed thoroughly at 1:1 weight ratio by high-energy ball milling for half hour and then calcined at various temperatures between 900 and 1100 °C for 2 h in air. The resulted products were then submitted to phase composition examination. Fig. 1 A shows the room-temperature X-ray diffraction patterns of BSCF, BCY and the BSCF + BCY mixture after the calcinations at various temperatures. No other phase appeared even after the calcination at 1100 °C for 2 h. A more detailed observation of the diffraction patterns reveals that the diffraction peak of BSCF at mirror index of (1 1 0) shifted steadily to the lower 2 θ direction with the increase of calcination temperature, while the diffraction peak of BCY perovskite at mirror index of (2 1 1) kept almost unmoved ( Fig. 1 B). Above phenomena strongly suggested that certain type of phase reaction between BSCF and BCY was actually happened during the high-temperature calcination, with the newly formed phases taking the same phase structure and similar lattice parameters to that of the reactants. In a recent study, Tolchard and Grande reported the physiochemical compatibility of SrCeO 3 with LaMO 3 (M = Mn, Fe, Co) oxides, and they observed that the diffusion of Sr 2+ in ceria is surprisingly fast with the primary reaction being the dissolution of SrO from SrCeO 3 into the LaMO 3 , and corresponding formation of La-doped CeO 2 [41] . Similar phase reaction by cation exchange is likely happened between BSCF and BCY in our case. Four possibilities are available, (1) the exchange of Sr 2+ in BSCF with Ba 2+ in BCY with the formation of Ba 2+ -enriched BSCF and Sr 2+ -substituted BCY; (2) the exchange of B-site cation; (3) the diffusion of Ba 2+ and Sr 2+ from BSCF to BCY with the formation of A-site cation-deficient BSCF and Ba 2+ -enriched BCY; and (4) the diffusion of Ba 2+ from BCY to BSCF with the formation of A-site cation-enriched BSCF perovskite and Ba 2+ -deficient BCY. Because Ba 2+ (12-coordinated with oxygen, 1.61 Å) has larger ionic size than Sr 2+ at the A-site (12-coordinated with oxygen, 1.44 Å) of perovskite, the cation exchange between Ba 2+ in BCY with Sr 2+ in BSCF would result in the lattice expansion of BSCF and the lattice shrinkage of BCY [42] . Since the lattice constant of BCY actually kept almost unchanged with respect to the firing temperature, the route (1) turns out to be unlikely, the route (2) is also less possible since the large difference in ionic radius between Ce 4+ /Y 3+ with Co 3+ /Fe 3+ in the B-site of perovskite. In our former studies [43,44] , we have demonstrated that BSCF can still sustain its perovskite lattice structure over a large deviation of its A / B cation ratio from unit (0.83 < A / B < 1.15) while the lattice parameter increased and decreased, respectively, for the A-site cation enrichment and deficiency. On the other hand, Ma and Iwahara et al. have demonstrated that BCY can also tolerate a large deviation of its A / B ratio away from unit (0.9 < A / B < 1.2) [45] , however its lattice constant kept almost unchanged no matter of either A-site cation deficiency or enrichment. Based on the results of Fig. 1 , it is likely that the Ba 2+ in BCY diffused to BSCF and resulted in the formation of Ba 2+ -deficient BCY and A-site Ba 2+ -enriched BSCF during the high temperature firing of BSCF + BCY mixture. In a previous paper, we have demonstrated that O 2 -TPD is an efficient and sensitive technique to characterize the local structural variation in BSCF [43] . Fig. 2 shows the O 2 -TPD curves of BCY, BSCF and BSCF + BCY mixture after calcined at various temperatures in air for 2 h. BCY demonstrated no any oxygen desorption peak, it agrees well with no any multivalent metal ion available in its structure. BSCF demonstrated a big desorption peak at the intermediate-temperature range of 300–600 °C (α-peak) and a smaller desorption peak at 700–900 °C (β-peak), ascribed to the reduction of Co 4+ /Fe 4+ to Co 3+ /Fe 4+ and Co 3+ to Co 2+ , respectively [42] . It was observed that the β-peak disappeared after the high-temperature firing. Shao and coauthors have demonstrated that the cation enrichment at the A-site of BSCF resulted in the disappearance of high-temperature oxygen desorption peak [44] , while the A-site cation deficiency resulted in increased intensity of the β-peak [43] . In another paper, Shao et al. have demonstrated that the β-peak could not be eliminated by varying the Ba 2+ to Sr 2+ ratio in the cation stoichiometric BSCF [42] . It then strongly supports that the reaction between BSCF and BCY is likely towards the formation A-site cation-enriched BSCF during the high-temperature firing. 3.2 Effect of interfacial reaction on the electrochemical performance To evaluate the interfacial phase reaction between BSCF cathode and BCY electrolyte on their electrochemical performance, cells with thick BCY electrolyte and symmetrical BSCF electrodes were prepared. In order to create different degree of reaction at the interface between BSCF and BCY, various firing temperatures to fix the electrode layers onto the electrolyte surfaces were tried. Fig. 3 shows the Nyquist plots of the electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) of the various cells at 600 °C, with BSCF calcined between 900 and 1100 °C for 2 h. The high-frequency intercept of the impedance spectrum gives the ohmic resistance of the cell ( R ohm ), which includes the resistive contributions of the electrolyte, the two electrodes, the current collectors and the lead wires, and also the interfacial layer of the reaction products (A-site cation-enriched BSCF and A-site cation-deficient BCY). In this study, the ohmic resistance of the two electrodes, the current collectors and the lead wires was reasonably considered to be negligible or the same for all samples. The low-frequency intercept gives the total resistance ( R ohm + R p ) of the cell, which includes the ohmic resistance of the cell, concentration polarization (mass-transfer or gas-diffusion polarization) resistance, and the polarization resistance associated with the electrochemical reactions at the electrode surface. As shown in Fig. 3 , the ohmic resistance of the cell increased steadily with the temperature for firing the cathode layer to the electrolyte surface, while the polarization resistance did not change significantly. Fig. 4 A and B shows the temperature dependence of R ohm and R p , respectively. The ohmic resistance increased steadily with the firing temperature, and the increment in R ohm is obvious at a firing temperature of 1050 °C or higher. Ma and Iwahara et al. have demonstrated that the A-site Ba 2+ -enriched or A-site Ba 2+ -deficient BCY could show significant lower protonic conductivity as compared to the cation stoichiometric BCY [45] . Based on the phase-reaction results of this study, the increase in the ohmic resistance with the firing temperature is attributed to the increase of A-site cation deficiency for the interfacial phase formed between BSCF and BCY. The conductivity of the electrolyte calculated based on the ohmic resistance in Fig. 4 A is around 0.01 S cm −1 at 600 °C for the cell with cathode fired at 900 °C, which is comparable to the value (0.009 S cm −1 ) reported by Ma and Iwahara et al. for a cation stoichiometric BCY [45] . It suggests that the impact of interfacial phase formation on the conductivity of thick BCY is not serious at a firing temperature of 900 °C. In order to improve the cell performance, a decrease of the firing temperature for attaching the cathode layer to the electrolyte surface is then crucial. As compared to the ohmic resistance, the electrode polarization resistance was much less influenced by the firing temperature. The cells fired from 900 to 1000 °C show the lowest and highest area specific polarization resistances, respectively, at the operation temperature of 750 °C, while the 1050 °C calcined one shows the lowest and the 950 °C calcined one shows the highest at an operation temperature of 500 °C. As demonstrated in the previous section, the high-temperature firing resulted in the formation of an A-site Ba 2+ -enriched BSCF. Zhou et al. have demonstrated that at small degree of cation enrichment, the A-site cation-enriched BSCF oxide shows even better electrode performance than the cation stoichiometric one [44] . On the other hand, the increase of firing temperature also resulted in the decrease of effective electrode surface area due to the cathode sintering. As a whole, no clear tendency of the cathodic polarization resistance with respect to the firing temperature was observed. 3.3 Anode-supported single cell fabrication and test To evaluate the impact of the interfacial reaction between BSCF and BCY on the cathode performance of BSCF in a real fuel cell, or single cell with the configuration of (anode) BCY + NiO|thin-film BCY|BSCF (cathode) were constructed. Preparation of dense electrolyte membranes on porous anodes is an important step in the fabrication of high-performance SOFCs. Dual-dry pressing has tested to be a simple, reproducible and effective process for the preparation of anode-supported thin electrolyte dual-layer cell [46–48] . Several authors have also successfully reported the fabrication of supported thin-film protonic electrolyte by dual-dry pressing process [18–20] . In this study, the BCY + NiO anode-supported BCY dual-layer cells were also prepared by this technique. The thickness of the electrolyte was controlled by the amount of the electrolyte powder applied during the fabrication. The electrolyte layer is well densified and shows a main grain size of 1–2 μm ( Fig. 5 A ). As shown in Fig. 5 B, the electrolyte layer adhered to the anode surface pretty well, which ensures a low contacting resistance between anode and electrolyte layer. The corresponding SEM images of the BSCF/BCY interface is shown in Fig. 5 C, as we can see that there is no clear third layer appeared between BSCF and BCY layers. It suggests that the interface phase may be formed in a compositionally graded structure. We have tried the compositional analysis on the interface area by EDX method. However, due to the porous structure of the substrate the error is too large to get reasonable results. Definitively, it is worthwhile to find other method in our future work to clarify this issue. Fig. 5 D shows the cross-section image of a post-examined single cell, the anode is highly porous and the fuel cell anode and cathode still adheres with the electrolyte layer pretty well. Although a firing temperature of 900 °C has testified to result in the lowest degree of phase reaction between BSCF and BCY, as demonstrated by the symmetric cell test, the connection between cathode particles was relatively poor; therefore a firing temperature of 950 °C was applied for the single cell fabrication. For comparison, a firing temperature of 1100 °C was also conducted for the cathode layer. As shown in Fig. 6 are the SEM images of the cathodes fired at 950 and 1100 °C, respectively, the cathode fired at 1100 °C is much more sintered than that fired at 950 °C. Single cells with anode thickness of ∼600 μm, electrolyte of ∼50 μm and cathode of ∼20 μm were applied for the I – V polarization test. Fig. 7 shows the I – V curves of the single cells operated on pure hydrogen as the anode fuel and ambient air as the cathode oxidant. The linear response of cell voltage with respect to applied current, even at high current density, suggests that the concentration polarization did not occur for both cells. An attractive peak power density of ∼550 mW cm −2 was achieved at an operation temperature of 700 °C for the cell with its cathode layer fired at 950 °C. It represents one of the highest power densities achieved for SOFC based on the proton-conducting oxide electrolyte, up to now. Even at an operation temperature of 400 °C, a peak power density of ∼100 mW cm −2 was also reached. Furthermore, a high OCV of ∼1.06 V was observed at 400 °C, suggesting that the electrolyte is sufficiently dense to prevent the gas leakage. As compared to the reduced-temperature SOFC-O 2− , the decrease in performance with respect to the reduction of temperature is much slower for the current proton-conducting SOFC [26] . It implies that SOFC-H + may be more suitable than SOFC-O 2− for low-temperature operation. As compared to the cell with the cathode fired from 950 °C, the cell with 1100 °C fired cathode shows much worse performance, as shown in Fig. 7 B. A peak power density of only ∼225 and ∼60 mW cm −2 was achieved at an operation temperature of 700 and 400 °C, respectively, which is only about one half that of the cell with the cathode fired from 950 °C. Since this fuel cell also demonstrates high OCVs, the difference in their power densities is unlikely due to gas leakage. As shown in Fig. 8 is the EIS of the single cells under OCV condition. The polarization resistances presented here are a sum of the cathode and anode polarization resistances. Very low area-specific polarization resistance of ∼0.36 Ω cm 2 was observed at an operation temperature of 500 °C for the cell with cathode fired from 950 °C. It suggests that BSCF cathode performs pretty well with BCY electrolyte when the cathode was fired from 950 °C. Fig. 9 shows the total cell resistance ( R total ), electrode polarization resistance ( R p ), cell ohmic resistance ( R ohm ), and the ratio of ohmic resistance to cell resistance obtained from the impedance spectra at different temperatures. The ohmic resistance of the cell is still overwhelming at 500 °C. A reduction of the electrolyte thickness could then result in the increase of the cell performance significantly. As compared to the ohmic resistance, the polarization resistance of the cell increased only slightly with the firing temperature. For example, it is about 0.36 and 0.52 Ω cm 2 at 500 °C, respectively, for the cell with its cathode fired at 950 and 1100 °C. To ensure a reasonable comparison of the different cathodes via the single-cell test, the microstructure of the electrodes and the electrolyte were fabricated as identical as possible for different cells by strictly optimizing the fabrication technique, therefore, it is reasonable to assume the difference in area-specific polarization resistance of the cells was mainly contributed from the variation in cathode activity. Based on Fig. 6 , such deterioration might be associated with the reduction of effective electrode surface area. However, the ohmic resistance of the cell increased more significantly from ∼0.77 to ∼1.39 Ω cm 2 . Fig. 10 shows the conductivities of the electrolyte layer (including the interfacial layer) of the cells with its cathode fired at 950 and 1100 °C, calculated based on the impedance data of the single cell under OCV condition, for comparison, the conductivities of the symmetric cells measured in dry air and with the electrode layer fired at 950 and 1100 °C, are also presented. For the asymmetric cell, a conductivity of ∼0.0125, 0.0088, and 0.0065 S cm −1 was achieved, respectively, at 700, 600 and 500 °C for the electrolyte (including the interfacial layer) with the cathode layer fired at 950 °C, while the conductivities decreased almost 50% for the electrolyte with the cathode fired at 1100 °C. It demonstrated that the formation of interfacial phase significantly blocked the protonic transportation from the electrolyte layer to the cathode layer, agreeing well with the results of the symmetric cell tests. It is reported that the protonic conductor usually shows smaller activation energy for proton conduction under hydrogen atmosphere than under air atmosphere [45] . Therefore, higher proton conductivity in air than in hydrogen is observed, respectively, at high temperature and low temperature zone. Higher conductivity of the electrolyte in the symmetric cell configuration (air/air) was observed at >600 °C than that in the asymmetric single cell configuration (air/H 2 ), agreeing with the literature results. The only available data about BSCF cathode for proton-conducting electrolyte fuel cell is reported by Peng et al. [18] . They applied a BSCF + BaCe 0.9 Sm 0.1 O 2.95 (BCS) composite oxide as the cathode for a proton-conducting BCS electrolyte and a firing temperature of ∼1100 °C for fixing the cathode layer to the electrolyte surface. An area-specific polarization resistance of ∼2.25 Ω cm 2 was observed at 600 °C, which is significantly larger than our results. The electrode polarization resistance started to overwhelm the ohmic resistance at a temperature of 650 °C or lower. Their poor performance might be related with the high firing temperature (1100 °C) and the composite cathode applied. In the composite cathode, the A-site cation-deficient BCS was formed throughout the electrode layer, which could cover the BSCF surface and blocked the oxygen reduction over the cathode seriously. In our study, a pure BSCF was applied as the cathode layer, the phase reaction occurred only at the interface between BSCF cathode and BCY electrolyte. Therefore, the oxygen reduction properties of the cathode layer are not seriously affected. 4 Conclusions The ohmic resistance of the cells (symmetric/asymmetric) based on BCY electrolyte and BSCF cathode seriously depends on the phase reaction between them, while the cathodic polarization resistance is not obviously impacted. The phase reaction involves the diffusion of Ba 2+ from BCY electrolyte to the cathode and leads to the formation of Ba 2+ -enriched BSCF and Ba 2+ -deficient BCY interfacial phases, which have the same phase structure and similar lattice parameters to that of the reactants. Such impurity phases have small influence on the oxygen reduction kinetics over the cathode, however, they input a significant blocking effect on the proton transferring from electrolyte to the electrode. Therefore, an obvious increase of ohmic resistance of the cell was observed. The higher the firing temperature, the larger deviation of A / B ratio for the perovskites and the worse the cell performance, was observed. The optimal firing temperature is ∼950 °C for the BSCF cathode layer. Anode-supported cell with electrolyte thickness of ∼50 μm was successfully fabricated by a dual-dry pressing process. High performance of >500 mW cm −2 at 700 °C was reached for an anode-supported cell with the cathode layer fired from 950 °C, nearly twice that of the cell with cathode fired from 1100 °C. The results were attractive compared to the literature results. It suggests the potential application of BSCF as a cathode for SOFCs based on proton-conducting electrolytes. In order to further improve the cell performance, the reduction of electrolyte thickness and the prevention of the formation of Ba 2+ -deficient BCY at the cathode–electrolyte interface is then of great importance, it will be our future research work on SOFC-H + . On the other hand, composite cathode by mixing BSCF with electrolyte material may be not a good choice. Aaf9VKtQ.title: Layered perovskite Y1-xCaxBaCo4O7+δ as ceramic membranes for oxygen separation
Aaf9VKtQ.abstract: Layer-structured mixed conducting oxides with the composition Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7+ δ ( x = 0.0–0.4) were synthesized and their performance as oxygen separating membranes was explored. The crystal structure, phase stability, oxygen absorption/desorption properties, and electrical conductivity of the oxides, as well as oxygen permeation fluxes of the corresponding membranes, were systematically investigated. The properties of YBaCo 4 O 7+ δ -based oxides were greatly improved by Ca incorporation into the lattice structure at an optimal concentration. In the series Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7+ δ , the Y 0.8 Ca 0.2 BaCo 4 O 7+ δ membrane exhibited the highest oxygen permeation flux, reaching a value of 0.75 × 10 −6 mol cm −2 s −1 at 900 °C under the conditions of air/helium oxygen gradient and a membrane thickness of 1.0 mm. Studies of the effect of membrane thickness on the oxygen fluxes implied that at membrane thicknesses larger than 0.7 mm, the permeation process was mainly controlled by bulk diffusion, indicating the potential to further improve the oxygen fluxes via thinner membranes of asymmetric structure. Keywords Oxygen permeation Perovskite Mixed conductor Ceramic membrane 1 Introduction Mixed ionic and electronic conducting (MIEC) perovskite oxides are attracting much research interest for their potential applications as ceramic membranes for oxygen separation from air, membrane reactors for partial oxidation of hydrocarbons to value-added products, catalysts for combustion of environmental pollutants, and solid-oxide fuel cell cathodes for electric power generation [1–10] . Nowadays, environmental problems resulting from rising atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide are challenging all industrialized countries. The production of electricity with zero carbon emissions to the atmosphere will become an essential element of future power infrastructure transformation. In this context, oxygen production by air separation is of particular importance, as most large-scale clean combustion technologies require oxygen as the feed gas. For example, if pure oxygen instead of air is used in power plants, the major constituent of the waste gas produced during the combustion process would be CO 2 , which can be readily and economically captured. Current tonnage O 2 production technology is based on expensive cryogenic distillation, which is impractical to integrate with coal gasifier or oxyfuel power plants because of its lower production efficiencies. Dense MIEC ceramic membranes can continuously deliver 100% pure O 2 under O 2 concentration gradients without the requirement of external electrical loadings, offering the potential to lower the oxygen production cost and improve the viability of CO 2 zero emission technology [11–16] . Recently, a group of cobalt-rich oxides with formula RBaCo 4 O 7+ δ (R = rare earth or yttrium) has captured the interest of many researchers due to their unique magnetic and electrochemical properties [17–23] . RBaCo 4 O 7+ δ has a crystal structure similar to that of hexagonal LuBaAlZnO 7 with more details shown in Fig. 1 . As can be seen, this layered structure is composed of Kagome sheets of CoO 4 tetrahedra linked by triangular layers of CoO 4 tetrahedra. Two different cobalt sites, i.e., Co1 and Co2, are tetrahedrally coordinated with the ratio of 3:1 between Co1 in Kagome and Co2 in the triangular lattice. The crystal structure of RBaCo 4 O 7+ δ is hexagonal with space group P 6 3 m [17,18] . Recently, Karppinen et al. reported that YBaCo 4 O 7+ δ has good oxygen desorption/adsorption capability at relatively low temperatures (200–400 °C) because its unique structure provides wide spaces for easy oxygen incorporation [19] . So far, most previous studies related to these layered RBaCo 4 O 7+ δ materials were focused on the magnetic and thermoelectric properties at intermediate temperatures. However, studies of their application as dense ceramic membranes for oxygen separation are still scarce. The oxygen permeation through these MIEC membranes involves many steps, such as bulk diffusion and surface oxygen exchange reactions. When the membrane thickness is much less than the critical value, the surface reaction kinetics will largely control the oxygen permeation rate. The surface exchange reactions consist of many substeps such as oxygen absorption, dissociation, as well as reactions among absorbed oxygen, oxygen vacancies, lattice oxygen, and electron holes. One effective way to facilitate the surface reaction rates is to prepare the MIEC membranes from materials with inherently good oxygen desorption/adsorption capability and YBaCo 4 O 7+ δ seems to be a good choice for a new membrane material. The purpose of this study was to determine the feasibility of using these new layered YBaCo 4 O 7+ δ perovskite oxides as MIEC membranes and their performance in air separation. In order to introduce more oxygen vacancies inside the YBaCo 4 O 7+ δ lattice to speed up the oxygen permeation rate, Y 3+ was partially substituted by another metal ion with lower valence state but larger ionic radius (i.e., Ca 2+ ) via a doping strategy. A series of Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7+ δ oxides were prepared by a combined EDTA-citrate complexing method. The effects of Ca 2+ doping on the structural stability, oxygen desorption properties, electrical conductivity, and oxygen permeation behavior were carefully examined. 2 Experimental Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7+ δ ( x = 0.0, 0.025, 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.025, 0.3, 0.4) composite oxides were synthesized through a sol-gel process based on the EDTA-citrate complexing method [24,25] . Ca(NO 3 ) 2 , Ba(NO 3 ) 2 Co(NO 3 ) 2 , and Y(NO 3 ) 3 (all in A.R. grade) were used as the raw materials for the metal-ion sources. The raw materials were first prepared into aqueous solutions with concentration around 1 M. The precision concentrations were determined by the EDTA titration technique. EDTA powder was added into aqueous ammonium hydroxide to form a water-soluble ammonium salt. Stoichiometric amounts of metal nitrates and citric acid were dissolved in distilled water. The required amount of EDTA was introduced into the nitrate solution under stirring. The mole ratio of EDTA and citric acid to the total metal ions in the final solution was 1:2:1. The pH value of the solution was adjusted at 6 by the addition of NH 3 ·H 2 O. The solution was heated to ∼90 °C over a hot plate under magnetic stirring until a gel was formed. This gel was heated in a preheated oven at 250 °C to obtain a black solid mass called the precursor powder. The precursor powder was calcined at 950–1000 °C in air for 5 h to form the oxide powders with desired structures. Lattice parameters of Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7 powders were calculated with the help of the software named Accelrys MS Modeling 3.0, and the related computation program was TREOR 90. The as-obtained oxide powders were then pressed into disk-shaped membranes in a stainless steel die (15.0 mm in diameter) under a hydraulic pressure of approximately 1.5 × 10 8 Pa. These green disks (∼1.0 mm in thickness) were further sintered at 1100–1200 °C for 2–5 h. The relative density of the sintered membranes was measured by the Archimedes liquid displacement technique ( Table 1 ). Their microstructure was examined by environmental scanning electronic microscope (ESEM, QUANTA-2000). The crystal structure of the synthesized powders or sintered membranes was characterized with an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Bruker D8 Advance). The room-temperature oxygen nonstoichiometry was measured by the iodometry titration technique and details can be found elsewhere [26] . The oxygen temperature-programmed desorption (O 2 -TPD) analysis was carried out by mass spectrometer (Hiden QIC-20). One hundred milligram oxide powder was placed inside a U-type quartz reactor with the inner diameter of 3 mm. A K-type thermocouple was used for temperature monitoring. A constant helium (purity >99.999%) or air flow at the rate of 20 ml min −1 under the conditions of standard temperature and pressure (STP) was introduced to the reactor. After flowing with air gas for around 30 min at 300 °C to guarantee that the samples sufficiently absorbed oxygen, the reactor was heated at 10 °C min −1 to 950 °C. Oxygen was released from the oxide lattice during the heating process and carried out by the flowing helium to mass spectrometer for in-situ concentration analysis. The electrical conductivity was measured by the four-probe dc method based on sintered bars with the dimensions of 2 × 5 × 12 mm 3 . The measurement techniques were performed in air upon cooling from 900 to 300 °C at 5 °C per step. A constant current was applied to the two current wires and the voltage responses were recorded using a Keithley 2420 Sourcemeter. The current was increased from 1 μA to a maximum value of 2 A. Details of the conductivity measurement techniques are described elsewhere [26] . Oxygen permeation properties of the membranes were investigated by the gas chromatography (GC) technique. A silver paste was used as the sealant to fix the membrane disk onto a dense quartz tube and expose an effective membrane area of ∼0.45 cm 2 at the sweep side for the permeation study. The sidewall of the membrane was also covered with the silver paste to avoid radial contribution to the oxygen flux. Air was supplied from a gas cylinder to the oxygen-rich side at a flow rate of 400 ml min −1 [STP], while helium was applied as the sweep gas at a flow rate of 100 ml min −1 [STP] to collect the permeated oxygen to a Varian GC equipped with a 5 Å capillary molecule column for analysis. For checking whether the membrane is gas tight at room temperature, we use the bubble flow meter to confirm that there is no gas leakage. At high temperature in oxygen permeation experiment, oxygen concentration in outlet gases from sweep side could be nearly up to 1.1%, and nitrogen was also observed in these outlet gases with concentration nearly up to 4.5 × 10 −2 %. Details of the oxygen permeation measurements can also be found elsewhere [26] . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Phase structure and stability Fig. 2 shows the room-temperature XRD patterns of Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7+ δ ( x = 0.0–0.4) oxides prepared by calcination of the precursor powders at 1000 °C in air for 5 h. The parent oxide YCaBaCo 4 O 7 , or the doped Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7+ δ oxides with lower Ca doping concentrations ( x ≤ 0.2), displayed a single-phase layered perovskite structure with hexagonal symmetry and space group of P 6 3 mc [17,18] . However, a careful examination of the calculated lattice parameters listed in Table 2 shows the doping effects on the unit cell parameters. The increase of Ca content in Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7+ δ slightly increases the lattice parameters. For instance, the cell parameters of the parent oxide and the oxides with 10% and 20% Ca incorporation are as follows: a : 6.30 Å; c : 10.24 Å; V : 352.9 Å 3 (YCaBaCo 4 O 7 ); a : 6.32 Å; c : 10.28 Å; V : 357.1 Å 3 (Y 0.9 Ca 0.1 BaCo 4 O 7+ δ ); a : 6.33 Å; c : 10.29 Å; V : 359.2 Å 3 (Y 0.8 Ca 0.2 BaCo 4 O 7+ δ ). This observation can be explained by the fact that calcium has a much larger ionic radius (1.12 Å) than yttrium (1.01 Å). With the further increase of Ca concentration up to 25% or above, some additional peaks appeared. It is possible that A site coordination in layered perovskite Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7+ δ cannot tolerate high concentrations of elements with larger ionic radius due to strict requirements of the crystal field stabilization. However, at this stage, these impurity phases cannot be identified. To test the structural stability of Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7+ δ oxides, the samples were annealed in nitrogen or air flow at 850 °C for 6 h and cooled to room temperature for XRD examination. The results are shown in Fig. 3 . Under nitrogen atmosphere, the layered perovskite phase structure of Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7+ δ was stable with no impurity phases detected. However, under air atmosphere, some phase transitions can be noticed for samples with lower Ca content ( x = 0.0–0.025). Similar observations have been made by other researchers during investigation of the oxygen adsorptive behavior of RBaCo 4 O 7+ δ at high temperatures [19] . The phase transition was caused by decomposition of the YBaCo 4 O 7+ δ phase to BaCoO 3 with oxygen adsorption at high temperatures. In the Y–Ba–Co–O–air system, the YBaCo 4 O 7+ δ phase is thermodynamically stable only at temperatures higher than 900 °C [19] . Walldor and Andersson found that Kagome Co1 triangles were possibly in a position where oxygen from the adsorption process might be incorporated [17,18] . In this absorption process, some CoO 4 tetrahedra would convert to pyramids or octahedra, resulting in sublattice distortion or disorder. A high-level Ca doping ( x = 0.5–0.2) improved the material stability of Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7+ δ in air atmosphere at high temperatures. This is demonstrated by the XRD patterns of three samples of higher Ca content shown in Fig. 3 a. The larger lattice parameters of the samples with higher Ca content may provide more space, reducing the adverse effects of distortion of the Co1–O sublattice by oxygen adsorption. 3.2 Oxygen desorption properties Based on TGA technology, the oxygen absorption properties of RBaCo 4 O 7+ δ have been investigated by several groups [20–23] . In this work, we used the O 2 -TPD technique to further investigate the oxygen desorption properties of such oxides. With rising temperature, the reduction of metal ions from high to low oxidation state takes place together with the creation of oxygen vacancies in the oxide and the release of oxygen from the lattice. For cobalt-based perovskite-related oxides, the oxygen desorption at 200–600 °C (α-peak) is typically associated with the reduction of Co 4+ to Co 3+ while the β-peak is related to the reduction of Co 3+ to Co 2+ and usually appears at a temperature higher than 800 °C. Fig. 4 shows the O 2 -TPD profiles of the Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7+ δ oxides. It can be observed that all samples have typical desorption with the α-peak in the lower temperature zone (300–500 °C), consistent with the observations of other researchers [19] . At first glance, the difference in the oxygen desorption behavior before and after the Ca doping is not obvious. However, a careful examination of all α-peaks illustrates the temperature at which the oxygen desorption moves to a lower value after Ca incorporation and with the increase in Ca concentration. By virtue of the larger crystal volume caused by Ca incorporation, the Columbic attraction between cations and oxygen ions would be decreased, facilitating oxygen ion diffusion and molecular oxygen desorption. Further comparison of the oxygen desorption at temperatures higher than 750 °C shows that the intensity of β-peaks is gradually decreased with the increase in Ca concentration, particularly for the sample Y 0.8 Ca 0.2 BaCo 4 O 7+ δ . This suggests that the reduction of Co 3+ to Co 2+ is suppressed by the introduction of Ca in the lattice structure. At elevated temperatures, the change in cobalt valence state usually accounts for the thermal instability of the compounds due to the mismatch of the different cobalt ion radii (Co 3+ to Co 2+ ) in the sublattices between Co1–O and Ba/Y–O. More importantly, this may result in the collapse of the layered perovskite structure. Therefore, it is clear that Ca doping at the appropriate concentration improves the structural stability by suppressing the reduction of Co 3+ to Co 2 at high temperatures. 3.3 Electrical conductivity The oxygen permeability of MIEC membranes is closely related to their oxygen ionic and electronic conductivities. An excellent oxygen-permeable membrane should possess high electronic and oxygen ionic conductivities over the operational conditions. The effect of Ca doping on the conductivities of the Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7+ δ oxide under air or inert gas atmosphere was investigated. Fig. 5 shows the temperature dependence of the electrical conductivity from 300 to 900 °C in air or nitrogen atmosphere. The conductivity decreased with the drop of oxygen partial pressure, implying a p-type electronic conductivity mechanism. Pure YBaCo 4 O 7+ δ without Ca incorporation has the highest conductivity value of 270 S cm −1 in air, while increasing the Ca content steadily reduces the electronic conductivity. The phase transition of YBaCo 4 O 7+ δ -based oxides at lower temperatures in air changes the crystal structure, reducing hole mobility, which may result in poorer electrical conductivity at lower temperatures. Electronic conduction within perovskite-related oxides is believed to occur via a process similar to the Zerner double exchange process [27] . The conductivity can be affected by the degree of overlap between the electron clouds of oxygen and cobalt ions. Ca incorporation stretches the Co–O bond, which makes the electron hopping more difficult and thus lowers the electronic conductivity. It is also observed that the electronic conductivity in nitrogen decreases sharply after 600 °C, and then levels off at 800 °C, especially for YBaCo 4 O 7+ δ . This may indicate the unique oxygen adsorption/desorption capability of RBaCo 4 O 7+ δ oxide at high temperatures. According to the p-type electronic conducting mechanism, oxygen adsorption/desorption from the crystal lattice may influence electronic conduction. The oxygen adsorption can decrease the concentration of electron carriers such as electronic holes. As can be seen, when Ca content increases, the magnitude of conductivity decreases at high temperatures. This phenomenon is associated with weaker oxygen adsorption in Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7+ δ oxides, suggesting a relatively stable phase structure in these Ca-doped oxides. In addition, the electronic conductivity of all samples in nitrogen atmosphere is quite high, with the maximum value of ∼70 S cm −1 at a temperature of ∼600 °C. The observed higher conductivity of all samples in nitrogen atmosphere is attributed to the easy electron hopping along a continuous two-dimension network of Co–O bonds in the Co1–O layer. 3.4 Oxygen permeation properties The Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7+ δ membranes used for the oxygen permeation test were sintered at 1100–1200 °C and the microstructure of the ceramic membranes was observed via SEM. All membranes displayed similar morphology under these sintering conditions, with a grain size up to 10 μm; a typical Y 0.8 Ca 0.2 BaCo 4 O 7+ δ membrane is shown in Fig. 6 . Gas leakage tests at room temperature confirmed that there were no through pinholes inside the ceramic disks. Fig. 7 shows the temperature dependence of oxygen permeation fluxes through Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7+ δ ( x = 0.0, 0.025, 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.25, 0.3) membranes with helium flow rate fixed at 100 ml min −1 [STP]. All membranes were of 1.0 mm thickness and their surfaces were polished to ensure relatively similar surface morphology. For YBaCo 4 O 7+ δ and Y 0.975 Ca 0.025 BaCo 4 O 7+ δ membranes, cracks were observed. The crack formation resulted from the internal stress created by the phase structure transition. The oxygen flux through Y 0.9 Ca 0.1 BaCo 4 O 7+ δ rose from 0.12 × 10 −6 to 0.33 × 10 −6 mol cm −2 s −1 as the temperature increased from 750 to 850 °C. Further inspection of the Ca doping effect on the fluxes at similar temperatures gives more important information. Over the entire range of the temperature investigated, the parent YBaCo 4 O 7+ δ or Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7+ δ ( x = 0.025) membranes demonstrated the lowest permeation fluxes ranging from 0.06 × 10 −6 (750 °C) to 0.14 × 10 −6 mol cm −2 s −1 (900 °C). As discussed previously, both samples of YBaCo 4 O 7+ δ and Y 0.975 Ca 0.025 BaCo 4 O 7+ δ experienced a phase transition in oxygen-containing atmosphere at high temperatures and their perovskite structure was totally replaced by other phases (as shown in Fig. 3 ). Such phase transitions are detrimental to oxygen ion diffusion and thus result in poor oxygen permeation behavior. A higher Ca doping concentration (0.05 ≤ x ≤ 0.2) inside the structure of YBaCo 4 O 7+ δ stabilizes the perovskite phase and therefore gives a significant increase in the oxygen permeation fluxes of the resultant membranes. When the doping concentration x is increased from 0.05 to 0.2, the oxygen absorption/desorption of the Co1–O sublattice in Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7+ δ is suppressed at high temperatures, which further improves the stability of the layered perovskite phase and thus contributes to higher oxygen fluxes. On the other hand, when more Y 3+ ions are substituted by Ca 2+ , a higher oxygen vacancy concentration will be formed to maintain the charge neutrality as evidenced by the data in Table 2 . The most preferable positions for oxygen vacancies in YBaCo 4 O 7+ δ -based oxides may be under the Kagome Co1 triangles ( Fig. 1 ). Higher concentrations of oxygen vacancies also contribute to larger oxygen fluxes. Oxygen permeation fluxes therefore gradually improve as Ca doping increases from x = 0.05 to 0.2. With an increase in Ca content above 0.2, the oxygen permeation flux begins to drop due to deterioration of the layered perovskite structure at high Ca content. It is clear from the Ca doping concentration analysis that Y 0.8 Ca 0.2 BaCo 4 O 7+ δ is the best composition for layered Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7+ δ oxides to be used as a membrane material. Meanwhile, a careful examination of the improving trend of the oxygen fluxes with the temperature increment in Fig. 7 illustrates that such increasing trend has been enlarged when the temperature is over 850 °C indicating that the change of the activation energy makes the oxygen permeation process easier after 850 °C. This activation energy change may be related to the phase transition. As discussed before, in the Y–Ba–Co–O–air system, the YBaCo 4 O 7+ δ phase is thermodynamically stable only at higher temperatures (>850 °C). However, with the increase in Ca 2+ content, such transition was obviously inhibited. Therefore, the oxygen permeation value of the corresponding membranes with higher Ca 2+ content ( x > 0.2) seemed to keep the same increasing trend when membrane operation was from the lower temperature zone (700–850 °C) to the higher temperature zone (>850 °C). At 900 °C, the oxygen permeation flux across Y 0.8 Ca 0.2 BaCo 4 O 7+ δ membrane reaches 0.75 × 10 −6 mol cm −2 s −1 for the 1 mm thick membrane. As shown in Fig. 8 , the value is much higher than those for other layered oxides, such as LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ (Ln = lanthanide) [28] . The significant improvement of the oxygen permeation flux for the Y 0.8 Ca 0.2 BaCo 4 O 7+ δ membrane is mainly due to its unique structure, which possesses wide spaces for easy oxygen incorporation and good oxygen desorption/adsorption capability at relatively low temperatures. Fig. 9 shows the effects of membrane thickness on the permeation fluxes at various temperatures with a He sweep rate of 100 ml min −1 [STP] and membrane material composition of Y 0.8 Ca 0.2 BaCo 4 O 7+ δ . As can be seen, decreasing membrane thickness is very effective for increasing the flux. As an example, the fluxes through the membranes at 800 °C for thicknesses of 0.7, 1.0, and 1.5 mm are 0.59 × 10 −6 , 0.41 × 10 −6 , 0.26 × 10 −6 mol cm −2 s −1 , respectively. Oxygen permeation through the MIEC membranes is controlled by the oxygen ion bulk diffusion rate as well as the surface exchange kinetics on either side of the membrane. In order to clarify the controlling steps, the proportionality ( K d 1 / d 2 ) between the oxygen flux and the membrane thickness was calculated via the following equation: (1) K d 1 / d 2 = J O 2 ( d 1 ) J O 2 ( d 2 ) d 1 d 2 In Eq. (1) , J O 2 ( d ) stands for flux at membrane thickness d at a specific temperature. When the oxygen permeation is totally controlled by the slow oxygen bulk diffusion, K should be equal to or close to 1, which can be derived by the application of Wagner theory [29] . While K d 1 / d 2 is equal to the value d 1 / d 2 , the permeation process should be governed by surface exchange kinetics. As shown in Fig. 10 , K d 1 / d 2 is close to 1 within the investigated membrane thickness range of 0.7–1.5 mm. This suggests that oxygen transport was mainly rate determined by the slow oxygen bulk diffusion process. To further speed up the oxygen permeation fluxes of Y 0.8 Ca 0.2 BaCo 4 O 7+ δ membranes, membrane thicknesses should be further reduced, which can be achieved using a composite membrane of asymmetric structure. 4 Conclusions Layered perovskite Y 1− x Ca x BaCo 4 O 7+ δ ( x = 0.0–0.4) oxides were synthesized by an EDTA-citrate complexing method and explored as potential materials for ceramic membranes for air separation. The calcium doping concentration ( x ) in the lattice structure had significant effects on the phase structure stability, oxygen absorption/desorption properties, electrical conductivity, and oxygen permeation flux of the oxides. To maintain the layered perovskite structure, the calcium doping in YBaCo 4 O 7+ δ should be controlled at less than x = 0.2. The calcium incorporation led to a decrease of electronic conductivity but an increase of oxygen nonstoichiometry in the oxides at room temperature. At 900 °C, the permeation flux through a 1 mm thick Y 0.8 Ca 0.2 BaCo 4 O 7+ δ membrane reached ∼0.75 × 10 −6 mol cm −2 s −1 under an oxygen gradient created by air and helium. The oxygen permeation through thick Y 0.8 Ca 0.2 BaCo 4 O 7+ δ membranes was rate limited mainly by the relatively slow oxygen bulk diffusion. Decreasing membrane thickness would be an effective way to further improve the oxygen permeation fluxes. 53JzQvtT.title: A mechanism study of synthesis of Li4Ti5O12 from TiO2 anatase
53JzQvtT.abstract: The formation mechanism of a spinel-type lithium titanate Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 with TiO 2 anatase as raw material, in both a conventional solid-state reaction (SSR) and a cellulose-assisted glycine-nitrate combustion (cellulose-GN) process are comparatively studied. XRD characterization demonstrates high-purity Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 forms at 750 °C by the cellulose-GN synthesis, which occurs at a temperature at least 100 °C lower than that via SSR. The solid-phase reaction between TiO 2 and lithium compounds to form Li–Ti–O spinel and the phase transition of TiO 2 from anatase to “inert” rutile phase occur competitively during both synthesis processes. SEM results suggest that the solid precursor from the cellulose-GN process has a smaller particle size and a more homogenous mixing of the reactants than that in the SSR. Temperature-programmed oxidation experiments demonstrate that cellulose thermal pyrolysis creates a reducing atmosphere, which may facilitate the oxygen-ion diffusion. Both factors facilitate the formation of Li–Ti–O spinel, while the TiO 2 anatase transforms to TiO 2 rutile during the SSR, which has slow lithium-insertion kinetics. As a result, a high calcination temperature is necessary to obtain a phase-pure Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 . Charge–discharge and EIS tests demonstrate the Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 obtained by the cellulose-GN process shows much better low-temperature electrochemical performance than that obtained by standard SSR. This improvement attributes to the reduced particle size due to the lower synthesis temperature. Keywords Lithium titanate Combustion synthesis Solid-state reaction Titanium dioxide

bALcT60v.title: Influence of high-energy ball milling of precursor on the morphology and electrochemical performance of Li4Ti5O12–ball-milling time
bALcT60v.abstract: High-energy ball milling (HEBM) was applied for the synthesis of spinel Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 and the influence of milling time was investigated systematically. With the increase of ball-milling time, the average particle size of the as-synthesized Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 powder decreased from ~ 900 nm to ~ 150 nm, while the particle morphology changed little. At the same time, the main particle size distribution peak split up into two parts, which were narrowed and moved to a smaller range. Electrochemical testing results showed that the Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 with precursor milled for 60 min at 500 rpm rotational speed showed a favorable discharge capacity of ~ 146.9 mAh/g with corresponding coulombic efficiency of 99.9% at 1 C rate. The rate performance was improved with the increase of milling time because of the smaller particle size of the resulted Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 . The voltage change between oxidation peak and reduction peak of Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 also became wider with milling time increasing. Keywords High-energy ball milling Precursor Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 Electrochemical performance 1 Introduction Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 is one of the most promising anode materials for high-power batteries or hybrid capacitors because of its unique properties. It is also called a “zero-strain” material because of its small structure changes during Li + intercalation/de-intercalation processes [1–3] . In comparison with natural graphite, it shows better thermal stability [4] and sharper voltage wave that can be served as an over charge/discharge indicator. Furthermore, Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 can be combined with many other electrode materials to obtain new power sources [5] . On the other hand, the electrochemical performance of the electrode is closely related with its specific morphology. Some particle morphologies have been demonstrated to be beneficial for improving the electrode performance [6,7] . HEBM is a promising way to synthesize micro- or nano-structured high-performance materials for a wide range of applications. It mainly utilizes the mechanical energy originating from the constant collisions between particles and balls or bowl to meliorate the performance of materials or promote a solid-state reaction [8–14] . In a HEBM process, the reactants are subjected to a thorough pulverization and intimate powder mixing [8] . As compared to other ball-milling processes, HEBM is more efficient in enhancing the reaction rate or modifying the particle morphology of materials [9] . Ball-milling time and rotational speed are two key factors that may affect the performance of the resulted materials. According to the literature there is no related work available. In this study, the influence of milling time on the morphology and consequently the electrochemical performance of Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 synthesized by HEBM was specifically investigated in detail. 2 Experimental A series of Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 powders were synthesized by a HEBM-assisted solid-state reaction. The raw materials, anatase TiO 2 (~ 20 nm), LiOH·H 2 O (AR), activated carbon (~ 1993 m 2 /g) and glycol, at the weight ratio of 1.2:1:6.8:28.5, were well mixed by high-energy ball milling using ZrO 2 balls and bowl at a ball-to-powder weight ratio of 47:1. The milling was performed in air at 500 rpm rotational speed for different times. The as-obtained black slurry was dried and further calcined at 800 °C in air for 12 h to result in the final white products [15] . The as-synthesized Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 powders were grounded and then mixed well with 10 wt.% SuperP conductive additive (Shanghai Hersbit Chemical Co., Ltd, China) and 5 wt.% LA-132 binder (Chengdu Indigo Power Sources Co., Ltd, China), which were mechanically homogenized in an agate mortar to form slurry for coating on a cleaned copper foil. After drying at 100 °C under vacuum for several hours, it was laminated and cut into 0.76 cm 2 wafer for use as working electrode. Metal lithium was used as counter and reference electrode. Electrochemical cells were assembled in an argon-filled glove box by sandwiching a Celgard 2400 microporous separator between two electrodes using an electrolyte of 1.0 M LiPF 6 /ethylene carbonate–dimethyl carbonate (1:1 in vol.) (Zhangjiagang Guotai-Huarong New Chemical Co., Ltd, China). Above cells were cycled galvanostatically between 1.0 and 3.0 V vs . Li/Li + at 298 K on a Neware battery-testing instrument (Shenzhen Neware Technology Ltd, China). Voltammetric technique was performed on an electrochemical workstation combined with a Solartron 1260A frequency response analyzer and a Solartron 1287 potentiostat/galvanostat. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 SEM analysis XRD results showed that the obtained products were spinel Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 . From the SEM images shown in Fig. 1 , the as-synthesized Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 powder with its precursor milled at 500 rpm had a smaller particle size than the others. Much less degree of aggregation was observed for the HEBM-derived samples as compared to that synthesized by a normal high-temperature solid-state reaction. The quasi-spherical particle morphology of the Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 , however, did not change a lot, when the average particle size decreased from ~ 900 nm to ~ 150 nm with the milling time increased from 0 min to 120 min. It indicates that HEBM is an effective tool to reduce the particle size of the resulted product [10] , while the particle morphology is less impacted. 3.2 Effects of milling on particle size From the results obtained by Laser Particle Analyzer (Malvern Zetasizer 300, UK) in Fig. 2 , the main particle size distribution peak of Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 split up into two when the milling time increased from 0 min to 120 min. Such a phenomenon was also observed in the preparation of Li 2 Ti 3 O 7 by ball milling [16] . It was originated from the unequal chances of the precursor milled between balls and bowl, because the moving particles and centrifugal moving balls are synchronous and the effective collision is various. The particle size of the Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 without precursor treated by HEBM was big and concentrated on a wide range of 400–1000 nm, while the particle size of the Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 with its precursor milled by HEBM became smaller and concentrated on two ranges. It implies that the HEBM may affect greatly the particle size distribution. The particle size distributions of the Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 with its precursor milled for 60 min concentrated on two ranges of 160–260 nm and 600–900 nm, while for 120 min concentrated on 90–180 nm and 500–600 nm. The longer ball-milling time of precursor resulted in a decline of particle size of the resulted powder after further calcination, agreeing with above SEM results. 3.3 Electrochemical performance Fig. 3 shows the typical galvanostatic charge/discharge curves of Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 at 1 C rate. They demonstrated a charge and discharge voltage of ~ 1.6 V and ~ 1.5 V, respectively, consisting well with other results [1–7,15] . On the other hand, between the milling time of 0 min and 60 min, the charge/discharge voltage plateau of Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 became wider with the increase of ball-mill time of the precursor. It suggests that the utilizable capacity increased with balling time prolonging. After 60 min, the charge/discharge profiles changed little with the further increase of milling time. According to Fig. 4 , the Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 with precursor milled for 60 min showed the best electrochemical performance at 1 C rate with a discharge capacity of 146.9 mAh/g and a corresponding coulombic efficiency of 99.9%. However, the rate performance increased monotonously with the ball-milling time, as shown in Fig. 4 (b). The improved rate performance of the powder at increased ball-milling time was attributed to the smaller particle size, which ensures a smaller diffusion resistance and larger surface reaction sites during the charge and discharge processes [17,18] . With discharge rate increasing from 1 C to 10 C, the capacity fading of Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 reached 47.4%, 32.9% and 23.4 % as corresponding milling time was 0 min, 60 min and 120 min, respectively. Therefore, the milling time of HEBM should be optimized to match the electrochemical performance of Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 . Fig. 5 is the voltammetric curves of the prepared Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 at 2 mV/s scan rate. They all showed good cathodic and anodic peaks, corresponding to the Li + insertion and Li + deinsertion, respectively. The peak position is not exactly at ~ 1.6 V or ~ 1.5 V, because it is a function of the applied scan rate [19] . Since the open circuit voltage was near 3.0 V, Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 was inserted with Li + at first step and then de-inserted Li + in cycle. The overall reaction in the cell is given as follows (1) Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 + 3Li + + 3 ē ⇌Li 7 Ti 5 O 12 Increasing milling time from 0 min to 120 min, the position of the oxidation peak moved from 1.75 to 1.85 V, while the position of corresponding reduction peak moved from 1.45 to 1.35 V, suggesting the voltage change between oxidation peak and reduction peak increased. 4 Summary HEBM utilized the mechanical energy originating from fast collisions to change effectively the particle size and electrochemical performance of Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 . The longer milling time led to a smaller particle size and the split of the main particle size distribution peak from one to two. The average particle size decreased from ~ 900 nm to ~ 150 nm when milling time increased from 0 min to 120 min. However, milling time had little effect on the quasi-spherical morphology. Galvanostatic charge/discharge tests showed that a milling time of 60 min was beneficial to improve the capacity and efficiency of Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 at 1 C rate. The discharge capacity and corresponding coulombic efficiency could reach 146.9 mAh/g and 99.9%, respectively. However, the rate capability increased with milling time prolonging, which was attributed to the smaller particle size. With discharge rate increasing from 1 C to 10 C, the capacity fading of Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 reached 47.4%, 32.9% and 23.4 % as corresponding milling time was 0 min, 60 min and 120 min, respectively. Voltammetric curves indicated that the Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 had good cathodic and anodic peaks, and the voltage change between oxidation peak and reduction peak became wider with milling time increasing. q6cSCvHO.title: Study on oxygen activation and methane oxidation over La 0.8Sr0.2MnO3 electrode in single-chamber solid oxide fuel cells via an electrochemical approach
q6cSCvHO.abstract: Single-chamber solid oxide fuel cells (SC-SOFCs), which apply fuel-oxidant (air) gas mixture as the atmosphere for both anode and cathode, are receiving many interests recently. This study aims to clarify the mechanism of oxygen reduction and methane oxidization over La0.8Sr0.2MnO 3 (LSM) cathode in SC-SOFCs by an electrochemical method in combination with mass spectrometry (MS). Before cathodic polarization, a large polarization resistance (Rp) for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) was observed and methane did not cause obvious effect on ORR because of the weak adsorption of methane over LSM surface. Cathodic polarization could decrease the Rp obviously due to the in-situ creation of oxygen vacancies; methane likely adsorbed on those oxygen vacancy sites to enhance its effect on ORR. Both the anodic and cathodic polarizations significantly increased the rate of methane oxidation over LSM electrode; in particular, the pumped oxygen anion was highly active for methane oxidation.
