N8yQ2e7K.title: Performance of SrSc0.2Co0.8O3-δ + Sm0.5Sr0.5CoO3-δ mixed-conducting composite electrodes for oxygen reduction at intermediate temperatures
N8yQ2e7K.abstract: In order to improve the electrical conductivity of the SrSc 0.2 Co 0.8 O 3− δ (SrScCo) electrode, a composite of 70 wt% SrSc 0.2 Co 0.8 O 3− δ and 30 wt% Sm 0.5 Sr 0.5 CoO 3− δ (SrScCo + SmSrCo) was prepared and investigated for electrochemical oxygen reduction at intermediate temperatures. The phase reaction between SrScCo and SmSrCo and its effect on the electrical conductivity, oxygen vacancy concentration and oxygen mobility were examined by XRD, 4-probe DC conductivity measurement, iodometry titration and O 2 -TPD experiment, respectively. The results showed that the composite reached a maximum conductivity around 123 S cm −1 at 600 °C, nearly five times that of SrScCo. AC impedance results showed that the electron charge-transfer process was greatly improved by forming the composite electrode, while the oxygen-ion charge-transfer process was somewhat deteriorated. By firing at 1000 °C for 2 h, a SOFC with the SrScCo + SmSrCo cathode and thin-film SDC electrolyte delivered peak power densities of 1100 and 366 mW cm −2 at 600 and 500 °C, respectively, which were only modestly lower than those of a similar cell with a pure SrScCo cathode. Keywords Solid-oxide fuel cell Composite electrode Oxygen non-stoichiometry Oxygen mobility SrSc 0.2 Co 0.8 O 3− δ 1 Introduction It is generally believed that the widespread commercialization of solid-oxide fuel cell (SOFC) technology can be greatly accelerated if its operation temperature is successfully reduced from traditionally around 1000 °C to the range of 500–800 °C without severe impact on the cell power output. This is because the intermediate-temperature operation allows cheaper stainless steel as interconnecting materials, more elegant sealing and better thermal management, and prolongs lifetime by significantly reducing the rate of interfacial reactions between cell components [1,2] . The main obstacle in the development of an intermediate-temperature solid-oxide fuel cell (IT-SOFC) is the poor activity of traditional cathodes for oxygen reduction, which leads to poor cell performance at reduced temperatures [3–5] . The development of new cathode materials with high electrocatalytic activity for oxygen-reduction reaction at intermediate temperatures is then of great importance and it has received considerable attention during the past decade [6,7] . The cathodic reaction involves the reduction of molecular oxygen to oxygen ion via a series of intermediate steps, including gas diffusion, surface adsorption, dissociation, charge transfer and so on [8,9] . High activation energy of 80–350 kJ mol −1 is typically observed for such a reduction process [10–15] . As a result, a sharp increase in cathodic polarization resistance with reducing operating temperature was frequently observed. One typical example is oxygen reduction over the La 0.8 Sr 0.2 MnO 3 (LSM) electrode, in which the charge-transfer reaction is limited to the triple phase boundary (TPB) where the electrode, the electrolyte and the gas phase (air) meet [16,17] . If the electrode possesses mixed-conducting capability, the oxygen-reduction reaction sites extend to the entire cathode surface because the oxygen ions can diffuse through the electrode bulk towards the electrode–electrolyte interface in addition to the surface diffusion paths [18–21] . Consequently, electrocatalytic activity of the cathode towards oxygen reduction at reduced temperatures can be significantly improved [20,13] . The ionic conducting channels can be created by introducing a second phase to form a composite electrode, or the electrode intrinsically possesses ionic conducting capability [4,6–8,22–25] . Recently we reported a new mixed-conducting perovskite-type oxide SrSc 0.2 Co 0.8 O 3-δ (SrScCo) as a potential cathode material of IT-SOFC. An area specific resistance (ASR) as low as 0.206 Ω cm 2 was obtained at 550 °C based on a symmetric cell test [13] . However, one serious drawback of the SrScCo electrode may be its poor electrical conductivity. Under ambient atmosphere, a maximum electrical conductivity of 40 S cm −1 was observed [26] . Under polarization, the electrical conductivity could even be much lower. As a cathode of SOFC, for efficient current collection, the electrical conductivity is preferred to be higher than 100 S cm −1 [27] . The poor electrical conductivity may introduce large contact resistance, especially if it is applied in a large cell stack. In order to increase the electrical conductivity, we can incorporate an electrical conducting phase into the SrScCo matrix to form a composite electrode. Previously, we have adopted LaCoO 3 as the electrical conducting phase in trying to increase the electrical conductivity of a Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ (BSCF)-based electrode [14] . Because LaCoO 3 is a purely an electron conductor, a reduction in the apparent ionic conductivity of the electrode is expected. In order to increase the electrical conductivity of SrScCo electrode without severe impair on the ionic conductivity, the formation of a composite electrode by introducing a mixed-conducting oxide Sm 0.5 Sr 0.5 CoO 3− δ (SmSrCo) with high electrical conductivity was tried in this study [28] . The phase reaction between SrScCo and SmSrCo and its impact on the electrical conductivity, oxygen vacancy concentration, oxygen mobility and activity of the composite electrode for oxygen reduction were investigated in detail. The performances of a single cell with various electrode materials were studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis and fabrication All the composite oxides, including Sm 0.2 Ce 0.8 O 1.9 (SDC), SrScCo, SmSrCo and Sm 0.13 Sr 0.87 Sc 0.15 Co 0.85 O 3-δ (SSSC) were synthesized by an EDTA–citrate complexing sol–gel process. Analytic reagents of Sc 2 O 3 , Sr(NO 3 ) 2 , Co(NO 3 ) 2 and Sm(NO 3 ) 3 ·6H 2 O were applied as the raw materials. For a typical synthesis, the required amounts of metal ions were first mixed into a solution, EDTA and citric acid were then added to serve as the complexing agents with the molar ratio of total metal ions to EDTA to citric acid set at 1:1:2, and the pH value of the solution was adjusted to around 6 by using NH 3 ·H 2 O. After the evaporation of water under heating, a transparent purple gel was obtained, which was then pre-treated at 240 °C to form a solid precursor and calcined at 900 °C in air for 5 h to obtain the targeted composite oxide. Symmetric cell configuration was used for evaluating the electrode performance for oxygen-reduction. SDC electrolyte pellets were fabricated by die pressing, followed by sintering at 1450 °C for 5 h in air. Electrode slurry was prepared by ball milling the electrode material with a liquid composed of glycerol, ethylene glycol and isopropyl alcohol at 400 rpm for 30 min. It was then painted onto each side of the SDC electrolyte pellets and calcined at 1000 °C for 2 h in air. Silver paste covered the entire surfaces of the electrode to act as the current collector. Silver wires were fixed to the electrode by silver paste to perform as the leads. Anode-supported thin-film electrolyte fuel cells were adopted for the single-cell test. Anode powders consisting of 60 wt% NiO and 40 wt% SDC were prepared through the mechanical mixing of NiO and SDC in an agate mortar. To fabricate the single cell, the well-mixed anode powder was firstly pressed as a substrate with the pressure of 150 MPa, Subsequently about 0.02 g SDC powder was added onto the substrate and pressed again to form a bi-layer pellet at 300 MPa. The bi-layer pellets were then fired under stagnant air at 1450 °C for 5 h. The cathode layer was fabricated onto the SDC electrolyte surface by spray-deposition followed by calcinations at various temperatures for 2 h in air. The thicknesses of the anode and cathode are ∼300 μm and ∼20 μm, respectively. Silver paste and silver wires were also adopted as the current collector and current lead, respectively. For oxygen permeation or electrical conductivity measurement purposes, disk-shape ceramic membranes or bar-shape pellets made of selected electrode materials were fabricated by die pressing followed by sintering at high temperatures. About 0.68 g oxide powder prepared from the calcination at 900 °C was pressed into disk-shape or bar-shape pellets in a stainless steel die at a pressure of 300 MPa. The SmSrCo, SrScCo and SSSC pellets were then sintered at 1100 °C for 5 h. The relative density of the pellets was always higher than 95% as measured by Archimedes liquid displacement method. For electrical conductivity measurement, the pellet of SrScCo + SmSrCo composite was also prepared and sintered at 1000 °C for 5 h. 2.2 Oxygen permeation test Oxygen permeation through SrScCo, SmSrCo and SSSC membranes was measured by the gas chromatograph method. The as-sintered membranes with a diameter of 12–13 mm were polished to a thickness of ∼0.85 mm by attrition paper and then sealed onto a dense quartz tube. The effective surface area of the membrane at the sweep side for permeation study was around 0.45 cm 2 . Helium was used as the sweep gas at a flow rate of 100 ml min −1 [STP]. The permeated oxygen was conducted to a Varian 3800 gas chromatograph for composition analysis. The amount of permeated oxygen can be calculated based on the helium flow rate and the oxygen concentration in the effluent gas. 2.3 Iodometry titration The iodometric titration was used to determine the average cobalt valency and the oxygen vacancy concentration (δ) in SmSrCo, SrScCo and SrScCo + SmSrCo. Initially, about 0.1 g of the sample was accurately weighed and placed in a 100 ml Erlenmeyer flask, which was filled with flowing nitrogen gas to prevent the oxidation of I − ions by air. Then 3 g of KI and 5 ml of 1 M HCl aqueous solution were added in sequence. The following reaction (Eq. (1) ) occurred. (1) Co ( 2 + x ) + + x I − = Co 2 + + x 2 I 2 where 2 + x expresses the effective oxidation level of cobalt by the theorem of charge neutrality, also called the cobalt average valency for simplicity. A buffer solution consisting of NH 4 Ac and HAc was applied to adjust the final pH value of the solution to around 3.5. The liberated I 2 was then titrated with the standard thiosulfate (Na 2 S 2 O 3 ) solution of 0.02 mol L −1 with starch as the indicator. The following reaction happened during the titration. The average cobalt valency can be calculated based on the amount of S 2 O 3 2− consumed and the amount of oxide powder applied. (2) I 2 + 2 S 2 O 3 2 − = 2 I − + S 2 O 6 2 2.4 Electrochemical characterization The single-cell test was conducted over an in-lab constructed fuel cell test station 3% H 2 O humidified H 2 and ambient air were supplied as the fuel and the cathode atmosphere, respectively. I–V polarization curves were collected by a digital electrometer (Model 2420, Keithley, USA). The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of the single cells or symmetric cells was measured under open circuit voltage (OCV) conditions. Impedance measurements were performed using an electrochemical workstation based on a Solartron 1260A frequency response analyzer together with a Solartron 1287 Potentionstat/Galvanostat. The applied frequency was in the range of 0.1 mHz to 1 MHz, and the voltage amplitude was 10 mV. 2.5 Other characterizations The crystal structures of the synthesized composite oxides, or the reaction products of SmSrCo and SrScCo, were analyzed by an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Bruker D8 Advance). O 2 -TPD experiments were conducted on the home-constructed multipurpose temperature- programmed apparatus. About 0.15 g sample in the size of 40–60 mesh was dropped into a U-type quartz tube reactor with an inner diameter of 4 mm. Argon was introduced from one end of the tube at the flow rate of 15 ml min −1 [STP], and the temperature was programmatically increased from room temperature to 930 °C. The oxygen in the oxide lattice was progressively released, which was carried out by the flowing argon to a mass spectrometer (Hiden QIC-20, UK) for on-line oxygen concentration analysis. Occasionally, the temperature remained at 930 °C for sufficient time to allow the completion of the oxygen desorption process. The electrical conductivity was measured by the 4-probe DC conductivity technique. Silver paste was painted on the endpoints of the rectangle and along the rectangular edges of the bar-shape pellets to form current and voltage electrodes. Two silver wires acted as current contacts and the other two silver wires acted as the voltage contacts and were attached to the electrodes after pre-treatment at 180 °C for 1 h. The current was applied to the two current wires and the voltage was detected by a digital source meter (Keithley 2420, USA) at intervals of 10 °C over the temperature range of 900–300 °C in air with a cooling rate of 5 °C min −1 . At each temperature step, sufficient time was allowed for conductivity stabilization. The conductivity was calculated by the following relationship: (3) σ = 1 R × l S where l , S and R represent the length, the cross-section area and DC resistance, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Phase reaction Regarding the composite electrode, phase reaction between the electrode components is a big concern for practical application. It may be beneficial or detrimental to the electrode performance, depending on the type and degree of the reaction [29,30] . In order to make the electrode layer firmly adhered to the electrolyte surface and the well connection between the electrode particles to minimize the contacting resistance during the fuel cell fabrication, the cell with the electrode layer should be fired at a temperature usually above 900 °C. However, it is well known that many cobalt-containing perovskite oxides have high reactivity with other cell components at such high temperatures. For example, we have previously demonstrated that BSCF can react with SDC and LaCoO 3 at temperatures above 900 °C [10,14] . To investigate the possible phase reaction between SrScCo and SmSrCo oxides at high temperatures, they were mixed in powder form at a weight ratio of 7–3 and then calcined at various temperatures between 950 and 1100 °C for 5 h in air. Shown in Fig. 1 are the X-ray diffraction patterns of the mixed powder after the various high-temperature calcinations. For comparison, the X-ray diffraction patterns of pure SmSrCo and SrScCo are also presented. Both SmSrCo and SrScCo oxides demonstrated a phase-pure perovskite structure, and their diffraction peaks can be indexed well based on orthorhombic and cubic lattice symmetry, respectively. For the mixed powder after the calcination at 950 °C, its diffraction peaks can be roughly indexed based on a mixture of two perovskite oxides with different lattice parameters. All of the diffraction peaks of the perovskite with the larger lattice parameter matched well with those of the SrScCo phase, thus becoming assigned to the SrScCo-related phase, while the other peaks are assigned to the SmSrCo-related phase. With increasing calcination temperature, the intensity of the SmSrCo-related phase steadily decreased and almost disappeared after the calcination at 1100 °C for 5 h. All of the diffraction peaks of the composite oxide can be indexed well based on a single-phase perovskite with cubic lattice symmetry and the unit cell constant similar to that of SrScCo. Thus suggests that the solid-state reaction between SmSrCo and SrScCo was likely completed with the formation of a new perovskite with a similar lattice parameter to that of SrScCo after the calcination at 1100 °C. To support this assumption, a new oxide with the nominal composition of Sm 0.13 Sr 0.87 Sc 0.15 Co 0.85 O 3-δ (SSSC), which had the same cation ratio as the SrScCo + SmSrCo mixture of this study, was synthesized. The new oxide demonstrated a pure phase perovskite structure with cubic lattice symmetry. Shown in Fig. 1 , the diffraction peaks of SSSC matched fairly well with those of the SrScCo + SmSrCo oxide calcined at 1100 °C. 3.2 Oxygen vacancy concentration and oxygen mobility For the mixed-conducting electrode, its performance for oxygen reduction is closely related to the ionic conductivity. If oxygen vacancy is the charge carrier for the oxygen ion, which is the case for SrScCo and SmSrCo, the oxygen ionic conductivity is determined by the oxygen vacancy concentration and the oxygen mobility inside the oxide lattice according to the famous Nernst–Einstein equation [31] , (4) σ o = D o C o q o 2 k T where D o represents the self-diffusivity of the oxide ion, C o is the concentration of oxide ion and q o is the charge of the oxygen ion. The oxygen vacancy concentration of the oxides is dependent on the average oxidation state of the cobalt ion. The average oxidation state of cobalt ion in SrScCo, SmSrCo and SrScCo + SmSrCo composite after calcinations at various temperatures for 5 h is then titrated by iodometry method with the results listed in Table 1 . For SrScCo oxide, the measured average oxidation state of Co is +2.91, in good agreement with our previous report [13] . It is 3.21 for cobalt in SmSrCo, suggesting that the cobalt in SmSrCo prefers to remain at a higher oxidation state. This could be explained by the smaller ionic size of Sm 3+ (0.124 Å) than that of Sr 2+ (0.158 Å). In order to maintain the perovskite lattice structure, the cobalt ion should remain at a smaller cation size to meet the requirement of the A-site cations. Assuming no phase reaction between SrScCo and SmSrCo, the cobalt in SrScCo + SmSrCo composite should have an average oxidation state of 3.007. According to the results in Table 1 , the phase reaction between SrScCo and SmSrCo did not result in an obvious change of the average oxidation state of cobalt in SrScCo + SmSrCo composites. For all the samples calcined at various temperatures the average cobalt ion oxidation state was located within the narrow range of 3.00–3.04. This suggests that the oxygen vacancy concentrations in SrScCo + SmSrCo composite calcined at different temperatures are similar to each other. O 2 -TPD is a facile technique to qualitatively analyze the oxygen mobility within the lattice and the reducibility of the cobalt ions. It is well known that the cobalt ion can occupy multiple oxidation states in a perovskite structure. With the programmatic increase of the temperature under an inert atmosphere, the reduction of the cobalt ions to a lower oxidation state could be thermally induced. To maintain electrical neutrality, the oxidation of O 2− to molecular oxygen should occur simultaneously with the creation of additional oxygen vacancies. The successful reduction of cobalt ions to a lower oxidation state should satisfy two basic requirements. Firstly, the reduction of cobalt ions to a lower oxidation state should be thermodynamically favorable; secondly, the oxide should have a certain level of oxygen ionic conductivity. Higher oxygen-ion mobility leads to lower expected initial oxygen release temperature. On the other hand, easier reduction of cobalt ion indicates that a larger amount of oxygen should be released. Shown in Fig. 2 are the O 2 -TPD profiles of SrScCo + SmSrCo mixture powder calcined at various temperatures for 5 h. For comparison, the profiles of the pure phase SmSrCo and SrScCo are also presented. SmSrCo has the lowest initial temperature for the oxygen release among the tested materials. It suggests that the oxygen ion in SmSrCo has the highest mobility. However, it also has the smallest oxygen desorption peak area, suggesting that the Co 4+ in SmSrCo has the highest stability. In connection with the low initial oxygen non-stoichiometry of the oxide, the relatively low oxygen vacancy concentration may be the decisive factor in determining the electrochemical activity of SmSrCo electrode for oxygen reduction. For the SrScCo + SmSrCo composite oxide, the oxygen desorption peak areas are comparable after the calcination at various temperatures, suggesting that the phase reaction did not induce any obvious variation in oxygen vacancy concentration inside the oxide lattice, agreeing well with the iodometry results. However, the increase of the calcination temperature resulted in the shift of the oxygen desorption peak to a higher temperature, indicating the lowering of oxygen mobility with the increase of calcination temperature. Reduced electrode performance should then be expected with the phase reaction. To further evaluate the overall effect of the phase reaction on the ionic conductivity of the composite electrode, the oxygen permeation through membranes made from SrScCo, SmSrCo and SSSC (the final reaction product between SmSrCo and SrScCo) were measured. The oxygen permeation flux of the dense membranes is determined by the oxygen bulk diffusion rate and the surface exchange kinetics. For a reasonable comparison, the oxides were fabricated into membranes with the same membrane thickness of 0.85 mm, and all membranes were polished with a SiC attrition paper to create the similar surface morphology. During the measurement, ambient air was applied as the oxygen-rich side atmosphere while helium at a sweep rate of 100 ml min −1 [STP] was adopted as the oxygen-lean side atmosphere. As shown in Fig. 3 a , SrScCo membrane had the highest oxygen permeation fluxes, followed by SSSC and then SmSrCo. If one assumes that the oxygen bulk diffusion is the rate-limiting step for oxygen permeation through the membranes, the average ionic conductivity can be calculated based on the oxygen permeation flux and the oxygen partial pressure of the atmosphere. Fig. 3 b clearly shows that the ionic conductivity of SSSC is higher than that of SmSrCo but lower than that of SrScCo. 3.3 Electrical conductivity Shown in Fig. 4 are the electrical conductivity of SmSrCo, SrScCo and SSSC calcined at 1100 °C for 5 h, as well as that of SrScCo + SmSrCo composite (7:3 in weight ratio) after calcination at 1000 °C for 5 h. The conductivity of the composite was corrected by the porosity because it remains porous in nature after the calcination at 1000 °C. It reached 25 S cm −1 at 600 °C for SrScCo. The increase of the electrical conductivity with temperature suggests the semiconductor conduction behavior for electron transport through SrScCo perovskite. As mentioned, the low electrical conductivity is the main drawback of a SrScCo electrode. SmSrCo demonstrated very high conductivity in air. It reached a value of 1630 S cm −1 at 400 °C. A steady decrease of the conductivity with increasing temperature was also observed, demonstrating the metallic conduction behavior of the electrical conduction in SmSrCo, in good agreement with the literature results [32] . As mentioned previously, the complete reaction between SmSrCo and SrScCo formed a new perovskite SSSC. As shown in Fig. 4 , the electrical conductivity of SrScCo + SmSrCo composite oxide calcined at 1000 °C matched well with the SSSC oxide. A value of 123 S cm −1 was reached at 600 °C for SrScCo + SmSrCo composite, which is about five times that of SrScCo (25 S cm −1 ). It suggests that the introduction of a mixed-conducting phase is an effective way of improving the electrical conductivity of the SrScCo electrode. The much higher conductivity of SSSC than SrScCo can be explained by the fact that the average oxidation state of cobalt ion in the composite (+3.05) is higher than that in SrScCo (+2.91). The electron conduction in oxides usually takes place by the “small polaron mechanism” through electron hopping along the B – O – B channel via a mechanism named the Zerner double exchange, as listed below. (5) B n + − O 2 − − B ( n + 1 ) + ⇒ B ( n + 1 ) + − O − − B ( n + 1 ) + ⇒ B ( n + 1 ) + − O 2 − − B n + The electron conduction is highly influenced by the overlapping between the O 2p and the transition metal 3-d orbitals. The extent of the overlap strongly depends on the B – O distance and the B – O – B angle. Due to the similar cubic lattice symmetry, there is no large difference in the B – O – B angle between SSSC and SrScCo oxides. The higher oxidation state of cobalt in SSSC than that in SrScCo ensures a higher extent of the overlap between the O 2p and the cobalt 3-d orbitals, thereby ensuring an easier Zerner double exchange. It in part accounts for the higher conductivity of SSSC than SrScCo. Because Sc 3+ has a fixed oxidation state, the presence of Sc 3+ at the B-site of perovskite would inhibit the Zenner double exchange. It is one of the main reasons for the relatively low conductivity of SrScCo oxide. Because phase reaction between SrScCo and SmSrCo resulted in the decreased Sc concentration in the B-site of the perovskite, it then additionally contributed to the conductivity of SSSC being higher than that of SrScCo. 3.4 Electrode performance As demonstrated previously, the formation of SrScCo + SmSrCo composite electrode resulted in the substantial increase of electrical conductivity as compared to SrScCo however, the oxygen ionic conductivity is decreased due to the reduced oxygen mobility. To exploit the effect of SmSrCo incorporation and the phase reaction on the electrochemical performance of the SrScCo electrode for oxygen-reduction reaction, the electrode performance of the SrScCo + SmSrCo composite for oxygen reduction was first investigated by EIS based on a symmetric cell test with SDC as the electrolyte. Shown in Fig. 5 a are the Nyquist plots of the EIS of SrScCo + SmSrCo composite at 600 °C. For comparison, the EIS data of SrScCo and SmSrCo are also presented. All of the electrodes were fabricated onto the electrolyte at 1000 °C for 2 h. The difference between the real axis intercepts of the impedance plot is considered to be the electrode polarization resistance ( R p ). SrScCo showed the lowest electrode polarization resistance among the others, followed by SrScCo + SmSrCo composite electrode and then SmSrCo electrode. The sequence coincides with the ionic conductivity of the oxides fairly well. It suggests that the oxygen ionic conductivity play a significant role in the oxygen reduction over the SrCoO 3− δ -based electrodes, as investigated in this study. To further exploit the effect of SmSrCo incorporation on the electrode performance, all of the spectra were well separated into two semi cycles based on an equivalent circuit with a configuration of LR ohm ( R E1 − CPE 1 )( R E2 − CPE 2 ), as shown in Fig. 5 b, where R ohm is the overall ohmic resistance; L is the inductance; CPE is a constant phase element. This suggests that the oxygen-reduction reaction over the electrodes could be composed of at least two different processes. It is generally believed in literature that the resistance at the high frequency is associated with the charge-transfer processes ( R E1 ), including the electron-transfer and ion-transfer processes occurring at the current collector/electrode and the electrode/electrolyte interfaces, respectively, while the low frequency arc is attributed to the diffusion processes ( R E2 ), including adsorption–desorption of oxygen, oxygen diffusion at the gas-cathode surface interface and surface diffusion of intermediate oxygen species [33,34] . The fitted values of R E1 and R E2 for SmSrCo, SrScCo and SrScCo + SmSrCo electrodes are shown in Fig. 6 a&b. It was found that R E1 is much larger than R E2 for the SrScCo electrode. In connection with our previous results, the electron charge-transfer process is the primary step in controlling the oxygen reduction over SrScCo electrode [26] . For SmSrCo electrode, R E1 is slightly smaller than R E2 . It suggests that the surface process contributed more to the polarization resistance for oxygen reduction over the SmSrCo electrode. Because of the ultra-high electrical conductivity of SmSrCo, the electron charge-transfer kinetics should be sufficiently high in SmSrCo electrode; therefore the main value of R E1 is contributed from the oxygen ionic charge-transfer process. The only slightly lower R E1 than R E2 suggests that the ionic charge-transfer process also induced a noticeable polarization resistance for oxygen reduction over SmSrCo electrode. This may be related to its relatively poor oxygen ionic conductivity, as demonstrated by the oxygen permeation study. Similarly, Fukunaga et al. demonstrated that the rate-limiting step for oxygen reduction over SmSrCo is the adsorption–desorption process at the surface of the electrode by adopting dense SmSrCo on SDC electrolyte [35] . Regarding the SrScCo + SmSrCo composite electrode, R E1 was found to be much smaller than R E2 , suggesting great improvement of the charge-transfer process by incorporating SmSrCo into the SrScCo matrix. This can be explained by the increased electrical conductivity of the electrode as demonstrated previously. However, the absolute value of the R E1 for SrScCo + SmSrCo composite is comparable to that of SrScCo. This can be explained by the simultaneous increase in ionic charge-transfer resistance alongside with the improvement in electron charge-transfer process by introducing the SmSrCo phase. 3.5 Single-cell performance To demonstrate the potential application of SrScCo + SmSrCo composite as an electrode in a real fuel cell, Ni + SDC anode-supported thin-film SDC electrolyte fuel cell was fabricated by dual dry pressing followed by sintering at 1450 °C for 5 h. SrScCo + SmSrCo was adopted as the cathode. For comparison, SrScCo and SmSrCo were also evaluated as the cathode materials. Shown in Fig. 7 are the I–V polarization curves of the cells with SrScCo + SmSrCo electrode. Very high cell performance was achieved, with a peak power density of 1100 mW cm −2 at 600 °C. It also reached about 366 mW cm −2 at 500 °C ( Fig. 7 a). Such results are only modestly lower than these of a fuel cell with SrScCo electrode ( Fig. 7 b) but much higher than these of a fuel cell with SmSrCo electrode ( Fig. 7 c). Although the fuel cell performance is modestly lower for the cell with the SrScCo + SmSrCo electrode as compared to that of the cell with pure SrScCo electrode, the much higher electrical conductivity of SrScCo + SmSrCo than SrScCo suggests that it is preferable for practical application. Previously we have found that for the electrode with poor electrical conductivity, the current collecting method has a significant influence on the electrode performance. For example, with BSCF electrode, the peak power density can vary by a factor of 40 depending on the current collection method [36] . Because of its greatly improved electrical conductivity, the SrScCo + SmSrCo may be more suitable for larger cell application. Shown in Fig. 8 is the EIS of the cell with SrScCo + SmSrCo electrode under OCV conditions. Here, the electrode polarization resistance is a sum of the anode and the cathode. A low value of 0.053 Ω cm 2 was obtained at 600 °C, and 0.27 Ω cm 2 at 500 °C. The results are even lower than those of the SrScCo + SmSrCo electrode measured under symmetric cell test ( Fig. 5 a), suggesting that the electrode performance was improved by the asymmetric cell conditions. 4 Conclusions SmSrCo is a mixed-conducting oxide with ultra-high electrical conductivity. Its incorporation into the SrScCo electrode to form composite electrode effectively increased the electrical conductivity of the electrode and solved the problem of low electrical conductivity of SrScCo. The composite electrode showed an electrical conductivity of around 123 S cm −1 at 600 °C, which is nearly five times that of SrScCo. Solid-state reaction between SrScCo and SmSrCo occurred at temperatures above 900 °C. This reaction did not induce an obvious change of the oxygen vacancy concentration of the electrode, Instead it resulted in reduced oxygen mobility within electrode. Even so, the newly formed compound still had higher oxygen mobility than SmSrCo. The incorporation of SmSrCo significantly improved the electron charge-transfer process. However, the ion charge-transfer process was somewhat impaired. By adopting 70 wt% SrScCo + 30 wt% SmSrCo composite as the oxygen-reduction electrode of a thin-film SDC electrolyte fuel cell, peak power densities of 1100 and 366 mW cm −2 were achieved at 600 and 500 °C, respectively, which are only modestly lower than of a similar cell with pure SrScCo electrode. However, due to the significantly improved electrical conductivity, 70 wt% SrScCo + 30 wt% SmSrCo composite electrode are more promising than SrScCo as the cathode material of reduced temperature solid-oxide fuel cell with SDC electrolyte. isY2PgdN.title: Systematic investigation on new SrCo1-yNbyO 3-δ ceramic membranes with high oxygen semi-permeability
isY2PgdN.abstract: SrCo1-yNbyO3-δ (y = 0.025-0.4) were synthesized for oxygen separation application. The crystal structure, phase stability, oxygen nonstoichiometry, electrical conductivity, and oxygen permeability of the oxides were systematically investigated. Cubic perovskite, with enhanced phase stability at higher Nb concentration, was obtained at y = 0.025-0.2. However, the further increase in niobium concentration led to the formation of impurity phase. The niobium doping concentration also had a significant effect on electrical conductivity and oxygen permeability of the membranes. SrCo0.9Nb0.1O3-δ exhibited the highest electrical conductivity and oxygen permeability among the others. It reached a permeation flux of ∼2.80 × 10-6 mol cm -2 s-1 at 900°C for a 1.0-mm membrane under an air/helium oxygen gradient. The further investigation demonstrated the oxygen permeation processwas mainly rate-limited by the oxygen bulk diffusion process. © 2008 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

wd4to1vr.title: Significant impact of the current collection material and method on the performance of Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe 0.2O3-δ electrodes in solid oxide fuel cells
wd4to1vr.abstract: The effects of the current collection material and method on the performance of SOFCs with Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ (BSCF) cathodes are investigated. Ag paste and LaCoO 3 (LC) oxide are studied as current collection materials, and five different current collecting techniques are attempted. Cell performances are evaluated using a current-voltage test and electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) based on two types of anode-supported fuel cells, i.e., NiO + SDC|SDC|BSCF and NiO + YSZ|YSZ|SDC|BSCF. The cell with diluted Ag paste as the current collector exhibits the highest peak power density, nearly 16 times that of a similar cell without current collector. The electrochemical characteristics of the BSCF cathode with different current collectors are further determined by EIS at 600 °C using symmetrical cells. The cell with diluted Ag paste as the current collector displays the lowest ohmic resistance (1.4 Ω cm 2 ) and polarization resistance (0.1 Ω cm 2 ). Meanwhile, the surface conductivities of various current collectors are measured by a four-probe DC conductivity technique. The surface conductivity of diluted Ag paste is 2–3 orders of magnitude higher than that of LC or BSCF. The outstanding surface conductivity of silver may reduce the contact resistance at the current collector/electrode interface and, thus, contributes to better electrode performance. Keywords Current collector Barium strontium cobalt ferrite Surface conductivity Solid oxide fuel cells Electrode performance 1 Introduction In recent years, increasing attention has been paid to the development of alternative energy sources because petroleum reserves are believed to be exhausted in the next few decades. As high-temperature electrochemical energy conversion devices with advantageous features of high efficiency, low emissions and fuel flexibility, solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) have attracted particular attention from both the public and research community to create a more sustainable future [1–3] . The reduction of the operation temperature from the convention of approximately 1000 °C to the intermediate temperature range of 500–800 °C is critical to accelerating the commercialization of this fascinating technology because many drawbacks associated with high-temperature operation can be eliminated. However, a quick increase in polarization resistance with the drop in operation temperature is often observed for the conventional La 0.8 Sr 0.2 MnO 3 (LSM) cathode. This transition occurs due to the large activation energy associated with the oxygen reduction process (typically greater than 120 kJ mol −1 ) and the small amount of active sites for oxygen reduction limited to the narrow region of electrolyte–electrode–air triple phase boundary (TPB) [4,5] . Currently, the cathode has become the major obstacle in realizing the lower temperature operation of SOFCs. The cathode performance is closely related to its material composition. By applying mixed oxygen ionic and electronic conducting oxides as the electrodes, the active sites for oxygen reduction can potentially extend from the typical TPB region to the entire exposed cathode surface; this adjustment could lead to an enhanced activity for oxygen reduction at reduced temperatures. At present, considerable research efforts aim to develop innovative materials possessing both high surface activity and bulk oxygen ionic conductivity as cathodes of SOFCs [6–10] . Meanwhile, the electrode performance is intimately related to the electrode microstructure, which can influence both the gas diffusion and charge transfer processes. In 2004, Shao et al. first reported the application of a perovskite-type Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ (BSCF) mixed conducting oxide as a cathode of intermediate-temperature (IT)-SOFCs on a thin-film samarium doped ceria (SDC) electrolyte [11] . BSCF shows an extraordinarily high oxygen vacancy concentration, which results in a high oxygen bulk diffusion rate and surface exchange kinetics, both of which are beneficial for the oxygen reduction reaction. The reports describe very low electrode area specific resistance (ASR) from symmetric cell tests and high cell power output for an anode-supported fuel cell with a thin-film SDC electrolyte (20 μm) and BSCF cathode. Inspired by the outstanding performance, many researchers have studied the properties and performance of BSCF, including its phase structure, oxygen nonstoichiometry, phase stability, and performance in a single cell [12–17] . However, as listed in Table 1 [11,15,18–27] , large deviations in the values of cell power outputs and/or ASRs were demonstrated in literature, though their cell configuration and fabrication processes are similar. For example, Shao et al. reported a maximum peak power density of 1010 mW cm −2 at 600 °C for an anode-supported cell with a 20-μm thick SDC electrolyte and BSCF cathode, while Yan et al. obtained a value of only 840 mW cm −2 at the same temperature for similar cells [11,15] . Meanwhile, ASR values of 0.072 Ω cm 2 and 0.51 Ω cm 2 at 600 °C were reported by Zhou et al. and Deng et al., respectively, though both were based on a two-electrode configuration [22,23] . Such discrepancies are hardly explainable by the difference in electrode microstructures. Understanding the origin of such large differences is significant for further optimization of electrode performance and for practical application. Because oxygen reduction processes involve electron transportation, the electrode is required to be electronically conductive. BSCF has relatively low electrical conductivity. A dense-type BSCF has a maximum conductivity value of only 40–50 S cm −1 in the intermediate temperature range (500–800 °C) in air, and this value is further reduced to only approximately 10 S cm −1 under a nitrogen atmosphere ( P O 2 ∼ 10 − 5   atm ) [28] . As a practical electrode of SOFCs, BSCF possesses a porosity of 20–50%, which may substantially reduce the apparent conductivity when compared to dense pellets. The electrical conductivity of a porous electrode could be at least one order of magnitude less than that of a dense pellet [29] . Although the current collector does not directly participate in the electrochemical process, inefficient current collection may introduce non-negligible contacting resistance and/or increase the charge transfer resistance noticeably, in particular under a large polarization current. In this study, the effect of the current collection material and method on the performance of BSCF electrodes was systematically investigated. Ag paste and LaCoO 3 (LC) oxide were specifically selected as the current collectors, and five different current-collecting techniques were studied. Significantly different electrode performances were demonstrated by both symmetric cell and single cell tests, suggesting that the discrepancies in the electrode performance of BSCF in the literature are likely related to the current collection problem. Adopting the proper current collection material and method is crucial to achieve the high performance of BSCF cathodes. 2 Experimental 2.1 Powder synthesis BSCF, LC and Sm 0.2 Ce 0.8 O 1.9 (SDC) were all synthesized by an EDTA–citrate complexing process. The preparation of BSCF is given as an example. Ba(NO 3 ) 2 , Sr(NO 3 ) 2 , Co(NO 3 ) 2 · y H 2 O and Fe(NO 3 ) 3 · y H 2 O were used as the raw materials for metal sources. Co(NO 3 ) 2 · y H 2 O and Fe(NO 3 ) 3 · y H 2 O were first dissolved in de-ionized water to prepare aqueous solutions, and their precise concentrations were determined by an EDTA titration method. The detailed procedure can refer to our published paper [10,22] . The final calcination temperatures of BSCF, LC and SDC were 900, 950 and 800 °C, respectively. 2.2 Fabrication of symmetric and anode-supported cells The as-synthesized SDC powder was ball milled to reduce the amount of soft aggregates and fabricated into disk-shape pellets by dry pressing. Those green SDC pellets were sintered at 1400 °C for 5 h in air. The sintered SDC pellets with a diameter of approximately 13 mm were polished by an attrition paper to a thickness of 0.9 mm. A BSCF slurry, prepared by ball milling BSCF powder in a premixed solution of glycerol, isopropyl alcohol and ethylene glycol, was then deposited onto both surfaces of the SDC pellets by a spray deposition technique. The resulting cells were fired at 1000 °C for 2 h in air to obtain symmetrical cells with the configuration of BSCF|SDC|BSCF for impedance measurement. The fuel cells applied in this study were in the anode-supported, thin-film electrolyte configuration. Two types of fuel cells were fabricated: (1) NiO + SDC anode-supported fuel cell with SDC electrolyte and (2) NiO + YSZ|YSZ|SDC anode-supported fuel cell with YSZ and SDC dual-layer electrolyte. The NiO + SDC|SDC dual layer pellets were fabricated by a dry pressing and co-sintering technique. The detailed fabrication process was described previously [30] . The NiO + YSZ anode substrates were prepared by tape casting and punched into disk-shaped anode substrates with diameters of 16 mm, and then they were sintered at 1150 °C in air to remove organic materials. The YSZ electrolyte layer was prepared via wet powder spraying and sintering. The spraying process was carried out at 200 °C by heating the anode substrates over a hot paste. The obtained NiO + YSZ|YSZ green disks were sintered at 1400 °C for 5 h in air. After sintering, the disks have a diameter of approximately 13 mm. Then the SDC thin-film electrolyte layer was prepared by the same wet powder spraying technique and sintered at 1350 °C for 5 h, resulting in anode-supported, YSZ|SDC dual-layer electrolyte pellets. Finally, the BSCF slurry was deposited on the central surface of the two types of anode-supported SDC electrolytes by spray deposition, and the device was fired at 1000 °C for 2 h. The cathode has a geometric surface area of 0.48 cm 2 . 2.3 Current collection Ag paste and LC oxide were studied as current collectors. All together, five different current collection techniques were investigated, including two different current collection methods for the Ag paste and two different techniques for LC oxide, as shown in Fig. 1 . In some studies, a silver wire was directly fixed to the central surface of the BSCF electrode by Ag paste; as the area of the Ag paste is very small (approximately 0.02 cm 2 ) compared to the geometric surface area of BSCF (0.48 cm 2 ), the resulting devices can be viewed as having no current collector applied (technique 1). To use Ag as a current collector, a dense Ag paste was applied to the material, which contained >80 wt.% silver powder that is balanced by organic additives. Two methods of the current collection were studied; the undiluted Ag paste was directly applied to the entire surface of BSCF electrode by painting (technique 2), or it was first diluted with ethanol with polyvinyl butyral (PVB) before applying it to the BSCF surface (technique 3). To apply LC as the current collector, it was deposited onto the BSCF electrode surface by painting and fired at 950 °C for 5 h to allow firm adhesion between LC and the BSCF layer while effectively suppressing the phase reaction between LC and BSCF [22] (technique 4). Also, the LC current collector surface was further modified with a layer of diluted Ag paste (technique 5). For techniques 2 through 5, silver wires were attached to the central electrode surface by Ag paste with a dot. 2.4 Electrochemical characterization The single cell test was conducted over an in-lab constructed fuel cell test station. During the measurement, H 2 was fed into the anode side as fuel at a flow rate of 80 ml min −1 [STP], while ambient air was the cathode atmosphere. I – V polarization curves were collected by a digital electrometer (Model 2420, Keithley, USA) in four-probe mode. The electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) of the single cells or symmetric cells were measured using an electrochemical workstation based on a Solartron 1260A frequency response analyzer and a Solartron 1287 Potentionstat/Galvanostat under open air circuit (OCV) conditions. The frequency range was 0.1 Hz to 1 MHz, and the signal amplitude was 10 mV. 2.5 Other characterizations The electrical conductivity of BSCF and LC was measured by a four-probe DC conductivity technique. Approximately 1 g BSCF and LC powders were pressed into bars and sintered at 1100 °C for 5 h. Undiluted Ag paste was painted on the square cross-sectional edges and two circumferential surfaces of the bar to form the current and voltage electrodes. Two silver wires acting as current contacts and two silver wires acting as voltage contacts were attached to the electrodes. The current was applied to the two current wires, and the voltage was detected by the digital electrometer (Model 2420, Keithley, USA) from 900 to 300 °C at intervals of 10 °C in air. The surface conductivity of the porous BSCF cathode, LC current collector and Ag paste collector was also tested using the same four-probe DC conductivity technique, as described above. Details can be found in literatures [31,32] . In this experiment, the BSCF or LC slurries were sprayed onto SDC electrolytes and fired at 1000 and 950 °C for 2 h, respectively. The diluted Ag paste was applied onto the SDC electrolyte with a brush, and the device was fired at 700 °C for 2 h. The electrical contact for the current and voltage probes was made with very small amounts of undiluted Ag paste. Measurements were carried out in air in the temperature range of 450 and 700 °C. The surface and cross-sectional morphologies of the symmetric cells were observed by an environmental scanning electron microscope (ESEM, QUANTA-200). 3 Results 3.1 Single cell performance The current collector is an important component of the fuel cell system that collects the current from the anode or distributes the current homogenously over the cathode. A potential material for current collectors should satisfy a number of different criteria, including good electrical conductivity, high thermal/chemical stability under operational conditions and low fabrication costs [33] . Silver, which has been often applied as the current collector for IT-SOFCs in lab investigation, has very high electrical conductivity (6.2 × 10 5 S cm −1 at room temperature); however, the long-term stability of silver may be still questionable. At the same time, some composite oxides with high electrical conductivities, such as LaNi 0.6 Fe 0.4 O 3 and La 0.8 Sr 0.2 MnO 3 , are also applied as current collectors [34,35] . Zhou et al. have demonstrated that LaCoO 3 perovskite oxide has high electrical conductivity (approximately 700 S cm −1 ) at elevated temperatures in air [22] . Thus, Ag paste and LC were tried as the current collectors in this study. The effect of current collection methods on the single cell performance was first investigated. Two types of fuel cells are investigated: the NiO + SDC anode-supported thin-film SDC electrolyte fuel cell and the NiO + YSZ anode-supported thin-film electrolyte fuel cell with a YSZ and SDC dual-layer electrolyte fuel cell. Fig. 2 presents I – V and I – P curves of the various anode-supported dual-layer electrolyte fuel cells with the same BSCF cathode and different current collection methods between 550 and 750 °C. All of the cells showed high open circuit voltages (OCVs), which are close to the predicted values from the Nernst equation, suggesting that the YSZ|SDC dual-layer electrolyte is dense and gas-tight. A significant impact of the current collection methods on the cell performance was clearly demonstrated from the results in Fig. 2 . For the cell without a current collector (technique 1), the peak power densities were only 77, 63, 48 and 31 mW cm −2 at 750, 700, 650 and 600 °C, respectively. By applying LC as the current collector (technique 4), the cell performance significantly improved, and the peak power densities reached 211, 156, 106 and 69 mW cm −2 at 750, 700, 650 and 600 °C, respectively. A further improvement in cell performance was demonstrated by adopting an LC-Ag current collector (technique 5), and the cell delivered peak power densities of 608, 363, 242 and 137 mW cm −2 at 750, 700, 650 and 600 °C, respectively. The maximum power densities of 1240, 873, 517 and 299 mW cm −2 were obtained at 750, 700, 650 and 600 °C, respectively, for the cell with diluted Ag paste as the current collector (technique 3). By applying undiluted Ag paste as the current collector (technique 2), the peak power densities are 698, 546, 431 and 283 at 750, 700, 650 and 600 °C, respectively. The noticeable difference in peak power densities of the cells with Ag paste as the current collectors (techniques 2 and 3) indicate that the cell performance is also influenced by the method of current collection. In this study, the maximum difference of peak power density among the cells with different current collection method is as large as factors of 16 and 10 at 750 and 600 °C, respectively. The significant effects of the current collection material and technique on the cell performance were also demonstrated for the cell with a single layer SDC electrolyte. Table 2 lists the peak power densities of the various anode-supported thin-film SDC electrolyte fuel cells with the same BSCF cathode and different current collection methods at 600 °C. At 600 °C, the cell with diluted Ag paste, undiluted Ag paste, LC-Ag, LC and no current collector have peak power densities of 960, 697, 546, 227 and 30 mW cm −2 , respectively. Because the cells were fabricated and tested under the same conditions, the large variations in performance are mainly related to their different current collection materials or methods. The cell performance is influenced by the cell ohmic resistance and the electrode polarization resistance [36] . Fig. 3 shows the EIS in Nyquist plots of the NiO + YSZ|YSZ|SDC|BSCF cells with different types of current collectors under open circuit conditions at 600 °C. The cell resistance was significantly affected by the current collection material and also by the current collection technique. The cell with the diluted Ag paste shows the lowest ohmic and polarization resistances when compared to the other cells; the cell without a current collector shows the highest ohmic and polarization resistances. The cell with the LC-Ag paste has a lower ohmic and polarization resistance relative to the cells with LC or nothing as the current collector; however, its ohmic resistance and electrode polarization resistance are higher than those of the cells with diluted or undiluted Ag paste. The cell ohmic resistance contains the electrical resistances of the electrodes and the electrolyte, the contact resistance between the lead wire and the electrode, and the resistance of the lead wire [37] . Clearly, the difference in ohmic resistance for the different cells is mainly attributed to the contact resistance because there is no difference in the electrolyte, electrode or lead wires of the various cells. The electrode polarization resistance in the single cell is the sum of the anodic and cathodic polarization resistances. The fact that the anode is identical for the various cells suggests that the current collectors have strong effects on the BSCF cathode performance. 3.2 EIS To further illustrate the effects of different current collectors (method and material) on the electrochemical performance of the BSCF cathode, symmetrical cells with a BSCF cathode and various current collectors were fabricated and tested. Fig. 4 presents the Nyquist plots of the symmetrical cells with different types of cathode current collectors at an operating temperature of 600 °C. The measured results of total resistance ( R total ), ohmic resistance ( R ohmic ) and electrode polarization resistance ( R p ) are listed in Table 3 . Large differences are present in both R ohmic and R total by applying the different current collection materials and current collection techniques. R total , R ohmic and R p decreased in the sequence of silver dot, LC, LC-Ag, undiluted Ag paste and diluted Ag paste. The ohmic resistance of the cell with only the silver dot to fix the silver wire, which reaches as high as 23.3 Ω cm 2 , is the highest. The cell with the LC current collector has an ohmic resistance of 12.7 Ω cm 2 , which is only half of that of the cell with the silver dot. The ohmic resistance of the cell decreases to 2.3 Ω cm 2 when the LC-Ag is applied as the current collector. Notably, the ohmic resistance of the cell with diluted Ag paste is reduced to only 1.4 Ω cm 2 , while this value is 1.7 Ω cm 2 when applying undiluted Ag paste as the current collector. As no differences in the electrolyte thickness are present, the ohmic resistance depends greatly on the contact resistance between the current collector and the cathode. These results indicate that using a proper current collector can lower the ohmic resistance of the cell, particularly the contact resistance between the cathode and the current collector. The cell with a silver dot shows the highest electrode polarization resistance (0.7 Ω cm 2 ), and the cell with LC, LC-Ag and diluted Ag paste current collectors have electrode polarization resistances of 0.3, 0.2 and 0.1 Ω cm 2 , respectively. The distinct behaviors of R ohmic and R p can be related to the different current collectors, suggesting that the current collectors not only affect the ohmic resistance of the cells but also the BSCF cathode polarization resistance. 3.3 Electrode morphology From EIS, the current collectors clearly have significant effects on the contact resistance and the electrode polarization resistance. To exploit the origin of such effects, the morphologies of the current collectors and the electrode were observed by SEM. Fig. 5 shows the surface and cross-sectional micrographs of the symmetrical cells with different current collectors. As shown in Fig. 5 a and b, the BSCF electrodes have similar highly porous structures, and the thicknesses of all of the cells are approximately 20 μm. The porous BSCF cathode shows good adhesion to the dense SDC pellet and has a homogeneous microstructure with well-contacted particles. This observation suggests that the differences in electrode and cell performance with different current collectors, as demonstrated in Sections 3.1 and 3.2 , are not likely due to the microstructure and thickness of BSCF cathode. The LC current collector was more porous with a thickness of 17 μm, and the particle size of LC is smaller than that of BSCF. As shown in Fig. 5 c and d, the Ag current collector prepared with undiluted Ag paste is much less porous than that prepared by the diluted Ag paste. 3.4 Surface conductivity High electrical conductivity is important for the efficient current collection and the decrease of contact resistance between the current collector and electrode [33,38] . Therefore, in this study, we first measured the electrical conductivity of LC, which will be used as a current collector for the BSCF cathode. The values of the dense LC sample for the temperature from 300 to 900 °C are shown in Fig. 6 ; for comparison, the electrical conductivity of BSCF and the reported value of LC are also given. The electrical conductivity of LC oxide increases with temperature up to a maximum and then decreases with increasing temperature; these results agree well with our previous study by Zhou et al. [22] . For the BSCF sample, the electrical conductivity first increases linearly with temperature until 510 °C; above this temperature, this value remains almost constant with respect to further increases in temperature. The conductivities of BSCF are much lower than those of LC in the temperature range of 300–900 °C. At 800 °C, for example, the conductivities of BSCF and LC are 31.6 and 679.5 S cm −1 , respectively; the electrical conductivity of LC is more than twenty times greater than that of BSCF at 800 °C. The results showed that LC has enough electrical conductivity to be applied as a current collector of a BSCF cathode. Although LC has very high electrical conductivity in a dense pellet, the electrode performance of the BSCF cathode with LC was worse than that of cells with diluted or undiluted Ag paste. As we know, the current collector layer should have enough porosity for gas diffusion; the electrical conductivity of LC will decrease with increasing porosity. To collect the current of the BSCF cathode effectively, the current collector should also have enough surface conductivity. Here we further investigated the surface conductivity of BSCF, LC, and diluted and undiluted Ag paste in the range of 450–700 °C, and the values are shown in Fig. 7 . The surface conductivities of BSCF and LC increase with temperature, and the values are 6.5 × 10 −3 and 1.1 × 10 −2 S cm −1 at 700 °C, respectively. The surface conductivity of LC is only two times greater than that of BSCF, although the electrical conductivity of LC is twenty times than that of BSCF at 700 °C (shown in Fig. 6 ). As shown in Fig. 7 c and d, the surface conductivity of Ag paste (diluted and undiluted) generally decreases with temperature, and the values of undiluted Ag paste are greater than that of diluted Ag paste at corresponding temperatures. The surface conductivity of undiluted and diluted Ag paste can reach 25.4 and 23.5 S cm −1 at 700 °C, respectively, which indicates that the surface conductivity is also affected by the porosity of material. Meanwhile, the value of Ag paste is two thousand times greater than that of LC or BSCF. 4 Discussion The choice of a proper current collector in an electrode has been identified as an important component, especially for the practical application of SOFCs due to the fact that an inadequate current collector will lead to large voltage losses in the SOFCs stack. In connection with the results in Fig. 2 , Fig. 3 and Table 2 , current collection material and method could significantly affect the ohmic and polarization resistances of the cells, thus, the outputs of single cells. Since the cells with different current collectors have the same anode, electrolyte and cathode, the difference in resistances may be affected by the current collectors. Therefore, symmetrical cells with BSCF cathodes and different current collectors were used to identify the origins of the effect of the current collection material and technique on the cell performance. As expected, shown in Fig. 4 and Table 3 , the R total , R ohmic and R p decreased, in the sequence, by applying LC, LC-Ag, undiluted Ag paste and diluted Ag paste as the current collector, and the decrease of R ohmic is dominant in R total . This observation indicated that the current collector affected not only the BSCF cathode polarization resistance but also the ohmic resistance of the cell. Usually, the oxygen-reduction reaction over the electrodes is regarded as a combination of charge-transfer processes and diffusion processes. The diffusion processes involve the adsorption and desorption of oxygen, oxygen diffusion at the gas–cathode interface and the surface diffusion of intermediate oxygen species. The charge-transfer processes include both electron transfer and ion transfer processes, which occur at the current collector/electrode and electrode/electrolyte interfaces [39] . Because all of the symmetrical cells with different current collectors have the same BSCF electrode material and similar electrode microstructures and thicknesses (shown in Fig. 5 ), the variation in R p is less likely to originate in the diffusion processes. Different current collection materials and methods likely result in different electron transfer processes occurring at the current collector/electrode interface and, thus, different R p values. At the same time, the R p of the cell with undiluted Ag paste as current collector is still much higher than that of the cell with diluted Ag paste as current collector. The gas diffusion polarization resistance is likely non-negligible for the insufficient porosity of the diluted Ag paste current collector. This hypothesis may explain the differences in cell performances reported by different researchers [11,15] , though they applied similar cells with BSCF cathodes and Ag pastes as the current collectors. The ohmic resistance primarily includes the electrolyte resistance, electrode ohmic resistance and contact resistances at the cathode/electrolyte and cathode/current collector interfaces. As shown in Fig. 5 , the difference in ohmic resistance is less affected by the electrolyte resistance, electrode ohmic resistance, microstructure and thickness. Thus, assumedly, the decrease of ohmic resistance of the cell with diluted Ag paste is mainly due to the improved BSCF cathode/current collector interface. As can be seen from Fig. 6 , the electrical conductivity of dense LC is quite high, and the value at 800 °C can reach 679.5 S cm −1 , which is more than twenty times greater than that of BSCF. However, as shown in Fig. 7 , the surface conductivities of BSCF and LC were still low, and the values are only 6.5 × 10 −3 and 1.1 × 10 −2 S cm −1 , respectively, at 700 °C. The poor surface conductivity of the LC current collector may be ascribed to poor sintering that resulted from the relatively low firing temperature in this study. The surface conductivity of diluted Ag paste is 2–3 orders of magnitude higher than that of LC or BSCF, for example, the surface conductivity of diluted Ag paste can reach 23.5 S cm −1 at 700 °C. As mentioned, the increased surface conductivity of the current collector can lower the ohmic resistances of the current collector and at the BSCF/current collector interface. 5 Conclusions From this study, the electrochemical performance of anode-supported SOFCs with BSCF cathodes was highly sensitive to the current collection material and method. We believed the large differences in the literature results about BSCF electrodes are, at least in part, due to the different current collection materials and/or techniques. The current collector affected not only the polarization resistance of BSCF but also the ohmic resistance of the cells. Although LC is a good electronic conductor in a dense form, its surface conductivity is still low in a porous state fired at 950 °C; thus, LC is not an ideal current collector for BSCF. The surface conductivity of undiluted or diluted Ag paste is more than 2000 times greater than that of LC or BSCF, which enhanced the contact at the cathode/current collector interface. However, the improper fabrication of Ag current collectors could create insufficient porosity, which increases the electrode polarization resistance. To achieve high cell performance, the choice of a proper current material and method is highly crucial because these properties help to lower the ohmic resistance of the cell, particularly the contact resistance between the cathode and the current collector. 1w6BesQP.title: Novel mixed conducting SrSc0.05Co0.95O 3-δ ceramic membrane for oxygen separation
1w6BesQP.abstract: A novel perovskite-type mixed-conducting oxide of SrSc 0.05Co0.95O3-δ (SSC) was synthesized by a combined EDTA-citrate complexing method. The 5 mol % of Sc3+ doping into the B-site of SrCoO3-δ (SC) through the sol-gel synthesis effectively stabilized the oxygen vacancy disordered cubic perovskite structure of the oxide, and simultaneously resulted in a substantial increase of the electrical conductivity. The oxide was fabricated into dense ceramic membrane for oxygen separation by pressing/sintering process. The oxygen permeation flux of the SSC membrdne and the rate-determination step of the permeation process were investigated between 750 and 900°C. The experimental results demonstrated that SSC is a promising membrane for oxygen separation with ultrahigh permeation fluxes, compared favorably with reported high oxygen semipermeable Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe 0.2O3-δ and SrCo0.8Fe0.2O 0.δ membrdnes under air/helium gradient. At the condition of reduced temperature and low oxygen partial pressure at the sweep side atmosphere, the permeation process was found to be rate-determined mainly by the slow oxygen surface exchange kinetics at the air (feed) side membrane surface based on the single cell oxygen permeation study. The activation energy for the oxygen surface exchange and oxygen bulk diffusion was found to be around 126 kJ mol-1 and ≤62.1 kJ mol-1, respectively. © 2007 American Institute of Chemical Engineers.
