2G3FXFII.title: A composite oxygen-reduction electrode composed of SrSc 0.2Co0.8O3-δ perovskite and Sm 0.2Ce0.8O1.9 for an intermediate-temperature solid-oxide fuel cell
2G3FXFII.abstract: SSC (70 wt.% SrSc 0.2 Co 0.8 O 3− δ )–SDC (30 wt.% Sm 0.2 Ce 0.8 O 1.9 ) composite was evaluated as cathode for intermediate-temperature solid-oxide fuel cells. The effect of firing temperature on the chemical interaction between SSC and SDC was characterized by oxygen-temperature programmed desorption (O 2 -TPD) techniques. Certain type of phase reactions occurred between SSC and SDC at calcination temperatures higher than 950 °C. The conductivity of the composite was measured by a four-prober direct current technique. The electro-catalytic activity of the composite electrode for oxygen reduction was measured by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) in a symmetric cell configuration. The electrode fired at 950 °C showed the best performance. By applying the SSC + SDC-composite electrode, a cell with a ∼20-μm thick SDC electrolyte delivered a peak power density of 760 mW cm −2 at 600 °C. This suggested that an SSC + SDC-composite electrode may be a promising cathode for intermediate-temperature solid-oxide fuel cells. Keywords Solid-oxide fuel cells Cathode Perovskite Composite electrode 1 Introduction It is generally believed that the successful reduction of the operating temperatures of solid-oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) from their traditionally high range near 1000 °C to the intermediate-to-low-temperature range of 500–800 °C will accelerate the commercialization of SOFC technology in the near future because this lower-temperature operation can provide several important benefits, including reduced material costs, prolonged cell lifetimes and more elegant sealing [1,2] . However, a major challenge associated with temperature reduction is the sharp increase in cathodic polarization resistance [3,4] . As a result, the power outputs of conventional SOFCs using yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) electrolytes, La 0.8 Sr 0.2 MnO 3 (LSM) cathodes, and Ni–YSZ cermet anodes are too low to have practical importance at operating temperatures lower than 600 °C. There have recently been considerable research efforts in developing novel cathode materials that can perform well in the intermediate-to-low-temperature range [5–12] . Among the various candidate cathode materials, mixed-conducting oxides have received particular interest [8–12] . Differing from the pure electronic conduction of LSM cathodes, where the oxygen-reduction reaction is strictly limited to the electrolyte–electrode–air triple-phase boundary (TPB), the oxygen-reduction reactions on mixed-conducting electrodes with high enough ionic conductivity can occur along the entire cathode surface. As a result, some mixed-conducting oxides still show high activity for oxygen reduction at temperatures down to 500 °C [13–15] . Among the various mixed-conducting cathodes, cobalt-based perovskites originating from the SrCoO x parent oxide have received considerable attention [16–24] . During the past several years, our group has made significant research efforts to develop novel cobalt-based perovskite-type oxide materials as cathodes in low-temperature SOFCs [20–24] . By the partial substitution of Co in SrCoO x with Sc 3+ , the cubic perovskite structure of the oxide was successfully stabilized at room temperature and the oxygen vacancies inside the lattice were also delocalized [21,22] . As a result, the oxides showed high ionic conductivity of oxygen and high electrochemical activity for oxygen reduction. In particular, SrSc 0.2 Co 0.8 O 3− δ perovskite (SSC) showed high activity for oxygen reduction at 450–600 °C, owing to its high oxygen vacancy concentration. This oxide also demonstrated an almost linear thermal expansion from room temperature to around 1000 °C in air, with an average thermal expansion coefficient (TEC) of 16.9 × 10 −6 K −1 [21] . A successful cathode for SOFCs should meet several requirements, such as sufficient electrical conductivity for efficient current collection, a suitable thermal expansion coefficient to match the electrolyte thermo-mechanically, good chemical compatibility with the electrolyte and high activity for oxygen reduction. Recently, the formation of composite electrodes has been extensively exploited, and this has proven to be an effective way of improving electrode performance [25–28] . For example, by introducing an ionic conducting phase, typically of the same material as the electrolyte, the electrode performance of (Sm,Sr)CoO 3− δ can be improved significantly, especially at reduced temperatures [10] . This improvement is attributed to the creation of continuous ionic and electronic diffusion paths within the bulk electrode, which effectively extends the active zone for the electrochemical reduction of oxygen. Another significant advantage of the composite electrode is its better compatibility with the electrolyte, both thermo-mechanically and chemically. Previously, we investigated an Sm 0.2 Ce 0.8 O 1.9 + Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ (SDC + BSCF) composite as potential for low-temperature SOFC electrode [23] . Although SDC is an ionic conductor with negligible electronic conductivity, the introduction of SDC to form a composite with BSCF considerably increased the apparent electrical conductivity of the composite oxide when it was fired at the proper temperature [29] . This improvement was due to the interfacial reaction between BSCF and SDC, which resulted in the incorporation of samarium and cerium from SDC into BSCF to form new phases with higher electrical conductivity than the parent BSCF oxide. For the purpose of making the SSC electrode more compatible with the SDC electrolyte, in this study the formation of a composite electrode with SSC and SDC was investigated. The phase reaction between SSC and SDC, the electrical conductivity and the electrode performance were investigated in detail. 2 Experimental 2.1 Powder synthesis and cell fabrication Both SSC and SDC powders were prepared by a combined EDTA–citrate sol–gel complexation process. Sr(NO 3 ) 2 , Co(NO 3 ) 2 ·H 2 O, Sm(NO 3 ) 3 ·6H 2 O, Ce(NO 3 ) 3 ·6H 2 O and Sc 2 O 3 were utilized as the metal sources. Sc 2 O 3 powder was prepared as an aqueous solution by dissolving it in a dilute nitric acid solution before using it in the sol–gel synthesis. The synthesis of SSC, as an example, is as follows: stoichiometric amounts of Sc(NO 3 ) 3 , Sr(NO 3 ) 2 and Co(NO 3 ) 2 ·H 2 O were first prepared as a mixed solution. An EDTA–NH 3 ·H 2 O solution and solid citric acid were then added sequentially under stirring and heating at a molar ratio of total metal ions to EDTA to citric acid of 1:1:2. NH 3 ·H 2 O was used to adjust the pH value to around 6. With the evaporation of water from the solution under heating on a hotplate a clear gel was obtained, which was calcined at 900 °C for 5 h under an air atmosphere to yield the target SSC powder. Electrolyte-supported symmetric cells were adopted for electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements. The SDC electrolyte pellets (12 mm in diameter, 0.6 mm in thickness) were obtained by dry pressing the SDC powder under a hydraulic pressure of around 200 MPa using a 15-mm stainless-steel die followed by sintering the green disks at 1450 °C for 5 h in air. The cathode slurry was prepared by ball-milling SSC and SDC powders in isopropyl alcohol at 400 rpm for 0.5 h. The resulting slurry was painted onto both surfaces of the SDC pellets symmetrically. The green pellets were then dried and fired at 950, 1000, 1050 or 1100 °C in air for 2 h to obtain the SSC + SDC|SDC|SSC + SDC symmetric cells. Anode-supported thin-film electrolyte fuel cells were adopted for the I – V polarization test. The anode powder was prepared by mixing nickel oxide and SDC at a weight ratio of 3:2 using an agate mortar and pestle. The anode-supported thin-film SDC dual-layer cells were prepared by dual dry pressing followed by co-sintering at 1450 °C in air for 5 h. The cathode slurry was then painted onto the central surface of the sintered electrolyte and fired at 950 or 1000 °C for 2 h in air to form the complete cells with an effective area of about 0.48 cm 2 for the porous cathode layer. 2.2 Basic characterization The electrical conductivities of SSC and the SSC + SDC composite were determined by a four-probe DC conductivity measurement from 900 to 300 °C at intervals of 10 °C. A constant DC current was created by a Keithley 2420 sourcemeter (USA) and the voltage response was recorded with the help of Labview software. The current was increased from 1 μA to a maximum value of 2 A, and only the data following the Ohmic law were applied for the calculation of the conductivity. At each temperature, 2 min was allowed for the conductivity to reach an equilibrium state. The reaction between SSC and SDC was investigated by ex-situ techniques. The SSC and SDC were mechanically mixed with the help of a high-energy ball miller employing zirconium oxide as the grinding ball and isopropyl alcohol as the solvent, and then calcined at 950, 1000, 1050 and 1100 °C in air for 5 h, respectively. After the calcinations, the samples were cooled to room temperature and ground to powders in a mortar for O 2 -TPD (O 2 -temperature programmed desorption) tests. For a typical O 2 -TPD experiment, approximately 0.15 g of oxide powder (SSC or SSC + SDC) was placed in a U-type quartz reactor with an inner diameter of about 3 mm. Pure argon at a flow rate of 15 mL min −1 (STP: standard temperature and pressure) was fed into the reactor. The reactor was heated from room temperature to 930 °C at a rate of 10 °C min −1 . The effluent gases from the reactor were monitored by a Hiden QIC-20 Mass Spectroscope (MS). The microstructures of the cells were examined by an environmental scanning electron microscope (ESEM, QUANTA-2000). 2.3 Electrochemical characterization For the EIS test, silver paste was coated onto the electrode surfaces as the current collectors. Electrochemical impedance spectra were obtained in the frequency range of 0.1 Hz–100 kHz with an AC signal amplitude of 10 mV using an electrochemical workstation composed of a Solartron 1260A frequency-response analyzer and a Solartron 1287 potentiostat. Z-view 3.0a software was used to analyze the obtained impedance spectra. The electrode performance was measured between the operating temperatures of 450–700 °C and oxygen pressures ranging from 0.04 to 1.00 atm created by mixing O 2 and N 2 gas streams. 2.4 Single-cell test For a fuel cell performance test, the fuel cells were sealed onto quartz tube reactors with silver paste. The anode chamber was fed with pure hydrogen at a flow rate of 60 mL min −1 [STP], while the cathode was exposed to ambient air. The I – V polarization test was conducted using a Keithley 2420 sourcemeter with a four-probe configuration. The power density was calculated based on the geometric cathode active area, which was ∼0.48 cm 2 in this study. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Phase reaction between SSC and SDC The solid-state reaction between electrode components in the composite electrode during cell operation could be a practical problem [30] . Although at the operating conditions of intermediate-temperature solid-oxide fuel cells (IT-SOFCs, 500–800 °C) such a reaction is less likely, it could occur during the cell fabrication process when firing the cathode layer onto the electrolyte membrane surface, which is usually performed at 950–1150 °C [31,32] . However, such a high-temperature firing process is necessary to create sufficient mechanical strength in the electrode layer, and it also allows the electrode to adhere firmly to the electrolyte surface. Previously, we investigated the phase reaction between SSC and SDC, between 800 and 1100 °C, by post-fabrication XRD examination [22] . No additional phases or shift of diffraction peaks were detected by XRD for the samples calcined at temperatures. It seems that there was no significant phase reaction between SSC and SDC even at 1100 °C. However, XRD may not be sensitive enough to probe the phase reaction in micro-domains. In this study the phase reaction between SSC and SDC was re-examined by O 2 -TPD. Equal amounts of SSC and SDC powder by weight were well mixed and subsequently sintered at various temperatures for 5 h, and the derived mixed powder was evaluated for phase composition. Previously, we demonstrated that O 2 -TPD was a useful technique to probe the phase reaction between BSCF and BaCe 0.9 Y 0.1 O 3 and also between BSCF and BaZr 0.1 Ce 0.8 Y 0.1 O 3 [33,34] . With a linear increase of operating temperature under an inert atmosphere, the cobalt ions can be thermally reduced to a lower oxidation state accompanied by the release of oxygen from the oxide lattice. The released oxygen can be detected by an on-line mass spectrometer. Typically, the oxygen released over the temperature zone of 300–700 °C, here denoted as α oxygen, is associated with the reduction of Co 4+ to Co 3+ and/or adsorbed oxygen on the surface of the oxide (which is typically small as compared to lattice oxygen of mixed-conducting cobalt-contained oxides), while the oxygen released at T > 800 °C, β oxygen, is related to the reduction of Co 3+ to Co 2+ [33] . The phase reaction may lead to a change of the local environment around the cobalt ion in the perovskite, which can induce the corresponding change of the desorption peak area and the peak temperature in the O 2 -TPD profile. To get more insight into the possible phase reaction between SSC and SDC, the O 2 -TPD technique [35–38] was applied. Shown in Fig. 1 are the O 2 -TPD profiles of the SSC + SDC composites calcined at various temperatures, and for comparison, the pure SSC oxide calcined at the same temperatures are also presented. It is well known that the surface and grain-boundary interfaces for many cathode materials are not necessarily the same phase as the bulk material. The α-oxygen desorption reflects the adsorption properties of the surface or near-surface of an oxide. The pure SSC powders calcined at different temperatures showed different α-oxygen desorption indicating that the different heating history influenced the surface properties of the SSC. However, we should also realize that the β-oxygen desorption peaks are almost the same for all the SSC samples tested. This suggests that the bulk properties of the SSC are negligibly influenced by heating history. After the formation of a composite with SDC, the α-oxygen peak of SSC shifted slightly to the lower-temperature zone as compared to the single-phase SSC. This suggested that the formation of the composite likely facilitated the reduction of Co 4+ to Co 3+ in SSC. Furthermore, the β-oxygen peak area of the composite oxide decreased with increasing calcination temperature and the β-oxygen peak totally disappeared at calcination temperatures of 1050 °C and higher. As for the single-phase SSC, the β-oxygen peak is almost unchanged with calcination temperature. These results imply that a phase reaction or interaction between SSC and SDC indeed occurred at a calcination temperature of 950 °C, especially at 1100 °C. However, interestingly, no impurity phases are observed at any calcination temperatures by XRD. Therefore, it is likely that phase reaction occurred by the diffusion of Sm and Ce from SDC into the A- or B-lattice sites of SSC. It is well known that more than 90% of the metallic natural elements in the Periodic Table can be doped into the perovskite lattice [39] . It has been reported that both Sm and Ce can be doped into the A-site and B-site of perovskite [40–42] . Sm 2+ (1.24 Å) and Ce 3+ (1.34 Å) have smaller ionic radii than Sr 2+ (1.44 Å) in the A-site, while Sm 3+ (0.958 Å) and Ce 4+ (0.87 Å) have larger ionic radii than the Sc 3+ (0.745 Å) and Co 3+/4+ (0.61/0.53 Å) in the B-site. Since there were almost no differences in the lattice parameters for the SSC oxide before and after the firing, it is likely that Sm and Ce doped simultaneously into the A-site and B-site of the SSC oxide lattice. This led to the very similar XRD patterns even after the formation of new phases. 3.2 Electrical conductivity Electron conduction in the perovskite oxide is via small-polaron hopping with a mechanism similar to the Zener double exchange [43] : B n + – O 2 − – B ( n + 1 ) + ⇒ B ( n + 1 ) + – O − – B ( n + 1 ) + ⇒ B ( n + 1 ) + – O 2 − – B n + The electron conductivity is closely related to the overlapping of the 3d orbital of Co with the 2p orbital of oxygen. The oxygen vacancy blocks the electron hopping between cobalt and oxygen ions, so a decrease in the electronic conductivity is expected with an increase of oxygen vacancy concentration. Similarly, Sc 3+ doping would also lead to a decrease in electronic conductivity because of its fixed valence state. In our previous investigation of the BSCF + SDC composite electrode, we observed a higher electronic conductivity of the composite than for pure BSCF because of the phase reaction between BSCF and SDC [23] . Such improvement can be explained in part by the fact that the doping of Ce 3+ and Sm 3+ into A-site of the BSCF resulted in the shrinking of the lattice. Because Ce 3+ /Sm 3+ have smaller ionic size than Ba 2+ /Sr 2+ , their doping in the A-site of the BSCF promotes the B-site metal ions to take a higher valence state. Consequently, the distance between the B-site metals became closer and thus it is easier for electron exchange between the B-site ions to occur. On the other hand, Ce 3+ /Sm 3+ have a higher valence state than Ba 2+ /Sr 2+ , and thus the doping of Ce 3+ /Sm 3+ into the A-site of the BSCF reduced the oxygen vacancy concentration, which is also beneficial for increasing the p-type conductivity. It is well known that SDC has a negligible electronic conductivity (<10 −1 S cm −1 ) as compared to SSC (30–40 S cm −1 ), suggesting that the formation of the SSC + SDC composite would result in a decrease of the apparent conductivity of the composite in the absence of a phase reaction between SSC and SDC. The electrical conductivity of the SSC + SDC composite sintered at different temperatures was then measured by the four-probe DC technique. The degree of phase reaction between SSC and SDC was closely related to the sintering temperature. Because it was impossible to obtain a dense-type composite at all sintering temperatures, the electrical conductivity was then corrected by the porosity as described by applying the empirical formula [44] : σ corrected = σ measured / ( 1 − ( p / 100 ) ) 2 with p = porosity ( in % ) . Table 1 lists the relative densities of the SSC + SDC sintered at various temperatures. For the calculation of the porosity, the absolute densities were assumed to remain unchanged with the phase reaction between SSC and SDC. The values were calculated using the Landauer’s model [45] as follows: σ = 1 / 4 { ( 3 V 1 − 1 ) σ 1 + ( 3 V 2 − 1 ) σ 2 + [ { ( 3 V 1 − 1 ) σ 1 + ( 3 V 2 − 1 ) σ 2 } 2 + 8 σ 1 σ 2 ] 1 / 2 } where σ 1 and σ 2 are the electrical conductivities of the two phases, respectively, and V 1 and V 2 are their volume fractions. This is a reasonable assumption as there was almost no variation of the lattice parameter for both SSC and SDC phases with the sintering temperature. Shown in Fig. 2 are the electrical conductivities of the SSC + SDC composite sintered at various temperatures corrected by the porosity, and for comparison is the electrical conductivity of pure SSC and the calculated conductivity of the SSC + SDC composite assuming no phase reaction between SSC and SDC. These data clearly show that the electrical conductivity of the composites increased with the sintering temperature. Furthermore, the measured values of conductivity for the composites calcined at all temperatures were higher than the calculated values for the composite without phase reaction implying that a phase reaction occurred between SSC and SDC indeed, which agrees well with the O 2 -TPD results. As mentioned previously, the phase reaction resulted in the incorporation of Sm and Ce into the perovskite lattice. Because Sm 3+ and Ce 4+ have higher valence states than Sr 2+ , the phase reaction would result in a decrease of the oxygen vacancy concentration, consequently facilitating electron hopping. A sufficient electrical conductivity is important for efficient current collection. In this aspect the phase reaction between SSC and SDC is beneficial for fuel cell applications. 3.3 Electrode performance The performance of the composite electrode for oxygen reduction was studied by EIS in symmetric cell tests. Fig. 3 shows the temperature dependence of the electrode polarization resistances of the SSC + SDC electrodes calcined at various temperatures, for comparison, the electrode polarization resistances of pure SSC calcined at 950 and 1000 °C are also presented. Lower area-specific resistances (ASRs) were observed for the SSC electrode calcined at 1000 °C than that calcined at 950 °C, while the activation energies were similar for both electrodes, with values of ∼111 kJ mol −1 . The improved performance of SSC by calcination at 1000 °C was attributed to a better connection between the SSC particles in the electrode and the better adhesion of the electrode to the electrolyte surface. However, for the SSC + SDC composite electrode a monotonic increase of the electrode polarization resistance with calcination temperature was observed. The performance of the composite electrode is worse than the pure SSC electrode, even for the SSC + SDC composite electrode fired at 950 °C. This suggests that the incorporation of SDC decreased the electrode activity of SSC for oxygen reduction. Electrode performance is closely related to the ionic and electronic conductivity of the electrode material. SDC has a negligible electronic conductivity compared to its oxygen-ionic conductivity. The formation of a composite electrode for SSC with SDC should then make the electron charge-transfer process more difficult as compared to the single-phase SSC electrode. The oxygen-ion charge-transfer process is much more complex because SSC also possesses oxygen-ionic conductivity. Owing to the mixed conductivity of SSC, it is difficult to directly measure its ionic conductivity. It was therefore roughly calculated based on the oxygen-permeation fluxes of the dense SSC membrane. Previously, we measured the oxygen-permeation fluxes of an SSC membrane under an air/helium oxygen gradient between 700 and 900 °C [46] . Assuming that bulk diffusion is controlling in the permeation process, the oxygen-ionic conductivity can be calculated based on the oxygen-permeation fluxes and the oxygen partial pressures at each side of the membranes. The oxygen partial pressure at the oxygen-rich side is constant at P O2 = 0.21 atm, while it varies at the oxygen-lean side, and it can be calculated based on the flux and helium-sweeping rate. The oxygen-ionic conductivity was calculated by the following equation: σ 0 = D 0 C 0 q 0 2 k T where σ 0 represents oxygen-ionic conductivity, D 0 is the self-diffusivity of the oxide ion, C 0 is the concentration of oxide ion, q 0 is the charge of the oxygen ion, k is the surface exchange coefficient, and T is the temperature [47] . For the conductivities of SDC, dense SDC pellets of 12 mm in diameter and 2 mm in thickness were prepared by dry pressing and then sintering in air at 1450 °C for 5 h. Silver paste was painted over both sides of the pellets as current collector before the EIS test. The intercept of the impedance plot at the high frequency with the real axis gave the Ohmic resistance ( R Ω ) of the SDC pellet. And the conductivities of SDC were calculated using the equation as follows: σ 0 = 1 R Ω ⋅ l S where l is the thickness and S is the area of the electrode. Shown in Fig. 4 is the temperature dependence of the calculated ionic conductivity of SSC and also the conductivities of SDC measured in our lab, these indicate that SSC has a higher ionic conductivity than SDC. Therefore, the introduction of the SDC phase also resulted in the reduced ionic conductivity observed, and it then well explains the reduced electrode performance of SSC when in a composite with SDC. The increase of ASRs with calcination temperature could also be due in part to the decreased surface area. The calculated activation energy of the ASRs were 114, 114, 115 and 117 kJ mol −1 for the SSC + SDC electrodes calcined at 950, 1000, 1050 and 1100 °C, respectively, as a comparison, it is 113 kJ mol −1 for the pure SSC electrode. The increase of activation energy suggests that the phase reaction between SDC and SSC leads to a slight but detectable change in the reaction mechanism over the composite electrode. Shown as Nyquist plots in Fig. 5 a and b are the typical EIS of the symmetric cells with SSC + SDC composite electrode calcined at 950 °C. Similar to that of the pure SSC electrode [22] , the impedance spectra contain two separable depressed arcs, suggesting that at least two different electrode processes limited the oxygen-reduction reactions. To separate the two processes, the impedance spectra were fitted to an equivalent circuit with a standardized configuration, as shown in Fig. 5 c, similar to that previously adopted for the symmetric cell with the pure SSC electrode [22] . The overall Ohmic resistance of the cell, R Ω , includes the electrolyte resistance, the electrode Ohmic resistance and the lead resistance. According to the literature the low-frequency arc is likely associated with the diffusion process, while the high-frequency arc is probably related to charge-transfer processes [48] . To further elucidate these two processes, the EIS of the SSC + SDC cathode is performed at 600 °C at various oxygen partial pressures, the results are shown in Fig. 6 . As can be seen here, the value of the overall electrode resistance, R p , increased from 0.052 to 0.157 Ω cm 2 as the oxygen partial pressure decreased from 1.0 to 0.04 atm. No additional arc was observed at the low-frequency range even at the oxygen partial pressure of 0.04 atm, which suggests the absence of gaseous diffusion polarization resistance. The corresponding separated R E1 and R E2 at various P O2 values are shown in Fig. 7 as 1/ R E1 and 1/ R E2 plotted as functions of oxygen partial pressure. log 1/ R E1 has a log P O2 -dependent slope of 0.24 (∼1/4) at 600 °C, implying that this process is likely to be related to the charge-transfer process. log 1/ R E2 had a log P O2 -dependent slope of 0.43 (∼1/2), indicating that this process is associated with the diffusion of oxygen species on the surface of the SSC + SDC electrode [49–53] , a similar observation has been reported for the pure SSC [22] . Shown in Fig. 8 are the R E1 and R E2 for the SSC + SDC electrodes calcined at different temperatures, for comparison, those of the pure SSC calcined at 1000 °C are also presented. This figure clearly shows that the formation of composite electrode resulted in the increase of both R E1 and R E2 . Therefore, both the charge-transfer process and the surface process were somewhat hindered by the formation of the composite electrode. The worsening of the charge-transfer process of the SSC electrode by composite formation with SDC can be readily understood, as both the ionic conductivity and the electronic conductivity of SDC are lower than SSC. The increase in R E2 then suggests that SSC also had a higher surface activity than SDC. The increase in both R E1 and R E2 with calcination temperature is a sign of the detrimental effect of the phase reaction on both the ionic charge-transfer process and the surface process. Because the electronic conductivity was improved with calcination temperature, it suggests that the ionic charge-transfer process was the main contributor to the charge-transfer polarization resistance. We have demonstrated previously that the incorporation of Sm 3+ and Ce 4+ into the SSC lattice reduced the oxygen vacancy concentration, which may reduce the oxygen-ionic conductivity of the oxide. However, it is well known that oxygen diffusion and adsorption on the electrode surface is also closely related to the oxygen vacancy concentration. Surface oxygen vacancies would facilitate the adsorption and diffusion of oxygen. The above results suggest that a lower calcination temperature is beneficial for obtaining a better electrode performance. 3.4 Single-cell performance To demonstrate the performance of the SSC + SDC composite electrode under real fuel cell conditions, complete cells were fabricated. Shown in Fig. 9 are SEM images of cross-sectional views of two complete cells with the SSC + SDC electrodes calcined at 950 and 1000 °C. The SSC + SDC composite electrodes calcined at 950 °C was much more porous than that calcined at 1000 °C. Shown in Fig. 10 are the I – V and I – P curves of the cells with SSC + SDC electrodes calcined at various temperatures. For all cells the electrolyte thickness was controlled at around 20 μm. A peak power density (PPD) of ∼760 mW cm −2 was achieved at 600 °C, which is only slightly lower than that of the pure SSC electrode (∼1000 mW cm −2 , Ref.  [21] ). Therefore, the SSC + SDC composite is still a promising electrode material for IT-SOFCs. With the increase of calcination temperature the cell performance decreased monotonically to ∼600 mW cm −2 for the cell with the SSC + SDC electrode fired at 1000 °C. As shown in Fig. 9 , the porosity of the cathode sintered at 1000 °C is lower than that sintered at 950 °C, which would result in the concentration polarization of the cathode, especially at the high current density. Therefore a dramatic drop in voltages at the high current density for the cell based on 1000 °C calcined SSC + SDC cathode was observed, indicating that the oxygen diffusion resistivity increased due to the decreased porosity of the cathode. The reduced cell performance can also be attributed to the increased phase reaction between the electrode components, which led to the further reduced oxygen vacancies. Although the electrode performance was somewhat reduced by the formation of composite with SDC, the electrode thermal expansion coefficient (TEC) was also reduced for the composite cathode, which made the electrode more thermo-mechanically compatible with the SDC electrolyte [29] . In the view of the long-term stability of the SOFCs, the SSC + SDC composite cathode is still a promising cathode for intermediate-temperature solid-oxide fuel cells. 4 Conclusions SSC and SDC underwent a phase reaction between 950 and 1100 °C, detected by O 2 -TPD characterization. The phase reaction likely occurred by the incorporation of cerium and samarium from SDC into both the A-site and B-site of SSC. The phase reaction increased the reducibility of the cobalt ions. The newly formed phase had a higher electrical conductivity than the calculated values for the composite of the reactants, SSC and SDC, without phase reaction. The derived electrical conductivity of the composite was only slightly lower than that of SSC. Due to lower ionic conductivity and electronic conductivity of SDC as compared to SSC, a lower electrode performance was observed for the SSC + SDC composite than for the pure SSC electrode. The increase in firing temperature resulted in a lower electrode surface area and in a higher degree of the phase reaction between SSC and SDC. As a result, the SSC + SDC electrode fired at 950 °C showed the best performance. A cell with an SSC + SDC electrode fired at 950 °C and a thin-film SDC electrolyte (20 μm) delivered a PPD of 760 mW cm −2 . Suppressing the phase reaction between SSC and SDC will be the key to improving the electrode performance of this composite electrode. sxMhqNPY.title: Electrochemical contribution of silver current collector to oxygen reduction reaction over Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe 0.2O3-δ electrode on oxygen-ionic conducting electrolyte
sxMhqNPY.abstract: Nowadays, there is a doubt about the electrochemical contribution of silver current collector on the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) over oxide electrodes in SOFCs since many reports have demonstrated that the modification of porous oxide electrodes with nano-size silver can obviously improve the electrocatalytic activity for ORR. In this study, the electrochemical contribution of silver current collector to the performance of Ba 0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O 3-δ (BSCF) electrode on Sm0.2Ce0.8O 1.9 (SDC) electrolyte for ORR was specifically investigated. The active layer of BSCF electrode was found to be around 25 μm by using both silver and gold current collectors. Much better performance was demonstrated by using silver current collector, both from symmetric cell and single cell tests. However, EIS of silver on SDC electrolyte demonstrated the silver alone as electrode actually had poor performance for ORR. In addition, SEM-EDX confirmed that there was no silver diffused from the current collector layer to modify the porous BSCF electrode. Interestingly, the activation energy for oxygen reduction over BSCF electrode was reduced by applying silver current collector. We then proposed a mechanism to explain the improved electrochemical performance of BSCF electrode by considering the high activity of silver for oxygen surface diffusion. © 2012, Hydrogen Energy Publications, LLC. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

H2Ekr5sj.title: Oxygen selective membranes based on B-site cation-deficient (Ba0.5Sr0.5)(Co0.8Fe0.2)yO3-δ perovskite with improved operational stability
H2Ekr5sj.abstract: (Ba0.5Sr0.5)(Co0.8Fe0.2)yO3-δ ((BS)(CF)y, 1.00 ≥ y ≥ 0.77) oxides were investigated for oxygen separation application with emphasis on long-term operational stability. Pure phase cubic perovskite was formed at y ≥ 0.83. The oxygen nonstoichiometry increased while electrical conductivity and permeability decreased with the decrease of y. However, the (BS)(CF)0.97 membrane still displayed an attractive oxygen flux as high as 2.4 × 10-6 mol cm-2 s-1 at 900 °C, as compared to 2.5 × 10-6 mol cm-2 s-1 for a cation stoichiometric BSCF membrane. The B-site deficiency greatly restrained the A-site cation diffusion and stabilized the perovskite structure and permeation properties of the membranes. During the long-term operation of the (BS)(CF)0.97 membrane at 850 °C for more than 300 h, a stable permeation flux of (1.8 ± 0.3) × 10-6 mol cm-2 s-1 was achieved. Further investigation demonstrated that the improved importance of oxygen bulk-diffusion regime in the rate-determination of oxygen permeation through the membranes. © 2008 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

SA8Wiio6.title: Improving single-chamber performance of an anode-supported SOFC by impregnating anode with active nickel catalyst
SA8Wiio6.abstract: In order to improve the single-chamber performance of a traditional anode-supported single-chamber solid-oxide fuel cell with NiO–ScSZ anode and ScSZ electrolyte, the modification of the anode with a fine nickel catalyst by impregnation method was exploited. Catalytic test demonstrated the nickel catalyst had higher catalytic activity than the severe sintered nickel–cermet anode between 700 and 900 °C, especially at the lower temperature range. SEM examination demonstrated the nickel catalyst impregnation increased the roughness of the nickel grains within the anode. Furthermore, some surfaces of the ScSZ grains are also covered with very fine nickel catalyst. By operating on a methane-air mixture gas with methane to oxygen ratio of 1.3:1, the cell with its anode impregnated with the nickel catalyst showed an open circuit voltage and peak power density of 0.954 V and 119 mW cm −2 at a furnace temperature of 750 °C, respectively, as a comparison of 0.893 V and 79 mW cm −2 for the cell without the nickel catalyst. The improved cell performance was attributed to the higher cell temperature and increased anode catalytic activity for methane partial oxidation.

PdQyrIx6.title: Fabrication and operation of flow-through tubular SOFCs for electric power and synthesis gas cogeneration from methane
PdQyrIx6.abstract: Flow-through type tubular solid oxide fuel cells were successfully fabricated and operated with a single-chamber configuration for realizing the simultaneous generation of electric power and synthesis gas from methane by integrating a downstream catalyst into the fuel cell reactor. A new operation mode, which completely eliminated the gas diffusion between cathode side and anode side, is proposed. The cell showed high open-circuit voltages of 1.02-1.08 V at the furnace temperature range of 650-800��C when operating on CH4-O2 gas mixture at a molar ratio of 2:1. A peak power density of approximately 300 mW cm-2 and a maximum power output of 1.5 W were achieved for a single cell with an effective cathode geometric surface area of 5.4 cm2 at the furnace temperature of 750��C. The in-situ initialization of the cell using CH4-O2 gas mixture was also realized via applying an effective catalyst into the tubular cell. ? 2013 American Institute of Chemical Engineers.

kbf0ve3G.title: Double-site yttria-doped Sr1-xYxCo1-yYyO3-δ perovskite oxides as oxygen semi-permeable membranes
kbf0ve3G.abstract: New mixed conducting oxides with the composition of Sr1-xYxCo1-yYyO3-δ (x = 0.0-0.8, y = 0.0-0.1) were exploited and synthesized. The resulted materials were investigated by X-ray diffraction, four-probe dc conductivity, temperature-programmed desorption characterization, and oxygen permeability measurement. As compared with the oxides with only one-site (A or B) being Y3+-doped, i.e., Sr1-xYxCoO3-δ and SrCo1-yYyO3-δ, the double-site Y3+-doped ones show improved phase stability, higher electrical conductivity under reduced atmosphere, and higher oxygen permeability and stability. Particularly, Sr0.95Y0.05Co0.95Y0.05O3-δ oxide demonstrates stable cubic perovskite phase in air, oxygen and nitrogen, high electrical conductivity of ∼110 S cm-1 in air and ∼50 S cm-1 in nitrogen, and a maximum permeation flux of 1.35 × 10-6 mol cm-2 s-1 at 900 °C under an air/helium gradient. Long-term permeation study at 850 °C indicates that Sr0.95Y0.05Co0.95Y0.05O3-δ can operate stably as oxygen semi-permeable membrane. © 2008 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

QqFOZg5t.title: Significant impact of nitric acid treatment on the cathode performance of Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3-δ perovskite oxide via combined EDTA-citric complexing process
QqFOZg5t.abstract: Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ (BSCF) perovskite was synthesized by the sol–gel process based on EDTA–citrate (EC) complexing method, nitric acid modified EC route (NEC) and nitric acid aided EDTA–citrate combustion process (NECC). A crystallite size of 27, 38 and 42 nm, respectively, was observed for the powders of NECC-BSCF, NEC-BSCF and EC-BSCF calcined at 1000 °C, suggesting the suppression effect of nitric acid on the crystallite size growth of BSCF. The smaller crystallite size of the powders resulted in the higher degree of sintering of the cathode. Oxygen permeation study of the corresponding membranes demonstrated that in the powder synthesis, nitric acid also had a noticeable detrimental effect on the oxygen surface exchange kinetics and on the oxygen bulk diffusion rate of the BSCF oxides. The effect of powder synthesis route on the bulk properties of the oxide was validated by the oxygen temperature-programmed desorption technique. On the whole, a decreasing cathode performance in the sequence of EC-BSCF, NEC-BSCF and NECC-BSCF was observed. A peak power density of 693 mW cm −2 was achieved for an anode-supported cell with an EC-BSCF cathode at 600 °C, which was significantly higher than that with an NEC-BSCF cathode (571 mW cm −2 ) or an NECC-BSCF cathode (543 mW cm −2 ) under similar operation conditions. Keywords Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ Synthesis Solid-oxide fuel cell Perovskite Electrical conductivity 1 Introduction Solid-oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) are a promising power generation technology characterized by high energy conversion efficiency and low pollutant emission. Traditional SOFCs are based on thick YSZ electrolyte membrane and operate at typically 1000 °C [1,2] . However, such high operating temperatures may result in a fast degradation of fuel cell performance due to the increased phase reaction between cell components and the easy sintering of the electrode. Therefore, it is a general trend for SOFCs to operate at reduced temperatures (<800 °C) [3–9] . Unfortunately the reduction of oxygen is a process requiring high activation energy, so that the decrease in operating temperature leads to a sharp increase in cathode polarization resistance of the traditional La 1− x Sr x MnO 3− δ cathodes. The improvement of cathode performance is therefore critical for SOFC technology at reduced temperatures. Considerable efforts have been devoted to decrease the cathode polarization at reduced temperatures [10–20] . One strategy is to develop new cathode materials with mixed oxygen ionic and electronic conductivity [10–16] . Such materials extend the oxygen reduction site from the traditional triple-phase boundary (cathode–electrolyte–gas phase) to the entire cathode–gas phase interface; therefore, a substantial increase in the cathode performance at reduced temperatures could be observed. On the other hand, cathode performance was also found closely related to the cathode architecture. The development of novel fabrication techniques that can promote gas diffusion and maximize the cathode area for oxygen reduction has also received great attention [17–20] . The cathode layer in SOFCs is usually fabricated with pre-crystallized powders by any of the methods including spray deposition, screen-printing or painting techniques, followed by high temperature sintering. Many powder synthesis methods have been applied to the synthesis of cathode materials, such as solid-state reaction, sol–gel, co-precipitation, hydrothermal synthesis, etc. [21–25] . Many researches have shown that synthesis methods may affect the morphology, conductivity, crystallite size and surface microstructure of the derived powders [26–30] . Such distinctions could have an evident influence on their properties in applications such as separation membrane and cathode for SOFCs. Indeed, it has been reported that powder synthesis methods had significant effects on the oxygen permeability of ceramic membranes based on mixed-conducting perovskite [28,30–32] . Establishing the relationship between the powder synthesis route and the cathode properties is therefore important for the improvement of the cathode performance. However, systematic reports about the effect of powder synthesis technique on cathode performance of SOFCs [29] are very rare. Shao et al. first reported Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ (BSCF) mixed-conducting perovskite oxide as a potential cathode for intermediate temperature solid-oxide fuel cells (IT-SOFCs) [33] . The application of this material in IT-SOFCs has since received considerable attention [34–40] . In this study, the BSCF perovskite was selected for the demonstration of the significant effect of powder synthesis route on cathode performance. In our previous study, we found that the combined EDTA–citrate (EC) complexing method was effective to synthesize nano-crystalline composite oxides [41] . The addition of nitric acid during the EC complexing process could improve the catalytic activity of La 0.6 Sr 0.4 Co 0.2 Fe 0.8 O 3− δ composite oxide [42] and depress the crystallite size of the BSCF composite oxide [43] . Therefore, the nitric acid modified EDTA–citrate (NEC) route and the nitric acid aided EDTA–citrate combustion (NECC) process were selected to compare with the EC complexing method. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of BSCF powders All the three synthesis routes started from the same EDTA–citrate–metal precursor with a preparation procedure similar to our previous reports [41] . Appropriate amounts of metal nitrates were dissolved in water to make a mixed solution followed by the addition of EDTA and citric acid, which served as the complexing agents. Mild heating induced the gelation of the solution. The gels thus obtained were pre-heated at 250 °C for 5 h to form solid precursors. For the combined EDTA–citrate complexing method, the solid precursor was directly calcined in stagnant air at 1000 °C or 5 h. As for the nitric acid modified EDTA–citrate and the nitric acid modified EDTA–citrate combustion routes, for preparing 0.01 mol BSCF, an amount of 10 ml (NEC) or 30 ml (NECC) concentrated nitric acid (67 wt.%) was dropped into the solid precursor to form a sticky gel, which was then re-heated at 250 °C for 5 h. After the heat treatment, the sample in the 10 ml case converted to a solid precursor, while the one in the 30 ml case resulted in an auto-combustion. Both precursors were then calcined in stagnant air at high temperatures for 5 h to obtain the final products. 2.2 Cell fabrication Symmetrical cells with the configuration of electrode|SDC|electrode were used for the impedance studies. Dense SDC pellets of 12 mm in diameter and 0.8 mm in thickness were prepared by dry pressing and sintered in air at 1450 °C for 5 h. BSCF powders were first dispersed in a mixed solution of glycerol, ethyleneglycol and isopropyl alcohol to form a colloidal suspension by milling with the help of an agate mortar and pestle. The obtained slurries were painted symmetrically on both surfaces of the SDC pellets, followed by calcination at 1000 °C for 2 h in stagnant air. Silver paste was painted onto the electrode surfaces as current collector. Anode-supported cells with SDC electrolyte were prepared using a co-pressing technique. Anode powders consisting of 60 wt.% NiO and 40 wt.% SDC were prepared by mixing NiO and SDC in an agate mortar. To fabricate the single cell, the well-mixed NiO–SDC powder was firstly pressed as a substrate, onto which the SDC powder was added and pressed again to form a bilayer pellet. The pellet was then sintered in stagnant air at 1450 °C for 5 h for the densification of the electrolyte layer; the BSCF slurry was painted onto the central surface of the electrolyte and fired at 1000 °C for 2 h in air. The resulting coin-shaped cathode had a thickness of 20 μm and an effective area of 0.52 cm 2 . 2.3 Characterization I–V polarization curves were collected using a Keithley 2420 source meter based on the four-probe configuration. Humidified H 2 (3% H 2 O) at a flow rate of 80 ml min −1 [STP] was fed into the anode chamber as fuel and compressed air was fed into the cathode chamber as oxidant. Gas flow rates were controlled by mass flow controllers. Silver paste was adopted as current collector. The electrode performance was investigated with a symmetrical cell or complete cell configuration by the ac impedance method using an electrochemical workstation Solartron 1287 potentiostat and a 1260 A frequency response analyzer. The test was conducted under open circuit voltage (OCV) condition with the frequency ranging from 0.01 to 100 kHz and a signal amplitude of 10 mV. The overall impedance data was fitted by a complex non-linear least square (CNLS) fitting program Z-View 2.9b. The crystal structure of the synthesized powders was determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 Advance) using Cu Kα radiation. The experimental diffraction patterns were collected at room temperature by step scanning within the range of 20° ≤ θ ≤ 80°. The crystallite size was calculated based on the Scherrer equation from the study of Bragg angle and half bandwidth at the index peak of the (1 1 0) plane for BSCF. The microscopic features of the prepared electrodes were characterized by a field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, LEO1530) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) attachment, or an environmental scanning electron microscopy (ESEM, QUANTA-2000). Four-probe dc electrical conductivity of the oxide was measured over the bar-shaped BSCF samples sintered at 1000 °C in air with silver applied as the electrodes. The current and the voltage were detected by the Keithley 2420 source meter at an interval of 10 °C in the temperature range of 300–900 °C. Oxygen desorption properties of the powders were studied by the oxygen temperature-programmed desorption technique (O 2 -TPD). About 150 mg of BSCF powder was loaded in a quartz tube. The assembly was placed in a single-zone furnace equipped with a temperature controller. Argon was used as the carrier gas with a flow rate of 20 ml min −1 [STP]. The temperature was increased from 200 to 1000 °C at the rate of 10 °C min −1 and the effluent gases were monitored by the mass spectrometer (Hiden, QIC-20). The oxygen permeation flux measurements were performed using the gas chromatography (GC) method. Single dense membranes or porous BSCF layer modified membranes were sealed onto the quartz support tubes with silver paste. The sidewall of the membrane disks was also covered with the sealant to avoid radial contribution to the oxygen flux due to electrochemical leakage. Helium was used as the sweep gas at a flow rate of 100 ml min −1 . A gas chromatograph (Varian, CP 3800) was used to analyze the outlet gas. The oxygen permeation flux was calculated by J O 2   ( ml   c m − 2   mi n − 1 ,     [ STP ] ) = C O − C N × 0.21 0.79 ( 28 / 32 ) 1 / 2 × F S where C O and C N are the measured concentrations of oxygen and nitrogen in the gas on the oxygen-lean side (ml ml −1 ), respectively; F is the flow rate of the exit gas on the oxygen-lean side (ml min −1 ), and S is the membrane geometric surface area of the sweep side (cm 2 ). 3 Results and discussion The synthesis route was found to have a significant effect on the formation of BSCF perovskite. Among the three synthesis routes, the EC method was found to be the most efficient one for preparing pure-phase nano-crystalline BSCF oxide. A pure-phase BSCF was obtained at a firing temperature as low as 850 °C for the EC method, while the temperature had to be as high as 1000 °C for the NEC and NECC methods. The EC method is characterized by the homogeneous mixing of metal ions on the molecular level; it eliminates the blockage of solid-state diffusion for the formation of BSCF oxide and therefore ensures a low temperature synthesis [41] . As shown in Fig. 1 , the solid precursor from the EC method took on an amorphous structure even after being heated at 250 °C for 5 h, which implies that the metal ions were still homogeneously distributed in the organic matrix. However, strong characteristic diffraction peaks for Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 (NO 3 ) 2 appeared in the NEC derived solid precursor, which indicated the destruction of the complex. This agrees well with the fact that the conditional stability constants of Ba and Sr with EDTA at a pH value of <4 are both less than zero, i.e., EDTA was not able to immobilize Ba 2+ and Sr 2+ anymore under the nitric acid condition. When more nitric acid was applied, i.e., 30 ml HNO 3 applied to the solid precursor for preparing 0.01 mol BSCF powder, a vigorous self-combustion happened. Fig. 2 shows the XRD pattern of the BSCF powders prepared by the three different methods after calcination at 1000 °C for 5 h. All the samples displayed phase-pure cubic perovskite structure. However, a decrease in the crystallinity was observed with the increase of nitric acid applied during the synthesis. The calculated crystallite size and lattice constant of the corresponding BSCF powders are listed in Table 1 . Obviously, the crystallite size of BSCF was depressed in the presence of nitric acid during the synthesis [43] . However, the lattice constant of BSCF oxide increased with the amount of nitric acid applied during the synthesis, which suggests that the average valences of cobalt and/or iron ions in BSCF were lowered after the nitric acid treatment of the solid precursor. Fig. 3 shows the SEM images of various as-synthesized BSCF powders calcined at 1000 °C for 5 h. The powders obtained by the NEC and NECC methods mostly had a conic shape with the grain size varying from several microns to tens of microns. However, the powder prepared by the EC method took on a spherical shape. The relative amount of conic BSCF in the powder increased with the increasing amount of nitric acid applied in the synthesis. The conic particle was actually composed of smaller spherical particles sized 20–40 nm ( Fig. 3 C), which was comparable to the values reported in other references [44,45] . Subramania et al synthesized nano-crystalline BSCF powders at a temperature as low as 450 °C by a novel sol–gel thermolysis method and the crystallite size of the BSCF provskite oxide was only 34 nm [44] . It should be noted that the temperature for cathode firing process can reach as high as 1000 °C while the BSCF oxide could be easily sintered due to the high surface energy at such a temperature. Therefore, it is more important to prepare nano-crystalline BSCF oxide at higher temperatures in practical use. The sintering behavior of the various BSCF powders was investigated. Bar-shaped BSCF samples were sintered at 1000 °C for 5 h, and the porosity and shrinkage of samples are shown in Table 2 . The relative density of the samples was found to be in the order of EC-BSCF < NEC-BSCF < NECC-BSCF, coinciding with the decreasing crystallite size of the starting powders. Since smaller crystallite size means higher surface energy, higher sintering of ceramics was observed [43] . The effect of the powder preparation method on the electrical conductivity was measured by the four-probe dc method. Fig. 4 A shows the temperature dependence of the adjusted conductivity considering the porosity of various BSCF samples measured within the temperature range of 300–900 °C in air. It shows that the electrical conductivity of all samples first increases linearly with temperature to around 450 °C, and then decreases, which can be attributed to the loss of lattice oxygen and the formation of oxygen vacancies at high temperatures (>450 °C). The electrical conductivity increased slightly with the increased amount of nitric acid applied during the synthesis, which might be related to the enhanced contact between neighboring particles. The electron conducting mechanism below 450 °C can be attributed to the hopping of p-type small polarons, which are associated with the behavior of triple and tetravalent state of cobalt and iron cations. The charge transfer is thermally activated and its temperature dependence is given by the following equation: σ = A T   exp − E a k T where A is a material constant containing the carrier concentration term, T the absolute temperature, E a the activation energy for small polaron hopping and k is the Boltzmann constant. Plots of log( σT ) versus 1/ T are constructed for the temperature range, as shown in Fig. 4 B. These plots are linear, and from their slopes the apparent activation energies are calculated. Although the apparent activation energy (300–450 °C) for the three samples is very similar, there are still some slight differences, which is a reflection of the small difference in valences of cobalt and iron ions. The slightly high amount of tetravalent cations within B site is beneficial for the charge transfer. The apparent activation energy is the lowest for EC-BSCF, which may indicate that the amount of Co 4+ and/or Fe 4+ in EC-BSCF was higher than those in NEC-BSCF and NECC-BSCF. Since Co 4+ /Fe 4+ has a smaller ionic radius than Co 3+ /Fe 3+ , a smaller lattice constant of EC-BSCF than NEC-BSCF and NECC-BSCF should be observed, which coincides with the XRD results. The BSCF powders were then fabricated onto the electrolyte surface as the cathode layer by a painting method followed by calcination at 1000 °C for 5 h in air, with the corresponding SEM photos of the cathode layer shown in Fig. 5 . All the three samples show similar porous surface morphology. It is interesting that the conic-shaped particles of BSCF with the powders prepared by the NEC and NECC methods totally disappeared in the cathode layer after the fabrication and calcination. An increased degree of sintering for the cathode layer in the order of EC-BSCF, NEC-BSCF and NECC-BSCF was also observed, coinciding with the fact that the crystallite size of the starting powders decreased in the reverse direction. Smaller crystallite size means a higher surface energy and therefore a higher sinterability. For cathodes based on mixed-conducting oxides, their performance is closely related to the effective surface area, the surface exchange kinetics and also the oxygen bulk diffusion rate of the cathode. The increased degree of sintering would have a detrimental effect on the cathode performance. The cathode performance of the BSCF oxides prepared by the three different methods was first tested by impedance spectroscopy, and symmetric cells composing of SDC electrolyte and BSCF electrodes were built for this purpose. Fig. 6 shows the temperature dependence of the area-specific resistances (ASRs) under the OCV condition. The EC-BSCF cathode shows both the lowest electrode resistance and activation energy. An ASR of 0.10 Ω cm 2 for the EC-BSCF cathode was observed at 600 °C, while it was 0.36 Ω cm 2 for the NECC-BSCF cathode. The activation energy for EC-BSCF is only 104 kJ mol −1 , while it is 117 kJ mol −1 for NECC-BSCF. All the above results strongly suggest that the powder preparation method has a significant effect on the cathode performance, the reason for which, according to Fig. 5 , could be due to the difference in the effective surface area of the cathodes prepared by different synthesis techniques. The increased degree of sintering with the increased amount of nitric acid applied during the synthesis resulted in the decreasing effective cathode area for oxygen reduction, which should account for the observed decrease in cathode performance. The performance of the mixed-conducting cathode is closely related not only to its effective surface area, but also to its oxygen surface exchange kinetics and bulk diffusion rate. The effect of the powder preparation method on the oxygen surface exchange and bulk diffusion properties was then quantitatively studied by the oxygen permeation method of dense ceramic membranes. Oxygen permeation through a dense mixed-conducting membrane is usually determined by oxygen surface exchange kinetics combined with oxygen bulk diffusion rate. Under the driving force of the oxygen partial pressure gradient across the membrane, an oxygen molecule first adsorbs over the membrane surface on the oxygen-rich side, where it dissociates into oxygen ions and generates electron holes, both of which then migrate through the bulk of the membrane to the other side of the membrane surface, where they recombine into an oxygen molecule; the molecular oxygen over the membrane surface finally desorbs and evolves into the oxygen-lean side atmosphere. Based on the oxygen permeation fluxes at various conditions, the information of oxygen surface exchange kinetics and bulk diffusion rate can be obtained. For the oxygen permeation study, BSCF powders were fabricated into dense ceramic membranes, and the permeation properties were characterized by the GC method. Shown in Fig. 7 is the temperature dependence of oxygen permeation flux through 1.0 mm thick BSCF membranes at a constant helium sweep rate of 100 ml min −1 with air being the feed gas. The permeation fluxes were found in the order of EC-BSCF > NEC-BSCF > NECC-BSCF. An increase of the activation energy for oxygen permeation in the sequence of EC-BSCF < NEC-BSCF < NECC-BSCF was also observed. We have shown in a previous paper that the oxygen permeation through surface-unmodified BSCF membrane was mainly rate-determined by the slow oxygen surface exchange kinetics at the oxygen-lean side membrane surface under an air/helium oxygen gradient [46] . It therefore suggests that the increase of nitric acid applied in the powder synthesis led to the decrease of oxygen surface exchange rate of the corresponding cathode. The effect of the powder preparation method on the oxygen bulk diffusion rate of the cathode was also investigated by the oxygen permeation study of the corresponding surface-modified BSCF membranes. A porous layer of BSCF was deposited onto the surface of BSCF membranes exposed to the oxygen-lean side atmosphere. The porous layer resulted in a significant improvement of the effective surface area for oxygen surface exchange; therefore, the importance of oxygen bulk diffusion in the rate determination of the oxygen permeation flux was enhanced. The oxygen permeation fluxes of the surface-modified membranes could then reflect the oxygen bulk diffusion rate. After the surface modification, as shown in Fig. 8 , the oxygen permeation flux increased most significantly for the BSCF membrane with the powder prepared by the EC method, followed by the membrane made of NEC-BSCF, while the improvement of the permeation flux of the membrane by NECC-BSCF was the smallest. It suggests that the synthesis techniques also have a significant influence on the bulk oxygen diffusion of the cathode materials. The higher amount of nitric acid applied during the synthesis, the lower oxygen bulk diffusion rate was observed. The influence of the preparation method on the bulk properties of the BSCF cathode was also supported by the O 2 -TPD experiments. Fig. 9 shows the oxygen temperature-programmed desorption curves of EC-BSCF, NEC-BSCF and NECC-BSCF. A significant difference in oxygen desorption behavior at a temperature higher than 800 °C was observed. The oxygen desorption at such a temperature in O 2 -TPD profile was associated with the reduction of Co 3+ to Co 2+ [47] . The difference in the shape of O 2 -TPD profiles for the various BSCF powders suggests that the preparation method has an effect on the cobalt valence state at high temperatures. Since the oxygen bulk diffusion rate is closely related to the oxygen vacancy concentration, which in turn is closely related to the valence state of metal ions in the perovskite structure, a difference in the oxygen bulk diffusion behavior of the various BSCF oxides can be anticipated. Complete fuel cells were built based on the thin-film SDC electrolyte and the EC-BSCF, NEC-BSCF or NECC-BSCF cathode. Fig. 10 shows the performances of the single cells using 3% water-humidified H 2 as the fuel and ambient air as the cathode atmosphere, operated at 550–650 °C. Peak power densities of 693 and 825 mW cm −2 were achieved for the cell with the EC-BSCF cathode at operating temperatures of 600 and 650 °C, respectively. As expected, worse performances were observed for the cells based on the other two cathodes. The peak power densities were only 571 and 543 mW cm −2 at 600 °C for cells based on NEC-BSCF and NECC-BSCF cathodes, respectively. Shown in Fig. 11 are the typical impedance spectra for the cells with the EC-BSCF, NEC-BSCF and NECC-BSCF cathodes measured at 600 °C under open circuit condition. Here, the intercept with the real axis at high frequencies represents the resistance of the electrolyte and lead wires (about 0.27 Ω cm 2 ), whereas the resistance between the two intercepts with the real axis corresponds to the impedance of the two interfaces, i.e. the cathode–electrolyte interface and the anode–electrolyte interface. The electrode ASRs for the cells based on EC-BSCF, NEC-BSCF and NECC-BSCF cathode are 0.067, 0.097 and 0.207 Ω cm 2 , respectively. Since the anodes are identical, the differences in the electrode ASRs can be essentially attributed to the cathode. Therefore, it is clear that the interfacial polarization resistance of EC-BSCF cathode was the lowest, which was about 0.03 and 0.14 Ω cm 2 lower than that of NEC-BSCF and NECC-BSCF, respectively. 4 Conclusions Synthesis technique has a significant effect on the cathode performance of Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ perovskite for solid-oxide fuel cells. The nitric acid treatment during the EDTA–citrate complexing process affects not only the sintering behavior of the cathode during fabrication, but also the oxygen surface exchange kinetics and the oxygen bulk diffusion properties of the cathode. Among the three synthesis methods including the combined EDTA–citrate (EC) complexing method, the nitric acid modified EDTA–citrate (NEC) route and the nitric acid modified EDTA–citrate combustion (NECC) process, the EC method was found to be the most promising one for fuel cell applications. The increase of nitric acid applied during the powder synthesis led to the decrease of the crystallite size of the powder, the increase of sintering during fabrication, and the reduced surface oxygen exchange kinetics and bulk diffusion rate of the cathode. Consequently, the addition of HNO 3 during the synthesis process had a detrimental effect on the performance of fuel cell with the BSCF cathode. Therefore, for advances of IT-SOFCs, besides the development of new cathode materials and the optimization of the cathode architecture, proper powder synthesis techniques of the cathode material is also critical.
