KX3XP8Xn.title: Effect of firing temperature on the microstructure and performance of PrBaCo2O5+δ cathodes on Sm0.2Ce0.8O1.9 electrolytes fabricated by spray deposition-firing processes
KX3XP8Xn.abstract: The effect of firing temperature on the microstructure and performance of PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ cathodes on Sm 0.2 Ce 0.8 O 1.9 electrolytes fabricated by spray deposition-firing processes is systematically studied by various characterization techniques. The grain size, porosity and particle connection of the electrode as well as the physical contact between the PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ and Sm 0.2 Ce 0.8 O 1.9 layers are influenced differently by the firing temperature. The area specific resistances (ASRs) of the various PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ cathodes are measured by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy in both symmetrical two-electrode and three-electrode configurations. The lowest ASR and cathode overpotential are achieved at a firing temperature of 1000 °C. Two main oxygen reduction reaction processes are proposed according to the oxygen partial pressure dependence of the electrode ASR. The rate-determining step is transmitted from a charge-transfer process at low firing temperatures to a non-charge-transfer process at high firing temperatures. A fuel cell with the PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ cathode fired at an optimal temperature of 1000 °C delivers the attractive peak power density of 835 mW cm −2 at 650 °C, while this density is much lower for other firing temperatures. This result suggests the firing temperature of PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ electrodes should be carefully optimized for practical applications. Keywords Solid oxide fuel cells Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy Cathode PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ Layered perovskite 1 Introduction Solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) are considered as promising alternative electric power generation devices to current fire power plants because of their high-energy conversion efficiency, environmental friendliness, and excellent fuel flexibility [1] . Additionally, it has been well recognized that the wide spread of this attractive technology can be greatly accelerated if its operation temperature is lowered from the conventional temperature of around 1000 °C to intermediate temperatures of 500–800 °C because of the multiple benefits including reduced fabrication and materials costs, prolonged lifetime, elegant sealing and versatile cell materials [2] . However, maintaining high cathodic performance and low electrolyte ohmic resistance at reduced operation temperature is a big challenge [3] . A typical SOFC cathode is composed of an electron-conducting La 0.8 Sr 0.2 MnO 3 (LSM) perovskite [4] , over which the oxygen reduction reaction is strictly limited to the triple-phase boundary (TPB) where the electrode, the electrolyte and the gas phase meet [5] . With a drop in operation temperature, the cathodic polarization resistance increases so sharply that LSM is no longer applicable at intermediate temperatures. Currently, there is considerable research activity on the potential of novel mixed ionic and electronic conductors as cathode materials of intermediate-temperature solid oxide fuel cells (IT-SOFCs) [6–9] . The mixed conductivity of such materials greatly extends the reaction sites, and consequently, these materials are expected to provide much higher electrode activity for oxygen reduction than LSM at reduced temperatures. Indeed, some materials, such as La x Sr 1− x Co y Fe 1− y O 3− δ [10–14] , Sm x Sr 1− x CoO 3− δ [15–17] and Ba x Sr 1− x Co y Fe 1− y O 3− δ [18–22] perovskites, have been reported to have high electrochemical activity at temperatures as low as 600 °C. Recently, several research teams have reported the potential application of cation-ordered double-perovskite LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ (Ln = Gd, Pr, Y, La, etc.) as cathodes of IT-SOFCs [23–35] . Based on a symmetric cell test, we have previously demonstrated that acceptable area specific resistance (ASR) can be achieved for PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ (PrBC) cathodes at intermediate temperature [33] . With the further investigation into these cathode materials, however, some discrepancies appeared in the literature. The reported ASR of electrodes composed of the same material and tested under similar conditions could vary by several orders of magnitude; for example, the reported ASRs at 600 °C in air were in the wide range of 1.9–5.5 Ω cm 2 for Sm 0.5 Sr 0.5 CoO 3− δ [15,17] and 0.071–0.51 Ω cm 2 for Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ [18,36] . It is well known that in addition to the intrinsic properties of cathode materials, which depend on the material composition and lattice structure, their electrode performance is also closely related to their microstructure [11,37–39] and to the interfacial phase reaction between the electrode and electrolyte [40] . The discrepancy in electrode performance of the cathodes composed of the same material reported by different authors may be a result of their different electrode microstructures and/or different interfacial reaction behavior. To fabricate a cathode layer on an electrolyte surface, crystallized cathode material is first prepared by various methods, such as solid-state reaction, sol–gel synthesis and many other advanced techniques, and then the cathode material is deposited onto the electrolyte surface and co-fired with the electrolyte layer at a high temperature. Previous works have shown that the ASR of many cathodes strongly depends on the firing temperature [11,37] . For example, Leng et al. reported that the electrode polarization resistance of La 0.6 Sr 0.4 Co 0.2 Fe 0.8 O 3− δ electrodes fired at 975 °C is much lower than that of electrodes fired at other temperatures [11] . A detailed investigation into the effect of firing temperature on electrode performance would be helpful in optimizing the cell performance. In the present study, PrBC was applied as the cathode for a SOFC with Sm 0.2 Ce 0.8 O 1.9 (SDC) electrolyte. The influence of firing temperature on the microstructure and performance of a PrBC cathode was systematically studied and explained. The optimized firing temperature was developed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Powder synthesis and cell fabrication Both PrBC and SDC oxide powders were prepared by a combined EDTA-citrate complexing sol–gel process. Sm(NO 3 ) 3 ·6H 2 O (A.R., Aladdin Reagent Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China) and Ce(NO 3 ) 3 ·6H 2 O (A.R., Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China) were applied as the raw materials to synthesize SDC. The synthesis of PrBC, for example, was performed as follows. Stoichiometric amounts of Pr(NO 3 ) 3 ·6H 2 O (A.R., Aladdin Reagent Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China), Ba(NO 3 ) 2 (A.R., Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China) and Co(NO 3 ) 2 ·6H 2 O (A.R., Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China), were prepared into a mixed solution, and then EDTA–NH 3 ·H 2 O and citric acid, serving as complexing agents, were added in sequence at a mole ratio for total metal ions to EDTA to citric acid of 1:1:2 under heating and stirring. After vaporizing the water from the solution via heating, a transparent gel was obtained. The gel was pre-fired at 250 °C to form a black solid precursor, which was subsequently calcinated at 950 °C for 5 h in an air atmosphere to remove the carbon residue and to form the desired PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ phase. To measure the electrode performance, both a symmetric cell and a three-electrode configurations were adopted and tried, as shown in Fig. 1 . The SDC electrolyte pellets prepared for symmetric two-electrode and three-electrode cells were fabricated by dry pressing SDC powder (particle size, 22.9 nm) into disk-shaped pellets using stainless steel dies under hydraulic pressure of 200 MPa, followed by sintering at 1450 °C for 5 h in air. The resulting dense pellets (relative density, 95.8%) have diameters of approximately 12 and 16 mm, respectively, for the two-electrode symmetric cells and the three-electrode cells. To prepare the electrode layers of symmetric cells, PrBC oxide was well dispersed in a mixed solution of ethylene glycol, ethanol and isopropyl alcohol using a high-energy ball miller (Fritsch, Pulverisette 6) at the rotational speed of 400 rpm for 0.5 h; it was then symmetrically deposited onto both surfaces of the electrolyte by air-driven spray, followed by firing at 900–1100 °C in air for 2 h. To prepare a three-electrode cell, PrBC slurry was painted on one side of the SDC electrolyte to form a round electrode with an area of 0.26 cm 2 , which acts as a working electrode (WE), followed by firing at 900–1100 °C in air for 2 h. A Pt electrode, with the same shape and position as the WE, was painted on the other side of the SDC electrolyte pellet to act as a counter electrode (CE) followed by firing at 900 °C in air for 30 min. A silver (DAD-87, Shanghai Research Institute of Synthetic Resins, Shanghai, China) electrode was ringed around the counter electrode to act as a reference electrode (RE). The gap between the counter and the reference electrode was about 4 mm to prevent systematic errors in electrochemical measurements. Anode-supported thin-film SDC electrolyte dual-layer cells were prepared via dual dry pressing. Well mixed powders containing 60 wt% NiO (A.R., particle size, ∼8 μm, Shudu Nano-Science Development Co., Ltd., Chengdu, China) and 40 wt% SDC were applied as anode starting materials, which were pressed into a green pellet using a 15-mm stainless steel die. The proper amount of SDC powder was dispersed homogeneously over the open surface of the green anode pellet inside the die and pressed again to form a dual-layer pellet. These green cells were then densified at 1450 °C for 5 h in an air atmosphere. The PrBC slurry was then spray-deposited over the electrolyte surface, followed by firing at 900–1100 °C in air for 2 h to form complete cells with an effective area of 0.48 cm 2 of the porous cathode layer. The three-layered pellets NiO + SDC|SDC|PrBC were then used for I – V characterization. 2.2 Electrochemical characterization Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was conducted using symmetric two-electrode and three-electrode configurations. Both the electrode surfaces of the symmetric cells and WE-surface of the three-electrode cells were painted with a thin layer of silver to act as current collectors. The cells were then loaded into a quartz tube reactor with controllable atmosphere. The ASR of the electrode was determined from its EIS using a Solartron 1260 Frequency Response Analyzer in combination with a Solartron 1287 potentiostat. The frequency used for EIS measurements ranged from 10 −1 to 10 5 Hz, and the signal amplitude was 10 mV with no applied dc bias. The overall impedance data were collected with the ZPlot 2.9c software program and fitted by a complex non-linear least squares (CNLS) fitting program using the ZView 2.9 software program. The oxygen partial pressure of the atmosphere was varied between 0.04 and 1 atm by mixing O 2 with N 2 using mass flow controllers. The cathodic overpotential was measured using a Solartron 1287 potentiostat/galvanostat, which was operated via the Corrware 2.9c software. The polarization current density was varied from 0 to 1000 mA cm −2 in 10 mA cm −2 intervals. The IR drop, originating from the electrolyte and lead/contact resistances, was compensated to establish the IR-free I / E polarization curves. The performance of the cathode fired at different temperatures was also evaluated in complete cells in an in-lab constructed SOFC test station. The cell was sealed onto the top of a quartz tube with silver to act as a fuel cell reactor, which was put into a vertical split tube furnace. The cathode side and anode side were fed with ambient air and humidified hydrogen at a flow rate of 80 ml min −1 , respectively. A thermocouple was inserted near the cathode surface for the temperature monitoring. A digital sourcemeter (Keithley 2420) was used for I – V polarization testing based on a four-terminal configuration. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Microstructure To fabricate PrBC cathodes on the SDC electrolytes, PrBC in suspension form was first spray-deposited onto the surface of a SDC disk, followed by high-temperature firing. The firing temperature may affect the microstructure of PrBC electrode by influencing its surface area, porosity, particle connection, and physical contact with the electrolyte layer; it may also induce an interfacial reaction between the SDC electrolyte and PrBC electrode layers. An insufficient porosity may create a serious concentration polarization, especially at high polarization current density. On the one hand, poor connection between electrode particles and/or poor physical contact between the electrolyte and electrode layers may hinder the charge transfer from particle to particle in the electrode, and/or from the electrode to the electrolyte; as a result, a large electrode polarization resistance is expected. On the other hand, the reduction in surface area because of sintering decreases the active sites for oxygen adsorption, dissociation and surface diffusion; as a result, an increase in electrode polarization resistance is expected. In addition, the phase reaction could create an interfacial phase, which may block the oxygen diffusion and lead to a sharp increase in the cell resistance. The microstructure of the PrBC electrodes fired at different temperatures was then examined by SEM observation. Fig. 2 shows the micrographs of the PrBC cathodes, both from the surface and cross-sectional views. For all firing temperatures, the electrodes show porous structures but with different levels of porosity, which are given in Table 1 . As a whole, a decrease in porosity with increasing firing temperature was observed. In particular, the electrode fired at 1100 °C was seriously sintered both at the surface and in the interior. The electrodes fired at 900 and 950 °C have high porosity and fine particle size; however, they also show relatively poor particle connections. With the increase of firing temperature to 1000 °C, the particle connection of the electrode improved noticeably, while the grain size increased only slightly. The average grain sizes are ∼0.65, 0.72 and 0.75 μm for the electrodes fired at 900, 950 and 1000 °C, respectively. With further increases in firing temperature, however, an obvious increase in grain size with the temperature was also observed. The electrode fired at 1050 and 1100 °C had average grain sizes of ∼1.64 and 2.62 μm, respectively, which are ∼2.5 and 4 times that of the electrode fired at 900 °C. 3.2 Electrochemical performance The electrochemical performance of the various electrodes was first investigated by EIS in symmetric cell configuration. The typical EIS in the Nyquist plots of the various cells from firing at different temperatures are shown in Fig. 3 . All the EIS include a high-frequency induction tail and a depressed arc. Since there was no serious phase reaction between PrBC and SDC within the whole temperature range investigated, of 900–1100 °C [33] , the ohmic resistance of the cell is not discussed in the following section. It was found that the corresponding frequency point, such as 100 Hz, shifted to the left intersection of the real axis of EIS with increased cathode firing temperature, implying that the rate-determining step of oxygen reduction reaction kinetics likely changed with the increase of firing temperature. It is well known that the oxygen reaction over a mixed conducting electrode is complex, which may include several sub-steps, such as surface oxygen diffusion, adsorption, dissociation, and charge transfers (both oxygen ions and electrons) [41–43] . The firing temperature has different impacts on the above processes; consequently a change in the rate-determining step could happen with the change of firing temperature. To get more insight into the effect of firing temperature on the performance of PrBC electrode, EIS of the symmetric cells at different oxygen partial pressures were measured. Fig. 3 a–e shows the EIS for the various PrBC cathodes in Nyquist plots, tested at 600 °C in atmosphere with oxygen partial pressure varied from 0.04 to 1 atm. The data were fitted to an equivalent circuit shown in Fig. 3 f. Here ( R E1 -CPE1) and ( R E2 -CPE2) represent the processes at high and low frequency, respectively. The constant phase element (CPE) represents a non-ideal capacitor, and the associated CPE-P parameter indicates the similarity of the CPE to a true capacitor, for which CPE-P = 1. The symbols in Fig. 3 a–e represent the measured data, while the solid lines are fitted curves. Good agreement between the fitted curves and the observed impedance data was observed. This implies that the equivalent circuit is a reasonable approximation for fitting the experimental data. It is well accepted that different processes for oxygen reduction reaction over mixed ionic and electronic conducting electrodes have different levels of dependence on the oxygen partial pressure [43,44] . The most commonly used parameter to determine the step in the oxygen reduction process is m , which indicates the relationship between the polarization resistance and oxygen partial pressure, expressed as ln ( 1 / R ) = m   ln ( p O 2 ) . The m values give information about the type of oxygen species involved in the oxygen reduction reaction, as listed in Table 2 . Typically, m values between 0.5 and 1 indicate non-charge-transfer processes, which include oxygen diffusion at the gas–cathode interface, adsorption–desorption of oxygen, and the surface diffusion of adsorbed oxygen species. The value 0.25 should be observed for a charge-transfer process [43,44] , which could happen at the air–electrode interface and electrode–electrode interface. The value 0 indicates the ion charge transfer from the electrode to electrolyte [40] . It is often difficult to separate the two processes ( m = 0.25 and m = 0) in the EIS because they typically have similar characteristic frequency [45] . Fig. 4 shows oxygen partial pressure dependence of the fitted R E1 and R E2 . It can be observed that ln(1/ R E1 ) had a ln( p O 2 ) dependent slope of 0.18–0.28, which implies that this process is likely related to the charge-transfer process. On the other hand, ln(1/ R E2 ) had a ln( p O 2 ) dependent slope of 0.36–0.52, indicating the non-charge-transfer process. It should be pointed out that the concentration polarization arc did not appear under all conditions. This may due to the porosity of the PrBC cathode fired at 900–1100 °C is sufficient for free gas diffusion ( m = 1) under conditions without a polarization current. Fig. 5 presents the fitted R E1 and R E2 (derived from Fig. 3 ) of the PrBC cathode as a function of the firing temperature, measured in an air atmosphere. As a whole, R E1 decreased while R E2 increased with increasing temperature. R E1 decreased noticeably with firing temperature between 900 and 1000 °C, after which the decrement became much smaller with further increases in firing temperature. As to R E2 , which is related to the non-charge-transfer process, it increased only slightly with firing temperature between 900 and 1000 °C, while with further increases in firing temperature a sharp increase in R E2 was then observed. The SEM results, shown in Fig. 2 , can now be well explained as follows. At the temperature range of 900–1000 °C, the increase in firing temperature did not have a significant impact on the grain size (surface area) of the electrode, while it led to an obvious improvement of the electrode particle connection; as a result, the surface processes were not seriously affected but the charge-transfer process was greatly improved. At firing temperatures higher than 1000 °C, the particle connection was well developed, so that the further increase in firing temperature did not lead to an obvious change in R E1 ; however, significant sintering of the electrode appeared, which led to an obvious decrease in the surface area, and consequently the non-charge-transfer surface processes were greatly impaired. Table 3 summarizes the values of R E1 and R E2 (derived from Fig. 3 ) at various oxygen partial pressures. The same tendency was observed at all other oxygen partial pressures. The optimal firing temperature that leads to the minimum value of the sum of R E1 and R E2 was found to be around 1000 °C. Cathodic overpotential is an important factor representing electrode performance. Three-electrode cells were fabricated to evaluate the performance of the various electrodes under current polarization conditions. It is well known that the accuracy of three-electrode test is strongly dependent on the preparation technique. To ensure the high reliability of the data, the work electrode and the counter electrode should be as symmetric as possible, while the reference electrode should be as far from the electrode as possible. To ensure the high reliability of the three-electrode electrochemical test in the current study, the cell was first tested without DC polarization, and the data obtained were compared with those obtained from two-electrode symmetric cell tests. ASR values from the symmetric two-electrode and three-electrode cells for a cathode fired at different temperatures tested at 600 °C in air, for example, are plotted in Fig. 6 . A line with the slope of 1 was drawn for reference. Good agreement in polarization resistance is obtained in both configurations, suggesting the high reliability of the three-electrode cells in the current study. To evaluate the performance of the various electrodes under current polarization, a current was then introduced between the working electrode and the counter electrode. The IR-corrected Tafel plots for the PrBC cathode, as a function of cathode firing temperature tested at 600 °C in air, are shown in Fig. 7 . At the overpotential of −0.15 V, the cathode current density was found to be around 135, 150, 205, 135 and 100 mA cm −2 in air at cathode firing temperatures of 900, 950, 1000, 1050 and 1100 °C, respectively. Although the graph indicates that three-electrode cells underestimate overpotential within several to 10%, the lowest cathode overpotential is achieved for the cathode fired at 1000 °C, in accordance with the EIS results. 3.3 Single cell performance Ni + SDC anode-supported thin-film SDC electrolyte fuel cells were fabricated to evaluate the performance of the PrBC electrode under real fuel cell operation conditions. Fig. 8 shows the I – V and I – P curves of the cells with PrBC electrode being fired at various temperatures. The test was conducted at 650 °C with ambient air as the cathode atmosphere and humidified hydrogen with 80 ml min −1 as the anode fuel. Since the anodes and electrolyte were fabricated following an identical procedure, the anode and electrolyte resistances of the various cells were reasonably assumed to be the same, so the main contribution to the difference in cell performance is from the PrBC cathode. A maximum peak power density of 835 mW cm −2 was achieved from the cell with the PrBC cathode fired at 1000 °C, which was much higher than those of the cells with the cathode fired at other temperatures, where densities of 621, 667, 546 and 360 mW cm −2 at firing temperatures of 900, 950, 1050 and 1100 °C, respectively. It was observed that the dependence of the cell voltage on the current density of cells is basically a straight line except for the cathode fired at 1100 °C. This suggests that the porosity of the cathode fired at 900–1000 °C is sufficient for free gas diffusion. As to the PrBC cathode fired at 1100 °C, due to the significant sintering during the high-temperature firing, noticeable concentration polarization likely occurred at the high current density. 4 Conclusions The firing temperature has significant effects on the microstructure and, consequently, the electrode performance of PrBC cathode. It affects the surface area, porosity, particle size, and particle connection of PrBC electrodes differently. An increase in firing temperature led to an obvious increase in particle connection of the electrode between 900 and 1000 °C, while the particle size was not significantly affected within this temperature range. With further increases in firing temperature, however, the particle size increased appreciably. The porosity of the electrode decreased monotonically with increasing firing temperature; however, only the electrode fired at 1100 °C showed significant sintering. Within the full temperature range of 900–1100 °C, there was no obvious phase reaction between PrBC and SDC electrolyte based on the powder reaction test. The electrode performance was determined by the complicated effects of the firing temperature on the microstructure of the PrBC electrode. The cathode firing temperature should be carefully optimized to get maximum power output by applying the PrBC cathode. As a whole, an increase in the electrode polarization resistance associated with non-charge-transfer processes and a decrease in the electrode polarization resistance associated with charge-transfer processes was observed with increasing firing temperature. The optimal firing temperature is that at which the overall electrode polarization resistance reaches minimum, which was found to be around 1000 °C for PrBC electrodes in this study. A cell with PrBC electrodes fired at 1000 °C delivered a peak power density of 835 mW cm −2 at 650 °C, which is more than double that of a similar cell with PrBC electrode fired at 1100 °C. fN6TlSig.title: Fabrication and performance test of a catalyst-coated membrane from direct spray deposition
fN6TlSig.abstract: Catalyst-coated membranes (CCMs) play an important role in the PEMFCs. The direct-spraying deposition method that is using ethylene-glycol (EG) soaked Nafion membrane and the catalyst ink with isopropyl alcohol as the primary liquid media and small amount of EG as additive has been developed for fabrication of high-quality CCMs. The properties of the CCMs have been analyzed by SEM, I–V and EIS characterization. Both modification of catalyst layers and membrane surfaces with Nafion had significant impacts on the cell performance. On favorable conditions, a peak power density of ~ 430mW/cm 2 could be achieved for a H 2 |O 2 cell at ambient pressure and total Pt loading of 0.3mg/cm 2 including both the anode and cathode.

pGAKZIVR.title: Effect of foreign oxides on the phase structure, sintering and transport properties of Ba 0.5Sr 0.5Co 0.8Fe 0.2O 3-anddelta; as ceramic membranes for oxygen separation
pGAKZIVR.abstract: A series of foreign oxides including CuO, ZnO, NiO, Co 2O 3 and Al 2O 3 were investigated as sintering aids to facilitate the densification of Ba 0.5Sr 0.5Co 0.8Fe 0.2O 3-anddelta; (BSCF) membranes for oxygen separation. The effects of these oxides on the phase structure, sintering behavior, electrical conductivity and oxygen permeability of BSCF oxide were systematically studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD), oxygen temperature-programmed desorption (O 2-TPD), environmental scanning electron microscopy (ESEM), four-probe direct current (DC) conductivity and gas permeation measurements. The results showed that reactions between the membrane material and the foreign oxides took place at elevated temperatures. These oxides displayed different sintering behaviors during the sintering process of BSCF perovskite, with obvious improvement demonstrated in the case of CuO, minimal effects observed from ZnO, Co 2O 3 and NiO samples, and suppressing effects from Al 2O 3. The electrical conductivity was clearly increased by introducing Co 2O 3 as a sintering aid, yielding a maximum value of 70 S cm -1 at 900 °C. The oxygen permeation fluxes of the membrane samples from BSCF + NiO (5 wt.%) and BSCF + ZnO (5 wt.%) are comparable to those of pristine BSCF membranes, whereas the fluxes decreased noticeably when the other foreign oxides were introduced. © 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

RGUukjTt.title: Comparative study of doped ceria thin-film electrolytes prepared by wet powder spraying with powder synthesized via two techniques
RGUukjTt.abstract: Fabrication of dense Sm 0.2 Ce 0.8 O 1.9 (SDC) thin-film electrolytes by wet powder spraying in combination with high-temperature sintering is investigated. Two powder synthesis techniques, i.e. , a hydrothermal synthesis and an EDTA–citrate complexing sol–gel process, were investigated. X-ray diffraction, BET surface area and laser particle size analysis demonstrate there is certain level of aggregation in both powders. However, it is more pronounced in powders obtained by the complexing process, and only the colloidal suspensions of powders prepared by hydrothermal synthesis are stable. SEM analysis of the green and sintered thin-film electrolytes demonstrate that the SDC electrolyte with powders prepared via the hydrothermal synthesis is denser. By optimizing the fabrication conditions, dense SDC electrolytes with a thickness of ∼12 μm are successfully fabricated. The cells with SDC prepared from hydrothermal synthesis demonstrate open circuit voltages and power outputs similar to those of similar cells fabricated from other advanced techniques. Because of its simplicity and flexibility for anode substrate geometric shape, it turns out to be a promising technology to fabricate thin-film SDC electrolyte for solid-oxide fuel cell application.

O1I64YC9.title: In situ templating synthesis of conic Ba0.5Sr 0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3-δ perovskite at elevated temperature
O1I64YC9.abstract: Conic Ba0-5Sr0-5Co0-8Fe 0-2O3-δ (BSCF) functional composite oxide was synthesized via a simple in situ templating process. The treatment of the solid precursor with concentrated nitric acid resulted in the mismatch of ionic radius at A-site and B-site of the ABO3 perovskite, due to the oxidation of cobalt/iron ions, and the formation of Ba0-5Sr0-5(NO 3)2 solid solution. Therefore, instead of the direct formation of BSCF oxide, an intermediate phase of Ba0-5Sr 0-5CoO3 (BSC) in hexagonal lattice structure and with conic particle shape was preferentially formed during calcination at low temperature. BSCF perovskite was then produced by the in situ templating of BSC with iron diffusing into the BSC lattice during calcination at high temperature. Wellcrystallized BSCF particles in conic shape were obtained by the calcination of the nitric acid treated precursor at 900°C. © Indian Academy of Sciences.

1T4j3dJA.title: Self-assembled mesoporous TiO2/carbon nanotube composite with a three-dimensional conducting nanonetwork as a high-rate anode material for lithium-ion battery
1T4j3dJA.abstract: Mesoporous three-dimensional (3D) TiO2/carbon nanotube conductive hybrid nanostructures can be successfully developed using polyethylene oxide (PEO) to modify the surfaces of carbon nanotubes (CNTs). During the synthesis process, PEO acts as not only "bridges" to connect the TiO2 nanoparticles to the CNT surfaces but also as "hosts" to accommodate and stabilize the in situ generated TiO 2 particles. As the electrodes for lithium-ion batteries, such mesoporous 3D TiO2/CNT hybrids, demonstrate high Li storage capacity, superior rate performance and excellent long-term cycling stability. They exhibit a reversible specific capacity of 203 mA h g-1 at 100 mA g-1 and a stable capacity retention of 91 mA h g-1 at 8000 mA g-1 (47.6 C) over 100 cycles; they also retain approximately 90% (71 mA h g-1) of their initial discharge capacity after 900 cycles at an extremely high rate of 15,000 mA g-1 (89 C). This facile synthetic strategy to construct mesoporous 3D TiO2/CNT conductive hybrids provides a convenient route that efficiently assembles various inorganic oxide components on the CNTs' surfaces and enables the formation of heterogeneous nanostructures with novel functionalities. In particular, utilizing a conductive 3D CNT network can serve as a promising strategy for developing high-performance electrodes for Li secondary batteries and supercapacitors. ? 2014 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

dkES2EWK.title: Effect of Sm3+ content on the properties and electrochemical performance of SmxSr1 - XCoO3 - δ (0.2 ≤ x ≤ 0.8) as an oxygen reduction electrodes on doped ceria electrolytes
dkES2EWK.abstract: Sm x Sr 1 − x CoO 3 − δ (SSCx) materials are promising cathodes for IT-SOFCs. The influence of Sm content in SSCx (0.2 ≤ x ≤ 0.8) oxides on their oxygen nonstoichiometry, oxygen desorption, thermal expansion behavior, electrical conductivity and electrochemical activity for oxygen reduction is systematically studied by iodometric titration, oxygen-temperature programmed desorption (O 2 -TPD), dilatometer, four-probe DC conductivity, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and three-electrode polarization test, respectively. Iodometric titration experiments demonstrate that the electrical charge neutrality compensation in SSCx proceeds preferably through the oxidation of cobalt ion for high Sm 3+ contents ( x ≥ 0.6). However, it proceeds mainly through the creation of oxygen vacancies at x ≤ 0.5. O 2 -TPD shows SSC5 possesses the highest oxygen desorption ability among the range of SSCx materials tested. The thermal expansion coefficients (TECs) are high between the transition temperature and 900 °C, showing values typically larger than 20 × 10 −6 K −1 . All dense materials show high electrical conductivity with a maximum value of ∼1885 S cm −1 for SSC6 in air, while SSC5 has the highest electrical conductivity in nitrogen. EIS analysis of porous electrodes demonstrates that SSC5 has the lowest area specific resistance (ASR) value (0.42 Ω cm 2 ) at 600 °C. Cathodic overpotential testing demonstrates that SSC5 also has the largest exchange current density of 60 mA cm −2 at 600 °C in air. Keywords Samarium strontium cobaltite Thermal expansion Electrical conductivity Oxygen vacancy concentration Electrode performance 1 Introduction Over the past several decades, there has been a major, international research effort to reduce the operating temperature of solid-oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) to the low-to-intermediate temperature (LIT) range of 400–800 °C [1–5] . This temperature range introduces several important benefits that may enhance the commercialization of SOFCs, including prolonged cell lifetime, improved flexibility in cell materials selection, reduced operation costs and reduced material costs. However, the LIT range also introduces a major challenge in maintaining a high cell power output. La 0.8 Sr 0.2 MnO 3 (LSM) is the state-of-the-art cathode for high-temperature SOFCs. This material is a pure electronic conductor with a low oxygen tracer diffusion coefficient of only 10 −15 –10 −16 cm 2 s −1 at 700 °C [6,7] . Application of LSM as a SOFCs electrode constricts the oxygen reduction reaction to the narrow region around the electrode–electrolyte–air triple phase boundary. A large polarization resistance has been observed for the LSM cathode at reduced temperatures, making it unsuitable for application at temperature lower than 700 °C. It is generally accepted that the improvement of cathode performance is critical to realize the practical application of LIT-SOFCs. Microstructure optimization and the development of new materials with high electrochemical activities for oxygen reduction are two general ways that the low-temperature electrochemical activity of SOFCs cathodes can be improved [8–11] . By introducing oxygen-ion diffusion paths into the electrode, the entire exposed electrode surface may become electrochemically active for oxygen reduction reactions. Consequently, a significant improvement in electrochemical activity at reduced temperatures would be expected. At present, considerable research efforts are being made towards the development of novel single-phase oxides with both high oxygen ionic conductivities and oxygen surface exchange kinetics as cathodes of LIT-SOFCs [12–18] . The doping strategy is the most frequently adopted method to tailor the properties and performance of mixed conductors. La x Sr 1 − x CoO 3 − δ (LSC) perovskites are typically in the form of mixed conductors with high electronic and ionic conductivities at elevated temperatures [19,20] . These materials have been recently investigated as LIT-SOFCs electrodes [21–23] . The phase structure, phase stability, oxygen vacancy concentration and oxygen ionic conductivity are all closely related to the lanthanum-to-strontium ratio in these oxides. The substitution of A-site or/and B-site cations in LSC has also been attempted to further improve the phase stability and/or electrode performance of these oxides at reduced temperatures [24–27] . The replacement of La in LSC by Sm with the development of Sm x Sr 1 − x CoO 3 − δ (SSCx) perovskite composite oxides has been shown to effectively improve the surface activity of these materials [28] . Fukunaga et al. have recently measured the reaction model of the dense Sm 0.5 Sr 0.5 CoO 3 − δ (SSC5) cathode and found that the surface exchange constants are one order of magnitude larger than the corresponding values for La 0.6 Sr 0.4 CoO 3 [28] . Recently, SSCx oxides (SSC5 in particular) have received considerable attention as alternative cathodes for LIT-SOFCs. Their electrochemical performance for oxygen reduction on doped ceria, Sr- and Mg- doped LaGaO 3 , yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) and proton-conducting BaCe 0.8 Sm 0.2 O 3 (BCS) electrolytes has been investigated [29–33] . To further improve electrode performance, the formation of composite electrodes with Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3 − δ (BSCF), La 0.6 Sr 0.4 Co 0.2 Fe 0.8 O 3 − δ (LSCF), Sm 0.2 Ce 0.8 O 1.9 (SDC), La 0.8 Sr 0.2 Ga 0.8 Mg 0.15 Co 0.05 O 3 (LSGMC5), BCS and Co 3 O 4 semiconductor have also been attempted [34–39] . Zhang and colleagues have demonstrated that anode-supported SOFCs with SSC5 + 25 wt.% SDC composite cathode and thin-film SDC electrolyte delivered a high peak power density of 0.75 W cm −2 at 600 °C when operating on hydrogen fuel [36] . Many research projects have investigated SSCx perovskites, with SSC5 gaining particular attention. However, a systematic investigation is still lacking into the effect of samarium doping content on the properties and electrochemical performances of SSCx materials as electrodes of LIT-SOFCs [32,40–44] . An ideal LIT-SOFCs cathode should meet several important requirements, including high electrical conductivity for efficient current collection, good thermal compatibility with other cell components to ensure a long operational stability, good chemical compatibility with the electrolyte to reduce interfacial polarization resistance, high surface activity towards oxygen reduction and bulk oxygen ionic conductivity to ensure low electrode polarization resistance. In this study, the effect of samarium content in SSCx (0.2 ≤ x ≤ 0.8) on oxygen nonstoichiometry, thermal expansion behavior, electrical conductivity and electrochemical activity for oxygen reduction on samaria-doped ceria electrolyte was systematically studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis and fabrication The composite oxides of SSCx (0.2 ≤ x ≤ 0.8) and SDC electrolyte were synthesized using an ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA)-citrate complexing sol–gel process with Sr(NO 3 ) 2 , Co(NO 3 ) 2 and Sm(NO 3 ) 3 ·6H 2 O as the cation sources. For a typical synthesis, the required amounts of metal nitrates were first prepared into a mixed solution. Subsequently, EDTA (in the form of EDTA-NH 3 ·H 2 O) and then citric acid were added using a molar ratio of total metal ions to EDTA to citric acid of 1:1:2. NH 3 ·H 2 O was used to adjust the pH value of the solution around 6. A transparent gel was obtained after the evaporation of excess water under heating. This gel was then pre-treated at 240 °C to form a solid precursor. And then precursor further was calcinated at 950 °C for 5 h in air and cooled naturally to room temperature to obtain the product with the target composition. Symmetric cells with the configuration of SSCx|SDC|SSCx configurations were used to measure the electrode performance by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). SDC electrolyte pellets were fabricated by dry pressing and sintering at 1450 °C for 5 h in air. For spray deposition, SSCx slurries were prepared by ball milling the SSCx powders at 400 rpm for 30 min with a solution composed of glycerol, ethylene glycol and isopropyl alcohol. The SSCx slurries were then painted on both surfaces of the SDC pellets in a symmetric configuration and subsequently calcinated at 1000 °C for 2 h under an air atmosphere. A three-electrode system was adopted for cathodic overpotential evaluation. SSCx slurries were painted onto one side of the SDC pellets and calcinated at 1000 °C for 2 h to form a working electrode (WE) with a surface area of 0.26 cm 2 . Pt paste was painted on the other side of the SDC pellet, in a configuration that was symmetry with the WE, and sintered at 900 °C for 30 min to act as the counter electrode (CE). The silver reference electrode was pasted as a ring surrounding the CE. 2.2 Electrochemical characterization EIS measurements were carried out using an ac impedance method with an electrochemical workstation comprised of a Solartron 1260A frequency response analyzer and a Solartron 1287 potentiostat. The applied frequency range was from 0.01 Hz to 1 MHz, and the signal amplitude was 10 mV under open-circuit conditions. The oxygen partial pressure of the atmosphere during the EIS measurement was controlled at 0.04–1.0 atm by mixing O 2 and N 2 with mass flow controllers. The data were collected with the Z-Plot 2.9c software program and fitted by a complex non-linear least squares (CNLS) fitting program within Z-View 2.9. The cathodic overpotential was measured using a Solartron 1287 potentiostat/galvanostat. The series resistance (IR) drop, originating from the electrolyte and lead/contact resistances, was compensated for by using the series resistance obtained from the EIS data to establish the IR-free I/E characteristics. 2.3 Other characterizations Crystal structures of the SSCx powders were analyzed by an ARL X’TRA diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The diffractometer was operated at 40 kV and 35 mA in the scanning 2 θ range of 20°–90° with a step size of 0.02°. The micrographs of symmetrical cells from the cross-sectional view were observed by an environmental scanning electron microscope (ESEM, QUANTA-200). Oxygen-temperature programmed desorption (O 2 -TPD) experiments were conducted on a home-constructed multi-purpose temperature-programmed apparatus [45] . About 0.15 g sample in the size of 40–60 meshes was placed into a U-type quartz tube reactor with an inner diameter of 4 mm. Argon was introduced from one end of the tube at a flow rate of 15 ml min −1 [Standard Temperature and Pressure, STP] and the temperature was programmatically increased from room temperature to 900 °C. During this temperature increase, the oxygen in the oxide lattice was progressively released and carried on a stream of argon gas into a mass spectrometer (Hiden QIC-20, UK) for on-line oxygen concentration analysis. In some cases, the temperature was held at 900 °C for an adequate period of time to allow for the completion of the oxygen desorption process. The oxygen vacancy concentration of the fresh and desorbed SSC samples at room temperature was evaluated using iodometric method. Briefly, 0.1 g samples were dissolved in HCl solution under an inert gas atmosphere to prevent the oxidation of iodine ions by air. Subsequently, the solution was titrated with a standard thiosulfate solution. Details of this measurement process are available in a previous publication [45] . The thermal expansion coefficients (TECs) of the SSCx pellets were measured in air using a Netzsch DIL 402C dilatometer in the temperature range from room temperature to 900 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C min −1 . The dilatometer was calibrated using a Netzsch quartz standard to yield an experimental error less than ±0.06 × 10 −6 K −1 . The TECs of all samples in this study were calculated using the expression: (1) α = d ( ( L 2 − L 1 ) / L 1 ) d T = d ( L 2 − L 1 ) L 1 ⋅ d T where α is the TEC and L 1 and L 2 are the initial and final gauge lengths, respectively. The electrical conductivity was measured using a four-probe DC conductivity technique. A bar with dimensions of 2 mm × 5 mm × 12 mm was sintered at 1100 °C for 2 h in air. Then silver paste was painted on the endpoints of the rectangle and along the rectangular edges of the bar-shape pellets to form current and voltage electrodes. Silver wires were attached to the electrodes to act as current contacts (2 wires) and voltage contacts (2 wires). A current was applied to the two current wires and the voltage was detected by a digital source meter (Keithley 2420, USA) at intervals of 10 °C over the temperature range of 900–300 °C under air and nitrogen atmospheres with a cooling rate of 5 °C min −1 . At each temperature step, sufficient time was given for the conductivity to stabilize. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Oxygen vacancy concentration and oxygen desorption The electrochemical activity of an electrode for oxygen reduction is closely related to its oxygen vacancy concentration and oxygen desorption. The oxygen vacancy is the carrier of oxygen ion and can be created by a doping strategy. For an ideal A 3+ B 3+ O 3 -type perovskite oxide, the oxygen content is 3. The partial substitution of A 3+ by a cation with a lower oxidation state (e.g., M 2+ ) unbalances the local electrical charge neutrality. This can be compensated by the creation of an oxygen vacancy or the increase in the oxidation state of the B-site cation to a higher value as follows: (2) Route     1 :     2 M M x + O O x ⇄ ABO 3 2 M ′ A + V O + 1 2 O 2 (3) Route   2 :     M M x + B B x ⇄ ABO 3 M ′ A + B B In SSCx, Sm and Sr take the fixed oxidation states of 3+ and 2+, respectively, while cobalt can take multiple valence states of 2+, 3+ and 4+. The partial substitution of Sm 3+ with Sr 2+ may lead to the creation of an oxygen vacancy via the compensation Route 1. This could also lead to the oxidation of cobalt ion to a higher valance state via the compensation Route 2. Improved oxygen ionic conductivity is expected with the increase in oxygen vacancy concentration, if no defect association appears. On the other hand, the surface activity is also closely related to the surface oxygen vacancy. The oxygen nonstoichiometry ( δ ) and average cobalt ion valence ( n ) for the various SSCx oxides prepared in air were determined by iodometric method, and the results of this analysis were summarized in Table 1 . Overall, an increase in δ with decreasing Sm content ( x ) was observed. The oxygen content is close to stoichiometry was observed for Sm 0.8 Sr 0.2 CoO 3 − δ (SSC8). The oxygen nonstoichiometry increased to 0.025 for Sm 0.6 Sr 0.4 CoO 3 − δ (SSC6) and reached 0.36 for Sm 0.2 Sr 0.8 CoO 3 − δ (SSC2). The ratios ( R ) of the amount of doped strontium with different electrical charge neutrality compensations (i.e., through the creation of oxygen vacancy versus through the increase in cobalt oxidation state) were calculated and the results are shown in Table 1 . These results clearly demonstrate that the electrical charge neutrality compensation proceeded preferably through Route 2 at high Sm 3+ contents ( x ≥ 0.6), while the compensation was mainly through Route 1 at x ≤ 0.5. According to Jonker et al., Route 2 predominates at x > 0.5, while Route 1 may take over as x becomes less than 0.5 [46] . The present results agree reasonably well with these previous findings. In addition to the requirement of having a sufficient oxygen vacancy concentration, the electrode material should also possess high oxygen desorption ability to have high electro-catalytic activity for oxygen reduction. O 2 -TPD is an effective and facile technique for analyzing the bulk oxygen desorption and surface oxygen activity of an oxide, as well as for determining the reducibility of cobalt ions. The thermal reduction of cobalt ions to a lower state in the oxide lattice and a subsequent release of oxygen can be carried out using a programmatic increase of temperature in a flowing inert atmosphere. The shape of the O 2 -TPD profile is closely related to the bulk and surface properties of the sample. The O 2 -TPD profiles of all SSCx oxides over the temperature range of 200–900 °C are shown in Fig. 1 . Two oxygen desorption peaks were observed in the profiles for x = 0.2–0.5. One peak appeared at 300 < T < 450 °C (denoted as α oxygen) and is ascribed to the reduction of Co 4+ to Co 3+ . With the increasing Sm content, a progressive change in the α peak was observed. Interestingly, SSC4 had the largest α peak area, while SSC6 and SSC8 had almost no α peak. This suggests the Co 4+ cation had the highest stability in SSC6 and SSC8, while it was less stable in SSCx oxides with lower Sm 3+ contents. On the other hand, the α peak shifted towards lower temperature with the increasing x and reached a minimum temperature at x = 0.5. The minimum desorption temperature of α oxygen suggests that the lattice oxygen in SSC5 may have the highest desorption ability. The second peak appeared at 770 < T < 900 °C (denoted as β oxygen) and is ascribed to the reduction of Co 3+ to Co 2+ . The desorption temperature of β oxygen increased with increasing Sm content. For the SSC8 sample, the thermal reduction occurred mainly through the reduction of Co 3+ to Co 2+ , instead of Co 4+ to Co 3+ . After the O 2 -TPD process, the obtained powders (identified as desorbed SSCx powders) were cooled to room temperature in an argon atmosphere. The oxygen vacancy concentration and the average valence state of the cobalt ions were then determined by iodometric method (also shown in Table 1 ). Compared with the fresh SSCx powders, the oxygen vacancy concentrations of the desorbed SSCx samples were increased and the average valence states of the cobalt ions were all smaller than +3, suggesting the thermal reduction of cobalt ions. 3.2 Thermal expansion The large variation in oxygen nonstoichiometry during the thermal process may have a significant impact on the thermal expansion behavior of the oxides. Thermal expansion data obtained upon heating for SSCx compositions are given in Fig. 2 . The thermal expansion behavior of the SSC pellets with x = 0.2–0.6 was relatively abnormal, yielding nonlinear results for all samples and with transitions occurring between 420 and 590 °C. The appearance of the transition points can be ascribed to the loss of lattice oxygen with the formation of an oxygen vacancy or the spin state transition of the cobalt ions. No obvious transition at the intermediate temperature range was observed for SSC8. This is consistent with the O 2 -TPD results, in which no α peak appeared in the same temperature range of the profile. Therefore, the transition is more likely related to oxygen release from the lattice. The TEC is defined as the slope of the dilatometric curve. Corresponding values for the TEC over the temperature range for the SSCx oxides are listed in Table 2 . SSC8 had a TEC of 21.3 × 10 −6 K −1 in the temperature range of 200–900 °C. Overall, there was no direct correlation between the compositions and the TECs of the SSCx samples. For x = 0.2–0.6, in the low temperature range (200–Tt °C, Tt: transition temperature), the dilatometric behavior was linear and all of the TECs were lower than 20 × 10 −6 K −1 . However, between Tt and 900 °C, the TEC values were all higher than 20 × 10 −6 K −1 for various SSCx oxides, which are remarkably larger values compared to those in the low temperature range. The expansion behavior for these two temperature ranges can be attributed to two different mechanisms. In the low temperature range, the intrinsic thermal expansion is mainly due to atomic vibrations of the lattice associated with the surrounding temperature. In the high temperature range, in addition to the intrinsic thermal expansion, another contribution to the volume expansion is caused by oxygen loss from the structure with the creation of oxygen vacancies. This mechanism is commonly called chemical-induced expansion. The thermal reductions of the Co cation from the high valence state of Co 4+ to the lower trivalent state of Co 3+ or Co 3+ to Co 2+ can be described according to the defect reaction as follows: (4) 2 C o Co + O O x ⇔ 2 C o Co x + V O + 1 2 O 2 (5) 2 C o Co x + O O x ⇔ 2 C o ′ Co + V O + 1 2 O 2 As the temperature increases, more oxygen vacancies are formed and the reduction of Co 4+ to Co 3+ or Co 3+ to Co 2+ takes place. In this study, the thermal reduction of cobalt ions led to an increase in the ionic radius of the cobalt ions. In addition, the reductions cause a decrease in the length of B–O bond according to Pauling's second rule, and hence the size of the BO 6 octahedra increases, thus enhancing the lattice expansion [47] . 3.3 Electrical conductivity As a potential SOFCs cathode, it is preferable for the electrical conductivity of the material to be above 100 S cm −1 [48] . Insufficient electrical conductivity may introduce large transfer resistance, especially under a large polarization current. Owing to the co-presence of electronic holes and oxygen vacancies, SSCx oxides possess mixed electronic and ionic conductivities at elevated temperatures. However, the electronic conductivity is much larger than the ionic conductivity (by more than three orders of magnitude). Therefore, the values measured using the four-probe DC conductivity technique can be treated solely as the electronic conductivity. Fig. 3 shows the electrical conductivity of SSCx oxides in air and nitrogen atmospheres between 300 and 900 °C. As shown in Fig. 3 a, under an air atmosphere, SSC6 had the highest electrical conductivity. This was followed by SSC5, which showed a conductivity value slightly lower than for SSC6. For example, the maximum values were 1885 and 1731 S cm −1 for SSC6 and SSC5, respectively. SSC8 showed the lowest electrical conductivity among the others SSCx materials analyzed with a maximum value of only 370 S cm −1 . For all SSCx oxides under investigation, except SSC8, the electrical conductivity was found to decrease gradually with increasing temperature, which could result from the metallic-like conduction behavior of the oxides in air. On the other hand, two electron holes were eliminated for each oxygen ion leaving the lattice (as shown in Eq. (4) ), resulting in a reduction in electronic conductivity. Thus the decrease in oxygen stoichimetry (3 − δ ) with increasing temperature can also produce the decrease in conductivity due to the reduction in electron hole concentration. For SSC8, the electrical conductivity first increased with temperature, reaching a maximum value at 630 °C, and then decreased with further increases in temperature. This unique behavior in electrical conductivity is obviously closely related to the different oxygen desorption properties observed for SSC8 compared to the other SSCx materials analyzed, as demonstrated by O 2 -TPD. Fig. 3 b shows the electrical conductivity of the various SSCx oxides in a nitrogen atmosphere. A reduced conductivity was observed in nitrogen compared to the results found in air. This indicates that a P-type electron conducting mechanism occurred (i.e., the electron conduction was created by an electron hopping between Co 3+ and Co 4+ ), which agrees well with the >3+ average oxidation states of the cobalt ions in SSCx oxides when under an air atmosphere, as shown in Table 1 . The electrical conductivity of all SSCx oxides in a nitrogen atmosphere gradually increased with temperature. SSC5 showed the highest conductivity among the analyzed SSCx materials with a value of 176 and 436 S cm −1 at 300 and 900 °C, respectively. Overall, all of the investigated SSCx oxides ( x = 0.2–0.8) demonstrated sufficient electrical conductivities for their application as SOFC electrodes. 3.4 Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy The oxygen reduction performances of the various SSCx electrodes on SDC electrolytes were first investigated by EIS analysis based on a symmetric cell configuration. To gain a reasonable comparison, all of the SDC electrolytes were polished to the same thickness of ∼0.6 mm, and the electrodes were controlled to the same thickness of 28 μm by adjusting the spray time. In addition, all of the symmetric cells were fired at 1000 °C for 2 h in air to minimize the difference in electrode microstructure for various SSCx materials. Fig. 4 shows typical SEM micrographs of the SSCx electrodes (SSC6 and SSC5) on the SDC electrolyte from a cross-sectional view. The electrodes showed similar microstructure and thicknesses as expected. The oxygen electrochemical reduction performance of the electrode, including the gas phase diffusion, surface adsorption, dissociation, charge transfer and incorporation of oxygen ion into the electrode, can be quantitatively evaluated by the area specific resistance (ASR) as follows: (6) ASR   ( Ω   c m 2 ) = R cathode × A 2 ( symmetry ) where R cathode is the polarization resistance of the electrode, which can be calculated from the distance between the low-frequency and the high-frequency intercepts of the semicircle at the real axis from the EIS, and A is the effective area of the electrode. The ASR values of the SSCx electrodes as a function of temperature are shown in Fig. 5 . In this analysis, SSC5 showed the best electrode performance of the materials studied, yielding an ASR of only 0.42 Ω cm 2 at 600 °C. Beak et al. have reported that an SSC5 electrode sintered at 1200 °C for 1 h had a high ASR of 0.87 Ω cm 2 at 600 °C [48] , which is more than two times the value of our result. A possible explanation for this difference is that the lower sintering temperature utilized in our study ensured a higher electrode porosity and weaker interfacial reaction between the electrode and the SDC electrolyte. As shown in Fig. 4 , the electrodes were highly porous, and no obvious interfacial layer was formed between the SSCx electrodes and the SDC electrolyte. Based on the Arrhenius equation, the activation energies of the oxygen electrochemical reduction for the various SSCx electrodes were also calculated, yielding values of 1.33, 1.17, 1.14, 1.38 and 1.36 eV for x = 0.2, 0.4, 0.5, 0.6 and 0.8, respectively. The lowest Ea observed for SSC5, among the SSCx series, has also been reported by other researchers for the SDC electrolyte [48] . Impedance measurements were performed as a function of oxygen partial pressure to study the oxygen reduction reaction that occurred on the SSC5 electrode. Fig. 6 shows the Nyquist impedance curves of the SSC5 electrode measured at 600 °C at various oxygen partial pressures. The electrode polarization resistance (Rp) value increased from 0.28 to 0.61 Ω cm 2 with the decrease of P O 2 from 1.0 to 0.04 atm. No additional impedance arc was found at the low frequency range, even under the 0.04 atm oxygen partial pressure. This suggests the absence of concentration polarization resistance owing to the well-constructed microstructure of the electrode (as shown in Fig. 4 ) The observed, separable impedance arcs at low and high frequencies suggest that at least two different electrode processes limited the oxygen reduction reaction. However, it is difficult to separate surface and bulk processes because the processes on porous electrodes are complicated [49] . It is worthy to be further studied to investigate the rate-limiting step of porous SSC5 cathode. 3.5 Cathodic overpotential Cathodic overpotential may be a good parameter for describing the performance of an electrode in a real fuel cell under polarization. The IR-corrected Tafel plots for the SSC cathode at 600 °C in air are shown in Fig. 7 . The exchange current density ( i 0 ) which directly reflects the intrinsic electrocatalytic activity can be obtained from the Butler–Volmer equation: (8) i = i 0 exp α a F η R T − exp − α c F η R T where n is the total number of transferred electrons passed in the reaction, η is the cathodic overpotential, α c is the cathodic coefficient, F is the Faraday constant, R is the gas constant and T is the absolute temperature. In a high-field overpotential, the anodic reaction is reasonably ignored and i 0 can be obtained from the y -intercept of a plot of log i versus η . Thus, i 0 can be calculated according to the following equation: (9) Log   i = Log   i 0 − α c n F 2.303 R T η The value of α c can be calculated by: (10) α c = γ υ + r β where γ is the number of electrons transferred before the rate limiting step, r is the number of electrons transferred during the rate limiting step and β is the symmetry coefficient (normally assumed to be 0.5). SSC2 was found to have the smallest i 0 , yielding a value of 8 mA cm −2 at 600 °C, while SSC5 showed the highest i 0 of 60 mA cm −2 at 600 °C. The i 0 values of the SSCx oxides with x = 0.4, 0.6 and 0.8 were similar, yielding values of approximately 40 mA cm −2 . This trend agrees well with the ASRs obtained based on the symmetric two-electrode test. The cathodic overpotential of the SSC5 cathode at various temperatures in air was further measured and the IR-corrected Tafel plots at various temperatures are shown in Fig. 8 . As expected, the cathodic overpotential decreased with temperature, suggesting that the electrochemical activity was improved with operation temperature. The polarization overpotential was −200 mV for the SSC5 electrode with the current densities of −243, −134, −56 and −27 mA cm −2 at 650, 600, 550 and 500 °C in air, respectively. However, the i 0 decreased from 90 to 19 mA cm −2 when the temperature was decreased from 650 and 500 °C. 4 Conclusions The Sm content had a significant effect on the oxygen nonstoichiometry, oxygen desorption, thermal expansion behavior, electrical conductivity and electrochemical activity for the oxygen reduction of Sm x Sr 1 − x CoO 3 − δ (SSCx, 0.2 ≤ x ≤ 0.8) oxides. Because of the higher valence state of Sm 3+ than Sr 2+ , the substitution of Sm 3+ with Sr 2+ would lead to an increase in the oxidation state of the cobalt ion or the creation of an oxygen vacancy. Iodometric titration analysis demonstrated that the former predominated at high samarium contents ( x ≥ 0.6) and the latter took over at low samarium content ( x ≤ 0.5). O 2 -TPD analysis demonstrated that the SSC5 had the highest oxygen desorption ability among all of the SSCx compositions studied. The formation of oxygen vacancies and the increase in cobalt oxidation state are sufficient to explain the transition in the dilatomertric curves at 420–590 °C of SSCx with x = 0.2–0.6. Chemical-induced expansion was the source of the high TECs found for the SSCx, which yielded values typically larger than 20 × 10 −6 K −1 between the transition temperature and 900 °C. All SSCx oxides showed high electrical conductivity values that are suitable for fuel cell electrode applications. In particular, dense SSC6 and SSC5 had the highest electrical conductivities in air and nitrogen, yielding values of 1885 and 436 S cm −1 , respectively. In addition, SSC5 showed the best electrochemical performance, with area specific resistance as low as 0. 42 Ω cm 2 at 600 °C and a low activation energy of 1.16 eV. SSC5 also had the highest exchange current density, with a value of 60 mA cm −2 at 600 °C. SSC5 was found to be the optimal material among the SSCx series for an oxygen reduction electrode on doped ceria electrolytes. r9aH88Yb.title: A novel efficient oxide electrode for electrocatalytic oxygen reduction at 400-600°C
r9aH88Yb.abstract: A novel SrNb 0.1Co 0.9O 3-δ electrode material, which possesses not only high electrical conductivity but also large oxygen vacancy concentration at 400-600°C, shows an excellent performance in the application of reduced temperature solid-oxide fuel cells. © The Royal Society of Chemistry.
