5iHogPR7.title: Assessment of Ba0.5Sr0.5Co1-yFeyO3-δ (y = 0.0-1.0) for prospective application as cathode for IT-SOFCs or oxygen permeating membrane
5iHogPR7.abstract: The influence of iron doping level in Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 1− y Fe y O 3− δ ( y = 0.0–1.0) (BSCF) oxides on their phase structure, oxygen nonstoichiometry, electrical conductivity, performance as symmetrical cell electrode and oxygen permeating membranes was systematically investigated. A cubic perovskite structure was observed for all the compositions with the presence of iron. The increase of iron doping level resulted in the decrease of the lattice constant, room-temperature oxygen nonstoichiometry, total electrical conductivity, and the increase of area specific resistance (ASR) as cathode with samaria doped ceria electrolyte. However, promising cathode performance with an ASR as low as 0.613 Ω cm 2 was still obtained at 600 °C for Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 FeO 3− δ (BSF). The ceramic membranes composing of BSCF with various iron doping level are all oxygen semi-permeable at elevated temperatures. The increase of iron doping level resulted in the decrease of oxygen permeation flux from J O 2 = 2.28 μmol cm −2 s −1 (STP) for Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ (BSCF5582) to ∼0.45 μmol cm −2 s −1 (STP) at 900 °C for BSF ( y = 1.0) with the same membrane thickness of 1.1 mm, alongside with the change of the rate-determination step from the oxygen surface exchange to the slow oxygen bulk diffusion. The formation of composite oxide with a proper electronic conducting phase and the thin film technology are important for their prospective application as cathode in IT-SOFCs and oxygen permeating membrane, respectively. Keywords BSCF Mixed conducting Ceramic membrane Cathode SOFCs 1 Introduction Mixed ionic and electronic conducting (MIEC) composite oxides are of increasing interest as ceramic membranes for oxygen production from air and electrode materials of reduced temperature solid-oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) for power generation [1–10] . The ceramic membranes based on mixed conducting oxides allow oxygen to permeate through with infinite oxygen selectivity under the drive of oxygen partial pressure difference across the membrane. Substantial reduction in capital cost of oxygen production for both plant construction and operation is envisaged by this novel membrane process as compared to traditional techniques such as the distillation of cryogenic air. On the other hand, the cathodes based on mixed conducting oxide can effectively extend the oxygen reduction site from the typical electrode–electrolyte-gas triple phase boundary to the entire exposed cathode surface, thus greatly reducing the cathode polarization at lower operation temperatures. The reduced operation temperature of SOFCs has several benefits such as increased operation life time and reduced fabrication/raw material cost. One group of perovskite materials, such as LaFeO 3− δ (1273 K, 10 −12 Pa) [7] , LaGa 0.65 Mg 0.15 Ni 0.2 O 3− δ (1223 K, 9.5 × 10 −10 Pa) [8] , SrFe 0.7 Al 0.3 O 3− δ (1100 K, 10 −14 Pa) [9] and Sr 0.7 Ce 0.3 MnO 3− δ (1223 K, 2 × 10 −9 Pa) [10] , have been extensively investigated due to their high oxygen ionic and electronic conductivities at elevated temperatures as well as their structural stability in both oxidizing and reducing atmospheres, where the quantity between brackets indicates the phase stability limits. Among many perovskite-type mixed conducting oxides, the Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ (BSCF5582) composite has received considerable attentions in recent years [11–20] . It was first reported by Shao et al. as an oxygen permeating membrane material, developed by a 50% substitution of Sr 2+ in SrCo 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ with a larger size cation of Ba 2+ [11,12] . High oxygen permeation flux and favorable phase stability were reported for this material [11,12] . Very recently, Shao et al. also proposed the application of BSCF5582 as a cathode material for intermediate temperature SOFCs with promising performances [21,22] . On the other hand, the BSCF5582 oxide has two main drawbacks including high thermal expansion coefficient (TEC) and low chemical stability. A thermal expansion coefficient of ∼24 × 10 −6 K −1 was reported [23] . Both the high TEC and low chemical stability are closely related with the high cobalt concentration in the structure. Cobalt ions are easily reduced by a reducing atmosphere. On the other hand, iron may be another most popular compositional metal ion in the B-site of perovskite. The LaFeO 3− δ is much more stable as compared to LaCoO 3− δ [7] , which indicates that iron ion has a much higher chemical stability in a/the perovskite structure under the same conditions. The other benefit of having iron ion in perovskite is the reduced thermal expansion coefficient. A steady decrease in TEC was observed with the increase of iron doping concentration in La 0.8 Sr 0.2 Co 1− y Fe y O 3− δ [24] . The modification of BSCF structure with other metal ions and their application as oxygen permeating membrane and cathode of SOFCs have been well studied [25–27] . However, there are little published results about the effect of iron doping concentration on the properties of BSCF. In this study, Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 1− y Fe y O 3− δ (BSCF, y = 0–1.0) with varied iron concentration ( y = 0.0–1.0) was synthesized by a sol–gel method. The influence of Fe/Co ratio in BSCF on the properties of the oxides was investigated. Their performance as ceramic oxygen permeating membranes and symmetrical cell electrodes was systematically studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 1− y Fe y O 3− δ powders were synthesized through a combined citrate and EDTA complexing method. Appropriate amounts of Ba(NO 3 ) 2 , Sr(NO 3 ) 2 , Co(NO 3 ) 2 ·6H 2 O and Fe(NO 3 ) 3 ·6H 2 O (analytical grades) were used as the raw materials for metal source. The details for the synthesis of materials can be found elsewhere [11] . The disk-shaped membranes to be used in the oxygen permeation test were prepared by uni-axial pressing with 280 MPa. The green disks were sintered at 1100 °C for 5 h in air at a heating/cooling rate of 5 °C min −1 . The sintered membranes had a diameter of ∼14 mm and were polished to the thickness of about 1.1 mm. The membranes had a relative density greater than 95% as measured by the Archimedes method. 2.2 Characterization The crystal structure of synthesized powders was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 Advance) using Cu Kα 1 radiation. The lattice parameters of the powders were calculated using the UnitCell program [28] . The oxygen nonstoichiometry at room temperature was measured by the iodometry titration technique. The oxygen nonstoichiometry under various atmospheres at high temperature was determined by the TGA process using a NETZSCH STA 409 thermal gravity analyzer. The samples were obtained from calcination at the aimed temperature for 5 h at a heating rate of 5 °C min −1 in air, and the TGA test was performed to the samples immediately after they cooled down to room temperature from calcination. No annealing was conducted in order to ensure identical conditions for the TGA measurements and iodometry titration. The electrical conductivity was measured by the four-probe DC method on sintered bars of BSCF. The measurements were performed under a heating condition and a cooling condition under different atmospheres of oxygen, air and argon, respectively. The cooling process decreased the temperature from 900 to 300 °C at an interval of 5 °C per step. At each temperature step, the stabilization time was 2 min; the heating process was performed from 300 to 900 °C also at 5 °C per step in every test with the same stabilization time. Very close results were obtained from the two processes, with the largest discrepancies between the conductivity values no larger than 2%. Silver paste was painted on the edges of the sample to form current and voltage electrodes. Two silver wires acted as current contacts and another two, acting as voltage contacts, were attached to the electrodes using silver paste. A constant current was applied to the two current wires and the voltage response on the two voltage wires were recorded using a Keithley 2420 sourcemeter. The current was increased from 1 μA to a maximum value of 2 A. The conductivity was calculated based on the following equation: σ = L A × K where A is the cross-sectional area, L the length and K is the slope of the curve of current versus voltage. 2.3 Symmetrical cell electrode tests The cathode performance of Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 1− y Fe y O 3− δ powders with SDC electrolyte was investigated by the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) technique based on the symmetrical cell configuration. The Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 1− y Fe y O 3− δ slurry was prepared by mixing the powders in an organic solvent, which was then spray-deposited on both surfaces of SDC pellet with a thickness of about 10 μm. Then the cell was calcined at 1000 °C for 2 h in air to obtain a symmetrical cell with porous electrodes. Silver paste was coated on both surfaces of the cell as the current collector. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy was tested by Solartron SI 1287 + 1260. 2.4 Oxygen permeation test The oxygen permeation flux measurements were performed with a gas chromatograph method. Membranes were sealed with a silver paste onto the quartz support tube. The sidewall of the membrane disk was also covered with the sealant to avoid leakage and radial contribution to the oxygen flux. Ambient air was used as the feed gas (oxygen rich side atmosphere) and helium with a flow rate of 100 ml min −1 (STP) as the sweep gas (oxygen lean side atmosphere). A gas chromatograph (CP 3800, Varian) was used to analyze the outlet gas. The oxygen permeation flux was calculated by J O 2 ( mol   c m − 2   s − 1 , STP ) = C O − C N × 0.21 0.79 × 28 32 1 / 2 × F S where C O and C N are the measured concentrations of oxygen and nitrogen in the gas on the sweep side, respectively, F the flow rate of the exit gas on the sweep side, and S is the membrane geometric surface area of the sweep side (cm 2 ). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Phase structure and oxygen nonstoichiometry The room-temperature X-ray diffraction patterns of the sol–gel synthesized Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 1− y Fe y O 3− δ (BSCF) oxides with y = 0.0–1.0 are shown in Fig. 1 . The perovskite structure was formed for the iron-doping concentrations from 0.2 to 1.0. The XRD pattern of Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 CoO 3− δ (BSC, y = 0) could be indexed using an oxygen vacancy-ordered 2-H type hexagonal perovskite structure, while an oxygen vacancy-disordered cubic perovskite structure, space group Pm 3 m , was formed for all other compositions. On the other hand, the air-calcined SrFeO 3− δ and BaFeO 3− δ oxides, prepared by parallel experiments under synthesis conditions similar to BSF, displayed oxygen vacancy-ordered tetragonal and rhombohedral structures, respectively. It suggests that the mixed doping at both the A-site and B-site was important to maintain the oxygen-vacancy disordered structure of the oxides. It was proposed that the mixed doping disrupted the uniform periodic potential required to form ordered structures [29] . The increase of the iron doping level led to the shift of the corresponding diffraction peaks to higher diffraction angles as shown in Fig. 1 . The calculated lattice constant for various iron concentrations is shown in Fig. 2 . A decrease of lattice constant ( a ) with the increase of iron concentration was observed, opposite to the case of La 0.8 Sr 0.2 Co 1− y Fe y O 3− δ [24] . Since Ba 2+ and Sr 2+ took the fixed valence state (2+) in perovskite, the lattice constant for BSCF was mainly determined by the radius of the B-site ions. Cobalt and iron can both take multi-valence states at the B-site of the perovskite, and iron has a larger ionic radius than cobalt at the same valence state [30] . Therefore, iron should take a higher average valence state than cobalt in BSCF oxides. This assumption is supported by the room-temperature oxygen nonstoichiometry of the oxides as shown in Table 1 . Generally, the higher the iron content, the smaller the nonstoichiometry observed for the BSCF oxides ( y = 0.0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8) from two calcination temperatures measured by the iodometry techniques. Mixed conducting oxides are capable of oxygen uptake and release from their lattice during heating and cooling processes, which is closely related to the lattice expansion/shrinkage and oxygen nonstoichiometry of the oxides. The lattice expansion associated with the oxygen release can be attributed to: (1) the repulsion force arising between those mutually exposed cations when oxygen ions are released from the lattice; (2) the increase in cation size due to the reduction of Fe and Co ions (for BSCF) from a higher to a lower valence state, which occurs simultaneously with the release of oxygen from lattice in order to maintain the electrical neutrality. The release or uptake of oxygen also results in the change of oxygen nonstoichiometry of the oxides, which may have significant influence on the cathode performance or oxygen permeation behavior of the membrane made of the materials. TGA measurements were then performed in order to accurately measure the oxygen nonstoichiometry of BSCF at elevated temperatures. As shown in Fig. 3 , all the materials with different iron concentrations started to lose weight at a temperature around 400 °C. The weight loss was associated with the oxygen release from the lattice as detected by the temperature programmed desorption (TPD) experiment using a Mass Spectroscopy (Hiden QIC-20). It suggests the lattice oxygen starts to be active at a temperature of ∼400 °C. As a whole, the higher the iron concentration the larger the weight loss observed. A weight loss as large as ∼2.5% was observed for selected BSCF oxides with a high iron concentration. Although a larger oxygen release was observed for BSCF at the higher iron concentration, the smaller starting nonstoichiometry resulted in the final oxygen nonstoichiometry at high temperature for different materials without a big difference. 3.2 Total electrical conductivity For any potential candidate for cathode of SOFCs or material of ceramic oxygen permeating membrane, a high electrical conductivity is important, since a low electronic conductivity may result in a poor current-collecting efficiency and a large ohmic resistance of cathode in SOFCs. For oxygen permeating membranes, it is well established that the oxygen permeation flux though a mixed conducting membrane can be expressed as J O 2 = − R T / 4 2 F 2 L ∫ ln ⁡ P ′ O 2 ln ⁡ P ″ O 2 ( σ ion σ el ) / ( σ ion + σ el ) d [ ln ⁡ P O 2 ] under the condition of the bulk transport process as the rate-determining step. Therefore, high electronic and ionic conductivities are also important to oxygen permeability of the membrane based on the equation. Fig. 4 shows the temperature dependence of the total electrical conductivity of BSCF with y = 0–1.0 measured in an oxygen, air and argon atmosphere, respectively. For the cases of air and pure oxygen, the conductivity of all the samples with different iron concentrations experienced a first increase with temperature, reaching a maximum, and then a decrease with further increased in operation temperature. The maximum electrical conductivity was reached at around 400 °C for most of the samples. Together with the TGA results in Fig. 3 , the decrease in electrical conductivity at temperatures higher than 400 °C was closely related to the release of lattice oxygen from the oxides. The release of oxygen resulted in the increase of oxygen vacancy concentration. Since oxygen vacancy is the carrier for oxygen ion and since it is a well-known fact that oxygen vacancy diffusion rate increases with temperature, an increase in ionic conductivity with temperature should be expected. The decrease of total conductivity with the increase of operation temperature at T > 400 °C was therefore attributed to the decrease of electronic conductivity, which is generally believed to be caused by the hopping of small polarons associated with the tetravalent state of the iron and cobalt cations. The release of oxygen from BSCF lattice changes the relative concentrations of various valence states of cobalt and iron ions, and therefore affects the electronic conductivity. Under the more reducing atmosphere of argon ( P O 2 ≈ 10 −5 atm), the conductivity displayed a monotonous increase with temperature. The increase of conductivity with the increase of oxygen partial pressure demonstrated the p-type conductivity mechanism for all the BSCF samples with varied iron concentrations. As a whole, the higher the iron doping level is, the lower the conductivity is. It agrees well with the fact that the mobility of p-type carrier of iron is much lower than that of cobalt. The same trend of decreasing electrical conductivity with the increase of iron concentration was also observed in the system of La 0.8 Sr 0.2 Co 1− y Fe y O 3− δ [24] . A maximum conductivity of ∼40 S cm −1 was reached for BSCF5582 at ∼450 °C under air, which is substantially lower than that of the La 0.8 Sr 0.2 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ oxide with the same composition at the B-site of perovskite (∼1000 S cm −1 ) [24] . For the mixed-conducting perovskite via the doping strategy such as BSCF and LSCF, in order to maintain charge neutrality, the A-site acceptor dopant (Ba 2+ , Sr 2+ ) should be compensated through either one or both of the following ways: (1) electronic compensation by the conversion of the B-site ions to a higher valence state, such as Fe 3+ /Co 3+ to Fe 4+ /Co 4+ , (2) and/or ionic compensation by the formation of oxygen vacancies. Based on the oxygen nonstoichiometry and the electrical conductivity data, BSCF preferred the charge neutrality compensation via the creation of oxygen vacancies as compared with LSCF. A higher oxygen vacancy concentration means more carriers for oxygen ion transport; therefore, a higher oxygen ionic conductivity is expected for BSCF than LSCF. The high oxygen ionic conductivity then ensures the high oxygen permeability of the membrane and the improved cathode performance. 3.3 Cathode performance BSCF5582 has been reported to deliver very promising cathode performances at intermediate temperatures with the SDC-based electrolyte in SOFCs [21,22] . The high cathode performance originated from the high oxygen ionic conductivity and surface exchange kinetics of the oxide [21] . The effect of iron doping level in BSCF on the cathode performance with SDC electrolyte was investigated by the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) technique based on the symmetrical cell configuration. Due to the low electrical conductivity of BSCF at high iron concentrations, silver paste was applied as the current collector for all the samples. It is worth noticing that the Ag particles played an important role in the improvement of cathode performance, which not only served as the current collector. The reasons are as follows. First of all, partial melting and volatilization of Ag are expected in the course of sintering. Second, oxygen incorporation into Ag under both anodic and catholic conditions leads to the formation of Ag–O solution with a low melting point. These factors may both lead to Ag penetration into the electrode layer and lead to direct contact between BSCF and Ag particles. Also, it is well known that Ag can absorb O 2 on its surface and let them dissolve into it. In addition, Ag particles can improve the electron supply through a porous structure. Based on these reasons, Ag helped to improve the cathode performance in this study. The as-synthesized BSCF powder was prepared into slurry and spray-deposited onto the both surfaces of SDC pellets with a thickness of ∼10 μm. The obtained cells were then calcined in a static air atmosphere at 1000 °C for 2 h to result in the symmetrical cell with well-attached porous BSCF layers. Figs. 5 and 6 shows the complex plane-plot of impedance spectra at 600 °C and the temperature dependence of the area specific resistances (ASRs) of BSCF at various iron doping levels, respectively. The impedance spectra were evaluated using an equivalent circuit with a configuration of LR ohm ( RQ ) HF ( RQ ) LF , where R ohm is the overall ohmic resistances including the electrolyte resistance, electrode ohmic resistance and lead resistance. L is the inductance, which could be due to the Ag current/voltage probes or the high frequency phase shift of electrochemical equipments. R is a resistance, Q a constant phase element, and the subscripts “HF” and “LF” represent the respective high- and low-frequency contributions. The difference between realaxes intercepts of the impedance plot is considered to be the electrode polarization resistance ( R p ). An increase in the ASRs was observed with the increase of iron concentration in BSCF. For example, an ASR value of 0.085, 0.13, 0.166, 0.3612, and 0.613 Ω cm 2 was observed at 600 °C for BSCF with y = 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0, respectively. A corresponding increase of the activation energy was also observed, with a value of 106.0, 120.2, 121.7, 123.8, and 139.5 kJ mol −1 for y = 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0, respectively. It suggests that cobalt is more beneficial than iron for oxygen electrochemical reduction. Anyway, BSF ( y = 1.0) still showed very promising cathode performance for oxygen reduction at intermediate temperatures. Although the decrease in the performance for oxygen reduction at reduced temperature was compared to BSCF5582, the increased chemical stability and low cost of iron than cobalt makes BSCF with high iron concentration, for example BSCF5528, a highly attractive candidate as cathode for IT-SOFCs. However, due to its poor electronic conductivity, the formation of composite cathode with a high electronic conductive phase, such as Ag, is critical for its application in SOFCs in order to reduce the ohmic polarization and improvement of current collecting efficiency. The long-term performance for SOFC was tested by symmetric cell configuration, and also in real complete fuel cell condition. A stable operation was observed for the symmetric cell configuration, while a stable slow decrease of the power density and open circuit voltage was observed based on the complete cell configuration. Due to the hydrogen embrittlement for silver under hydrogen atmosphere, many micro pores had formed over the sealant, which led to the increased hydrogen leakage with time and thus accounting to the decrease of power density for the tested SOFC. A better sealing material is necessary for future long-term stability test based on the complete fuel cell configuration. The influence of Ag paste on the cathode performance will be studied in our future work. 3.4 Oxygen permeation properties Besides the potential application as the cathode material in IT-SOFCs, another promising application of mixed-conducting oxides is as oxygen semi-permeable membrane. Fig. 7 shows the temperature dependence of oxygen permeation fluxes through various BSCF membranes with different iron concentrations. The experiments were conducted with the one side of membrane surface exposed to ambient air and the other side of membrane surface swept with a constant helium flow of 100 ml min −1 (STP). It was found that the permeation flux decreased steadily with the increase of iron concentration. However, the difference of oxygen permeation fluxes between the membranes with y = 0.2, 0.4 and 0.6, or y = 0.8 and 1.0 was much smaller than that between y = 0.6 and 0.8. A sharp decrease in the permeation flux was observed for BSCF membranes with the increase of iron concentration from y = 0.6 to 0.8. A permeation flux as high as 2.28 μmol cm −2 s −1 (STP) was reached for BSCF5582 ( y = 0.2) at 900 °C, comparable to the value reported in literature [31] with a similar precious metal sealing. While it reached only ∼0.45 μmol cm −2 s −1 (STP) for BSF ( y = 1.0) under similar operation conditions. As mentioned above, Ag can absorb O 2 on its surface and let it dissolve into it. But the oxygen transport rate through Ag membrane is relatively low compared to BSCF [32] , so its influence is negligible. Ag paste can enhance the electron transport through the surface of BSCF, which may improve the oxygen permeation flux. Oxygen permeation through conducting membrane is a complex process, which involves the oxygen adsorption and dissociation at the feed side membrane surface, the diffusion of oxygen ion through bulk of the membrane from the high oxygen partial pressure membrane surface to the opposite membrane surface and the re-combination of oxygen ion into molecular oxygen and desorption into the gas atmosphere. Both the oxygen bulk diffusion and the oxygen surface exchange at both or either side of the two membrane surfaces could be the rate-limiting step in oxygen permeation process. The investigation of oxygen partial pressure dependence of permeation flux has been applied to get the information of the rate-determination step in the permeation process [33] . Under the control of bulk diffusion and the overwhelming electronic conductivity, the permeation flux through a mixed conducing membrane can be expressed by: (1) J O 2 = − R T 4 2 F 2 L ⋅ ∫ ln ⁡ P ′ O 2 ln ⁡ P ″ O 2 σ ion ⋅ d ln ⁡ [ P O 2 ] = a [ ( P ′ O 2 ) n − ( P ″ O 2 ) n ] where P ′ O 2 and P ″ O 2 are the oxygen partial pressures at the feed side and sweep side atmosphere, respectively, and n is the power coefficient, indicating the creation speed of oxygen vacancy with the change of ambient oxygen partial pressure. The P O 2 dependence of experimental permeation flux usually can also be well fitted to this equation at the condition of surface-limiting or a mixed bulk diffusion-surface exchange limiting of the permeation process. Since the oxygen ionic conductivity increases with the decrease of oxygen partial pressure due to the increase of oxygen vacancy concentration, a negative value of n should be observed under the oxygen bulk diffusion control of the permeation process. A positive value of derived n may suggest the rate determination by the slow oxygen surface exchange kinetics or a combined surface exchange-bulk diffusion process [33] . Fig. 8 shows the dependence of oxygen partial pressure on oxygen permeation flux through BSCF membranes on the sweep side with different iron concentration ( y = 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1.0) with air being the feed-side atmosphere ( P ′ O 2 = 0.21 atm). A steady increase of the permeation flux with the decrease of oxygen partial pressure at the sweep side ( P ″ O 2 ) was observed for all the composition. The dependence of oxygen partial pressure on permeation flux can be well fitted to Eq. (1) . The derived values for a and n at various P ″ O 2 ranges for various BSCF membranes are listed in Table 2 . The change of n from positive at y = 0.4 to negative at y = 0.2 was observed, which strongly suggests that a change in the rate-determination step in oxygen permeation process happened simultaneously. It was reported that the oxygen permeation through BSCF5582 was mainly rate-determined by the relatively slow surface exchange kinetics at the sweep-side membrane surface [33] . The rate limited by the slow oxygen bulk diffusion of the permeation process through BSCF5528 membrane was then proposed based on the negative value of n . If the oxygen permeation through a conducting membrane was rate-determined mainly by the slow surface exchange kinetics, the surface modification with a porous layer of oxide with much higher surface exchange kinetics than the membrane itself would result in a sharp increase of the permeation flux. However, if it is mainly rate-limited by the slow oxygen bulk diffusion, no significant increase in permeation flux would be observed via the surface modification. BSCF5582 was reported to have very a high oxygen bulk diffusion rate and oxygen surface exchange rate [21] . The high surface exchange rate is supported by the low cathode polarization resistance as shown in Figs. 5 and 6 in this study. Therefore, a porous layer of BSCF5582 was deposited onto the surface of BSCF5528 membrane by the spray-deposition technique to investigate the influence of surface modification on the oxygen permeation behavior of BSCF5528 membrane. Fig. 9 shows the oxygen permeation fluxes through the BSCF5528 membranes at 900 °C and the condition with and without the surface modification by porous BSCF5582. It shows that the oxygen permeation flux was only slightly improved for the surface modified ones as compared to those without the porous layer. It suggests that the permeation process through BSCF5528 was mainly rate-limited by the slow oxygen bulk diffusion. Therefore, in order to increase the oxygen permeation flux through BSCF membrane with high iron concentration (for example BSCF5528), the thin film membrane technology should be applied. Based on the results in Fig. 9 , the oxygen surface exchange over the air-side membrane surface had relatively more importance in the rate-limiting step than that of the sweep-side membrane surface. This is significantly different from the case of BSCF5582 [33] . The results shown in Figs. 5, 6, 8 and 9 suggest that the increase of iron concentration in BSCF has a more significant influence on the oxygen bulk diffusion rate than the surface exchange kinetics of the oxides. 4 Conclusions The iron doping concentration has a significant effect on the lattice constant, oxygen nonstoichiometry, and electrical conductivity of Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 1− y Fe y O 3− δ oxides. The iron ion has a higher average valence state than the cobalt ion in BSCF, which resulted in the decrease of the lattice constant of the cubic perovskite structure and the oxygen nonstoichiometry with the increase of the iron concentration. All BSCF oxides with different iron concentrations demonstrated the p-type electrical conductivity. The increase in iron concentration resulted in the decrease of electrical conductivity. Favorable cathode performance was observed for BSCF oxide even at high iron concentrations, although an increase in the area specific resistance was observed with the increase of iron doping level. The ceramic membranes made of BSCF resulted in a high oxygen permeation flux with a maximum value of 2.28 μmol cm −2 s −1 (STP) at 900 °C under a helium sweep rate of 100 ml min −1 (STP) for BSCF5582. The increase of iron concentration in BSCF had a more significant influence on the decrease of the oxygen bulk diffusion rate than the surface exchange kinetics of the oxides, which resulted in a change of the rate-determination step of oxygen permeation process from the slow oxygen surface exchange to the slow oxygen bulk diffusion with the increase of the iron doping concentration. The formation of composite oxide with a proper electronic conducting phase and the thin film technology are important for the BSCF oxide with a high iron concentration as cathode in IT-SOFCs and oxygen permeating membranes, respectively. BJUy34RG.title: A Comparative Structure and Performance Study of La[sub 1−x]Sr[sub x]CoO[sub 3−d] and La[sub 1−x]Sr[sub x]Co[sub 0.9]Nb[sub 0.1]O[sub 3−d] (x=0.5, 0.7, 0.9, and 1.0) Oxygen Permeable Mixed Conductors

wsqSqZNd.title: Properties and performance of A-site deficient (Ba0.5Sr0.5)1-xCo0.8Fe0.2O3-δ for oxygen permeating membrane
wsqSqZNd.abstract: (Ba0.5Sr0.5)1-xCo0.8Fe0.2O3-δ (BSCF) (x = 0-0.3) oxides were prepared by a combined EDTA-citrate complexing method. The crystal structure, electrical conductivity, sintering behavior and oxygen desorption property of the oxides were studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD), four-probe direct current (DC) conductivity, environmental scanning electron microscopy (ESEM) and oxygen temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) technologies, respectively. At x = 0.0-0.15, BSCF had a cubic perovskite structure, the lattice parameter and electrical conductivity both decreased steadily with increasing A-site deficiency. The A-site deficiency resulted in the increasing oxygen vacancy concentration in the lattice structure and improved the sintering of the oxides. BSCF (x = 0.03) showed the highest oxygen permeability with the flux reaching 3.5 × 10-6 mol cm-2 s-1 [STP: standard temperature and pressure] at 900 °C through a 1.0 mm thickness membrane. Long-term stability test of BSCF (x = 0.03) membrane at 850 °C indicated a slight deterioration of the permeation flux, which was attributed in part to the increased A-site deficiency of the bulk from Ba2+ and Sr2+ segregation over the membrane surface. © 2007 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

wOIUYIeS.title: Progress in understanding and development of Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3−δ-based cathodes for intermediate-temperature solid-oxide fuel cells: A review
wOIUYIeS.abstract: Solid-oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) convert chemical energy directly into electric power in a highly efficient way. Lowering the operating temperature of SOFCs to around 500–800 °C is one of the main goals in current SOFC research. The associated benefits include reducing the difficulties associated with sealing and thermal degradation, allowing the use of low-cost metallic interconnectors and suppressing reactions between the cell components. However, the electrochemical activity of the cathode deteriorates dramatically with decreasing temperature for the typical La 0.8 Sr 0.2 MnO 3 -based electrodes. The cathode becomes the limiting factor in determining the overall cell performance. Therefore, the development of new electrodes with high electrocatalytic activity for oxygen reduction becomes a critical issue for intermediate-temperature (IT)-SOFCs. Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ (BSCF) perovskite oxide was first reported as a potential IT-SOFC cathode material in 2004 by Shao and Haile. After that, the BSCF cathode has attracted considerable attention. This paper reviews the current research activities on BSCF-based cathodes for IT-SOFCs. Emphasis will be placed on the understanding and optimization of BSCF-based materials. The issues raised by the BSCF cathode are also presented and analyzed to provide some guidelines in the search for the new generation of cathode materials for IT-SOFCs.

F9mtO3oC.title: Methane-fueled SOFC with traditional nickel-based anode by applying Ni/Al2O3 as a dual-functional layer
F9mtO3oC.abstract: Novel γ-Al 2 O 3 supported nickel (Ni/Al 2 O 3 ) catalyst was developed as a functional layer for Ni–ScSZ cermet anode operating on methane fuel. Catalytic tests demonstrated Ni/Al 2 O 3 had high and comparable activity to Ru–CeO 2 and much higher activity than the Ni–ScSZ cermet anode for partial oxidation, steam and CO 2 reforming of methane to syngas between 750 and 850 °C. By adopting Ni/Al 2 O 3 as a catalyst layer, the fuel cell demonstrated a peak power density of 382 mW cm −2 at 850 °C, more than two times that without the catalyst layer. The Ni/Al 2 O 3 also functioned as a diffusion barrier layer to reduce the methane concentration within the anode; consequently, the operation stability was also greatly improved without coke deposition. Keywords Solid-oxide fuel cells Ni/Al 2 O 3 Methane Coke Nickel–ScSZ cermet 1 Introduction Fuel cells are electrochemical energy conversion devices characterized by high fuel efficiency and low emissions. A solid-oxide fuel cell (SOFC) is typically composed of nickel-based cermet anode, oxide electrolyte and oxide cathode. A major advantage of SOFCs is their fuel flexibility because of high operation temperature [1] . Methane is the simplest and widely available hydrocarbon with a huge resource in the world. It is the main component of natural gas and coal gas. It is also the main component of biogas and can be treated as a renewable energy resource. Nowadays, there is a great interest of SOFC operating on methane fuel [2,3] . Typically there are three routes available for operating on methane fuel in a SOFC, i.e., direct electrochemical conversion, external reforming and internal reforming [4–6] . The later route is superior to external reforming because of their simplicity. State-of-the-art SOFC anodes are composed of nickel-based cermets which show high electrical conductivity and excellent activity for hydrogen electrochemical oxidation. However, sintered nickel has high catalytic activity towards hydrocarbon cracking reaction. Coke is easily formed over anode surface and causes rapid deterioration of the fuel cell performance when hydrocarbons are applied as the fuels. Most recently, the concept of applying a Ru–CeO 2 functional layer over a conventional nickel-based cermet anode has been proposed [7] , which allows high-efficient internal reforming of hydrocarbons over the thin catalyst layer without coke formation. However, the high cost of ruthenium becomes the major hurdle for commercialization. Development of alternative cost-attractive catalyst layer is then of great importance for practical operation of SOFC on methane fuel. In this paper, an γ-Al 2 O 3 supported nickel catalyst was proposed for the first time as a dual-functional layer over traditional Ni–ScSZ anode for operating on methane fuel. The new catalyst showed favorable activity for partial oxidation, steam and CO 2 reforming of methane to syngas (CO + H 2 ) at intermediate temperatures. By adopting Ni/Al 2 O 3 layer high fuel cell performance and excellent carbon coking resistance were achieved. 2 Experimental Both 7 wt.% Ni–Al 2 O 3 and 7 wt.% Ru–CeO 2 powders, investigated as the materials for the catalyst layer, were synthesized by a glycine nitrite process according to Ref. [8] . The fuel cell materials include the cathode La 0.8 Sr 0.2 MnO 3 (LSM) and the electrolyte (Sc 2 O 3 ) 0.1 (ZrO 2 ) 0.9 (ScSZ) were prepared by an EDTA–citrate complexing process. The fuel cell adopted in this study is 60 wt.% NiO + 40 wt.% ScSZ anode-supported thin film ScSZ electrolyte fuel cell (∼20 μm) fabricated by a dual dry pressing/sintering process. The catalytic activity of the catalysts and anode material was studied in a flow-through type fixed-bed quartz tube reactor with an inner diameter of ∼6 mm. About 0.2 g catalyst particles in the size of 60–80 meshes was dropped into the middle of the reactor, the gas mixture of He–CH 4 –O 2 , He–CH 4 –CO 2 or He–CH 4 –H 2 O at targeted mole ratio was introduced from the top of the reactor, the effluent gases from the bottom of the reactor was introduced to a Varian 3800 gas chromatography for compositional analysis at 750–850 °C. Typically methane was kept at 10 ml min −1 [standard temperature pressure, STP] while the diluting gas of helium at 80–100 ml min −1 [STP]. The I – V polarization of the cells was measured using a Keithley 2420 source meter at 4-probe mode at 750–850 °C. Methane fuel or a mixture of CH 4 –O 2 , CH 4 –CO 2 or CH 4 –H 2 O was fed into the anode chamber at a flow rate of 40 ml min −1 [STP]. Ambient air was served as the oxidant gas at the cathode chamber. The cross-sectional morphologies of the fuel cell were examined using a scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JSM-5610LV). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity The catalytic activity of Ni/Al 2 O 3 for partial oxidation, steam reforming, and CO 2 reforming of methane to syngas (CO + H 2 ) were first investigated at methane to O 2 , H 2 O and CO 2 mole ratios of 2:1, 1:1 and 1:1, respectively. For comparison the catalytic activity of 7 wt.% Ru–CeO 2 and Ni–ScSZ anode for such reactions was also conducted. As the catalyst layer, the Ni/Al 2 O 3 was fired onto the anode surface at 850 °C while the anode was co-sintered with electrolyte at 1500 °C for the densification of the electrolyte layer. Thereby, for the catalysis evaluation, the Ni/Al 2 O 3 and Ru–CeO 2 catalysts were fired at 850 °C for 5 h while the Ni–ScSZ catalyst was sintered at 1500 °C for 5 h. Table 1 lists the methane conversions and CO selectivity at 850, 800 and 750 °C over the three catalysts. Ni/Al 2 O 3 demonstrated comparable catalytic activity for methane partial oxidation to that of Ru–CeO 2 catalyst. Both catalysts showed much better catalytic activity than the Ni–ScSZ. For example, at 750 °C, the methane conversion/CO selectivity are 94%/99%, 96%/98% and 16%/3.5% for Ni/Al 2 O 3 , Ru–CeO 2 and Ni–ScSZ catalysts, respectively. Besides its excellent catalytic activity for methane partial oxidation, Ni/Al 2 O 3 also shows favorable catalytic activity for methane steam and CO 2 reforming reactions. It shows even a slightly higher catalytic activity than Ru–CeO 2 catalyst for such reactions while the Ni–ScSZ anode had very poor activity. The methane conversion reached more than 94% for all above three reactions at 750 °C over Ni/Al 2 O 3 catalyst while it is only 16–37% when Ni–ScSZ was the catalyst. 3.2 Cell performance One cell whose anode surface was modified with a thin Ni/Al 2 O 3 catalyst layer (20 μm) prepared by spray deposition followed by firing at 900 °C for 5 h. Table 2 lists the peak power density (PPD) at 850 °C operated on gas stream composed of methane and oxygen mixture at various mole ratios. When pure methane was applied as the fuel, the cell with the catalyst layer delivered a PPD of 382 mW cm −2 , which is 2.51 times that of the cell without the catalyst layer (152 mW cm −2 ). Since the Ni/Al 2 O 3 catalyst layer was deposited over the anode which has a thickness of ∼600 μm while the active zone for electrochemical oxidation of fuel is only about tens of micron away from the electrolyte interface [9] , thereby the Ni/Al 2 O 3 catalyst layer should be inert for the electrochemical oxidation of the fuel. In connection with the catalytic results, the improved cell performance was then attributed to the increased catalytic activity for CO 2 and steam reforming of methane to syngas via the introduction of the Ni/Al 2 O 3 layer. The effect of the reaction with methane and the products on the polarization resistance has been proposed by some researchers [2,10,11] . Under polarization, electrochemical oxidation products of CO 2 and H 2 O were produced, which reacted with the methane under the catalysis of the Ni/Al 2 O 3 catalyst layer to produce H 2 and CO. The formed CO and H 2 then diffused to the anode layer where they were electrochemically oxidized to produce H 2 O, CO 2 and electricity. Since CO and H 2 have higher electrochemical activity than methane, it then well-explained the improved cell performance with the introduction of Ni/Al 2 O 3 catalyst layer by operating on pure methane. As shown in Table 2 , the increase in oxygen to methane mole ratio first envisaged an increase in PPD slightly, reached the maximum PPD at CH 4 to O 2 mole ratio of 4:1 and then decreased with the further increase of oxygen concentration. The increased power density when introducing proper amount of oxygen into the fuel stream was attributed to the increased H 2 concentration due to the partial oxidation of methane to syngas over the Ni/Al 2 O 3 catalyst layer. However, too much oxygen would induce the deep oxidation of methane and resulted in a decrease in hydrogen concentration with the further increase in O 2 concentration in the feed gas. The fuel cell performance without and with the catalyst layer was then further investigated in detail at different temperatures. As shown in Fig. 1 a and b, when no catalyst layer was applied, the peak power densities at 750, 775, 800, 825 and 850 °C are 75, 95, 126, 165 and 231 mW cm −2 , respectively, while the corresponding power densities increased to 293, 325, 373, 406 and 456 mW cm −2 when the Ni/Al 2 O 3 catalyst layer was applied. 3.3 Operation stability To examine the operation stability, pure methane was applied as the fuel at the flow rate of 40 ml min −1 [STP] and the PPD with time was monitored periodically. As shown in Fig. 1 c is the dependence of PPD on operation time. When no Ni/Al 2 O 3 catalyst layer was adopted, after operation on methane stream for 90 min, the PPD reduced to about ∼41% of the initial value, while the decrease in PPD was just about 3% when Ni/Al 2 O 3 catalyst layer was adopted and it was still only 4% after operation on methane fuel for about 150 min. It clearly indicates that the application of a Ni/Al 2 O 3 catalyst layer increased the operation stability of the fuel cell significantly. SEM images of the fuel cell after testing at 850–750 °C with a total period of ∼25 h are shown in Fig. 2 , the catalyst layer still adhered to the anode surface pretty well without any delimitation observed. Furthermore, no any carbon deposition was observed over both the anode surface and the Ni/Al 2 O 3 catalyst surface. It is well-known that Ni/Al 2 O 3 has good resistance towards the coke formation due to the interaction between nickel and alumina substrate [12] while coke is easily formed over Ni–ScSZ anode when operating on methane [13] . In reality, no carbon formation over the Ni–ScSZ anode was observed which can be explained by the barrier effect of the catalyst layer. Recently Lin et al. also demonstrated that the cell operation stability on methane fuel could be greatly improved by adopting an anode gas diffusion barrier layer [14] . As shown in Fig. 2 , the catalyst layer has a much denser morphology than the porous Ni–ScSZ cermet that caused a gas diffusion barrier for methane into the anode layer. The diffusion barrier effect of the catalyst layer was supported by the appearance of concentration polarization at high current density in I – V curves as shown in Fig. 1 b. The gas diffusion limitation within the Ni/Al 2 O 3 layer then decreased the methane content and increased the product content within the nickel anode layer. 4 Conclusions The 7 wt.% nickel supported on γ-Al 2 O 3 (Ni/Al 2 O 3 ) catalyst had excellent and comparable catalytic activity to that of Ru–CeO 2 for partial oxidation, steam reforming and CO 2 reforming of methane to syngas reactions between 750 and 850 °C. By adopting Ni/Al 2 O 3 as the catalyst layer over the typical Ni–ScSZ anode, the peak power density reached 382 mW cm −2 when operating on pure methane at 850 °C, more than two times that of the cell without the catalyst layer. The Ni/Al 2 O 3 catalyst layer also functioned as a gas diffusion barrier which effectively increased the O 2− to methane ratio within the anode and suppressed the coke formation thereby increased the cell operation stability. The much cheaper price of Ni/Al 2 O 3 and the excellent catalytic properties promise its application in methane-fueled solid oxide fuel cells. Da98HzNa.title: Hydrazine as efficient fuel for low-temperature SOFC through ex-situ catalytic decomposition with high selectivity toward hydrogen
Da98HzNa.abstract: Hydrazine is a promising fuel for portable fuel cells because it is a liquid, it is carbon free and it has a high energy density. In this work, hydrazine was investigated as an efficient fuel for low temperature solid-oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) with a traditional nickel anode. A catalytic system with high selectivity toward hydrogen was developed using Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3-δ (BSCF) as the main catalyst and potassium hydroxide as the promoter. The result of compositional analysis of the products showed that the hydrazine can be decomposed into hydrogen and nitrogen with 100% selectivity when an appropriate amount of KOH promoter is used. Acceptable power densities were achieved for a thin-film samaria-doped ceria (SDC) electrolyte cell operating on hydrazine decomposition products and hydrogen over a complete operation temperature range of 650–450 °C. In addition, a similar cell with ammonia as the fuel displayed a much lower performance.

zoofk5Uf.title: Performance of PrBaCo2O5+δ as a proton-conducting solid-oxide fuel cell cathode
zoofk5Uf.abstract: The potential application of PrBaCo2O5-δ (PBC) double perovskite oxide as a cathode for a proton-conducting solid-oxide fuel cell based on a BaZr0.1Ce0.7Y0.2O 3-δ(BZCY) electrolyte was systematically investigated. XRD and O2-TPD results demonstrated that cation exchange between BZCY and PBC perovskites simultaneously occurs from the formation of Co3+-doped BZCY and Y3+-doped PBC. This event does not significantly change the cathodic polarization resistance. Under real fuel cell conditions, neither the electrolyte nor electrode resistances were significantly affected by the phase reaction and morphologic change of PBC. Anode-supported cells with an electrolyte thickness of ∼30 μm were successfully fabricated via a dual dry pressing process. Relatively high performance of 520 and 407 mW cm -2 at 700 °C was achieved for the cell with a PBC cathode fired at 950 and 1100 °C, respectively. A low electrode polarization resistance of 0.06 cm2 was achieved at 700 °C for the PBC cathode calcined at 950 °C. © 2010 American Chemical Society.

VC5IbBey.title: Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3 - δ + LaCoO3 composite cathode for Sm0.2Ce0.8O1.9-electrolyte based intermediate-temperature solid-oxide fuel cells
VC5IbBey.abstract: A novel Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3 - δ + LaCoO3 (BSCF + LC) composite oxide was investigated for the potential application as a cathode for intermediate-temperature solid-oxide fuel cells based on a Sm0.2Ce0.8O1.9 (SDC) electrolyte. The LC oxide was added to BSCF cathode in order to improve its electrical conductivity. X-ray diffraction examination demonstrated that the solid-state reaction between LC and BSCF phases occurred at temperatures above 950 °C and formed the final product with the composition: La0.316Ba0.342Sr0.342Co0.863Fe0.137O3 - δ at 1100 °C. The inter-diffusion between BSCF and LC was identified by the environmental scanning electron microscopy and energy dispersive X-ray examination. The electrical conductivity of the BSCF + LC composite oxide increased with increasing calcination temperature, and reached a maximum value of ∼300 S cm-1 at a calcination temperature of 1050 °C, while the electrical conductivity of the pure BSCF was only ∼40 S cm-1. The improved conductivity resulted in attractive cathode performance. An area-specific resistance as low as 0.21 Ω cm2 was achieved at 600 °C for the BSCF (70 vol.%) + LC (30 vol.%) composite cathode calcined at 950 °C for 5 h. Peak power densities as high as ∼700 mW cm-2 at 650 °C and ∼525 mW cm-2 at 600 °C were reached for the thin-film fuel cells with the optimized cathode composition and calcination temperatures. © 2007 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

63T0IdI4.title: A novel way to improve performance of proton-conducting solid-oxide fuel cells through enhanced chemical interaction of anode components
63T0IdI4.abstract: We proposed a novel way to improve the cell performance of proton-conducting solid-oxide fuel cells by increasing the chemical interaction between the anode components using BaZr 0.4 Ce 0.4 Y 0.2 O 3−δ (BZCY4) as the ionic conducting phase of anode for a fuel cell with a BaCe 0.8 Y 0.2 O 3−δ (BCY) electrolyte. The strength of the chemical interaction between NiO and the ionic conducting phase (BZCY4 or BCY) was analyzed by the hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H 2 -TPR) technique. The effect of chemical interaction between NiO and the ionic conducting phase on the NiO diffusivity was investigated by SEM-EDX. The results demonstrated NiO had a much stronger interaction with BZCY4 than with BCY, thereby resulting in suppressed diffusivity of NiO into the BCY electrolyte. Using BZCY4 as the ionic conducting phase of the anode, a cell with an ohmic resistance of 0.65 Ω cm 2 at 700 °C was obtained. In contrast, a cell with BCY as the ionic conducting phase of the anode had an ohmic resistance of 0.82 Ω cm 2 at 700 °C. Therefore, the single cell with NiO + BZCY4 anode showed a peak power density higher than that of the cell with the NiO + BCY anode.

9zghEc80.title: Fabrication and performance of a carbon dioxide-tolerant proton-conducting solid oxide fuel cells with a dual-layer electrolyte
9zghEc80.abstract: A proton-conducting solid oxide fuel cells with a dual-layer electrolyte, constructed of a highly protonic conductive BaCe 0.8 Y 0.2 O 3−δ (BCY) electrolyte and chemically stable BaZr 0.4 Ce 0.4 Y 0.2 O 3−δ (BZCY4) electrolyte, was easily fabricated by dry pressing the electrolyte powders onto an NiO + BZCY4 anode substrate, followed by co-sintering at a high temperature. The performance of the as-fabricated cell with the BCY and BZCY4 dual-layer electrolyte was studied. Peak power densities of 249 and 101 mW cm −2 were achieved at 700 and 500 °C, respectively. Zinc was applied as a sintering promoter to increase the relative density of the BZCY4 electrolyte. Cross-sectional micrographs of the as-fabricated, dual-layer electrolyte cells were obtained by scanning electron microscopy. The results showed that the sintering ability of BZCY4 was improved by using zinc as sintering aid. A cell with BCY and zinc-modified BZCY4 dual-layer electrolyte delivered peak power densities of 276 and 247 mW cm −2 and OCVs of 1.03 and 1.02 V at 700 °C under humidified hydrogen and 15% CO 2 -containing hydrogen atmospheres, respectively. The operation stability of the dual-layer electrolyte cell under a 15% CO 2 -containing hydrogen atmosphere was also investigated.
