JhqkAYi7.title: Process investigation, electrochemical characterization and optimization of LiFePO4/C composite from mechanical activation using sucrose as carbon source
JhqkAYi7.abstract: LiFePO 4 /C composite was synthesized by mechanical activation using sucrose as carbon source. High-energy ball milling facilitated phase formation during thermal treatment. TG–DSC and TPR experiments demonstrated sucrose was converted to CH x intermediate before completely decomposed to carbon. Ball milling time, calcination temperature and dwelling time all had significant impact on the discharge capacity and rate performance of the resulted power. The optimal process parameters are high-energy ball milling for 2–4 h followed by thermal treatment at 700 °C for 20 h. The product showed a capacity of 174 mAh/g at 0.1C rate and around 117 mAh/g at 20C rate with the capacity fade less than 10% after 50 cycles. Too low calcination temperature or insufficient calcination time, however, could result in the residual of CH x in the electrode and led to a decrease of electrode performance. Keywords Lithium-ion battery Cathode Sucrose LiFePO 4 Mechanical activation 1 Introduction Nowadays, there is a great interest in rechargeable lithium-ion battery for applications in electric and electric-hybrid vehicles and dispersed energy storage systems, which require much larger battery size than the portable electrical devices, such as cameras and laptop computers. Such applications also have stricter requirements on safety, high-rate performance, and volumetric/gravimetric energy density. It means LiCoO 2 , the currently widely applied positive electrode (cathode) material in commercial lithium-ion batteries, should be replaced. Orthorhombic lithium iron phosphate, LiFePO 4 , as first demonstrated by Padhi et al. [1] , is attracting considerable yet still increasing attention as a safe, low-cost and high-capacity cathode material for lithium-ion battery [2–8] , especially for application in electric and hybrid-electric vehicles. Similar to Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 anode, the lithium insertion/extraction into LiFePO 4 cathode involves two-phase mechanism [9–12] . On lithium extraction, LiFePO 4 changes to FePO 4 , a material with a similar structure and a cell volume difference of only ∼7% to LiFePO 4 [1] . Such characteristics ensure an excellent cycling stability. LiFePO 4 also features a favorable theoretical capacity around 170 mAh/g, a flat voltage curve with a plateau around 3.5 V vs. Li/Li + , high thermal and chemical stability, a wide safety margin of usage for many organic electrolytes, low material cost, low toxicity and improved safety [1] . The main drawbacks of the olivine-type LiFePO 4 include low electronic conductivity and low lithium-ion diffusivity. Serious polarization is typically observed under high charge/discharge rate, which results in a poor rate capacity. To overcome these drawbacks, three strategies are frequently applied: (i) reducing the grain size to lessen the diffusion distance for lithium ion inside the electrode bulk [13–15] , (ii) doping the lattice with foreign cations to increase the intrinsic electronic conductivity and lithium-ion diffusivity [16–18] and (iii) surface modification such as carbon coating to increase the electronic conductivity consequently the interfacial reaction kinetics [19–22] . On the other hand, the electrochemical performance of LiFePO 4 cathode also depends on a number of factors, e.g., phase purity, particle size and morphology, which are closely related with the synthesis technique and process parameters. Recently, a variety of techniques have been exploited for the synthesis of high-performance LiFePO 4 [23–27] . Mechanical activation, which involves the blending of ingredients by high-energy ball milling followed by thermal treatment at high temperature, has turned out to be a versatile technique with high capability for scale up [28–30] . The ball milling can reduce the particle size and create close contact of the reactants. Thereby, a decrease in the thermal treatment time and temperature is usually experienced during the following calcination to obtain a pure phase product. It then effectively avoids undesirable grain growth. Mechanical activation process also allows the in situ formation of carbon layer over LiFePO 4 when carbon black or a suitable organic/polymeric compound is incorporated as the carbon source during the synthesis. Besides performing as the coating material for LiFePO 4 , the carbon also acts as a reducing agent to suppress the oxidation of Fe 2+ to form Fe 3+ impurities during the synthesis. The carbon may further act as a diffusion barrier by blocking the particle contact, thereby suppressing the grain growth. Improved performance at high charge/discharge rate has been observed for the LiFePO 4 /C composite as compared to the LiFePO 4 prepared by the same technique but without adopting carbon additive [31] . Among various carbon raw materials for the coating layer, sucrose was found to be an excellent candidate [5] . Numerous studies have been conducted in literature on the synthesis of high-performance LiFePO 4 /C composite by applying sucrose as the carbon source [5,32–34] . However, most of the investigations were focused on the electrochemical performance of the as-synthesized samples. Very limited attention was paid to the synthesis process. Such information is, however, important guidance for further optimizing the material properties. In this study, the synthesis of LiFePO 4 /C composite cathode by a mechanical activation process applying sucrose as the carbon source was systematically investigated. Importance was paid to the synthesis process and the influence of process parameters on the electrochemical performance of the product. High electrochemical performance was achieved for the LiFePO 4 /C composite synthesized under optimal conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material synthesis LiFePO 4 /C was synthesized by a mechanical activation process followed by high-temperature calcination. Li 2 CO 3 , FeC 2 O 4 ·2H 2 O and NH 4 H 2 PO 4 (all chemicals of >99% purity) were applied as the raw materials and sucrose was selected as the carbon source. They were weighed in stoichiometric amounts according to the nominal LiFePO 4 to C weight ratio 94 to 6, assuming the sucrose following the thermal pyrolysis reaction C 12 H 22 O 11 → 12C + 11H 2 O. The ingredients together with 60% acetone were magnetically stirred at room temperature for 5 min, followed by high-energy ball milling in a zirconia container with zirconia balls (ball-to-powder weight ratio 10 to 3) at room temperature for different periods under an argon atmosphere using a Pulverisette-6 planner mill at 400 rpm. The as-obtained slurry was dried by evaporating the acetone liquid media under vacuum. Finally the solid precursors were fired at temperatures ranging from 500 to 900 °C for various hours in a tube furnace purging with pure nitrogen atmosphere. 2.2 Electrode fabrication The electrochemical cycling performance of LiFePO 4 or LiFePO 4 /C powders was tested with coin-shaped cells using metallic lithium film as the counter and reference electrode at room temperature (∼30 °C). The cells are based on the configuration of Li metal (−)|electrolyte|LiFePO 4 (+) with a liquid electrolyte (1 M solution of LiPF 6 in ethylene carbonate (EC)–dimethyl carbonate (DMC) (1:1, v/v). Microporous polypropylene film (Celgard 2400) was used as the separator [35] . Slurries composed of 85 wt.% LiFePO 4 with 10 wt.% conductive Super P (NCM HERSBIT Chemical Co., Ltd., China) and 5 wt.% LA-132 binder (Chengdu Organic Chemicals Co., Ltd., China) in de-ionized water were prepared, which were deposited on current collectors of 6 μm thick aluminum foils by blade. The electrode was dried under vacuum at 100 °C for 12 h before electrochemical evaluation. Cell assembly was conducted in a glove box filled with pure argon. 2.3 Characterization The crystal structures of the synthesized powders were examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a Bruker D8 advance diffractometer with filtered Cu Kα radiation. The experimental diffraction patterns were collected at room temperature by step scanning at the range of 10° < 2 θ < 80°. The crystallite size was calculated based on the Scherrer equation from the study of the Bragg angle and half bandwidth of the index peaks. The mean value of crystallite sizes calculated based on [1 0 1], [1 1 1], [2 1 1] and [3 1 1] diffraction planes was adopted as the crystallite size of as-synthesized LiFePO 4 . The particulate morphology was examined by Environmental Scanning Electronic Microscope (ESEM, QUANTA-2000). The specific surface area of the samples was characterized by N 2 adsorption at the temperature of liquid nitrogen using a BELSORP II instrument. Prior to analysis, the samples were put in vacuum at 200 °C for 3–5 h to remove the surface adsorbed species. Thermogravimetry–differential scanning calorimetric analyses (TG–DSC) were performed using a NETZSCH STA 409 PC in the range of 25–1000 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under flowing argon atmosphere. Temperature programmed reaction (TPR) experiments were conducted using a U-type quartz reactor. About 0.02 g sample in 40–60 mesh was dropped into a quartz tube reactor and a constant helium flow at 20 ml/min [STP] was introduced. The temperature of the reactor was programmatically increased. The effluent gas from the reactor was introduced to a mass spectroscope (QIC 20) for in situ compositional analysis. Before the electrochemical performance test, the cells were activated through one charge/discharge cycles with a small current (0.1C, 1C = 170 mAh/g) using a NEWARE BTS-5V50mA computer-controlled battery test system. The charge/discharge characteristics of the cells were recorded over the potential range between 2.0 and 4.2 V at different range of 0.1–50C at 30 °C. Cyclic voltammetry tests were performed over the potential range of 2.0–4.2 V using a Princeton Applied Research PARSTAT 2273 advanced electrochemical system at the scanning rate 0.1–1 mV/s. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis The reactants, a physical mixture of stoichiometric amounts of NH 4 H 2 PO 4 , Li 2 CO 3 , FeC 2 O 4 ·2H 2 O and C 12 O 11 H 22 , demonstrated the color of light yellow, a typical color of FeC 2 O 4 ·2H 2 O. It changed steadily to light green with increasing ball milling time during the mechanical activation. This implies that certain type of interaction between the reactants appeared during the high-energy ball milling. It is well known that Fe(H 2 O) 6 2+ has a color of light blue. Hereby, the ball milling likely led to the interaction of the hydroxide groups in sucrose with FeC 2 O 4 ·2H 2 O. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the precursor after the ball milling at room temperature for various hours. Before ball milling, the characteristic diffraction peaks of FeC 2 O 4 ·2H 2 O were detected. However, an amorphous structure at room temperature was observed when the precursor was ball milled for 2 h or longer. This implies that the crystallite phase of the FeC 2 O 4 ·2H 2 O was destroyed by reaction or certain type of interaction between FeC 2 O 4 ·2H 2 O and other reactants existed after the ball milling, in accordance with the color change after the ball milling. During the thermal treatment, the cracking of sucrose and the phase reaction among NH 4 H 2 PO 4 , Li 2 CO 3 and FeC 2 O 4 ·2H 2 O to form LiFePO 4 could happen simultaneously or separately. Different formation mechanism may result in significantly different anode morphology or phase structure, consequently, differed electrochemical behavior. The thermal decomposition behavior of sucrose was first investigated. As shown in Fig. 2 is the TG–DSC curves of sucrose under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The weight loss started at ∼215 °C, mainly happened between 220 and 400 °C, and finished around 700 °C. The final weight loss reached 84%. The DSC curve showed a sharp endothermic peak around 194 °C corresponding to a zero weight loss, which was assigned to the cleavage of glucose ring in sucrose. Another endothermic peak was observed around 230 °C accompanied with a sharp weight loss in the TG profile. There were two small successive endothermic peaks at 296 and 450 °C, respectively. The appearance of several successive endothermic peaks in the DSC profile suggests that the thermal cracking was conducted in several successive steps. For the thermal decomposition of sucrose, a theoretical weight loss 58% should be expected if carbon and water were the sole products. The actual weight loss 84% implies that only 38% carbon in sucrose was successfully converted to solid carbon. On other words, ∼62% carbon was lost in the form of gaseous products, i.e., CO and CO 2 . The overall thermal decomposition reaction of sucrose could be expressed as C 12 O 11 H 22 → 4.56C + 7.44(CO/CO 2 ) + 11(H 2 O/H 2 ). If assuming decomposition behavior of sucrose in the solid precursor was similar to pure sucrose, the actual carbon content in the derived LiFePO 4 /C composite is only around 2.3 wt.%. To further exploit the thermal decomposition reaction of sucrose, a TPR was conducted. As shown in Fig. 3 , there was almost no any gaseous species produced at T < 220 °C, agreed well with the TG–DSC results. A broad water peak and a CO 2 peak were observed within the temperature range of 220–550 °C, and 250–500 °C, respectively. A CO peak was also appeared alongside with the CO 2 peak. At T > 550 °C, a large and broad H 2 peak was appeared, however, no other peak was detected in the same temperature zone. Since carbon is the only final solid residual, the hydrogen was then produced from the thermal decomposition of CH x . Above results demonstrated that the sucrose first cracked to CH x intermediate during the thermal decomposition, which was further converted to carbon at relatively high temperature of >550 °C. To exploit the role of the high-energy ball milling in the phase formation and its effect on the thermal decomposition behavior of the solid precursor, TG–DSC and TPR of the solid precursors with and without the ball milling process were conducted. As shown in Fig. 4 , without the ball milling process, the weight loss started at 162 °C. A sharp weight loss appeared between 162 and 230 °C, which accounted for a weight loss of about 25%. Another obvious weight loss amounting to ∼20% of initial weight appeared between 230 and 420 °C. Between 420 and 800 °C and mainly between 550 and 650 °C there was additional modest weight loss amounting to ∼6%. The ball-milled precursor showed somewhat different decomposition behavior. One significant difference is that the weight loss initiated at room temperature. In combination with the color change after the ball milling, such weight loss was attributed to the evaporation of dehydrated water from FeC 2 O 4 ·2H 2 O, created during the high-energy ball milling process. Another significant difference is that the sharp weight loss between 550 and 650 °C was disappeared. As shown in Fig. 5 , for the precursor without the ball milling process, there were almost no gaseous decomposition products at T < 180 °C, however, a big water peak was observed between 60 and 130 °C for the ball-milled sample. Such different behaviors are in well agreement with the TG–DSC results. It further supported that the hydrated water in FeC 2 O 4 ·2H 2 O was released during the high-energy ball milling process. Starting at around 180 °C and happening mainly between 180 and 380 °C, a strong and broad water peak was appeared for the solid precursor without the ball milling process, which was ascribed to the thermal decomposition of sucrose and the dehydration of FeC 2 O 4 ·2H 2 O. Between 220 and 260 °C, CO and CO 2 decomposition peaks with similar intensity were appeared simultaneously. In connection with the thermal decomposition behavior of the sucrose, they were ascribed to the thermal decomposition of sucrose via the reaction C 12 O 11 H 22 → CH x + CO + CO 2 + H 2 O. As compared to pure sucrose, the CO and CO 2 decomposition peaks become sharper and moved to a lower temperature zone. It suggests that the formation of solid mixture facilitated the thermal decomposition of sucrose. Ammonia peak, attributed to the thermal decomposition of NH 4 H 2 PO 4 to NH 3 and H 3 PO 4 , was detected between 160 and 500 °C. Between 380 and 430 °C, sharp peaks of CO and CO 2 with similar intensity appeared simultaneously, which were attributed to the thermal decomposition of FeC 2 O 4 via the reaction FeC 2 O 4 → FeO + CO + CO 2 . A big and broad hydrogen peak was also observed in the same temperature zone, which was ascribed to the thermal dehydrogenation of CH x to C and H 2 . Between 600 and 700 °C, hydrogen, CO and CO 2 peaks with low intensity were appeared simultaneously, which were assigned to the thermal decomposition of Li 2 CO 3 to Li 2 O and CO 2 , and the reaction of CO 2 with CH x to form CO and H 2 , and so on, via the reactions as follows. Li 2 CO 3 → Li 2 O + CO 2 Li 2 O + FeHPO 4 → LiFePO 4 + H 2 O H 2 O + CH x → CO + H 2 CO 2 + CH x → CO + H 2 When the solid precursor was subjected for high-energy ball milling, the reactants were mixed thoroughly and had close contact. The ball milling process also led to the dehydration of FeC 2 O 4 ·2H 2 O with the formation of free water as demonstrated previously. Such free water can be easily evaporated. It then well explained the observation of the water peak between 60 and 150 °C for the ball-milled sample. Starting at 180 °C, additional water desorption peak appeared, which was produced from the thermal decomposition of sucrose. Two small ammonia peaks were observed between 50 and 180 °C, while they were not detected for the solid precursor without the ball milling process during the synthesis. It suggests that the high-energy ball milling also facilitated the thermal decomposition of NH 4 H 2 PO 4 . Between 180 and 400 °C, relatively broad ammonia peak alongside with the CO 2 and CO peaks appeared. The CO 2 peak was found to have much stronger intensity than CO, different from the decomposition behavior of the precursor without the ball milling process. It was attributed to the thermal decomposition of sucrose alongside with the reaction of NH 4 H 2 PO 4 and Li 2 CO 3 (Li 2 CO 3 + NH 4 H 2 PO 4 → LiH 2 PO 4 + CO 2 ), facilitated by the high-energy ball milling. Between 400 and 450 °C, sharp CO and CO 2 peaks with similar densities appeared, which were ascribed to the thermal decomposition of FeC 2 O 4 to FeO, CO and CO 2 . At T > 500 °C, a broad hydrogen peak was also appeared without the formation of other decomposition product, in connection with the thermal decomposition behavior of sucrose, it was assigned to the decomposition of CH x . Based on the TG–DSC and TPR results, a calcination temperature of around 700 °C was necessary in order to achieve the complete reaction of the reactants in the solid precursor without the ball milling process, while a similar temperature was required for the ball-milled precursor allowing the CH x completely decomposed to carbon. Thereby, 700 °C was selected for the thermal treatment of solid precursors. As shown in Fig. 6 are the XRD of the as-prepared LiFePO 4 /C composites by solid-state reaction at 700 °C for 20 h with or without the mechanical activation process, and LiFePO 4 synthesized without the high-energy ball milling process and without sucrose adopted during the synthesis. All three samples showed a well-crystalline single-phase LiFePO 4 . For each sample, all its diffraction peaks can be indexed well based on orthorhombic structure with the space group pnmb. No carbon diffraction peaks were detected for both LiFePO 4 /C composites with or without the ball milling process during the synthesis. This implies the formed carbon coating layer over LiFePO 4 surface was in an amorphous phase. 3.2 Electrochemical performance Fig. 7 shows the first charge/discharge profiles at 0.1C rate (current density of 17 mAh/g) for the samples of LiFePO 4 electrode prepared by solid-state reaction of NH 4 H 2 PO 4 , Li 2 CO 3 and FeC 2 O 4 ·2H 2 O at 700 °C for 20 h (sample I), LiFePO 4 /C composite prepared from the similar procedure of sample I but applying sucrose as carbon source during the synthesis (sample II), and LiFePO 4 /C composite prepared by the similar procedure of sample II with high-energy ball milling of the solid precursor for 2 h during the synthesis (sample III). The sample I showed the first discharge capacity around 110 mAh/g, similar to the literature result for a pure LiFePO 4 prepared by a similar solid-phase reaction process [36] . When sucrose was introduced as a carbon source during the preparation, the as-obtained LiFePO 4 /C composite showed a capacity around 140 mAh/g. It is generally believed that the carbon additive had several functions during the synthesis of LiFePO 4 . Besides its main function to improve the electronic conductivity by performing as surface coating layer, it also effectively prevents the oxidation of Fe 2+ to Fe 3+ and acted as a diffusion block to suppress the LiFePO 4 grain growth. The measured BET surface area of samples I and II was 13.6 and 23.6 m 2 /g, respectively. It suggests that the sucrose indeed increased the surface area of the resulted LiFePO 4 . Both the increase in surface area and the improvement in electronic conductivity may account for the improved discharge capacity of LiFePO 4 /C composite as compared to conventional LiFePO 4 . When both high-energy ball milling (mechanical activation) and carbon additive were introduced during the synthesis of LiFePO 4 , the surface area further increased to 28.3 m 2 /g. The first discharge capacity increased obviously to 174 mAh/g, which reached the theoretical value for a LiFePO 4 cathode (170 mAh/g) Within experimental error. This implies all LiFePO 4 in the electrode became electrochemically active. The sample also demonstrated excellent reversible capacity around 97%. Thereby, the high-energy ball milling together with in situ carbon coating is highly effective to increase the electrochemical activity of LiFePO 4 cathode. As shown in Fig. 8 are the discharge curves of the LiFePO 4 /C composite at various discharge/charge rates varied from 0.1 to 50C. For accurate comparison of the rate performance during discharging, the cell was recharged at 0.1C rate to assure identical initial conditions for all the discharges [37,38] . The discharge capacities decreased from 171 mAh/g at 0.1C to 117 mAh/g at 20C. Even at 50C, a capacity of 81 mAh/g was still maintained, which is even higher than 76 mAh/g of the LiFePO 4 /C composite without the ball milling process during the synthesis at 5C rate. These results are among the best for LiFePO 4 /C composite electrode reported ever in literature. By a similar synthesis process Kim et al. reported a first discharge capacity of around 164 mAh/g at 0.1C rate and ∼120 mAh/g at 1C rate [33] . The cycling characteristics of the as-prepared LiFePO 4 /C cathode material at different discharge rate are shown in Fig. 9 . Favorable cycle performance was demonstrated. At all discharge rates, the capacity fade after 50 cycles was less than 10%. The good long-term cycling behavior of the LiFePO 4 /C composite at various discharge rates confirms the excellent reversibility of lithium insertion/extraction reactions. Cyclic voltammograms of the LiFePO 4 /C electrode at the scan rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5 and 1 mV/s between 4.2 and 2.0 V are shown in Fig. 10 a . The oxidizing peak and the reduction peak are highly symmetric to each other. The ratios of I pa / I pc are close to 1, implying that the good reversibility of lithium intercalation into and de-intercalation from the carbon-coated LiFePO4. There is a linear relationship between I pa and square root of the scan rate, as shown in Fig. 10 b. The slope k was found to be 1.446 × 10 −2 A s 0.5 /V 0.5 , where A is the current in Ampere, s is the time in second and V is the voltage. CV is a quasi-static electrode characterization technique. In an electrochemical process of LiFePO 4 /C electrode, the anodic process corresponds to the lithium-ion de-intercalation from LiFePO 4 bulk with the simultaneous diffusion of electron from the electrode to the current collector, while the cathodic process corresponds to the Li + intercalation into FePO 4 and acquiring electron from the current collector. Diffusion coefficient of lithium ions ( D o ) can be roughly estimated by cyclic voltammetry since the intercalation and de-intercalation is also a redox process. Under the condition of semi-infinite and infinite diffusion process, the peak current I p and the square root of scanning rate ( ν ) has the relationship of Eq. (1) [39] . (1) I p = 2.69 × 10 5 S ⋅ C o ⋅ D o 1 / 2 ⋅ n 2 / 3 ⋅ ν 1 / 2 where S is the total surface area of the anode material (cm 2 ), C o is the concentration of lithium ions in the cathode (mol/ml), D o is the average diffusion coefficient of lithium ion (cm 2 /s), n is the number of electrons transferred per molecule during the intercalation, it is 1 for LiFePO 4 , and ν is the scanning rate (s −1 ).The surface area of the anode material can be calculated by (2) S = S m × n o where S m is the mole surface area of anode (cm 2 /mol) and n o is the amount of the active material in the electrode (mol). If assuming the electrode material is in sphere shape, the mole surface area can be calculated by (3) S m = 3 V m r where V m is the mole volume of the electrode (ml/mol) and r is the radius of the particle (cm). The electrical charge Q transferred during charge/discharge process can be related with C o by (4) Q = n F V m × C o Since I p is in linear relationship with n 1/2 with the slope of k , the lithium diffusion coefficient D o can be expressed by the following equation [40] : (5) D o = r 2 k 2 69.9 n 3 Q 2 The electrical charge that transferred through the active material during the charge/discharge process could be took as its capacity, which can also be calculated from the weight amount of the active material and the theoretical specific capacity. It can also be calculated from the discharge/charge curves or be obtained by integrating the CV curves with respect to time. Here, D o was calculated based on theoretical capacity, i.e., Q = 0.95C. As shown in Fig. 11 a is the SEM of the as-synthesized LiFePO 4 powder. It shows that LiFePO 4 had quasi-sphere shape with an average particle size of 1.5 μm, i.e. r = 7.5 × 10 −5 cm. Together with the k value of 1.446 × 10 −2 A s 0.5 /V 0.5 , the lithium diffusion coefficient D o of ∼8.93 × 10 −13 cm 2 /s was calculated according to Eq. (5) . The reported value for a pure LiFePO 4 is ∼1.8 × 10 −14 cm 2 /s [41] . It then implies that the lithium-ion diffusion coefficient was greatly improved by applying sucrose as a carbon source in combination with high-energy ball milling, which may be the cause for the excellent high-rate performance of the LiFePO 4 /C composite prepared in this study. 3.3 Process optimization To exploit the effect of process parameter on the electrochemical performance of the derived LiFePO 4 , various ball milling times, thermal treatment temperatures and times were investigated in the synthesis of LiFePO 4 /C. As shown in Table 1 , the ball milling of 2–4 h resulted in the maximum surface area. The further increase in milling time, however, led to a steady decrease in surface area and increase in grain size. It is well known that the high-energy ball milling could result in a close contact of the reactants, which facilitated the solid-phase reaction, therefore reduced the sintering temperature and time for obtaining a pure phase LiFePO 4 . However, it can also break down the reactant particles and increase the surface activity. It means the particle sintering could be accelerated during the successive thermal treatment when the reactants were over ball milled. The thermal treatment temperature was found to have most significant impact on the surface area, the higher the calcination temperature the lower the surface area. As shown in Fig. 11 a–c, the increase of calcination temperature resulted in obvious size growth of the particles. The calcination time also had an impact on the surface area, the longer the cacination the lower the surface area, as shown in Table 1 . The discharge capacities at various rates for the LiFePO 4 /C composites prepared at various conditions were then measured with the results also listed in Table 1 . The discharge capacity and rate performance of the as-prepared LiFePO 4 /C composite was found highly dependent on the process parameters. The best performance was achieved at a ball milling time of 2–4 h followed by heat treatment at 700 °C for 20 h. X-ray diffraction pattern demonstrated a pure phase LiFePO 4 was already formed for the 600 °C calcinated sample. SEM examination demonstrated it had a mean particle size of 0.5 μm, smaller than the 700 °C calcinated one of 1.5 μm ( Fig. 11 b). A smaller particle size means a shorter lithium diffusion distance, which is beneficial for high-rate discharge and charge processes. However, the capacities at both low and high discharge rates were reduced as compared to the 700 °C calcinated one. The poor electrochemical performance of the 600 °C calcinated sample was then contributed from the coating layer, which was likely in the state of CH x based on the TGA and TPR experiments. Since CH x has poor electronic conductivity it would have a serious block effect on the electronic transfer. The poor electrochemical performance of the 800 °C calcinated sample was attributed to its large grain size (around 2.2 μm), as shown in Fig. 11 c, due to the sintering. Relatively poor electrochemical performance was also observed for the LiFePO 4 /C composite calcinated at 700 °C for 15 h. It was likely that some of carbon in the coating layer was still in the form of CH x due to the insufficient calcination time. As shown in Table 1 , the ball milling time also had a significant impact on the discharge capacity and rate performance of the derived LiFePO 4 /C composite. The optimal ball milling time was 2–4 h. The further increase of ball milling time resulted in obvious decrease of capacity at both low and high discharge rates. It was believed that the over ball milling accelerated the LiFePO 4 sintering during the following high-temperature treatment. To summary, ball milling time, heat treatment temperature and time should be specifically optimized in order to achieve a high-performance LiFePO 4 /C composite synthesized by mechanical activation adopting sucrose as carbon source. 4 Conclusions Olivine-type LiFePO 4 /C composite was successfully synthesized by mechanical activation followed by thermal treatment. Ball milling time, thermal treatment temperature and time all have significant impact on the electrochemical performance of the derived LiFePO 4 /C composite. The high-energy ball milling facilitated the phase reaction between reactants and the thermal decomposition of sucrose. The sucrose was first cracked to CH x intermediate, which was then further converted to solid carbon at 700 °C or higher for a sufficient time. Too low calcination temperature for example 600 °C, and too short calcination time for example 15 h, resulted in the residual of undecomposed CH x , which seriously blocked the electron transfer and consequently decreased the electrochemical performance of LiFePO 4 /C composite. Over ball milling or over heating, however, resulted in grain growth of LiFePO 4 electrode during the following thermal treatment, a decrease in electrochemical performance was then experienced. Thereby, the process parameter should be optimized in order to obtain a high electrochemical performance. At a ball milling time of 2–4 h, thermal treatment at 700 °C for 20 h, the derived LiFePO 4 /C composite showed a discharge capacity of 174 mAh/g at 0.1C rate, it reached the theoretical value for LiFePO 4 within experimental error. It also showed a high-rate performance with a discharge capacity of 117 mAh/g at 20C rate. The performance of the derived LiFePO 4 /C composite, prepared by mechanical activation was very sensitive to the process parameters. Suppressing the grain growth and avoiding CH x are the keys to achieve high-rate performance LiFePO 4 /C composite cathode. dyVFFYmA.title: High performance tubular solid oxide fuel cells with BSCF cathode
dyVFFYmA.abstract: Compared with planar SOFCs, tubular SOFCs have the advantages of facile sealing and easy scale up. In this study, a tubular anode-supported thin-film YSZ electrolyte SOFC was successfully fabricated by extrusion of the anode substrate in combination with wet powder spraying of the electrolyte layer. The fuel cell performance was tested by applying either hydrogen or methane as the fuel and ambient air as the cathode atmosphere. Peak power densities of 432 and 145 mW cm -2 were achieved respectively at 800 and 600°C for a cell with conventional LSM and silver wire as the cathode and the current collector. The performance was further improved by adopting BSCF cathode with an SDC buffer layer. EIS demonstrated the large electrode polarization resistance is the main source of cell resistance, while the contact resistance is also not negligible. The performance of the cell directly operating on methane fuel was also investigated. A special operation mode by alternatively operating on methane and hydrogen fuels was adopted, which can effectively increase the cell operational stability. © 2012 Hydrogen Energy Publications, LLC. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Rqmo2Zlm.title: Synthesis, characterization and evaluation of cation-ordered LnBaCo2O5+δ as materials of oxygen permeation membranes and cathodes of SOFCs
Rqmo2Zlm.abstract: LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ (Ln = La, Pr, Nd, Sm, Gd, and Y) was synthesized via an EDTA–citrate complexing process. The particular Ln 3+ dopant had a significant effect on the oxide’s phase structure/stability, oxygen content, electrical conductivity, oxygen permeability, and cathode performance. Stable, cation-ordered oxides with layered lattice structures were obtained with medium-sized Ln 3+ ions over a wide range of oxygen partial pressures, a property essential for applications as oxygen separation membranes and solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) cathodes. PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ demonstrated the highest oxygen flux (∼5.09 × 10 −7 mol cm −2 s −1 at 900 °C), but this value was still significantly lower than that of Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ perovskite (∼3.1 × 10 −6 mol cm −2 s −1 at 900 °C). The observed difference was attributed to the much longer diffusion distance through a polycrystalline membrane with a layered lattice structure than through cubic perovskite because bulk diffusion was the rate-limiting step of permeation. An area-specific resistance of ∼0.213 Ω cm 2 was achieved at 600 °C with a PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ cathode, suggesting that the layer-structured oxides were promising alternatives to ceramic membranes for SOFC cathodes. Keywords LnBa 2 Co 2 O 5+ δ Mixed conductor Cation-ordered SOFC Ceramic membrane 1 Introduction Some solid oxides with defined molecular structures, like perovskite, demonstrate mixed ionic and electronic conductivity at elevated temperatures, and they are promising materials for applications in power-generating solid-oxide fuel cell (SOFC) cathodes or in dense ceramic membranes for oxygen separation [1,2] . These new technologies offer enormous economic and environmental benefits. In contrast to the traditional oxygen separation processes of cryogenic fractional distillation and pressure swing adsorption, this new membrane technology could be exploited to develop a new oxygen separation process that would allow for continuous operation and increased energy savings [3] . Furthermore, a ceramic oxygen membrane can be coupled to an oxidative reaction, such as partial oxidation of methane to syngas, allowing the two processes to be performed in a single step. This would greatly simplify reactor design, improve safety, increase the selectivity of product formation, and, most importantly, reduce operational costs [4–6] . In addition, SOFCs are much more efficient than internal combustion engines in converting chemical energy into usable work while simultaneously reducing CO 2 and pollutant emissions [7–9] . Dense ceramic membranes fabricated from these oxides are oxygen-permeable; oxygen ions can permeate from the oxygen-rich side, through the bulk of the material, to the oxygen-poor side. Electron countercurrents opposing the flow of oxygen ions maintain charge balance within the material. The mechanism of oxygen permeation through these membranes is outlined in Fig. 1 a. First, gas-phase molecular oxygen on the oxygen-rich side diffuses to the membrane surface where it is adsorbed. The adsorbed oxygen then withdraws two electrons form the membrane and dissociates into oxygen ions. Driven by the oxygen partial pressure gradient across the membrane, the oxygen ions diffuse across the membrane bulk to the membrane surface on the oxygen-poor side, where they recombine with electron holes to form adsorbed molecular and atomic oxygen. Finally, the molecular oxygen is desorbed into the gas phase on the oxygen-poor side. High-oxygen surface-exchange kinetics and a high rate of oxygen diffusion through the membrane bulk are, therefore, crucial to achieving superior oxygen fluxes through a membrane with a given thickness and a given transmembrane oxygen partial pressure gradient. The widespread commercialization of SOFCs requires both lowering cost and enhancing the cell stability, and finding suitable materials that operate efficiently at reduced temperatures (400–700 °C) is one way of achieving these goals [10,11] . Most SOFC cathodes are fabricated from La 0.8 Sr 0.2 MnO 3 perovskite, which is a strong electronic conductor [12] . During fuel cell operation, the reduction of oxygen is strictly limited to the electrode–electrolyte–gas triple phase boundary, and sharp increases in electrode polarization resistance are typically observed at lower operating temperatures. Applying a mixed ionic and electronic conducting (MIEC) oxide as an electrode should allow for the oxygen reduction sites to penetrate into the electrode bulk to a finite depth. The mechanism of oxygen activation at a MIEC cathode is depicted in Fig. 1 b. The pertinent reactions involve both oxygen surface exchange and bulk diffusion processes. As demonstrated by Adler et al., oxygen surface sorption and bulk diffusion limit the characteristic depth of oxygen reduction in porous MIEC electrodes [13] . To achieve high oxygen fluxes through ceramic membranes or efficient SOFC performance at reduced temperatures, MIEC materials with faster oxygen diffusion rates through the material bulk and improved surface exchange kinetics are of great importance. Substituted perovskite oxides have been the most thoroughly investigated oxides for these purposes. Specific compositions have demonstrated outstanding oxygen diffusion rates, favorable electronic conductivities, and good oxygen surface exchange kinetics [14–18] . Recently, however, perovskite-related oxides, LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ (Ln = Y, Pr, Nd, Sm, Gd) have received tremendous attention as potential alternative MIEC oxides. These materials possess an ordered structure in which lanthanide and alkali-earth ions occupy the A-site sub-lattice and oxygen vacancies are localized into layers [19–25] . The structures of these materials are compared with those of the perovskite oxides in Fig. 2 . The ideal structure of this family of compounds can be represented by the stacking sequence …∣LnO δ ∣CoO 2 ∣BaO∣CoO 2 . Transformation of a simple cubic perovskite with randomly occupied A-sites into a layered crystal with alternating lanthanide and alkali-earth planes reduces the strength of oxygen binding and provides disorder-free channels for ionic motion, thereby theoretically increasing the oxygen diffusivity by many orders of magnitude [19] . Until now, most investigations of cation-ordered materials have focused on their magnetic properties at low temperatures [26–30] . Recently, however, they have also received attention for their potential application as SOFC cathodes [19–25] . Nevertheless, their performance as ceramic membranes has not yet been investigated experimentally. Furthermore, a systematic investigation of the effect of the Ln 3+ cation on the high-temperature properties of LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ is also still lacking. In this study, experiments to determining the effect of the Ln 3+ cation on the properties of mixed conducting double perovskite, such as phase structure and stability, oxygen content, electrical conductivity, oxygen permeation, and cathodic performance, were conducted. 2 Experimental procedure 2.1 Synthesis and fabrication LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ (Ln = La,Y, Pr, Nd, Sm and Gd) composite oxides were synthesized via combined EDTA–citrate complexing sol–gel process [31,32] . Ba(NO 3 ) 2 , Co(NO 3 ) 2 · x H 2 O and Ln(NO 3 ) 3 · x H 2 O (all A.R. grade) served as the raw materials for the necessary metal ions. Separate 1 M solutions of the nitrates were prepared, and their precise concentrations were determined by titration with EDTA. From these solutions, solutions were prepared with molar ratios of total metal ions:EDTA:citric acid of 1:1:2, and their pH values were adjusted to ∼6 with NH 3 · H 2 O. The solutions were heated continuously at 90 °C until sufficient water had evaporated that a transparent purple gel was obtained. This gel was pre-fired at 250 °C and subsequently calcinated at various temperatures for 5 h under an air atmosphere to yield the desired oxide powder products. These oxide powders were pressed into disk-shaped pellets using a stainless steel mold (15.0 mm diameter) under approximately 1.5 × 10 8 Pa hydraulic pressure. The resulting green disks were roughly 1.0 mm thick and were further sintered in an electrical box furnace at 1100–1150 °C for 2–5 h under an air atmosphere. During this time, the heating and cooling rates were controlled at 1–2 °C min −1 . The resulting sintered membranes had diameters of ∼12 mm and relative densities measured by a liquid displacement technique with pure water acting as the medium. The relative densities and theoretical densities of the samples are given in Table 1 . Both faces of the membranes were polished with 1000 mesh SiC paper until the desired thickness was achieved. 2.2 Basic characterization The crystal structures of the metal oxide powders and the sintered membranes were determined using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Bruker D8 Advance). An environmental scanning microscope (ESEM, QUANTA-2000) equipped with an energy disperse X-ray (EDX) attachment was used to measure the samples’ surface morphologies. The stoichiometry of oxygen vacancies was measured with the iodometric titration technique [33] . Samples were dissolved in a solution of potassium iodide in HCl and heated in an oxygen-free environment. The iodide reduced any cobalt ions (Co 3+ , Co 4+ ) present to Co 2+ and was simultaneously oxidized to form I 2 . The amount of I 2 released was quantified via redox titration with thiosulfate, and the oxygen vacancy stoichiometry was then calculated based on the amount of I 2 formed. For oxygen temperature-programmed desorption (O 2 -TPD) experiments, 0.05–0.1 g of oxide powder was deposited into a U-type quartz reactor with an inner diameter of ∼3 mm. A K-type thermocouple was positioned near the powder to monitor and control sample temperature. High-purity helium (>99.999%) was fed into the reactor at a rate of 20 ml min −1 (STP, standard temperature and pressure). After circulating helium gas at room temperature for around 30 min to get rid of any weakly adsorbed species, the reactor was heated at 10 °C min −1 to a final temperature of 950 °C. As the adsorbed molecular oxygen was released from the oxide lattice during the heating, the helium carried the molecules to a mass spectrometer (Hiden QIC-20), which was coupled to the reactor outlet, for in situ analysis. For carbon dioxide temperature-programmed desorption (CO 2 -TPD) experiment, the samples were first pretreated by CO 2 atmosphere at 800 °C for 5 h and quickly cooled down to room temperature under the same atmosphere. The helium sweep gas at 20 ml min −1 (STP) was then switched on. After blew away the residual CO 2 gas inside the reactor by the flowing helium for a couple of minutes, the temperature was increased from ∼200 °C at a rate of 10 °C min −1 to 930 °C and dwelled until no more CO 2 released from the sample. The evolved CO 2 during the TPD process was in situ analyzed by a mass spectrometer (MS). The electrical conductivities of sintered bars with approximate dimensions of 2 mm × 5 mm × 12 mm were measured using a four-probe DC method. Measurements were performed under an air atmosphere while cooling from 900 to 300 °C at intervals of 5 °C. A constant current was applied to the two current wires. The voltage response of the two voltage wires was monitored using a Keithley 2420 Sourcemeter. Sufficient time (∼5 min) was allowed for the conductivity to reach its steady-state value. The current was increased from 1 μA to a maximum value of 2 A. Only data in the ohmic regime were used to calculate conductivity. 2.3 Oxygen permeation measurement Membrane permeability was assessed using a high-temperature oxygen permeation apparatus via the gas chromatography (GC) method [33] . A silver paste was used to fix the membrane disk onto a dense quartz tube. The effective exposed area on the sweep side was ∼0.45 cm 2 . The membrane sidewall was also painted with the silver paste to avoid any radial contributions to the oxygen flux. Air was supplied to the oxygen-rich side of the membrane at a flow rate of 400 ml min −1 (STP), and helium was employed not only as a sweep gas to create an oxygen partial pressure gradient across the membrane but also as the carrier gas for transporting the permeated oxygen to a Varian GC equipped with a 5 Å capillary column and thermal conductivity detector for quantitative oxygen concentration analysis. The oxygen permeation flux was calculated using the following formula: (1) J O 2 ( mol cm - 2 s - 1 ) = C O 2 - C N 2 × 0.21 0.79 × 28 32 1 / 2 × F S , where C O and C N are the measured gas-phase concentrations of oxygen and nitrogen, respectively, on the sweep side (mol ml −1 ), F is the flow rate of the exit gas on the sweep side (ml s −1 ), and S is the geometric surface area of the membrane on the sweep side (cm 2 ). 2.4 Electrochemical characterization Electrochemical characterization was conducted using a symmetric cell configuration. Electrolyte disks were fabricated from Sm 0.2 Ce 0.8 O 1.9 (SDC) powder via die-pressing and were subsequently sintered at 1500 °C for 5 h under an air atmosphere. The average thickness and diameter of the sintered electrolyte disks were approximately 1.0 and 13 mm, respectively. Cathode slurry was sprayed onto each side of the electrolyte substrate as symmetrically as possible, and the substrate was then calcinated at 1000 °C for 2 h under an air atmosphere. The area-specific polarization resistance of the cathode under an air atmosphere was determined from its electrochemical impedance spectrum (EIS) using a Solartron 1260 frequency response analyzer in combination with a Solartron 1287 potentiostat/galvanostat. The frequency range of EIS measurement was from 0.1 Hz to 100 kHz, and the signal amplitude was 10 mV. Data were collected with ZPlot 2.9c software. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Phase and oxygen nonstoichiometric properties Oxides were prepared from the appropriate chemical precursors via calcination at 900 °C for 5 h under an air atmosphere, and the oxide’s XRD patterns were acquired ( Fig. 3 ). Samples with the nominal compositions of LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ (Ln = Y, Pr, Nd, Sm or Gd) were pure-phase oxides with orthorhombic lattice geometry of space group Pmmm, and these findings were in agreement with previously published reports [26,34,35] . These structures resembled that of simple cubic perovskite-type Ln 1− x Ba x CoO 3− δ , but the distributions of rare-earth and alkali-earth ions were stratified into individual layers instead of being randomly intermixed [36] . The measured difference in diffraction angle (2 θ ) between the peaks corresponding to the (1 2 0) and (1 0 2) planes was steadily reduced as the radius of the Ln 3+ ion was increased, suggesting that the difference in bond length between Ba–O and Ln–O bonds was reduced with increasing Ln 3+ cation size. Furthermore, steady increases in ionic radius shifted the diffraction peaks to lower values of 2 θ , and the Ln 3+ ions were ranked in descending order according to the reverse shift in 2 θ as follows (radius of Ln 3+ in 8-coordination with oxygen is also given in parentheses): Pr 3+ (1.13 Å), Nd 3+ (1.11 Å), Sm 3+ (1.08 Å), Gd 3+ (1.05 Å), and Y 3+ (1.02 Å). This trend in the diffraction patterns was indicative of unit cell contractions. Finally, impure phases were observed for LaBaCo 2 O 5+ δ , suggesting that the La 3+ dopant was, in fact, over-sized. The complete list of relevant lattice parameters is given in Table 2 . If these oxide materials are applied in oxygen separation membranes for solid-oxide fuel cells, then they will be subjected to an oxygen partial pressure gradient during operation. Typically, one side of the membrane is exposed to either air or compressed air and the other side is exposed to a steady flow of an inert carrier gas. Although an SOFC cathode is usually exposed to air, the oxygen partial pressure at its surface could be much lower than that of the surrounding environment during current-induced polarization. The oxide phase structure must be stable under operation conditions to ensure a high trans-membrane oxygen permeation flux or a stable cathode performance. For example, under a cathodic polarization potential of ∼0.2 V, the local partial pressure of oxygen at the cathode surface is ∼5 × 10 −6 atm at 600 °C when air is used as the cathodic atmosphere. This value is nearly the same as that present in a high-purity sample of inert gas. The structural stability of the oxides under realistic oxygen separation conditions was investigated by annealing the materials at 850 °C under an atmosphere of air, pure oxygen, or pure nitrogen for an extended period (100 h). The samples were then examined using XRD techniques ( Fig. 4 ). A phase transition was observed for the LaBaCo 2 O 5+ δ and YBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxides under a reducing nitrogen atmosphere. In addition, impure phases also appeared in the YBaCo 2 O 5+ δ sample under an oxidizing oxygen atmosphere. For the other oxide formulations, the double perovskite structure was stable under all atmospheres tested, suggesting that the size of the dopant Ln 3+ cation was essential for a stable, layered crystalline structure. It has been previously demonstrated that the phase structures of LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxides are dependent upon the oxygen contents of their LnO δ layers [25] . In agreement with these observations, various superstructures, which resulted from the ordering of oxygen vacancies in the LnO δ layer, were observed in the YBaCo 2 O 5+ δ samples [37] . The iodometic titration method was employed to assess the precise value of δ at room temperature for the various samples annealed under atmospheres of air, oxygen, or nitrogen ( Table 3 ). The value of δ declined both when the partial pressure of oxygen during annealing was decreased and when the Ln 3+ ionic radius was decreased. Furthermore, increasing the Ln 3+ cationic radii also resulted in higher nominal oxidation states for the cobalt ions. Taskin et al. noted that the concentration of oxygen in an LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxide was very sensitive to the size of the lanthanide; those containing larger Ln 3+ ions possessed a greater number of oxygen atoms within their LnO δ planes [38] . Our results confirmed these observations ( Table 3 ). Low oxygen content in the LnO δ layer may have partly accounted for the poor stability of YBaCo 2 O 5+ δ under a nitrogen atmosphere (see Table 3 ). 3.2 Oxygen desorption properties and carbon dioxide sensitivity It is generally believed that pervasive cationic ordering at the crystal lattice A-site facilitates oxygen diffusion through the LnO δ layer of LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxides [19] . Experiments employing TGA, electrical conductivity relaxation measurements, and oxygen–isotope exchange/depth profiling techniques have corroborated the validity of this hypothesis [19,21,23,25] . In the present work, an O 2 -TPD technique was adopted to further investigate the oxygen diffusivity properties of such oxides. With the programmed increase in sample temperature, the reduction of metal ions from higher to lower oxidation states occurs simultaneously alongside the creation of oxygen vacancies in the oxide bulk and the release of oxygen from the lattice. For cobalt-based perovskite-related oxides, the oxygen desorption α-peak (200–600 °C) is typically associated with the reduction of Co 4+ to Co 3+ , while the β-peak (>800 °C) is usually related to the reduction of Co 3+ to Co 2+ [39] . The initial temperature of oxygen desorption ( T i ) and the peak temperature ( T p ) were determined from the oxygen surface-exchange kinetics and oxygen diffusion rate through the bulk, the particle size of the powder, and the heating rate. The peak intensity was closely related to the variability of cobalt oxidation state within the oxides. To minimize the effect of particle morphology on oxygen desorption behavior, the different oxides were prepared in a manner that was as consistent as possible. Thus, all the samples were synthesized using the same EDTA–citrate complexing technique and were calcinated under identical conditions, 950 °C for 5 h under an air atmosphere. SEM imaging showed that all of the samples possessed similar particle morphologies with mean particle sizes of 1 μm regardless of their specific Ln 3+ dopants ( Fig. 5 ). The O 2 -TPD profiles of the various LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxides were compared to the oxygen desorption curve for BSCF ( Fig. 6 ). Similar to BSCF, two desorption peaks were observed for the LaBaCo 2 O 5+ δ , PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ and NdBaCo 2 O 5+ δ samples. In accordance with literature precedent, the first desorption peak was ascribed to the de-intercalation of oxygen from the LnO δ plane that is typically associated with the reduction of Co 4+ to Co 3+ . The T i and T p values for the α-oxygen desorption were 219 and 421 °C, respectively, for PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ , while the corresponding values were 311 and 437 °C, respectively, for BSCF perovskite (see Table 4 ). This indicated that the double-layered perovskite structure facilitated oxygen de-intercalation from the lattice, so these results agree with those of previous experiments employing TGA and electrical relaxation techniques [19,23] . As the size of the Ln 3+ cation was decreased, the T i and T p of α -oxygen desorption both shifted to higher temperatures, suggesting that oxygen mobility within the LnO δ plane had been reduced. Such a trend was attributed to the increased columbic attraction between Ln 3+ and O 2− ions. The reduced peak intensity of β-oxygen desorption with decreases in Ln 3+ cation size (from Ln = Pr to Gd) suggested that this change suppressed the thermal reduction of Co 3+ to Co 2+ . Interestingly, two consecutive peaks appeared in the low-temperature ranges of spectra corresponding to the SmBaCo 2 O 5+ δ and GdBaCo 2 O 5+ δ samples, implying that oxygen desorption might also occur in the CoO 2 planes. Four successive desorption peaks appeared in the α-zone of the YBaCo 2 O 5+ δ spectrum that were presumably connected to the collapse of the double-layered perovskite structure following the O 2 -TPD experiment and the phase transition during the O 2 desorption process. In addition, the instability of perovskite containing alkaline-earth elements in the presence of CO 2 emerged as one of the limiting factors for their application. Therefore, it is important to check whether LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxides are also sensitive to CO 2 pickup. CO 2 -TPD can provide effective information on the behavior of CO 2 over these materials. As shown in Fig. 7 , The CO 2 -TPD profiles of the various LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxides were compared to the CO 2 desorption curve for BSCF. The obvious CO 2 desorption peaks were observed for all LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ samples. The peak intensity of LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ samples, which represented the amount of CO 2 adsorbed, were relatively small as compared to that of BSCF. This result indicated that the interaction between CO 2 and LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ was depressed on a certain extent. It is likely that the slow diffusion of Ba 2+ in the Ba–O plane inhibited carbonate formed over the powder surface, owing to the double-layered perovskite structure. 3.3 Electrical conductivity High electrical conductivity is one fundamental requirement for MIEC materials used either as electrodes for SOFCs or as oxygen permeation membranes. There are two primary conduction mechanisms relevant to these oxides, electronic and ionic conduction, as a result of the simultaneous presence of both electronic holes and oxygen vacancies within these materials. The total conductivity of LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ materials under air and nitrogen atmospheres was measured using a four-probe DC method ( Fig. 8 ). Because ionic conductivity is much lower than electronic conductivity, the values reported herein were assumed to be attributable to electronic conductivity alone. The maximal conductivity of LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ was 120–350 S cm −1 , which was reached under an air atmosphere and which was highly dependent on the Ln 3+ dopant. Conductivity values initially increased with increasing Ln 3+ cation size and the reached a maximum value before declining. The two highest conductivies observed under an air atmosphere were attributable to SmBaCo 2 O 5+ δ followed by NdBaCo 2 O 5+ δ . Electronic conduction within perovskite-related oxides is believed to occur via electron hopping along B–O–B bonds. The exact mechanism is thought to resemble a Zerner double exchange process, which is closely related to both the mobility of the electrical carriers and the path of diffusion. As the O 2 -TPD experiments demonstrated, increasing the ionic radius of the Ln 3+ cation facilitated the reduction of Co 4+ to Co 3+ . These results were also used to explain the following conductivity ranking: YBaCo 2 O 5+ δ < GdBaCo 2 O 5+ δ < SmBaCo 2 O 5+ δ . Nevertheless, the degree of overlap between the electron clouds of the oxygen and cobalt ions also affects a material’s conductivity. Generally, increasing B–O–B bond lengths in cobalt-containing perovskites leads to decreased electron delocalization and to more difficult direct electron hopping between Co 4+ and Co 3+ centers [40] . Consequently, further increases in Ln 3+ ionic radius should decrease the electrical conductivity such that SmBaCo 2 O 5+ δ > NdBaCo 2 O 5+ δ > PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ > LaBaCo 2 O 5+ δ . Within the 20–900 °C temperature range, LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxides demonstrated predominately metal-like conductivities when exposed to an air atmosphere. The observed increase in electrical conductivity with increases in oxygen partial pressure, Fig. 8 suggested P-type electron conduction, in which electrons hopped between Co 3+ and Co 4+ . This agreed well with previous results, indicating a nominal cobalt ion oxidation state greater than 3+ in most LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxides that were investigated. The conductivity tended to drop suddenly as the temperature was decreased to ∼150 °C under an air atmosphere, suggesting a transition to insulator–metal behavior [26] . Under the low oxygen partial pressure of a pure nitrogen atmosphere, all LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxides exhibited relatively high electrical conductivity and reached maximal conductivities from 50 to 100 S cm −1 . Generally, decreasing the partial pressure of oxygen and increasing the operating temperature decreased the materials’ electrical conductivities due to the creation of oxygen vacancies. Such lattice defects broke the B–O–B bonds and resulted in obvious decreases in electronic conductivity [41] . As a result of the layered structure of LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxides, oxygen release usually occurred in the LnO δ plane. For many materials, no oxygen vacancies were created in the CoO 2 plane, thus ensuring a contiguous path of B–O–B bonds for electron transport processes. This explained the high electron conductivities of the LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxides examined in low-oxygen environments. 3.4 Oxygen permeation properties The potential application of LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxides as materials for constructing ceramic oxygen separation membranes was also investigated. There is no existence of open pores observed form the SEM micrographs. All of the samples possessed similar morphologies with mean grain size of 5 μm ( Fig. 9 ). The temperature dependence of the oxygen permeation flux through 0.7 mm thick membranes was measured for a variety of Ln 3+ -doped oxides ( Fig. 10 ). Ambient air was used as a feed gas to maintain the partial pressure of oxygen at 0.21 atm on the oxygen-rich side of the membrane, and a helium carrier gas was pumped across the opposing side of the membrane at a constant flow rate of 100 ml min −1 (STP) to create an oxygen partial pressure gradient across the membrane. For the YBaCo 2 O 5+ δ membrane, zero oxygen permeability was detected within the limits of experimental error at temperatures between 700 and 900 °C. A similarly low permeability was also observed for the LaBaCo 2 O 5+ δ membrane at 900 °C (0.625 × 10 −7 mol cm −2 s −1 ) that quickly decayed to zero as the temperature was lowered to 825 °C. Such poor oxygen permeability was attributed to the poor stability of the oxides’ layered structures, as measured during XRD experiments. Under identical operating conditions, the oxygen flux through the LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ membrane increased as the Ln 3+ ionic radius was increased such that the permeabilities were ranked as follows: PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ > NdBaCo 2 O 5+ δ > SmBaCo 2 O 5+ δ > GdBaCo 2 O 5+ δ . This ranking was identical to that of oxygen mobility within the LnO δ layer, suggesting that the rate of oxygen diffusion within the membrane bulk may be rate-limiting for the passage of oxygen through thick LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ membranes. The highest permeation flux of ∼5.09 × 10 −7 mol cm −2 s −1 at 900 °C was achieved using a membrane composed of PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ . The dependence of the oxygen flux through a PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ membrane on the membrane thickness ( Fig. 11 ) supported the aforementioned hypothesis regarding the rate-limiting step of oxygen transport. Reducing the membrane thickness was predicted to increase the trans-membrane oxygen flux ( Fig. 11 b), and these two quantities were roughly inversely proportional between 700 and 900 °C. This strongly indicates that the rate of diffusion with the bulk was controlling the overall rate of oxygen permeation. Although the oxygen flux across PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ membranes at high temperatures were higher than those across other layered oxides, such as YBa 2 Cu 3 O 7 [42] , the values were still much lower than that across a BSCF membrane, the membrane with the highest oxygen permeability. A maximal permeation flux of ∼3.1 × 10 −6 mol cm −2 s was achieved at 900 °C using a 0.7 mm thick BSCF membrane under similar conditions, and this value was almost 6 times that of the PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ membrane tested in this study. Since PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxides have been reported to possess superior oxygen diffusion rates and faster surface exchange kinetics than those of A-site cation-disordered perovskite-oxide-related oxides, these findings were somewhat peculiar. To explain this discrepancy, it was necessary to determine the membranes’ oxygen ionic conductivities. For the ceramic MIEC membranes, when diffusion of oxygen through the membrane bulk controls the rate of permeation, the permeation flux can be expressed using the Wanger equation as follows: (2) J O 2 = - RT 4 2 F 2 L ∫ ln P O 2 ′ ln P O 2 ″ t ion t el δ total d ln P O 2 , where F is Faraday’s constant, L is the membrane thickness, t ion is the ionic transference number, t el is the electronic transference number, σ total is the sum of ionic and electronic conductivities, and P O 2 ′ and P O 2 ″ are the equivalent partial pressures of oxygen on the feed side and sweep side, respectively. Because the ionic conductivity of oxygen seldom exceeded 1 S cm −1 , and the total conductivity of PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ was greater than 30 S cm −1 even under a reducing nitrogen atmosphere between 700 and 900 °C ( Fig. 11 b), Eq. (2) was simplified in the following manner: (3) J O 2 = - RT 4 2 F 2 L ∫ ln P O 2 ′ ln P O 2 ″ δ ion d [ ln P O 2 ] . The average oxygen ionic conductivity can then be calculated using the following expression: (4) σ ave = J O 2 4 2 F 2 L RT ln P O 2 ′ P O 2 ″ - 1 . The temperature dependence of nominal ionic conductivity was measured for the various LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxides ( Fig. 12 ). For PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ , values of 0.011, 0.028, 0.048, 0.073, and 0.099 S cm −1 were achieved at 700, 750, 800, 850, and 900 °C, respectively. Based on oxygen flux measurements, the nominal oxygen ionic conductivity of BSCF at 900 °C was found to be greater than 1.4 S cm −1 [43] , suggesting that the ionic conductivity of PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ was much smaller than that of BSCF. Based on TGA and electrical conductivity relaxation measurements, the oxygen ionic conductivity of GdBaCo 2 O 5+ δ was reported to be as high as 0.01 S cm −1 at 500 °C [19] , so PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ possesses even greater ionic conductivity than GdBaCo 2 O 5+ δ [23] . From linear extrapolation of the ionic conductivity curve ( Fig. 12 ), the ionic conductivity was calculated to be 0.0016 S cm −1 , a value 6.3 times lower than the anticipated value, 0.01 S cm −1 . This suggested that different methods could produce divergent nominal ionic conductivity measurements. Ceramic membranes are typically composed of polycrystalline oxides. For membranes composed of perovskite oxide with cubic phase structures, the distribution of oxygen vacancies within the lattice is disordered, and oxygen can diffuse freely within the lattice. Thus, variations in microstructure have less effect on oxygen transport through the membrane. In contrast, in A-site cation-ordered LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxides, it has been demonstrated that oxygen diffusion is restricted within the LnO δ plane and that oxygen diffusion through the CoO 2 plane or in a direction perpendicular to the LnO δ plane is negligible. This implies that changes in the polycrystalline membrane microstructure could result in significant changes in the oxygen diffusion path. The oxygen transport path within the polycrystalline oxide membrane was more distorted than that of the single-crystal membrane because the individual crystals composing the polycrystalline oxide were randomly oriented ( Fig. 13 ). The actual oxygen diffusion distance could be much longer than just the membrane thickness, the distance used in calculation of the material’s ionic conductivity. This may have explained the lower-than-expected oxygen ionic conductivity calculated from measurements of transmembrane oxygen flux. 3.5 Cathode performance Considering the outstanding oxygen surface-exchange kinetics of A-site cation-ordered oxides, these materials are perhaps best applied either as surface coatings for ceramic oxygen separation membranes or as reduced temperature solid-oxide fuel cell cathodes. For such applications, the oxide layers are limited to being tens of microns thick. Consequently, the reduction of adsorbed oxygen plays a much larger role in determining the polarization resistance when the diffusion distance is much shorter (i.e., tens of microns) rather than longer (i.e., hundreds to thousands of microns). The performance of LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ as an SOFC cathode was assessed at intermediate temperatures. A symmetric cell configuration was used with SDC serving as the electrolyte. The area-specific polarization resistance (ASR) of LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ between 500 and 700 °C was measured for each of the various Ln 3+ dopants ( Fig. 14 ). Among the oxides examined, PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ performed best. The area-specific polarization resistance of this material at 600 °C was ∼0.213 Ω cm 2 , a value very similar to that reported by Jacobson et al. [23] for PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ + GDC composite cathodes. For the purposes of comparison, the ASRs of BSCF is ∼0.1 Ω cm 2 at 600 °C under similar operation conditions ( Fig. 14 ). Thus, the performance characteristics of LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxides are very attractive because they suggest serious potential for application of these materials as IT-SOFC cathodes. The differences between PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ and BSCF in terms of their polarization resistances was much smaller than their differences in terms of transmembrane oxygen flux (a factor of 2.1 versus a factor of ∼6), thereby supporting the hypothesis that layer-structured oxides would be more successful if applied to fabricate cathodes rather than to fabricate ceramic membranes. The performance of the individual LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxides was ranked as follows: Pr 3+ > Gd 3+ > Nd 3+ > Sm 3+ > La 3+ > Y 3+ . This ranking mirrored the aforementioned oxygen permeation assessment. The Y 3+ - and La 3+ -doped samples demonstrated the poorest performance, which coincided with the instability of the layered structures within these materials as determined from XRD studies ( Fig. 4 ). 4 Conclusions LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxides were synthesized using an EDTA-citrate complexing process at relatively low calcination temperatures. The stabilities of the double-layered perovskite structure of the LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxides were closely related to the ionic radius of the Ln 3+ cation. Stable layered structure was observed for Ln = Pr, Nd, Sm, and Gd, while layer structure was in a metastable state for Ln = Y and La. Increasing the ionic radius of the Ln 3+ cation increased oxygen content and the nominal oxidation state of the cobalt ions in the oxide. In addition, larger ionic radii for the Ln 3+ cation translated into higher the oxygen mobility in the LnO δ layer. Ceramic membranes fabricated from LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ demonstrated moderate oxygen permeation fluxes. While PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ membranes demonstrated the highest fluxes, these values were still much lower than those of Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ membranes, which are cubic perovskite lattice structures and have the highest measured oxygen permeability. The rate of oxygen diffusion through thick PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ membrane bulk was slow, so oxygen permeation was rate-limiting. This was attributed to the oxides’ polycrystalline structure and to the fact that oxygen diffusion was limited to the LnO δ layers only. Attractive high electrode performance, however, was observed for LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ , especially PrBaCo 2 O 5+ δ , which possessed an area-specific polarization resistance of ∼0.213 Ω cm 2 at 600 °C. These results were attributed to the fast exchange kinetics across the oxides’ surfaces, and they suggest that these layer-structured LnBaCo 2 O 5+ δ oxides might be best applied as materials for reduced-temperature solid-oxide fuel cell electrodes rather than as materials for ceramic oxygen-separation membranes.
