Oma6Gr0p.title: Proton-conducting fuel cells operating on hydrogen, ammonia and hydrazine at intermediate temperatures
Oma6Gr0p.abstract: Anode-supported proton-conducting fuel cell with BaZr 0.1 Ce 0.7 Y 0.2 O 3− δ (BZCY) electrolyte and Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ (BSCF) cathode was fabricated. Peak power densities of ∼420 and 135 mW/cm 2 were achieved, respectively, at 700 and 450 °C for a cell with 35 μm thick electrolyte operating on hydrogen fuel. The endothermic nature of the ammonia decomposition reaction, however, resulted in cell temperature 30–65 °C lower than the furnace when operating on ammonia. Accounting the cooling effect, comparable power density was achieved for the cell operating on ammonia and hydrogen at high temperature. At reduced temperature, the cell demonstrated worse performance when operating on ammonia than on hydrogen due to the poor activity of the anode towards NH 3 catalytic decomposition. By applying on-line catalytic decomposition products of N 2 H 4 as the fuel, similar cell performance to that with NH 3 fuel was also observed. Keywords BaZr 0.1 Ce 0.7 Y 0.2 O 3− δ Solid-oxide fuel cells Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ Ammonia hydrazine 1 Introduction Fuel cells, reputed for their high efficiency and low environmental impact, represent an attractive technology for converting fuel directly into electricity [1] . Proton-conducting perovskite-type oxides have received increasing attention as electrolytes of reduced temperature solid-oxide fuel cells (SOFC–H + ) since the pioneering work of Iwahara et al. [2] . Selected oxides have shown higher conductivity than many oxygen-ionic conducting electrolytes at temperature lower than 600 °C [3,4] . Furthermore, SOFC–H + leads to the production of water vapor at the cathode side, which helps to improve the electrical motive force and the conversion efficiency of SOFC system [5] . Although its high conductivity, many research works have demonstrated that BaCe 0.9 Y 0.1 O 2.95 (BCY) can react with CO 2 [6] . Recently Zou et al. reported that the resistance of the oxide towards CO 2 induced decomposition was greatly suppressed while the high conductivity was still maintained by partial substitution of Ce 4+ in BaCe 1y Y y O 3− δ with Zr 4+ at proper amount, specifically with the composition of BaCe 0.7 Zr 0.1 Y 0.2 O 3− δ (BCZY) [3,7] . As an eligible fuel for SOFCs, it is supposed to be cheap, safe and pollution-free, have no electrode contamination, and be easy to store and transport. Ammonia is produced in high quantities, mostly used as raw material for the production of artificial fertilizer and nitric acid. Recently, ammonia as the potential fuel of fuel cell has been recognized [8] . On the other hand, hydrazine is in liquid state at room temperature and ambient pressure; it can be treated as the carrier of NH 3 . By applying ammonia or N 2 H 4 as the fuel of SOFC–H + , both the CO 2 induced decomposition of electrolyte and the formation of NO x are avoided. In this study, an anode-supported SOFC with proton-conducting electrolyte of BaZr 0.1 Ce 0.7 Y 0.2 O 3− δ (BZCY) and mixed oxygen-ionic and electronic conducting cathode of Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ (BSCF) was fabricated. The performance of the fuel cell with hydrogen, ammonia and hydrazine as the fuels was comparatively studied. 2 Experimental Both BZCY and BSCF oxides were synthesized by a combined EDTA–citrate complexing sol-gel process [9,10] . Anode-supported electrolyte dual-layer cells were fabricated using a co-pressing technique followed by high-temperature sintering. Anode powders were prepared by mixing NiO and BZCY in weight ratio of 60:40 with the help of a high-energy ball miller (Dalton, Pulverisette 6). To fabricate the single cell, the powders of NiO + BZCY were first pressed as a substrate, onto which a proper amount of fine BZCY powder was added and pressed again to form a bi-layer pellet [11] . The green pellets were then sintered in air at 1450 °C for 5 h to result in the densification of the electrolyte layer. BSCF slurry was spray deposited onto the central surface of the electrolyte and fired at 950 °C in air for 2 h. The phase structure of the oxides was examined by X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Bruker D8 Advance). The microscopic features of the prepared electrodes or single cell were characterized using an Environmental Scanning Electron Microscope (ESEM, QUANTA-2000). A single cell was sealed onto a quartz tube reactor with the cathode side exposed to ambient air while the anode swept with 3% H 2 O humidified H 2 at a flow rate of 80 ml/min [STP], or NH 3 at a flow rate of 60 ml/min [STP], or on-line catalytic decomposition products of N 2 H 4 by BSCF (0.5 g) at a temperature of 40 °C [12] . I – V polarization curves were collected using a digital source meter (Model 2420, Keithley, Cleveland, OH). Four-probe configuration was adopted. Silver paste was applied as the current collector. The electrochemical impedence spectroscopy (EIS) of the cell was investigated under open circuit voltage (OCV) conditions by AC impedance using an electrochemical workstation based on a Solartron 1260A frequency response analyzer in combination with a Solartron 1287 potentiostat. The frequency applied was ranged from 0.01 Hz to 1 MHz with a signal amplitude of 10 mV. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 a shows the SEM morphologies of a typical three-layer single cell. The electrolyte with a thickness of ∼35 μm was highly densified, which was composed of well-sintered grains with the main size of 2–3 μm ( Fig. 1 b). Both the anode and the cathode were found to have good adhesion with the electrolyte layer ( Fig. 1 c and d), which ensured a low contact resistance. The anode (reduced) was composed of particles with uniform size of ∼3 μm, while the cathode was composed of grains with the particle size varied from 1 to 10 μm. No obvious interfacial layer was observed between BZCY electrolyte and BSCF cathode according to Fig. 1 d. Fig. 2 a and b shows the XRD diffractions of the electrolyte and cathode layers. The compositions of the electrolyte and cathode layers matched well to the perovskite-type BZCY and BSCF, respectively. The absence of serious reaction between BZCY and BSCF layers was further supported from the phase reaction experiment by mixing BSCF and BZCY powders in weight ratio of 50–50 followed by calcining at 950 °C for 5 h. As shown in Fig. 2 c, the XRD patterns of the mixture after the calcinations can be indexed well based on a physical mixture of BSCF and BZCY. Fig. 3 a shows the I – V curves of a typical cell with hydrogen fuel at temperatures varied from 450 to 750 °C. The linear response of cell voltage with the polarization current indicates that the concentration polarization was not appeared, even at high current density. It implies that there were sufficient pores inside the electrodes, ensuring the free gas diffusion. A peak power density of ∼420 mW/cm 2 was achieved at 700 °C. The performance of fuel cells with the same electrolyte (BZCY) and anode (BZCY + Ni) but a different cathode composition has been reported in literature [3,13,14] . At 700 °C, Zuo et al. got a peak power density of 270 mW/cm 2 with a Ba(Ce 0.4 Pr 0.4 Y 0.2 )O 3− δ cathode and electrolyte thickness of 65 μm [3] , Xie et al. of 330 mW/cm 2 with a La 0.5 Sr 0.5 CoO 3− δ cathode and electrolyte thickness of 50 μm [13] , and Lin et al. of 266 mW/cm 2 with a GdBaCo 2 O 5+ x cathode and electrolyte thickness of 10 μm [14] . At 550 °C we still obtained a peak power density as high as ∼222 mW/cm 2 while Zuo and Lin both reported a value of ∼85 mW/cm 2 [3,14] . Above results suggest that BSCF performed much better as a cathode of SOFC–H + on BZCY electrolyte than the others, especially at lower temperatures. As shown in Fig. 3 b are the corresponding impedances of the single cell at various temperatures under OCV conditions in Nyquist plots. The high-frequency intercept of the impedance spectrum gives the ohmic resistance of the cell ( R ohm ), which includes the resistive contributions of the electrolyte, the two electrodes, the current collectors and the lead wires. In this study, the ohmic resistance of the two electrodes, the current collectors and the lead wires were reasonably considered to be negligible. The low-frequency intercept gives the total resistance ( R ohm + R p ), which includes the ohmic resistance of the cell and the effective interfacial polarization resistance associated with the electrochemical reactions at the both electrode–electrolyte interfaces. The interfacial resistance which includes both the anode and cathode is 0.28 Ω cm 2 at 600 °C. It is considerably lower than the reported values of 0.63 Ω cm 2 for the similar cell with a GdBaCo 2 O 5+ x cathode [14] , 0.9 Ω cm 2 with a La 0.5 Sr 0.5 CoO 3− δ cathode (650 °C) [13] , and 0.7 Ω cm 2 with a Ba(Pr 0.4 Ce 0.4 Y 0.2 )O 3− δ cathode [3] . Above results support that the high power density achieved in this study is due to, at least in part, the improved cathode performance. At 500 °C, nearly half of the cell resistance was still contributed from the ohmic loss of the electrolyte, implying that a decrease of the electrolyte thickness would envisage noticeable increase in fuel cell performance further. The same cell was then investigated for operating on ammonia fuel. As shown in Fig. 4 a are the corresponding I – V curves at furnace temperatures of 450–750 °C. As compared to the results by applying hydrogen as the fuel, as shown in Fig. 3 a, the OCVs were somewhat lowered. For example, an OCV of ∼1.1 V was achieved at 450 °C for the cell operating on hydrogen fuel, while it was only ∼0.98 V by applying ammonia as the fuel. Furthermore, the OCV was almost unchanged with respect to decreasing temperature, different from that operating on hydrogen, which showed a steady increase in OCV with decreasing temperature. When ammonia was adopted as the fuel for a SOFC–O 2− , two anode reaction routes are possible. The ammonia could be directly electro-oxidized to N 2 and H 2 O via the electrochemical reaction as follows: 2NH 3 + 3O 2− → N 2 + 3H 2 O + 6e − or the ammonia was indirectly oxidized by first decomposed into N 2 and H 2 followed by electro catalytic oxidation of the hydrogen to form H 2 O: 2NH 3 → N 2 + 3H 2 H 2 → 2H + + 2e − 2H + + O 2− → H 2 O For the SOFC–H + , since the water was mainly formed at the cathode side, the anode reaction was likely proceeded via the indirect route. It means that the unreacted NH 3 and the formed N 2 would serve as the diluting gas for H 2 , which may account, at least in part, for the relatively low OCV at reduced temperatures. At the same furnace temperature, as comparison to hydrogen fuel the peak power density was somewhat lowered when ammonia was applied as the fuel. For example, the peak power density was 465 and 390 mW/cm 2 , respectively, by applying hydrogen and ammonia as the fuel at a furnace temperature of 750 °C. To get more information to proper intercept the difference of cell performances with hydrogen and ammonia fuels, the cell impedance operated on ammonia fuel under OCV conditions was also measured with the results shown in Fig. 4 b. Similar to that with hydrogen fuel, the impedance spectra are composed of two overlapped arcs. However, at the same furnace temperature the electrolyte resistance of the cell operating on NH 3 seems be higher than that on hydrogen. For example, it is 0.37 Ω cm 2 at 750 °C by applying hydrogen fuel while it is about 0.42 Ω cm 2 operating on ammonia. It suggests that the real cell temperature by applying ammonia fuel may be lower than the furnace temperature. It is well known that the ammonia decomposition reaction is endothermic in nature, 2 NH 3 → N 2 + 3 H 2 , Δ H 0 = 46.02 kJ/mol The in situ endothermic ammonia decomposition reaction over the anode then likely took the heat from the fuel cell and resulted in a lower cell temperature. Considering the same cell adopted and negligible impact of fuel type on the ionic conductivity of the electrolyte, the electrolyte resistance should keep unchanged at the same cell temperature whether operating on hydrogen or ammonia fuels. The actual cell temperature at various furnace temperatures by applying ammonia fuel could then be estimated from the electrolyte resistance. A quasi linear response of 1/ R ohm versus 1000/ T was observed. The actual cell temperature with ammonia as the fuel was then estimated by fitting the electrolyte resistance measured by EIS into the temperature dependence of electrolyte resistance operating on hydrogen fuel. Cell temperatures of ∼700, 669, 624, 535, 489, 450, 400 °C, respectively, were derived at the furnace temperature of 750, 700, 650, 600, 550, 500 and 450 °C with ammonia as the fuel. It indicates that the endothermic decomposition of ammonia could result in the cell temperature 30–65 °C lower than the furnace. Accounting the cooling effect of the ammonia decomposition reaction on the fuel cell, similar power density was observed for the cell operating on hydrogen and ammonia fuel at high cell temperatures. For example, the peak power density is around 420 mW/cm 2 at a cell temperature of 700 °C when operating on hydrogen, while it is ∼390 mW/cm 2 by applying ammonia as the fuel. With the decrease of operating temperature, however, the difference in power density was enlarged. For example, a peak power density of 135 mW/cm 2 was achieved at a cell temperature of 450 °C by applying hydrogen as the fuel, while it was only 65 mW/cm 2 when operating on ammonia. As mentioned previously, the actual fuel for the direct electro-oxidation over the anode of SOFC–H + is hydrogen when operating on ammonia. The cell performance strongly relies on the catalytic activity of anode towards the ammonia decomposition. The catalytic activity of Ni + BZCY anode for ammonia decomposition was then examined at OCV conditions. The ammonia conversion rate was then calculated based on the difference on the total flow rate between the inlet and outlet of the anode chamber. As shown in Fig. 5 , at an operating temperature of 600 °C about 45% of the NH 3 was decomposed into N 2 and H 2 , while the conversion reached only 2% at 450 °C. The decrease of ammonia conversion resulted in lowering hydrogen concentration in the anode stream, which accounted at least in part for the relatively low OCV and poor power density at lower operating temperature. A modification of the anode composition for improving the catalytic activity of anode for ammonia decomposition is necessary in order to achieve high performance at reduced temperature. As shown in Figs. 3 b and 4 b, EIS of the single cell under OCV conditions are composed of two overlapped arcs when operating on hydrogen or ammonia fuel. The impedance spectroscopes are similar to each other for the cell operating on hydrogen and ammonia at temperatures higher than 600 °C. However, at lower temperature, the high-frequency arc was enlarged obviously when the ammonia was the fuel. Since the same atmosphere (air) was applied for the cathode chamber, the impedance contributed from the cathode should keep unchanged when varying the anode fuel. Therefore, the enlargement of the high-frequency arc was contributed from the increase in anode polarization resistance. Some researchers also observed a two-arc impedance based on single cell under OCV conditions, and they associated the high-frequency arc with the anode oxidation [15,16] . Although it is still not clear whether the high-frequency arc had also the contribution from the cathode, the important role of anode oxidation in the high-frequency impedance is undoubted. At cell temperature of 600 °C or higher, more than 45% of NH 3 was decomposed to N 2 and H 2 as demonstrated previously, the high hydrogen concentration then ensured a similar oxidation kinetics over the anode by applying ammonia or hydrogen as the fuel. Consequently, a similar electrode polarization resistance was observed. At lower temperatures, the catalytic activity of anode for NH 3 decomposition was reduced. Furthermore, the undecomposed NH 3 may competitively occupy the active site for H 2 adsorption. Both factors would lead to an increase of the anode polarization resistance. For portable application, the fuel should have high gravimetric or volumetric energy density and easy to store. N 2 H 4 is an ideal fuel for such purpose; it is a liquid at room temperature and ambient pressure. Recently we have demonstrated that N 2 H 4 can be catalytically decomposed into NH 3 , N 2 and H 2 at room temperature. The cathode material BSCF happens to be an excellent catalyst for N 2 H 4 catalytic decomposition. A new fuel cell was fabricated for the performance test operating on N 2 H 4 . About 0.5 g BSCF catalyst was dropped to 30 ml N 2 H 4 and heated at 40 °C by a water bath. The system was stirred homogeneously to avoid over heating since the N 2 H 4 decomposition reaction is exothermic in nature. The gaseous products, a mixture of mainly N 2 (∼23%), NH 3 (66%), and a small portion of H 2 (11%) [12] , were then introduced to the anode chamber of the fuel cell. For comparison, the cell performance was also investigated by applying hydrogen and ammonia as the fuels. As shown in Fig. 6 is the I – V curves of the cell with an electrolyte thickness of ∼35 μm at cell temperature of 600 °C. Comparable fuel cell performance was achieved at 600 °C operating on all the three fuels. The high-energy density and carbon-free composition of N 2 H 4 makes it a potential fuel for portable SOFC. Another significant advantage of N 2 H 4 is that the decomposition of hydrazine to N 2 and H 2 is exothermic in nature, N 2 H 4 → N 2 + 2 H 2 , Δ H 0 = − 50.6 kJ/mol The heat released from the decomposition reaction may be applied to heat up the products. Under adiabatic conditions, the decomposition of N 2 H 4 at room temperature (25 °C) could heat up the products (N 2 + 2H 2 ) to ∼608 °C. Therefore, no external heating system is needed once the decomposition reaction of N 2 H 4 can be made adiabatic. 4 Conclusions In this study, SOFCs composed of thin-film (∼35 μm) proton-conducting BZCY electrolyte was successfully fabricated. High cell performance at reduced temperatures was achieved by applying BSCF as the cathode material. When the cell was operated on ammonia, the anode reaction adopted the indirect route, i.e., the ammonia was first decomposed into H 2 and N 2 , and H 2 was then electro-oxidized into H 2 O to produce electricity. The endothermic nature of the ammonia decomposition resulted in cell temperature of 30–65 °C lower than the furnace. At the same cell temperature of 700 °C, the cell delivered similar performance whether operating on hydrogen or ammonia fuels. However, at lower temperature, the performance on ammonia is worse than hydrogen due to the reduced activity of anode towards the ammonia catalytic decomposition. When the decomposition products of hydrazine were applied as the fuel, the cell delivered comparable performance to that operating on ammonia. Since the liquid state of hydrazine at room temperature and ambient pressure and carbon-free composition; it is promising as fuel for portable SOFCs. Acknowledgements This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under contract Nos. 20703024 and 20676061, by National 863 program under contract No. 2007AA05Z133, and by National Basic Research Program of China under contract No. 2007CB209704. Dr Zongping Shao also would like to acknowledge the financial support from Chinese Ministry of Education via the Program for Changjiang Scholars and Innovative Research Team in University (No. IRT0732). zFcdRnPd.title: Catalytic decomposition of hydrous hydrazine to hydrogen over oxide catalysts at ambient conditions for PEMFCs
zFcdRnPd.abstract: Highlights ► Perovskite and perovskite-related oxides show high activity for decomposition of N 2 H 4 . ► Phase structure, cobalt ion and oxygen nonstoichiometry of catalysts are important. ► 100% hydrogen selectivity achieved for BSCF + KOH and LSC2+KOH catalysts. ► 510 mW cm −2 was achieved for a PEMFC over BSCF + KOH catalyst system.

NP84nEPG.title: Iron incorporated Ni-ZrO 2 catalysts for electric power generation from methane
NP84nEPG.abstract: On the purpose to perform as functional layer of SOFCs operating on methane fuel, NiFe-ZrO 2 alloy catalysts have been synthesized and investigated for methane partial oxidation reactions. Ni 4Fe 1-ZrO 2 shows catalytic activity comparable to that of Ni-ZrO 2 and superior to other Fe-containing catalysts. In addition, O 2-TPO analysis indicates iron is also prone to coke formation; as a result, most of NiFe-ZrO 2 catalysts do not show improved coking resistance than Ni-ZrO 2. Anyway, Ni 4Fe 1- ZrO 2 (Ni:Fe = 4:1 by weight) prepared by glycine-nitrate process shows somewhat less carbon deposition than the others. However, Raman spectroscopy demonstrates that the addition of Fe does reduce the graphitization degree of the deposited carbon, suggesting the easier elimination of carbon once it is deposited over the catalyst. Ni 4Fe 1-ZrO 2 has an excellent long-term stability for partial oxidation of methane reaction at 850°C. A solid oxide fuel cell with conventional nickel cermet anode and Ni 4Fe 1-ZrO 2 functional layer is operated on CH 4-O 2 gas mixture to yield a peak power density of 1038 mW cm -2 at 850°C, which is comparable to that of hydrogen fuel. In summary, the Ni 4Fe 1-ZrO 2 catalyst is potential catalyst as functional layer for solid-oxide fuel cells operating on methane fuel. © 2012, Hydrogen Energy Publications, LLC. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

qyvGXmV1.title: Evaluation of the CO2 poisoning effect on a highly active cathode SrSc0.175Nb0.025Co0.8O3-δ in the oxygen reduction reaction.
qyvGXmV1.abstract: A solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) is a highly efficient device for converting chemical energy to electrical energy. In addition to the efforts to reduce the operating temperature of SOFCs to below 600 °C, research studies of the basic mechanism of CO2 poisoning on cathode materials are envisioned to improve the operation of dual-chamber SOFCs using ambient air. In this work, we comparatively studied the CO2 poisoning effect on two highly active perovskites SrSc0.175Nb0.025Co0.8O3-δ (SSNC) and Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3-δ (BSCF), using complementary characterisation techniques, e.g., powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform-infra red (FT-IR) spectroscopy, atomic force microscopy (AFM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), CO2-temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD), and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). The SSNC cathode shows better tolerance to CO2 as compared with BSCF, which is attributed to the absence of Ba, higher average metal-oxygen bond energy (ABE) of SSNC, and the higher acidity of Nb5+ cations, whereas the oxygen vacancy concentration plays a less important role.

KgW9gmRg.title: A novel CO2-resistant ceramic dual-phase hollow fiber membrane for oxygen separation
KgW9gmRg.abstract: Abstract   Robust oxygen permeable ceramic membranes have potential applications in clean energy industries like oxyfuel power plants and green chemical synthesis like syngas production combining the separation and reaction in one unit. The well-known and highly permeable perovskite oxide membranes are limited by their lower chemical stability. In this work, a novel dual-phase hollow fiber membrane based on a fluorite Pr 0.1 Gd 0.1 Ce 0.8 O 2−δ (PCGO) and a spinel CoFe 2 O 4 (CFO) composite was developed via a phased inversion/sintering method. Enhanced oxygen permeability and unprecedented high CO 2  resistance were realized by the 50 wt%PCGO–50 wt%CFO dual-phase hollow fiber membrane. The composite was synthesized via a one-pot sol-gel preparation method to achieve the homogenous distribution and the formation of percolative network of each phase for both oxygen ionic and electronic conduction purpose. The oxygen permeation flux of 0.54 mL min −1  cm −2  was achieved using He as sweep gas at 1000 °C. Membrane performance was further improved by coating a perovskite Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ   (BSCF) layer on the outside surface of the dual phase membrane to face the feed gas-air leaving the other membrane side untouched to maintain its high stability to withstand the harsh gas condition containing CO 2 . The dual phase membrane had been successfully operated at 950 °C in pure CO 2  atmosphere for more than 200 h with flux rate fixed at 0.40 mL min −1  cm −2  without any noticeable performance degradation or membrane deterioration. By contrast, the flux rate of pure perovskite membrane had been sharply dropped down by 80% albeit operated for only 8 h.

WyxwTM5H.title: Dry reforming of methane over Co–Mo/Al2O3 catalyst under low microwave power irradiation
WyxwTM5H.abstract: In this work, microwave (MW) irradiation was used to activate Co/Al2O3, Mo/Al2O3, and Co–Mo/Al2O3 catalysts for dry reforming of methane (DRM) reactions. Experimental results indicate that single metallic catalysts of either Co or Mo are inactive for DRM under all the tested conditions due to their limited MW-absorbing ability. In contrast, Co–Mo bimetallic catalysts supported by Al2O3 exhibit high catalytic activity due to the formation of a magnetodielectric Co0.82Mo0.18 alloy, which plays the dual role of a good MW acceptor and the provider of active centers for the DRM reaction. The MW power level required to activate such bimetallic catalysts for DRM is significantly dependent on the molar ratio between Co and Mo. The CoMo2 catalyst (with a molar ratio of 2.0 Co to 1.0 Mo) supported on Al2O3 exhibits the best catalytic performance, converting 80% CH4 and 93% CO2 to syngas at a ratio of H2/CO of 0.80 at the total volumetric hourly space velocity (VHSV) of 10 L g−1 h−1 and MW power of 200 W. As compared to the reported C-based catalysts, the Co–Mo/Al2O3 catalyst delivers more favorable stability over 16 time-on-stream (TOS) by virtue of its intrinsic ability to absorb MW without the inclusion of auxiliary MW acceptors.

vFIlnAxc.title: Perovskite materials in energy storage and conversion
vFIlnAxc.abstract: In this review, the recent progress in the application of an important category of materials, i.e. ABO3 perovskite-type compounds in the fields of energy storage and conversion, is reviewed. Four main areas, as materials for oxygen transporting membrane toward the application in oxy-fuel combustion, as key material for solid oxide fuel cells for efficient power generation from fuels, as room-temperature electrocatalysts for oxygen reduction reaction and oxygen evolution reaction, and as material for solar cells for solar energy harvest, are referred. Our past efforts in these research areas are emphasized. Some prospects about the future development in the application of perovskite materials in energy storage and conversion is proposed. © 2016 Curtin University of Technology and John Wiley u0026 Sons, Ltd.

RXV44x1T.title: Nanocellulose-assisted low-temperature synthesis and supercapacitor performance of reduced graphene oxide aerogels
RXV44x1T.abstract: Abstract   Here, we have synthesized reduced graphene oxide (rGO) aerogels using a nanocellulose-assisted low temperature (less than 500 °C) thermal treatment route where nanocelluloses promote the gelation of graphene oxide (GO) solution that benefits the fabrication of GO aerogels from low concentration dispersion (2.85 mg mL −1 ), and after their thermal decomposition the residual nanofibers act as spacer both prevent the re-stacking of graphene sheets and integrate with rGO sheets to give a particular kind of carbon-based aerogel along with numerous defects (holes). Thermal decomposition of nanocellulose appears to be complete beyond 350 °C thus its presence in form of amorphous carbon nanofibers in rGO sheets. The rGO aerogels synthesized at 350 °C provide the best balance in terms of wide interlayer spacing, high content of CO-type functional groups, and high defects content. This translates into a high discharge capacitance of 270 F g −1  at a current rate of 1 A g −1  for compressed rGO aerogels without any binder or conductive additive. Detailed electrochemical tests using 6 M KOH electrolyte establish the fact that pseudocapacitance component has substantial contribution towards the overall capacitance; closely approaching the contribution of the double layer capacitance that is the most dominant capacitance component.

sKhuTjKt.title: Activity and Stability of Ruddlesden-Popper-Type Lan+1 Nin O3n+1 (n=1, 2, 3, and ∞) Electrocatalysts for Oxygen Reduction and Evolution Reactions in Alkaline Media.
sKhuTjKt.abstract: Increasing energy demands have stimulated intense research activity on cleaner energy conversion such as regenerative fuel cells and reversible metal-air batteries. It is highly challenging but desirable to develop low-cost bifunctional catalysts for both the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), the lack of which is currently one of the major limiting components towards commercialization of these technologies. Here, we have conducted a systematic study on the OER and ORR performances of the Ruddlesden-Popper family of Lan+1 Nin O3n+1 (n=1, 2, 3, and ∞) in an alkaline medium for the first time. It is apparent that the Ni-O bond lengths and the hyperstoichiometric oxides in the rock-salt layers correlate with the ORR activities, whereas the OER activities appear to be influenced by the OH(-) content on the surface of the compounds. In our case, the electronic configuration fails to predict the electrocatalytic activity of these compounds. This work provides guidelines to develop new electrocatalysts with improved performances.

VM9r33H9.title: Promotion of oxygen reduction by exsolved silver nanoparticles on a perovskite scaffold for low-temperature solid oxide fuel cells.
VM9r33H9.abstract: Solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) have potential to be the cleanest and most efficient electrochemical energy conversion devices with excellent fuel flexibility. To make SOFC systems more durable and economically competitive, however, the operation temperature must be significantly reduced, which depends sensitively on the development of highly-active electrocatalysts for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) at low temperatures. Here we report a novel silver nanoparticle-decorated perovskite oxide, prepared via a facile ex-solution process from a Sr0.95Ag0.05Nb0.1Co0.9O3-δ (SANC) perovskite precursor, as a highly active and robust ORR electrocatalyst for low-temperature SOFCs. The ex-solved Sr0.95Ag0.05Nb0.1Co0.9O3-δ (denoted as e-SANC) electrode is very active for ORR, achieving a very low area specific resistance (~0.214 Ω cm2 at 500 oC). An anode-supported cell with the new heterostructured cathode demonstrates very high peak power density (1,116 mW cm-2 at 500 oC) and stable operation for 140 h at a current density of 625 mA cm-2. The superior ORR activity and stability are attributed to the fast oxygen surface exchange kinetics and the firm adhesion of the e-SANC electrode to the electrolyte. Moreover, the e-SANC cathode displays improved tolerance to CO2. These unique features make the new heterostructured material a highly promising cathode for low-temperature SOFCs.

PgAg59dJ.title: On Students' Improper Concepts of Mathematics and Causes of Their Formation
PgAg59dJ.abstract: Students' improper concepts of mathematics lie mostly in their attitudes towards mathematics and learning. Their improper concepts of mathematics have something to do with teachers, textbooks, methodologies and teachers' concepts of mathematics, and also with students' self-consciousness. This paper analyses students' improper concepts of mathematics and causes of formation. The conclusion will help students form a correct concept of mathematics in order to improve teaching quality of mathematics.

o8wOg70V.title: Relationship between Self-efficacy and Academic Help-seeking of Off-Tibetan Students in Junior Middle Schools
o8wOg70V.abstract: This article adopted SEIS and "Academic Help-seeking Scale" to investigate 294 off-Tibetan students in junior middle schools.The results showed: ①Girls had more instrumental help-seeking behaviors than boys(t=-2.421,P<0.05).There were significant differences on instrumental help-seeking behavior and executive help-seeking behavior in different graders(F=4.537,P<0.05;F=15.269,P<0.001).After multiple comparisons,we found that instrumental help-seeking behaviors of seventh-graders were significantly more than ninth-graders'.Executive help-seeking behaviors of eighth and ninth-graders were significantly more than seventh-graders.②Academic help-seeking was greatly influenced by perceived self-efficacy.Self-regulated learning self-efficacy had a positive effect on instrumental help-seeking(β=0.373,P<0.001) and a negative effect on both executive help-seeking and avoidance of help-seeking(β=-0.320,-0.321,P<0.001).Academic self-efficacy had a significant negative effect on both executive help-seeking and avoidance of help-seeki(β=-0.306,-0.203,P<0.001).Conclusion: Instrumental help-seeking behavior was influenced by gender and grade of Off-Tibetan Students in Junior Middle Schools.Executive help-seeking behavior was influenced by grade.The results supported the Vulnerability Hypothesis: the higher self-efficacy students had,the more help-seeking behaviors they exhibited;the lower self-efficacy they had,the less help-seeking behaviors they exhibited.
keywords: Off-Tibetan students in junior middle schools

DKiEiL77.title: The Relationship Between Self-efficacy and Academic Achievement of Junior High School Students in the Mainland Tibetan Class(School)
DKiEiL77.abstract: With the methods of self-efficacy comprehensive scale,a questionnaire survey was conducted among 262 Junior High School Students in the Mainland Tibetan Class(School) to explore the relationship between their self-efficacy and academic achievement.Results show that most students' self-efficacy is in the medium level;there is no significant sex disparity in general self-efficacy and academic self-efficacy,but there are significant gender differences in self-adjusting learning efficacy;General self-efficacy in preppie is supreme,while there is no obvious discrepancy between the junior one and junior two students in their general self-efficacy;academic self-efficacy and self-adjusting learning efficacy of preppie,junior one and two students decrease with higher grade;academic self-efficacy and self-adjusting learning efficacy show a significant positive correlation with academic achievement.

5gVt7K9X.title: A Comparative Study of Several Methods for General Question Database Management System
5gVt7K9X.abstract: This paper studies several question input-output methods of the general question database management system.It compares their strong and weak points,and gives corresponding program codes.Simul- taneously, it puts forward a special input-output method of developping general question management system.The experimental result indicates this method is more stable than other methods and the processing efficiency is also higher.

PCEOJOcc.title: The History, Current Situation and Problem of the Research on "Problem Solving"
PCEOJOcc.abstract: This dissertation is based on the review of the history and analysis of the current situation to point out that there has been lacking in the clear consensus on the understanding of the problem solving,as well as the different opinions on it.And this will certainly make the teachers don’t know what to do during the education and teaching.As a result,it is still quite necessary to strengthen the researches on problems and problem solving.

aiySoURh.title: Reflections on the Reforms of Teaching Problem and Teaching Material Construction in Education of Cognitive Psychology
aiySoURh.abstract: Investigations show that there are some problems in teaching and learning of cognitive psychology.The ultimate problem lies in the poor teaching materials used in colleges and universities.Emphases must be put on "Collective Wisdom" and "Conspicuous Localized Specialty" to improve the quality of the teaching materials of cognitive psychology.

ZVF2Bd8G.title: A Humble Opinion for Truth——Discussions of a Number of Problems on Educational Psychology Examination Syllabus
ZVF2Bd8G.abstract: Educational Psychology Examination Syllabus(for applicants for qualifications of secondary school teachers) issued by the Division of Personnel and Education Examination Center of the Ministry of Education has questions open to discussions.For example,the definition of educational psychology which is too general does not reveal the essential nature of the discipline.The statement "Educational Psychology was originally introduced from the West to China" ignores the rich historical facts of the thought of educational psychology in ancient China.The critical period mentioned in the syllabus is a misreading of the research on Lorenz and its value.Definitions of motivation and learning motivation make them extremely confusing and difficulty to understand.The psychological structures of attitude should include cognition,emotion and behavioral intention instead of cognition,emotion and behaviors.The statement "by randomly and intentionally memorizing" does not make sense semantically.And the definition of cooperative learning makes a "circularly defining" mistake.This paper analyzes the reasons for these problems,and provides its own explanations.

RoMVd58g.title: A Comparative Study of Personality Traits of the Off-Tibetan and Han Students in Junior High School
RoMVd58g.abstract: Adopting"Eysenck Personality Questionnaire(EPQ)"(Junior Edition)revised by GONG Yao-xian(1983),this article makes a sampling analysis of 130 Tibetan students in Tibetan Middle School,Changzhou,Jiangsu Province,and 160 Han students,a randomly sampled cluster,of the local Junior High School.The following conclusions are reached:(1)the various dimensions of personality that Tibetan and Han middle school students have are mostly intermediate.From the view of a typical personality type,the off-Tibet classes(school)junior high school students have the highest proportion of the spirit of cytoplasmic,followed by nervous type,and with the minimum of export-oriented type.The number of Han students in junior high school is highest in typical neurotic type,the quality type of spirit lowest;(2)off-Tibetan classes(schools)within junior high school and the Han students make no difference in neuroticism and extraversion,but are quite different in spirit of cytoplasmic and covering-up nature;(3)off-Tibetan junior high school students have gender differences in the covering-up nature,while the Han students have sex differences in extraversion;(4)off-ibetan junior high school boys are more introvert than their Han counterparts and female psychoticism scores higher than the Han junior high girls.

fvz8JXnq.title: Questions and Causes in the Development of Education Psychology in Our Country
fvz8JXnq.abstract: There are many questions in the development of education psychology in our country. For example, its content is numerous and jumbled; its system is disorderly; the relationship close to subject is not distinct; the opinion of the subject nature is different, and so on. The cause is that the subject objective of education psychology is not clear. So stricdy defining the subject objective of education psychology has an important meaning. This article advances the own opinion, which considers that the research objective of education psychology is the psychology phenomena and disciplinarian of the teachers and students and their reciprocity in the teaching activity.

088kNuo9.title: Efficacy of Unilateral Continuous Spinal Anesthesia with Hypobaric Ropivacaine in Elderly Patients Undergoing Hip Replacement
088kNuo9.abstract: Objective To evaluate the efficacy of unilateral continuous spinal anesthesia with hypobaric ropivacaine in the elderly patients undergoing hip replacement.Methods Sixty elderly patients scheduled for hip replacement were randomly divided into hypobaric ropivacaine group(group HR) and isobaric ropivacaine group(group IR),(n=30 each).The patients in group HR and IR received intrathecal injection with 0.5% hyperbaric ropivacaine 1.0 mL and 0.5% isobaric ropivacaine 1.0 mL at a rate of 0.1 mL/s,respectively.The levels of sensory block and degree of motor block were measured every 5 minutes using a pinprick test and modified Bromage scale respectively.The block level at T8~T10 was maintained with 0.5% ropivacaine by 0.5 mL increments every time.BP,MAP and HR were recorded before intrathecal injection and at the time of the block level reached T8~T10.Adverse reaction,total amount of ropivacaine consumed,duration of analgesia and duration of motor block during operation were recorded.The complications were also recorded during two weeks after operation.Results Compared with group IR,SBP at the time of the block level reached T8~T10 was significantly increased,the total amount of ropivacaine consumed was decreased,duration of analgesia and motor block were both shortened,adverse effects were decreased in group HR(P<0.01).No complications were observed after operation in both groups.Conclusion The unilateral continous spinal anesthesia with hypobaric ropivacaine produces controlled sensory block level with stable hemodynamics and less adverse reaction in the elderly patients undergoing hip replacement.

sfVds5Yf.title: Comparison between the Lightwand and the Direct Laryngoscope during Oral Tracheal Intubation in Elderly Patients
sfVds5Yf.abstract: Objective To compare the hemodynamic changes and the injuries to the oral cavity and throat during oral tracheal intubation with the Lightwand or the direct laryngoscope in elderly patients.Methods One hundred patients,ASA Ⅰ~Ⅱ,aged 62~76 years,scheduled for surgery under general anesthesia with oral tracheal intubation,were randomly divided into two groups: the Lightwand group and the direct laryngoscope group.General anesthesia in all two groups were induced with same methods.SBP,DBP,SpO2 and HR were recorded at 5 time points: before anesthysia induction(T0),after anesthysia induction(T1),immediately after intubation(T2),1 minute(T3) and 3 minute(T4) after intubation.The successful cases with one intubation or two incubation and the incubation time were recorded.The injuries of oral mucosa,throat mucosa,tooth and gum were observed after incubation.The incedence of pharyngodynia and cerchnus after operation were also recorded.Results Compared with that at T1 point,SBP,DBP and HR at T2 and T3 points in the direct laryngoscope group were significantly increased(P<0.05).Compared with the lightwand group,the SBP,DBP and HR in the direct laryngoscope group were significantly increased at T2 and T3(P<0.05).The sucessful cases with one incubation in the lightwand group were more than those in the direct laryngoscope group(P<0.05).The time of incubation in the lightwand group were significantlly less than that in the direct laryngoscope group(P<0.05).Compared with the direct laryngoscope group,the incidence of postoperative complication,such as oral throat mucosa injury,tooth and gingival injury,were significanlty decreased in the lightwand group(P<0.05).Conclusion Incubation with lightwand can attenuate the haemodynamics changes,decrease the incidence of airway complication.Lightwand is a safe and valid incubation tool.

AsNZC3rM.title: Effect of Dexmedetomidine on the Tourniquet-induced Hyperdynamic Response in Patients Undergoing Lower Limb Surgeries
AsNZC3rM.abstract: Objective: To evaluate the effects of dexmedetomidine on the tourniquet-induced hyperdynamic response during combined spinal anesthesia(CSEA).Methods: 60 patients of ASA Ⅰ～Ⅱ undergoing lower limb surgeries under CSEA were allocated randomly into two groups,30 cases in each group: dexmedetomidine group(Group D) and control group(Group C).Under CSEA,the group D was received a loading dose of dexmedetomidine(0.8 μg/kg,over 10 min) followed by continuous infusion of dexmedetomidine(0.4 μg.kg-1.h-1) until tourniquet deflation.The group C received normal saline instead.Tourniquet-induced changes in hemodynamic parameters,including heart rate(HR),mean arterial pressure(MBP) were compared between two groups.Results: Before drug administration,no significant difference of hemodynamic parameters,including HR,MAP and SPO2 was observed between the two groups(P>0.05).MAP of group D at T2,T3,T4 and T5 were significantly higher than that of T1 after a bolus dose of dexmedetomidine(0.8 μg/kg)(P<0.05),which was lower slightly at T6 than that at T1(P>0.05).HR of group D at T4,T5 and T6 were significantly higher than that at T1,and it was significantly lower at T1 than that at T0 after a bolus dose of dexmedetomidine(0.8 μg/kg)(P<0.05).MAP and HR of group C at T2,T3,T4,T5 and T6 were higher than that at T1(P<0.05).MAP of group D at T2,T4 and T6 were lower than that of group C(P<0.01).HR of group D from T1 to T6 were lower than that of group C(P<0.05).The incidence of hyperdynamic response in the group C was significantly higher than that in the group D(66.7% versus 20.0%;P<0.01).The total consumption of nicardipine and atropine was comparable in these two groups(P>0.05).However,the total ephedrine consumption was higher in group D than in group C(P<0.05) None of the cases received esmolol.Conclusion: Dexmedetomidine attenuated tourniquet-induced hyperdynamic response in combined spinal anesthesia patients undergoing lower limb surgeries.

i8Lq9TaO.title: Effect of different doses of parecoxib pretreatment on propofol injection pain
i8Lq9TaO.abstract: Objective To investigate the effect of different doses of parecoxib pretreatment on propofol injection pain. Methods A total of 160 ASA patients with physical status Ⅰ~Ⅱ scheduled for elective surgery were randomized to four groups, with 40 patients each, to receive pretreatment with parecoxib 40 mg (Group A), parecoxib 20 mg (Group B), lidocaine 40 mg (Group C) , or normal saline (Group D). All pretreatment drugs were prepared in 5 ml doses. After 2 minute drug injection, the proplfol was administered. Pain scores were obtained by a study-blinded observer during propofol injection following the different pretreatment solutions. Results Pain scores among the four groups were significantly different. Pain was significantly reduced in Group A (P≤0.01) compared with the control group. Moderate to severe pain was experienced by 33 (82.5%) patients in Group D and 4 (8%) patients in Group B, whereas no patient in Group A (P<0.01). Reduction in pain severity was statistically significant after pretreatment with either parecoxib 20 mg (P=0.002) or parecoxib 40 mg (P<0.01). Conclusion Parecoxib 40 mg pretreatment is effective to reduce the frequency and severity of pain with propofol injection. Pretreatment with 20 mg of parecoxib reduces the severity of propofol injection pain significantly but does not reduce frequency.

Xn66KZ3W.title: The clinical research of penehyclidine hydrochloride injection combined with scopolamine in the whole body hyperthermia
Xn66KZ3W.abstract: Objective To investigate the clinical validity of penehyclidine hydrochloride injection combined with scopolamine in the whole body hyperthermia(WBH).Methods 30 patients,ASA Ⅰ-Ⅱ,were randomly divided into three groups: A,B and C group.The patients in A group(n=10) and B group(n=10) intramuscularly injected with penehyclidine hydrochloride(0.02mg/kg) before closing the infrared cabin.C group(n=10) intramuscularly injected with scopolamine(0.01mg/kg) at the same time.If patient had obvious sweat during WBH,additional scopolamine were injected in A and C group,and penehyclidine hydrochloride in B group.Record the time during the esophageal temperature increased to 41.8 ℃.The HR,MAP,CVP and incidence of adverse effect were recorded respectively at the time of pre-heating,heating to 39 ℃,40℃,41.8℃,and keeping body temperature at 41.8℃ for 2 hour.Results The time heating to 41.8℃ in A group had no significant different with that in the B group(P>0.05).Compared with C group,A and B group had significant shorter heating time(P<0.05).Although the HR in A group were faster than that in B group at the time of heating to 40℃,41.8℃ and keeping body temperature at 41.8℃ for 2 hour,there were no significant difference.The HR in C group at each time were all faster than HR in A and B groups(P<0.05).After the esophageal temperature increased to 40 ℃,the MAP decreased along with the HR increase,and the CVP increased.Compared with A and B group,the MAP in C group were significantly decreased,and the CVP were increased.The incidence of adverse effects in B group were significantly increased(P<0.01).Conclusion Penehyclidine hydrochloride injection combined with scopolamine in WBH can significantly decrease the heating time,keep haemodynamics stability and decrease the incidence of adverse reaction.

VUnfnhup.title: Protective effect of Edaravone on ventilator induced lung injury in rats
VUnfnhup.abstract: Objective To explore the potential protective effect in vivo of Edaravone,a free radical scavenger,on me chanical ventilation-induced lung injury in rats.Methods 24 healthy male SD rats weighing 280-320 g were randomly divided into 3 groups(n =8): traditional tidal volume group(group C),large tidal volume mechanical ventilation group(group MV) and Edaravone pretreatment group(group E).In group C rats were ventilated with traditional tidal volume(VT=8 mL/kg) for 4 h.In group MV and E the animals were mechanically ventilated with high volume ventila tion(VT=40 mL/kg) for 4 h.In group E 0.2% Edaravone 15 mg/kg was administered iv at 30 min before mechanical ventilation.Equal amount of normal saline was given to rats in other two groups at the same time.The lung tissue samples were collected at 4 h after mechanical ventilation.The wet/dry(W/D) weight ratio of lung tissue was mea sured.The levels of myeloperoxidase(MPO),malondialdehyde(MDA) and superoxide dismutase(SOD) in lung tissue homogenate were assayed.The pathological changes and expression of nuclear factor-kappa B(NF-κB) in lung tissue were also studied.Results Compared with the C group,the W/D,NF-κB expression,MPO and MDA levels in the MV group were significantly higher(all P < 0.05),and the level of SOD was apparently lower(P < 0.05).The W/D,NF-κB expression,MPO and MDA levels in the E group were significantly lower than those in the MV group(all P < 0.05),and higher than those in the C group(all P < 0.05).And the level of SOD in lung tissue of the E group was higher than that in the MV group and lower than that in the C group(P < 0.05).Conclusion Edaravone has protective effect on mechanical ventilation-induced lung injury in rats.The mechanism maybe related to its ability of clearing the reac tive oxygen species,inhibiting the activation of the signal pathway of NF-κB and inflammatory cascade.

ZoBXkrb1.title: The role of GABA-A receptor on the dorsal root ganglion in the rats with neuropathic pain
ZoBXkrb1.abstract: Objective To investigate the role of GABA-A receptors in the mechanism of neuropathic pain.Methods Fifty adult female SD rats were randomly divided into five groups with 10 each.After L5 spinal nerve ligation,the rats were immediately injected with muscimol 20 μg(group A),bicuculline 0.15 μg(group B),both muscimol 20 μg and bicuculline 0.15 μg(group C),muscimol 20 μg five days later (group D),and saline 20 μl (group E).The mechanic and thermal threshold of the injured paw was measured the day before ligation and every day after the ligation until ten days later.Results L5 spinal nerve ligation induced the syndrome of neuropathic pain,such as licking injured paw and limp.The mechanic and thermal threshold of group E started to decrease on 1st day and 3rd day after pain respectively (P<0.05).Then,the thresholds were stable at the 10th day (P<0.05).Compared with group E,the mechanic and thermal thresholds of group A were increased and maintained a high level for 10 days.In group B,the mechanic and thermal threshold decreased on the 1st day (P<0.05).Compared with group E,the mechanic and thermal thresholds of group B on the 10th day significantly decreased (P<0.05).In group D,the mechanic and thermal thresholds were increased since the 6th day and followed by a transient peak on the 7th day (P<0.05).Conclusion Activation of GABA-A receptors on the dorsal root ganglion can prevent the neuropathic pain,and it is just a transient effect when used afterwards.

sS8khevo.title: Clinical Application of Dexmedetomidine Combined with Sufentanyl and Tramado in Patient-controlled Intravenous Analgesia Postoperation for Orthopedics Operation
sS8khevo.abstract: Objective To investigate the analgesic efficiency of dexmedetomidine combined with sufentanyl and tramado in patient-controlled intravenous analgesia(PCIA) after orthopedics operation and their influence to circulation and respiration of patients.Methods PCIA were taken in 80 patients with ASAⅠ~Ⅱ undergoing orthopedics operation under general anaesthesia.The patients in M1,M2,M3 groups were given dexmedetomidine injection at a constant speed of 0.1,0.2,0.3 μg/(kg·h),respectively.The VAS,MAP,HR,SPO2,PaCO2 and Ramsay scores were recorded at the following time points:before PCIA(T0),30 minutes after PCIA(T1),1 h after PCIA(T2),4 h after PCIA(T3),12 h after PCIA(T4),24 h after PCIA(T5).Results The VAS values of M1,M2 and M3 groups were significantly lower than that of S group at all the recorded time points,but had no significant difference between M2 group and M3 group.The Ramsay scores results of all groups was M3>M2>M1>S(P<0.05).The MAP,SPO2,PaCO2 in M1,M2 and M3 groups had no significant difference,but the HR were significantly decresed before and after given dexmedetomidine injection(P<0.05).Conclusion Low dosage dexmedetomidine combined with sufentanyl and tramado could be effectively and safety used in postoperative analgesia for patients undergoing orthopedics operation.

ZSaPfw2R.title: Effect of analgesic solution combined with triamcinolone on the prognosis of the nerve injury under epidural anesthesia
ZSaPfw2R.abstract: Objective To investigate the effect of the analgesic solution combined with triamcinolone on the prognosis of the nerve injury under epidural anesthesia and evaluate its security.Methods 60 patients ASA I-II grade suffered from the radiating pain because the nerve root was stimulated under epidural anesthesia were randomly allocated into two groups,group S(n=30) and group D(n=30).In group S 10ml analgesic solution consisted of 0.8% lidocaine and triamcinolone 20mg plus vitB1 100mg and vitB12 500ug was infused after operation.In group D 10ml analgesic solution consisted of 0.8% lidocaine plus vitB1 100mg and vitB12 500ug was infused after operation.The incidence of root pain and the visual analgesic score(VAS 0-10) were recorded,when VAS>3 the above treatment was repeated every 7 days until VAS<3.Recovery time of root pain and blood glucose were measured in both groups.Results Compared with group D,the incidence of root pain and VAS in group S was significantly decreased.The recovery time in group S was significantly shortened.Compared with the preoperative BS,postoperative BS in group S was increased.But there was no statistic significance.Conclusion Epidural injection of the analgesic solution combined with triamcinolone was an effective and secure methods to prevent the root pain and promote the nerve repair after nerve injury.

SFkRkAMV.title: Effects of dexmedetomidine on the electrocorticography monitoring in patients undergoing epilepsy surgery
SFkRkAMV.abstract: Objective To investigate the effects of dexmedetomidine on the electrocorticography ( ECoG ) monitoring in the different dose.Methods Sixty patients with epilepsy , were randomly divided into four groups , n=15for each group.A loading dose of 1 μ g / kg dexmedetomidine was slowly injected in group D2 , D4 , D6.Then the maintenance dose of dexmedetomidine was injected with speed of 0.2 μ g · kg -1 · h -1 in group D2 , 0.4 μ g · kg -1 · h -1 in group D4 , 0.6 μ g · kg -1 · h -1 in group D6 respectively.The equal volume of physiological saline was injected for group C.The anesthesia was maintained with sevoflurane and remifentanil. Time from drug discontinuance to definitely electrocorticographical location , the amplitude , classification and frequency of electrocorticography waveform in operation were recorded.Results Compared with group C , the time of electrocorticography location in group D6increased ( P<0.05 ) .Classification of electrocorticography in groups D2and D4were very similar with group C.Compared with group C , the incidence of severe abnormality in group D6significantly decreased ( P<0.05 ) .The spike wave showed in all of four groups during electrocorticography recording.Compared with group C , the frequency of spike wave decreased in groups D2 , D4and D6 , but there was no significant difference.There was no significantly difference with the amplitude of spike wave in four groups.Conclusion Dexmedetomidine , injected with 0.2-0.4 μ g · kg -1 · h -1 , is eligible during anesthesia in epilepsy surgery , which neither evokes nor inhibits spike wave during electrocorticography monitoring.

I4roISPw.title: Bispectral Index-guided Sedation with Different Doses of Dexmedetomidine in ICU Patients
I4roISPw.abstract: Objective To evaluate the postoperative efficacy and safety of Bispectral index(BIS)-guided sedation with different doses of Dexmedetomidine(Dex).Methods Sixty ICU patients of postoperation on mechanical ventilation for at least 24 hour were randomized double blindly into group Dex1,group Dex2 and group M.The BIS,Ramsay score,MAP and HR were monitored,before Dex or Mid infusion and at each point in three hours after continuous infusion.The level of BIS was kept at 61~ 84 and used as criteria to speed up or stop the infusion to maintain sedation.The intermittent injection of Morphine(Mor) was adjusted according to the degree of the pain.Recorded mechanical ventilation time,extubation time,wake time,the changes of MAP and HR,the doses of Mor among three groups.The cases of Steward awakening score and adverse events such as delirium occurred after extubation of all patients was evaluated and recorded.Results Among the three groups,there were no significantly differences in the sedative effects(P>0.05).The two groups of giving Dex were easier to wake up and keep quiet.The BIS decreased(P<0.05) and Ramsay score was higher(P<0.01) significantly compared with that before.At the same level of sedation,in group Dex1 and Dex2,compared with group M,the wake time decreased significantly(P<0.05) and the extubation time also decreased(P<0.01),after extubation Steward higher(P<0.05),the incidences of delirium and sleeping again decreased significantly,so were the doses of Mor.Conclusion The BIS guided with Dex may provide safe and effective sedation,the high quality of wake up and reduced adverse reactions such as delirium,the higher doses of Dex is more suitable for ICU patients.

9XLMcIHl.title: Affection of Dexmedetomdine on perioperative patients with intracranial aneurysm administration in interventional treatment
9XLMcIHl.abstract: Objective To evaluate the effect of dexmedetomidine in the patient with intracranial aneurysm during the perioperative period of interventional treatment.Methods A total of 38 patients with intracranial aneurysm underwent interventional treatment in the People's hospital affiliated to Hubei university of medicine were randomly divided into group D and group C.The patients of Group D were intravenously administered with 0.6 μg/kg Dexmedetomidine preoperatively and 0.4 μg/(kg·h) during operation,while the same amount of saline would be used in Group C.Two groups all applied endotracheal intubation total intravenous anesthesia(TIVA).Mean artery pressure(MAP) and heart rate(HR) of the patients were measured and compared at the time points of baseline(T0),before induction(T1),pre-intubation(T2),just after intubation(T3),operation began(T4),parent artery embolization(T5),at the end of operation(T6),pre-extubation(T7),just after extubation(T8).The used amount of vasoactive drugs and postoperative recovery conditions and complications were compared between groups.Results The blood pressure and heart rate of group D were lower than group C at the time of T1,T3,T4,T7,T8(P < 0.05).Compared with group C,the postoperative recovery time of group D was no obvious defference,but the incidence of adverse events and the used amount of vasoactive drugs were reduced in group D(P < 0.05).Conclusion Dexmedetomidine used as a peri-anaesthetic drugs for interventional treatment of intracranial aneurysm patient is beneficial to reduce the blood pressure and heart rate,and stabilize hemodynamics,thus it can reduce the risk of aneurysm rupture and the incidence of adverse events.

ZBJwZhzv.title: Study on the Improvement of Euthyroid Sick Syndrome by Thyroxine Supplement before Mitral Valve Replacement in Patients with Rheumatic Heart Disease
ZBJwZhzv.abstract: Objective To investigate the effects of preoperative supplement of thyroxine on the thyroid hormone level and heart function during the perioperative period in rheumatic heart disease(RHD) patients underwent mitral valve replacement.Methods Total 36 RHD patients underwent mitral valve replacement under extracorporeal circulation were randomly divided into control group and experimental group.The experimental group were given thyroxine tablets with dose of 0.5 mg/kg daily for 7 days postoperation.The serum levels of T3,FT3,T4,FT4 and TSH were measured at first day in hospital(t1),before anesthesia induction(t2),before AAO liberalization(t3),the first day postoperation(t4),4th day(t5) and 7th day(t6),respectively.The serum levels of CK-MB and TnI were measured at 24h postoperation.The MAP,HR,CVP and the application of inotropic agent during the operation were also recorded.Results The levels of FT3 and T3 in both group at t1 were significantly lower than those at t2(P<0.05).The levels of T3,FT3,T3,FT4 at t1 in both groups were significantly lower than those at t2 after CPB(P<0.05).Compared with control group,the levels of FT3 and T3 in exprimental group significantly increased at t3,t4 and t5,and the levels of T4 was significantly increased at t2 and t3,and FT4 increased at t2.There was no significant difference in TSH level between two groups.Compared with control group,CK-MB content and TnI positive rate in exprimental group were significantly lower in experimental group(P<0.05).There was no significant defference in MAP,CVP and HR between two groups.From post CPB to the postoperative 4th day,the inotropic agent during the perioperative period in exprimental group was less than that in control group.Conclusion The preoperative supplement of thyroxine could relief the euthyroid sick syndrome(ESS) during perioperative period in RHD patients underwent mitral valve replacement,improve the heart function,decrease the dosage of inotropic agent and preserve myocardium.

wVafPXPB.title: Effect of Parecoxib Preapplication on Propofol Injection Pain
wVafPXPB.abstract: Objective: To investigate the effect of parecoxib pretreatment with venous occlusion on propofol injection pain.150 ASA physical status I patients were scheduled for elective surgery.Methods: Patients were randomized to three groups of 50 patients each to receive pretreatment with parecoxib 40 mg(Group A),parecoxib 20 mg(Group B) or normal saline(Group C).All groups underwent venous occlusion for one minutes before propofol was injected.All pretreatment drugs were prepared in 5 mL doses.Pain scores were obtained by a study-blinded observer during propofol injection following the different pretreatment solutions.Results: Pain scores among the three groups were significantly different(P ≤0.001).In Group C,29(58%) patients had pain during propofol injection compared with 22(40%) Group B and 13(26%) Group A patients(P ≤ 0.005).Pain was significantly reduced in Group A(P ≤ 0.001) compared with the control group.Moderate to severe pain was experienced by 18(36%) Group C and 4(8%) Group B patients,whereas no Group C patient experienced moderate or severe pain(P<0.001).Reduction in pain severity was statistically significant after pretreatment with either parecoxib 20 mg(P = 0.002) or parecoxib 40 mg(P < 0.001).Conclusion: Parecoxib 40 mg with venous occlusion is effective in reducing the frequency and severity of pain with propofol injection.Pretreatment with 20 mg of parecoxib reduces the severity of propofol injection pain significantly but does not reduce frequency compared with the control group.

nI9xfUSJ.title: The Application of Combined Blockade of Obturator Nerve and Basilar Part of Bladder Tumor in Transurethral Electroresection of Bladder Tumor
nI9xfUSJ.abstract: Objective To investigate the combined blockade of the feasibility of obturator nerve and basilar part of bladder tumor in preventing obturator nervous reflex during transurethral electroresection of bladder tumor(TURBT).Methods Seventy-two patients with bladder tumor close to the ureter,suffered from TURBT under combined spinal epidural anesthesia,were randomly divided into two group: N group(n=36) and P group(n=36).Before TURBT,obturator nerve blockade under guidance of nerve stimulator were performed in N group.Obturator nerve and basilar part of bladder tumor combined blockade were performed in P group.Results In N group,seven patients(7/36,19%) showed obturator nervous reflex during TURBT,five patients showed slight obturator nervous reflex,two patients showed apparent nervous reflex.In P group,only three patients(3/36,8%) showed slight obturator nervous reflex during TURBT without vesical perforation.Compared with N group,there had a significant difference(P<0.05).Conclusion In TURBT,the combined blockade of obturator nerve and basilar part of bladder tumor could inhibit the obturator nerve reflex and decrease the incidence of operative complications.

LCZSJ1XS.title: Influence of Different Dosage Propofol on Pulmonary Function in Patients with Cardiopulmonary Bypass
LCZSJ1XS.abstract: Objective To investigate the effects of different dosage of porpofol on pulmonary function in patients with cardiac valve replacement under cardiopulmonary bypass(CPB).Methods Total 42 patients with cardiac valve replacement under cardiopulmonary bypass(CPB) were randomly divided into group C,group P1 and group P2.In group P1 and P2,propofol were continuously injected with TCI after tracheal intubation till postoperation.No propofol was given in group C.The radial artery blood of all patients were collected at pre-CPB(T1),30 min post-lung reperfusion(T2),60 min(T3),120 min(T4),respectively.The blood gas,the concentrations of TNF-α,IL-6,Sicam-1 and MDA,the activity of SOD were measured.The P(A-a)O2 and RI were calculated based on the blood gas.Results Compared with T1,the P(A-a)O2 and RI in three groups from T2 to T4 were significantly increased(P<0.05).Compared with group C,P(A-a)O2 and RI in propofol group were significantly decreased from T2 to T4(P<0.05).Compared with P1 group,P(A-a)O2 and RI in P2 group were significantly decreased(P<0.05).Compared with group C,the concentrations of TNF-α,IL-6,sICAM-1 and MDA in propofol groups were significantly decreased from T2 to T4(P<0.05),and the concentration in P2 group were significantly less than that of P1 group(P<0.05).Compared with group C,the activity of SOD in propofol groups were significantly increased(P<0.05),and the activity in P2 group were significantly higher than that of P1 group(P<0.05).Conclusion During CPB,propofol administration by TCI with 2 μg/mL and 4 μg/mL could relieve the pulmonary injury through inhibiting the release of inflammatory factors,reducing the production of oxygen free radical,increasing the capability of oxygen free radical clearing.The protective effects on pulmonary function was in a dose dependent manner.

2vn46iqY.title: Significance and Expression of γ-GABA and Its Receptor in Dorsal Root Ganglion of Rats with Neuropathic Pain
2vn46iqY.abstract: Objective To investigate the expression of gamma aminobutyric acid(γ-GABA) and its receptor in dorsal root ganglion(DRG) of rats with neuropathic pain and to explore its significance.Methods The rat model with chronic neuropathic pain were prepared in 20 SD rats by L5 DRG ligation(SNL group).The expression of γ-GABA and its receptor GABAAα1 in DRG were determined with SABC method,and another 10 rats were selected as sham operation group.Results Compared with sham operation group,the expression levels of γ-GABA and its receptor GABAAα1 in DRG were both significantly decreased(P<0.05) in SNL group.Conclusion The decrease of GABA neuron and down regulation of GABAA receptors could induce the decrease of GABA signal transmission,which may play an important role in the development of neuropathic pain.

lcfIKGr4.title: Effects of Parecoxib on Preemptive Analgesia for Gynaecological Laparoscopic Surgery
lcfIKGr4.abstract: Objective To evaluate the preemptive analgesic effects and safety of parecoxib sodium for gynaecological laparoscopic surgery.Methods Sixty patients ASA Ⅰ~Ⅱ undergoing gynaecological laparoscopic surgery under general anesthesia were randomly divided into three groups(n=20).Parecoxib sodium were intravenously injected with 40 mg at 10 minutes before anesthesia and 10 minutes before the operation over in group A and group B,respectively.0.9% sodium chloride solution were intravenously injected with 5 mL at 10 minutes before anesthesia.MBP,HR,SpO2 and PETCO2 were recorded at the following time points,T0(before anesthesia),T1(trachea intubation),T2(5 minutes in the operation),T3(trachea extubation),T4(10 minutes after operation).The analgesic effect was evaluated by Visual Analogue Score(VAS) at 1,2,4,8 and 12 hours after operation.Ramsay sedation scale and adverse reactions were recorded.Results All the indexes before anesthesia had no significant difference during three groups(P<0.05).MBP,HR were all increased in three groups at T1,T2,T3,and MBP,HR in group B and group C were obviously increased than those of group A at T1 and T2(all P<0.05).The VAS of group A and group B were obviously lower than those of group C at all time points(all P<0.05).Ramsay sedation scale of group A and group B were obviously higher than those of group C at 1,2,4 hours after operation.There was no significant difference in adverse reaction of all groups.Conclusion Preemptive analgesia with parecoxib sodium is effective and safe in patients undergoing gynaecological laparoscopic surgery with less adverse reactions.

MX7e5qbw.title: Effect of Dexmedetomidine Combined Remifentanil on Anesthesia of Patients Underwent Hyperthyreosis Surgery
MX7e5qbw.abstract: Objective To investigate the feasibility and safety of dexmedetomidine combined with remifentanil using in the trachel-epidural anesthesia in patients underwent hyperthyreosis srugery.Methods Sixty patients of primary hyperthyroidism with subtotal thyroidectomy were randomly divided into three groups:control group(group F),remifentanil group(group R) and dexmedetomidine combined remifentanil group(group D).All patients were suffered from trachel-epidural anesthesia.At the onset of operation,midazolam(0.5 mg/kg) and fentanyl(0.1 mg) were intravenous injected in group F,midazolam(0.5 mg/kg) and remifentanil [0.12~0.05 μg/(kg·min)-1] were given in group R,dexmedetomidine(0.5 μg/kg) were pretreated in 10 minutes and dexmedetomidine[0.2 μg/(kg·h)-1]and remifentanil [0.05 μg/(kg·min)-1] were given in group D.The drugs withdrawal were performed after hematischesis.MAP,HR,SpO2,VAS,Ramsay score at pre-operation(T0),5 min post-operation(T1),dissociation of thyroid(T2),after operation(T3) were recorded,respectively.Results At T2,the VAS,MAP and HR in group R and group D were obviously decreased than those of group F(P<0.01),the Ramsay scores were significantly increased(P<0.05).There were no significant difference between group R and group D(P>0.05).Conclusion Dexmedetomidine combined with remifentanil showed satisfactory sedative and analgesia effects in the trachel-epidural anesthesia of hyperthyreosis surgery,which could sustain the stability of patient's repiratory and circulation,and reduce the incidence of complication.

tKmW3pSZ.title: The role of the GABA-A receptor of the adjacent intact dorsal root ganglion neurons in rats with neuropathic pain.
tKmW3pSZ.abstract: We aim to investigate the changes of The γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) signals in the adjacent intact dorsal root ganglion (DRG) and the contribution of these changes to the development and maintenance of neuropathic pain (NPP). After establishment of neuropathic pain model with the lumbar 5 spinal nerve ligation (L5 SNL), the GABA-evoked currents were recorded in the acutely dissociated L4 DRG neurons using whole-cell patch clamp. Moreover, Muscimol or Bicuculline were respectively topically injected to the L4 DRG at the time of nerve injury and post-operative 5 days (POD5). The pain thresholds of hind paw were recorded. We found that the incidence and amplitude of GABA currents significantly decreased in the large and medium L4 DRG neurons after SNL (P<0.05). Furthermore, in the L5 SNL rats, 20 μg Muscimol injected immediately after injury caused a long-lasting attenuation of mechanical allodynia (P<0.05), whereas the thermal hyperalgesia was not alleviated (P>0.05). 0.15 μg Bicuculline further decreased the pain thresholds (P<0.05) and reversed the pain-alleviating effects of Muscimol. However, at POD5, 20 μg Muscimol only exhibited transient alleviating effects (P<0.05). In conclusion, the decrease of inhibition signal mediated by GABA-A receptor in the adjacent intact DRG neurons may be crucial in the development of hyperalgesia in NPP.

9vS7bYN4.title: 1180: RESPIRATORY DEPRESSION IN THE INTOXICATED TRAUMA PATIENT: ARE OPIOIDS TO BLAME?

S9Q7xHea.title: Respiratory depression in the intoxicated trauma patient: are opioids to blame?
S9Q7xHea.abstract: Providing effective pain management to acutely intoxicated trauma patients represents a challenge of balancing appropriate pain management with the risk of potential respiratory depression from opioid administration. The objective of this study was to quantify the incidence of respiratory depression in trauma patients acutely intoxicated with ethanol who received opioids as compared with those who did not and identify potential risk factors for respiratory depression in this population. Retrospective medical record review was conducted for subjects identified via the trauma registry who were admitted as a trauma activation and had a detectable serum ethanol level upon admission. Risk factors and characteristics compared included demographics, Injury Severity Score, Glasgow Coma Score, serum ethanol level upon arrival, urine drug screen results, incidence of respiratory depression, and opioid and other sedative medication use. A total of 233 patients were included (78.5% male). Patients who received opioids were more likely to have a higher Injury Severity Score and initial pain score on admission as compared with those who did not receive opioids. Blood ethanol content was higher in patients who did not receive opioids (0.205 vs 0.237 mg/dL, P = .015). Patients who did not receive opioids were more likely to be intubated within 4 hours of admission (1.7% vs 12.1%, P = .02). Opioid administration was not associated with increased risk of respiratory depression (19.7% vs 22.4%, P = .606). Increased cumulative fentanyl dose was associated with increased risk of respiratory depression. Increased cumulative fentanyl dose, but not opioid administration alone, was found to be a risk factor for respiratory depression.

fA8g2ohq.title: Achieving ventricular rate control in patients taking chronic beta-blocker therapy.
fA8g2ohq.abstract: The objective of this study is to evaluate the difference in response to ventricular rate control with intravenous (IV) metoprolol compared to IV diltiazem in patients taking chronic beta-blocker therapy who present to the emergency department (ED) in atrial fibrillation (AF) with rapid ventricular rate (RVR).This was a single-center, retrospective study of adult patients taking chronic oral metoprolol. Chronic metoprolol therapy was defined as patients prescribed and taking oral metoprolol within 5days of study inclusion. Rate control was defined as either a decrease in ventricular rate<100bpm or <120bpm if the decrease was at least 20% from the presenting heart rate.A total of 332 patients were included, with 16 patients in the IV diltiazem group and 316 patients in the IV metoprolol group. In the diltiazem arm, 68.8% of patients achieved successful rate control compared to 42.4% of patients in the metoprolol group (p=0.067). Treatment with IV metoprolol resulted in more hospital admissions (58% vs. 6.25% with diltiazem, p<0.001). Treatment with diltiazem was associated with a greater incidence of bradycardia compared to IV metoprolol (13% vs. 0%, p=0.002).The use of IV diltiazem was associated with a higher rate of successful response to rate control compared to IV metoprolol in patients in AF with RVR on chronic beta-blocker therapy, however the difference between groups was not statistically significant.

w0pEbvmP.title: Topical tranexamic acid for the treatment of acute epistaxis in the emergency department.
w0pEbvmP.abstract: This investigation did not demonstrate a significant difference in ED LOS among patients with acute epistaxis treated with topical TXA or standard care. However, this data does add to existing evidence that TXA may be associated with a reduction in resource utilization, suggesting it may provide more effective bleeding control. Overall, more data is needed to confirm the potential benefits of this practice.
